original: garahavacanaṃ uppannaṃ, idāni pana taṃ ajjhāyatīti ajjhāyako, mante parivattetīti🔽iminā atthena pasaṃsāvacanaṃ katvā voharantīti. Ayaṃ panattho “adhipubbassa i ajjhayane”ti
analyzed: garaha vacanam uppannam idāni pana tam ajjhāyati iti ajjhāyakaḥ mante parivatteti iti  iminā atthena pasaṃsā vacanam katvā voharanti iti ayam pana atthaḥ adhipubbassa i ajjhayane iti
translated: The word “reciter” is derived from the word “to recite” (ajjha-yate). The meaning is that he recites, he recites the mantras, he recites the praise, he recites the blame.🔽But this meaning should be taken according to the analysis of the syllable idh in the expression “of the one who recites, the idh” .

original: dhātussa vasena gahetabbo. Evaṃ adhipubbassa idhātussa vasena imassa dhātussa atthaparivattanaṃ
analyzed: dhātussa vasena gahetabbaḥ evam adhipubbassa i dhātussa vasena imassa dhātussa attha parivattanam
translated: Thus there is a change of meaning of this syllable according to the syllable idh of the one who recites.

original: bhavati. Yaṃ sandhāya “ajjhāyako mantadharo”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhavati yam sandhāya ajjhāyakaḥ manta dharo ti vuttam
translated: With reference to this it is said: “The reciter, the mantra-bearer” .

original: Jhe dittiyaṃ. Dīpo jhāyati, dārūni jhāyanti. Ettha jhāyatīti jalati. Jhāyanajalanasaddā hi ekatthā.
analyzed: dittiyam dīpaḥ jhāyati dārūni jhāyanti ettha jhāyati iti jalati jhāyana jalana saddāḥ hi ekatthā
translated: Jhe, in the sense of burning. Dīpo jhāyati, dārūni jhāyanti. Here jhāyati is burning. For the words jhāyati and jalati have the same meaning.

original: Jajjha paribhāsanatajjanesu. Jajjhati.
analyzed: paribhāsana tad janesu jajjhati
translated: Jajjha, in the sense of reproaching and tormenting. Jajjhati.

original: Ujjha ussagge. Ussaggo chaḍḍanaṃ. Ujjhati. Ujjhitaṃ.
analyzed: ujjhaḥ ussagge ussaggaḥ chaḍḍanam ujjhati ujjhitam
translated: Ujjha, in the sense of throwing away. Ussaggo is throwing away. Ujjhati. Ujjhitaṃ.

original: Jhakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: jhakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: Jhakārantadhāturūpāni.

original: Ñakārantadhātu
analyzed: ñakāra anta dhātu
translated: Ñakārantadhātu

original: Ñā avabodhane. “Ñāti, ñanti, ñāsi. Ñātu, ñantu. Ñeyya, ñeyyu”ntiādīni yathāpāvacanaṃ
analyzed: avabodhane ñāti ñanti ñāsi ñātu ñantu yathā apa vacanam
translated: Ñā, in the sense of understanding. “Ñāti, ñanti, ñāsi. Ñātu, ñantu. Ñeyya, ñeyyu” . And so on according to the Pāṇini rule.

original: gahetabbāni. Ñāti, ñātako, añño, ñattaṃ, ñatti, paññatti, viññatti, saññatti, saññā,
analyzed: gahetabbāni ñāti ñātakaḥ aññaḥ ñattam ñatti paññatti viññatti saññatti saññā
translated: Ñāti, ñātako, añño, ñattaṃ, ñatti, paññatti, viññatti, saññatti, saññā,

original: saññāṇaṃ, paññā, paññāṇaṃ, ñāṇaṃ, viññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: saññāṇam paññā paññāṇam ñāṇam viññāṇam
translated: saññāṇaṃ, paññā, paññāṇaṃ, ñāṇaṃ, viññāṇaṃ.

original: Tattha ñātīti jānāti. Puna ñātīti bandhu. So hi “ayaṃ amhāka”nti ñātabbaṭṭhena ñātīti.
analyzed: tattha ñātī iti jānāti puna ñātī iti bandhu saḥ hi ayam amhākan ti ñātabba ṭṭhena ñātī iti
translated: Herein, ñāti is one who knows. Again, ñāti is a kinsman. For he is a ñāti in the sense of what should be known thus “This is ours” .

original: Evaṃ ñātako. Aññoti diṭṭhadhammikādayo atthe na ñāti na jānātīti añño, avidvā bāloti
analyzed: evam ñātakaḥ aññaḥ ti diṭṭhadhammika ādayaḥ atthe na ñāti na jānāti iti aññaḥ a vidvā bālaḥ ti
translated: So too ñātako. Añño is one who is not a kinsman or a knower of the meaning of the present life, etc.; the meaning is, an ignorant fool.

original: attho. Ñattanti jānanabhāvo. “Yāvadeva anatthāya, ñattaṃ bālassa jāyatī”ti pāḷi nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ ñattanti jānana bhāvaḥ yāvat eva anatthāya ñattam bālassa jāyati iti nidassanam
translated: Ñattaṃ is the state of knowing. The passage “The fool’s knowing is only for his own affliction” is the example.

original: Saññāṇanti cihanaṃ. Kārite “ñāpeti saññāpeti viññāpayatī”tiādīni bhavanti. Yasmā
analyzed: cihanam kārite ñāpeti saññāpeti viññāpayati iti ādīni bhavanti yasmā
translated: Saññāṇaṃ is a sign. The words “He makes known, he makes known to, he makes known by, he makes known that” are formed from it.

original: pana “aññāti paṭivijjhati. Attatthaṃ vā paratthaṃ vā ñassati. Anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ.
analyzed: pana aññā iti paṭivijjhati atta attham vā para attham vā ñassati an aññāta ñassāmi iti indriyam
translated: But since the following passages are found: “He knows what is not known” , “He will know what is for his benefit or for another’s benefit” , “The faculty of final knowledge” ,

original: Ekacce nabbhaññaṃsu, ekacce abbhaññaṃsū”ti pāḷiyo dissanti, tasmā ñātītiādīni ākhyātikapadāni
analyzed: ekacce ekacce abbhaññaṃsu iti pāḷiyaḥ dissanti tasmā ñāti iti ādīni ākhyātika padāni
translated: “Some penetrated it, some penetrated it” , therefore the words ñāti, etc., are words for a class.

original: diṭṭhāniyeva honti nayavasena. Tathā hi aññātīti ettha āiti upasaggo, so parassakkharassa
analyzed: diṭṭhāniyā iva honti naya vasena tathā hi aññāti iti ettha ā iti upasaggo so
translated: are seen by way of the meaning of the word. For in the word aññāti, the prefix ā is a reduplicated form, and it is shown as a short vowel by the desire to pronounce it as a short vowel in the word parassa.

original: saññoguccāraṇicchāya rassaṃ katvā niddiṭṭho. Ñātīti sāsane ākhyātikapadaṃ diṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: rassam katvā niddiṭṭhaḥ ñātī iti sa āsane ākhyātika padam diṭṭham
translated: The word ñāti is seen as a derivative word in the Dispensation.

original: tasmāyeva “ñāti, ñanti. Ñāsī”tiādinā padamālākaraṇe nattheva doso.
analyzed: pada mālā karaṇe natthā iva doso
translated: Therefore there is no fault in the formation of the word-group beginning with ñāti, ñanti, ñāsī.

original: Ñā māraṇatosananisānesu. Māraṇaṃ jīvitindriyupacchedakaraṇaṃ. Tosanaṃ tuṭṭhi. Nisānaṃ tikkhatā. Ñatti. Manuññaṃ. Paññatti.🔽Ettha ñattīti māretīti vā tosetīti vā nisetīti vā attho. Ayañca ñattisaddo “vatti
analyzed: ñā māraṇa tosana nisānesu māraṇam jīvitindriya upaccheda karaṇam tosanam tuṭṭhi nisānam tikkha tā ñatti manuññam paññatti  ettha māreti iti vā toseti iti vā niseti iti vā atthaḥ ayam ca ñatti saddo vatti
translated: Ñā is in the sense of killing, pleasing, and sitting. Killing is the cutting off of the life faculty. Pleasing is satisfaction. Sitting is the state of being seated. Ñatti. Manuññaṃ. Paññatti.

original: etāyāti vācā”ti ettha vattisaddo viya ākhyātikapadanti daṭṭhabbo. Tathā ādatteti
analyzed: etāya ati vācā iti ettha vatti saddaḥ viya ākhyātika padam ti daṭṭhabbo tathā ādatta iti
translated: Here the meaning is: it kills, or it pleases, or it sits. And this word ñatti should be regarded as a derivative word, like the word vatthi in the passage: “By this (ñattā) it is said (vatti).”

original: ettha vibhattibhūtassa tesaddassa viya vibhattibhūtassa tisaddassa saññogabhāvo ca
analyzed: ettha vibhatti bhūtassa te saddassa viya vibhatti bhūtassa ti saddassa saññoga bhāvaḥ ca
translated: Similarly, in the word ādatte, the word tesa, which is a case-ending, is a reduplicated form,

original: dhātuantassarassa rassattañca. Manuññanti manaṃ ābhuso ñeti tosetīti manuññaṃ. Ayamattho
analyzed: dhātu antassa rassa rassa ttam ca manuññanti manam ābhusaḥ ñeti toseti iti manuññam ayam attho
translated: and the vowel a of the root is short. Manuññaṃ. Manuññaṃ is that which goes to (ñeti) the mind (mana) of the one who is pleased (ābhuso). This is the meaning.

original: manasaddūpapadassa āpubbassimassa ñādhātussa vasena daṭṭhabbo. Paññattīti nānappakārato🔽pavattinivāraṇena akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ñatti māraṇaṃ paññatti. Atha vā dhammaṃ suṇantānaṃ🔽dhammadesanāya citte anekavidhena somanassuppādanaṃ. Atikhiṇabuddhīnaṃ anekavidhena🔽ñāṇatikhiṇakaraṇañca paññatti nāma, tathā sotūnaṃ cittatosanena cittanisānena ca
analyzed: mana saddu upapadassa ā pubbassimassa ñā dhātussa vasena daṭṭhabbo paññatti iti nānā pakārato  pavatti nivāraṇena akusalānam dhammānam ñatti māraṇam paññatti atha vā dhammam suṇantānam  dhamma desanāya citte anekavidhena somanassa uppādanam ati khiṇa buddhīnam anekavidhena  ñāṇa tikhiṇa karaṇam ca paññatti nāma tathā sotūnam citta tosanena citta nisānena ca
translated: It should be regarded as the noun-base of the word manasaddūpapadassa āpubbassimassa ñādhātussa.🔽The “announcement” is the announcing, the killing off, of unprofitable thoughts by preventing their occurrence in various ways.🔽Or alternatively, the “announcement” is the arousing of gladness in various ways in the minds of those who listen to the Dhamma by teaching the Dhamma to them, and it is the sharpening in various ways of the knowledge of those whose minds are already glad.

original: paññāpanaṃ paññattīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: paññāpanam paññattī iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: And the “announcement” should be regarded as the announcing to the listeners of the Dhamma by gladdening their minds and by sharpening their minds.

original: Iti bhūvādigaṇe cavaggantadhāturūpāni
analyzed: iti bhū ādi gaṇe ca vak g anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: So these noun-bases in -ā, etc.,

original: Idāni ṭavaggantadhāturūpāni vuccante –

analyzed: soṭu gabbe gabbam dabbanam soṭati
translated: Soṭu gabbe. Gabbaṃ dabbanaṃ. Soṭati.

original: Yoṭu sambandhe. Yoṭati.
analyzed: yoṭu sambandhe yoṭati
translated: Yoṭu sambandhe. Yoṭati.

analyzed: kaṭa vassa āvaraṇesu kaṭati
translated: Kaṭa vassāvaraṇesu. Kaṭati.

original: Saṭa paribhāsane. Saṭati.
analyzed: saṭa paribhāsane saṭati
translated: Saṭa paribhāsane. Saṭati.

original: Laṭa bālye ca. Pubbāpekkhāya cakāro. Laṭati. Lāṭo.
analyzed: laṭa bālye ca pubba apekkhāya cakāraḥ laṭati lāṭaḥ
translated: Laṭa bālye ca. Pubbāpekkhāya cakāro. Laṭati. Lāṭo.

original: Saṭa rujāvisaraṇagatyāvasānesu. Rujā pīḷā. Visaraṇaṃ vippharaṇaṃ. Gatyāvasānaṃ gatiyā avasānaṃ osānaṃ abhāvakaraṇaṃ, nisīdananti vuttaṃ hoti. Saṭati. Sāṭo vuccati sāṭako.
analyzed: rujā visaraṇa gati avasānesu rujā pīḷā visaraṇam vippharaṇam gatya avasānam gatiyāḥ avasānam osānam abhāva karaṇam nisīdananti vuttam hoti saṭati sāṭaḥ vuccati sāṭakaḥ
translated: Rujā is pain. Visaraṇa is spreading. Gatyāvasāna is the end of the course, the end, the finish, the destruction, the non-existence, the collapse, the meaning is.

original: Vaṭa vedhane. Vaṭati. Vaṭo. Vāṭo.
analyzed: vaṭa vedhane vaṭati vaṭaḥ vāṭaḥ
translated: Vaṭa is in the sense of “to be distressed.” Vaṭati. Vaṭo. Vāṭo.

original: Khiṭa uttāsane. Kheṭati, ākheṭako, kheṭo, ukkheṭito, samukkheṭito.
analyzed: khiṭaḥ uttāsane kheṭati ākheṭakaḥ kheṭaḥ ukkheṭito samukkheṭito
translated: Khiṭa is in the sense of “to be lifted up.” Kheṭati, ākheṭako, kheṭo, ukkheṭito, samukkheṭito.

original: Siṭa anādare. Seṭati.
analyzed: siṭaḥ an ādare seṭati
translated: Siṭa is in the sense of “to be contemptuous.” Seṭati.

original: Jaṭa ghaṭa saṅghāte. Jaṭati. Jaṭā, jaṭilo, jaṭī. Antojaṭā bahijaṭā, jaṭāya jaṭitā pajā. Kārite “so imaṃ vijaṭaye jaṭaṃ. Arahattamaggakkhaṇe vijaṭeti nāmā”ti payogo.

translated: Jaṭa is in the sense of “to be a mass.” Jaṭati. Jaṭā, jaṭilo, jaṭī. Antojaṭā bahijaṭā, jaṭāya jaṭitā pajā. Kārite “so imaṃ vijaṭaye jaṭaṃ. Arahattamaggakkhaṇe vijaṭeti nāmā”ti payogo.

analyzed: bhaṭa bhattiyam bhaṭati bhaṭaḥ vetanam bhaṭakaḥ yathā
translated: Bhaṭa is in the sense of “to be a servant.” Bhaṭati. Bhaṭo. Vetanaṃ bhaṭako yathā.

analyzed: taṭe ussaye ussayaḥ ārohaḥ ubbedhaḥ taṭati taṭaḥ giri taṭaḥ nadī taṭaḥ taṭī taṭam
translated: Taṭa is in the sense of “to be a slope.” Ussayo āroho ubbedho. Taṭati. Taṭo, giritaṭo, nadītaṭo, taṭī, taṭaṃ.

original: Khaṭa kaṃse. Khaṭati. Khaṭo.
analyzed: khaṭa kaṃse khaṭati khaṭaḥ
translated: Khaṭa is in the sense of “to be a bronze vessel.” Khaṭati. Khaṭo.

original: Naṭa natiyaṃ. Naṭati. Naṭo, nāṭakaṃ.
analyzed: naṭa natiyam naṭati naṭaḥ nāṭakam
translated: Naṭa is in the sense of “to be dancing.” Naṭati. Naṭo, nāṭakaṃ.

original: tasmā ṭhānanti vuccati.

original: Ṭhe saddasaṅkātesu. Ṭhīyati.
analyzed: ṭhe sadda saṅkātesu ṭhīyati

original: Ṭhe veṭhane. Ṭhāyati.
analyzed: ṭhe veṭhane ṭhāyati
translated: The verb ṭhāyati is found in the sense of holding fast.

original: Paṭha viyattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ. Dhammaṃ paṭhati. Pāṭho, nakkhattapāṭhako, so horapāṭhakaṃ

original: pucchi. Sabbapāṭhī bhavissati. Paṭhituṃ, paṭhitave, paṭhitvā, paṭhitvāna, paṭhituna, paṭhiya, paṭhiyāna.🔽Evaṃvidhaṃ tuṃpaccayantādivibhāgaṃ sabbattha yathārahaṃ vattukāmāpi gantha vitthārabhayena
analyzed: pucchi sabbapāṭhī bhavissati paṭhitum paṭhitave paṭhitvā paṭhitvāna paṭhituna paṭhiya paṭhiya  evaṃvidham tum pacca yanta ādi vibhāgam sabbattha yathāraham vattu kāmā api vitthāra bhayena

translated: For in the Vinaya Commentary it is said: “Vaṭharo means thick, and this bhikkhu is said to be thick and of stout body” .

original: Maṭha nivāse. Maṭhati. Maṭho.

translated: Kaṭha, to live by difficulty, as in kaṭhati, he lives by difficulty, kaṭho, a person who lives by difficulty.

analyzed: uṭha ruṭha luṭha upaghāte oṭhati roṭhati loṭhati
translated: Uṭha, ruṭha, luṭha, in the sense of “to strike.” He strikes. He strikes. He strikes.

original: Piṭha hiṃsāsaṃkilesesu. Peṭhati. Piṭharo.
analyzed: piṭha hiṃsā saṃkilesesu peṭhati piṭharaḥ
translated: Piṭha, in the sense of “to harm” and “to defile.” He defiles. He is a defiler.

original: Saṭha ketave ca. Pubbatthesu cakāro. Saṭhati. Saṭho saṭhoti kerāṭiko vuccati.
analyzed: saṭha ketave ca pubbatthesu cakāraḥ saṭhati saṭhaḥ saṭhaḥ iti kerāṭikaḥ vuccati
translated: Saṭha, in the sense of “to deceive” and “to be crooked.” The particle ca indicates the previous meanings. He deceives. He is a deceiver. A deceiver is called a kerāṭika .

original: Suṭha gatipaṭighāte. Gamanapaṭihananaṃ gatipaṭighāto. Soṭhati.
analyzed: gati paṭighāte gamana paṭihananam gati paṭighātaḥ soṭhati
translated: Suṭha, in the sense of “to obstruct movement.” The obstruction of movement is the obstruction of going. He obstructs.

original: Kuṭhi luṭhi ālassiye ca. Cakāro pubbatthe ca. Kuṇṭhati. Kuṇṭho. Luṇṭhati. Luṇṭho.
analyzed: kuṭhi luṭhi ālassiye ca cakāro pubbatthe ca kuṇṭhati kuṇṭhaḥ luṇṭhati luṇṭhaḥ
translated: Kuṭhi, luṭhi, in the sense of “to be lame” and “to be crooked.” The particle ca indicates the previous meanings. He is lame. He is crooked.

original: Suṭhi sosane. Suṇṭhati.🔽Ruṭhi luṭhi aṭhi gatiyaṃ. Ruṇṭhati. Luṇṭhati. Aṇṭhati.
analyzed: suṭhi sosane suṇṭhati  ruṭhi luṭhi aṭhi gatiyam ruṇṭhati luṇṭhati aṇṭhati
translated: Suṭhi, in the sense of “to burn.” He burns.🔽Ruṭhi, luṭhi, aṭhi, in the sense of “to go.” He goes. He goes. He goes.

original: Veṭha veṭhane. Veṭhati, nibbeṭhati. Veṭhanaṃ, nibbeṭhanaṃ.
analyzed: veṭha veṭhane veṭhati nibbeṭhati veṭhanam nibbeṭhanam
translated: Veṭha, in the sense of “to cover.” He covers. He uncovers. Covering, uncovering.

original: Vaṭhi ekacariyāyaṃ. Vaṇṭhati.
analyzed: vaṭhi eka cariyā ayam vaṇṭhati
translated: Vaṭhi, in the sense of “to go alone.” He goes alone.

original: Maṭha kuṭhi soke. Maṭhati. Kuṇṭhati.
analyzed: maṭha kuṭhi soke maṭhati kuṇṭhati
translated: Maṭha, kuṭhi, in the sense of “to grieve.” He grieves. He is lame.

original: Eṭha heṭha vibādhāyaṃ. Eṭhati. Heṭhati. Viheṭhati. Viheṭhanaṃ.
analyzed: eṭha heṭha vibādha ayam eṭhati heṭhati viheṭhati viheṭhanam
translated: Eṭha, heṭha, in the sense of “to obstruct.” He obstructs. He obstructs. He obstructs. Obstruction.

original: Luṭha paṭighāte. Loṭhati.
analyzed: luṭha paṭighāte loṭhati
translated: Luṭha in the sense of striking: he strikes.

original: Paṭha vikhyāne. Paṭhati.
analyzed: paṭha vikhyāne paṭhati
translated: Paṭha in the sense of announcing: he announces.

original: Luṭha saṃkilese. Loṭhati.🔽Ṭhakārantadhāturūpāni.🔽Ḍakārantadhātu🔽Ḍi vihāyasagatiyaṃ gamanamatte ca. Ḍeti, ḍayati. Ḍemāno. Ucce sakuṇa ḍemāna. Ye maṃ pure paccuḍḍenti.🔽Ḍi khipanuḍḍanesu. Ḍeti. Uḍḍeti.🔽Ito bahiddhā pāsaṇḍā, diṭṭhīsu pasīdanti te;🔽Na tesaṃ dhammaṃ rocemi, na te dhammassa kovidā.🔽Ettha ca pāsaṇḍāti pāsaṃ ḍentīti pāsaṇḍā, sattānaṃ cittesu diṭṭhipāsaṃ khipantīti attho. Atha vā taṇhāpāsaṃ diṭṭhipāsañca ḍenti uḍḍentīti pāsaṇḍā.🔽Muḍi kaṇḍane. Muṇḍati. Kumāraṃ muṇḍiṃsu. Muṇḍo.🔽Cuḍḍa hāvakaraṇe. Cuḍḍati.🔽Aḍḍa abhiyoge. Aḍḍati.🔽Gaḍi vadanekadese. Gaṇḍati. Gaṇḍo.
analyzed: luṭha saṃkilese loṭhati  ṭhakāra anta dhātu rūpāni  ḍakār anta dhātu  gamana matte ca ḍeti ḍayati ḍemānaḥ ucce sakuṇa ḍemāna ye mam pure paccuḍḍenti  ḍi khipa nuḍḍanesu ḍeti uḍḍeti  itas bahiddhā pāsaṇḍāḥ diṭṭhīsu pasīdanti te  na tesam dhammam rocemi na te dhammassa kovidā  ettha ca pāsaṇḍā ati pāsam ḍenti iti pāsaṇḍā sattānam cittesu diṭṭhi pāsam khipanti iti atthaḥ atha vā taṇhā pāsam diṭṭhi pāsam ca ḍenti uḍḍenti iti pāsaṇḍā  kaṇḍane muṇḍati kumāram muṇḍiṃsu muṇḍaḥ  cuḍḍa ha avakaraṇe cuḍḍati  aḍḍa abhiyoge aḍḍati  vadana eka dese gaṇḍati
translated: Luṭha in the sense of defiling: he defiles.

original: Huḍi piḍi saṅghāte. Huṇḍati. Piṇḍati. Piṇḍo.
analyzed: saṅghāte huṇḍati piṇḍati
translated: The roots Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and Ṭha, Kara, and

original: Hiḍi gatiyaṃ. Hiṇḍati, āhiṇḍati.
analyzed: hiḍi gatiyam hiṇḍati āhiṇḍati
translated: Hiḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘going’. He wanders, he wanders about.

original: Kuḍi dāhe. Kuṇḍati. Kuṇḍo.🔽Vaḍi maḍi veṭhane. Vaṇḍati. Maṇḍati. Maṇḍalaṃ.
analyzed: dāhe kuṇḍati kuṇḍo  vaḍi maḍi veṭhane vaṇḍati maṇḍati maṇḍalam
translated: Kuḍi is the base for ‘burning’. It burns. A burning.🔽Vaḍi and maḍi are the bases for the meaning of ‘striking’. He strikes, he strikes. A circle.

original: Bhaḍi paribhāsane. Bhaṇḍati. Bhaṇḍanaṃ. Bhaṇḍo.
analyzed: paribhāsane bhaṇḍati bhaṇḍanam
translated: Bhaḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘scolding’. He scolds. A scolding. A scold.

original: Maḍi majjane. Maṇḍati. Maṇḍanaṃ.
analyzed: maḍi majjane maṇḍati maṇḍanam
translated: Maḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘washing’. He washes. A washing.

original: Tuḍi toḷane. Tuṇḍati. Tuṇḍo. Tuṇḍenādāya gaccheyya.
analyzed: tuḍi toḷane tuṇḍati tuṇḍo tuṇḍena ādāya gaccheyya
translated: Tuḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘tearing’. It tears. A tear. Taking a tear, he would go.

original: Bhuḍi bharaṇe. Bhuṇḍati.🔽Caḍi kope. Caṇḍati. Caṇḍo. Caṇḍālo, caṇḍikkaṃ.
analyzed: bhuḍi bharaṇe bhuṇḍati  kope caṇḍati caṇḍo caṇḍālo caṇḍikkam
translated: Bhuḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘filling’. It fills.🔽Caḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘anger’. It is angry. An angry man. An outcaste, a scoundrel.

original: Saḍi rujāyaṃ. Saṇḍati. Saṇḍo.
analyzed: saḍi saṇḍo
translated: Saḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘pain’. It aches. An ache.

original: Taḍi tāḷane. Taṇḍati. Vitaṇḍā.
analyzed: taḍi tāḷane taṇḍati vitaṇḍā
translated: Taḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘beating’. It beats. A beating.

original: Paḍi gatiyaṃ. Paṇḍati. Paṇḍā, paṇḍito. Ettha paṇḍāti paññā. Sā hi sukhumesupi atthesu
analyzed: paḍi gatiyam paṇḍati paṇḍā paṇḍitaḥ ettha paṇḍā ati paññā sā hi su khumesu pi atthesu
translated: Paḍi is the base for the meaning of ‘going’. It goes. A paṇḍā, a paṇḍit. Herein, paṇḍā is wisdom. For that

original: paṇḍati gacchati dukkhādīnaṃ pīḷanādikampi ākāraṃ jānātīti “paṇḍā”ti vuccati. Paṇḍitoti
analyzed: paṇḍati gacchati dukkha ādīnam pīḷana ādikam pi ākāram jānāti iti paṇḍā ati vuccati paṇḍito ti
translated: goes, it goes, to subtle meanings, and it knows the mode of the suffering, etc., thus it is called ‘paṇḍā’. A paṇḍit is🔽one who has gone, who has come from, paṇḍā. Or he is a paṇḍit because paṇḍā has arisen in him. He goes,

original: paṇḍāya ito gato pavattoti paṇḍito. Atha vā sañjātā paṇḍā etassāti paṇḍito. Paṇḍati
analyzed: paṇḍāyaḥ itas gataḥ pavattoti paṇḍitaḥ atha vā sañjātā paṇḍā etassa ati paṇḍitaḥ paṇḍati
translated: he goes, to paṇḍā.

original: ñāṇagatiyā gacchatītipi paṇḍito. Tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ “paṇḍantīti paṇḍitā.
analyzed: ñāṇa gatiyā gacchati iti pi tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam paṇḍanti iti paṇḍitā
translated: He goes by the way of knowledge, thus he is wise. For this is said in the Commentary: “They go by the way of knowledge, thus they are wise .

original: Sandiṭṭhikasamparāyikatthesu ñāṇagatiyā gacchantīti attho”ti.
analyzed: sandiṭṭhika samparāyika atthesu ñāṇa gatiyā gacchanti iti atthaḥ ti
translated: The meaning is that they go by the way of knowledge in the case of what is to be known here and now and in the case of what is to be known in the life to come.”

original: Gaḍi made. Gaṇḍati.
analyzed: gaḍi made gaṇḍati
translated: Gaḍi means to be intoxicated. It intoxicates.

original: Khaḍi manthe. Khaṇḍati. Khaṇḍito, khaṇḍo.🔽Laḍi jivhāmathane. Laṇḍati. Laṇḍo.
analyzed: manthe khaṇḍati khaṇḍitaḥ khaṇḍaḥ  jivhā mathane laṇḍati laṇḍo
translated: Khaḍi means to be broken. It is broken. It is broken off.🔽Laḍi means to be vomited. It is vomited. It is vomited up.

original: Ḍakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: ḍakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: The ḍhak and ḍak verbal-action bases.

original: Ḍakārantadhātu
analyzed: ḍakār anta dhātu
translated: The ḍhak verbal-action base

original: Vaḍḍha vaḍḍhane. Vaḍḍhati. Sirivaḍḍhako, dhanavaḍḍhako, vaḍḍhito, buḍḍho. Ettha ca vakārassa bakāro, akārassa cukāro.
analyzed: vaḍḍha vaḍḍhane vaḍḍhati sirivaḍḍhakaḥ dhanavaḍḍhakaḥ vaḍḍhitaḥ buḍḍhaḥ ettha ca vakārassa bakāraḥ akārassa cukāro
translated: Vaḍḍha means to increase. It increases. It is increased. It is increased in prosperity. It is increased in wealth. It is increased in size. It is grown up. And here the a becomes u and the v becomes b.

original: Kaḍḍha ākaḍḍhane. Kaḍḍhati, ākaḍḍhati, nikaḍḍhati. Akāmā parikaḍḍhanti, ulūkaññeva vāyasā.
analyzed: kaḍḍhe ākaḍḍhane kaḍḍhati ākaḍḍhati nikaḍḍhati akāmā parikaḍḍhanti ulūkaññā iva vāyasā
translated: Kaḍḍha means to drag. It drags. It is dragged. It is dragged along. They drag him unwilling. The kites drag the owl.

original: Imāni ḍhakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: imāni ḍhakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: These are the ḍhak and ḍak verbal-action bases.

original: Ṇakārantadhātu🔽Aṇa raṇa vaṇa bhaṇa maṇa kaṇa sadde. Aṇati. Aṇako brāhmaṇo. Raṇati. Raṇaṃ. Vaṇati.
analyzed: ṇakāra anta dhātu  raṇa vaṇa bhaṇa maṇa kaṇa sadde aṇati aṇakaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ raṇati raṇam vaṇati
translated: The ṇak verbal-action base

original: Vāṇako. Bhaṇati. Bhāṇako. Maṇati. Maṇiko. Kaṇati. Kāṇo. Tattha brāhmaṇoti brahmaṃ
analyzed: vāṇakaḥ bhaṇati bhāṇakaḥ maṇati maṇikaḥ kaṇati kāṇaḥ tattha brāhmaṇoti brahmaṃ
translated: Aṇa means to go. It goes. It is gone. It is gone to. Raṇa means to make a noise. It makes a noise. It is a noise. Vaṇa means to pierce. It pierces. It is a piercing. Bhaṇa means to speak. It speaks. It is spoken. It is a speaking. Maṇa means to think. It thinks. It is thought. It is a thinking. Kaṇa means to be squint-eyed. It is squint-eyed. It is squint. Herein, brāhmaṇo is a brahmin.

original: aṇatīti brāhmaṇo, mante sajjhāyatīti attho. Akkharacintakā pana “brahmuno apaccaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ mante sajjhāyati iti atthaḥ akkhara cintakā pana brahmunaḥ
translated: He is a brahmin because he has gone to the end of the chants, that is, he has recited the chants.🔽But those who think in terms of syllables say that he is a brahmin because he is a descendant of Brahmā.

original: brāhmaṇo”ti vadanti. Ariyā pana bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇoti.
analyzed: brāhmaṇā iti vadanti ariyā pana brāhmaṇā iti
translated: But the noble ones are called brahmins because they have expelled evil.

original: Brāhmaṇo sottiyo vippo, bhovādī brahmabandhu ca;
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ sottiyaḥ vippaḥ bho vādī brahmabandhu ca
translated: A brahmin is a scholar, a Vipassī, one who uses bho, a kinsman of Brahmā,

original: Brahmasūnu dvijo brahmā, kamalāsanasūnu ca;
analyzed: brahma sūnu dvijaḥ brahmā kamalāsana sūnu ca
translated: A son of Brahmā, a twice-born, a brahmin, a lotus-born,

original: Raṇasaddo “saraṇā dhammā araṇā dhammā”tiādīsu kilesesu vattati. Kilesā hi raṇanti kandanti etehīti raṇāti vuccanti.
analyzed: raṇa saddaḥ saraṇāḥ dhammāḥ araṇāḥ dhamma ati ādīsu kilesesu vattati kilesāḥ hi raṇanti kandanti etehi iti raṇā ati vuccanti
translated: The word raṇa occurs with defilements in the sense of “the dhammas that are quarrels are the unwholesome dhammas” , “the dhammas that are not quarrels are the wholesome dhammas” , and so on. For defilements are called raṇa because they quarrel and wail in the sense of “they quarrel from here” .

original: “Dhanuggaho asadiso, rājaputto mahabbalo;
analyzed: dhanuggahaḥ asadisaḥ rāja puttaḥ mahā balaḥ
translated: “The matchless archer, the prince of great strength,

original: Sabbāmitte raṇaṃ katvā, saṃyamaṃ ajjhupāgamī”ti
analyzed: sabba amitte raṇam katvā saṃyamam ajjhupāgami iti
translated: Having made all his enemies his quarrel, he came to the observance of the rule of conduct” .

original: Ettha yuddhe vattati. Raṇaṃ katvāti hi yuddhaṃ katvāti attho. “Tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca
analyzed: ettha yuddhe vattati raṇam katvā ati hi yuddham katvā ati attho tiṇam ca kaṭṭham ca
translated: Here it occurs in the sense of battle. For the meaning is “having made all his enemies his battle.” “They ran in all directions,

original: raṇaṃ karontā, dhāviṃsu te aṭṭhadisā samantato”ti ettha cuṇṇavicuṇṇakaraṇe vattati.
analyzed: raṇam karontā dhāviṃsu te aṭṭhadisā samantataḥ ti ettha cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa karaṇe vattati
translated: making a quarrel of the grass and sticks” , here it occurs in the sense of making small pieces.🔽For the meaning is “making a quarrel of the grass and sticks” is the same as “making small pieces of the grass and sticks.”

original: Raṇaṃ karontāti hi cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ karontāti attho. Evaṃ atthavivaraṇampi saddasaṅkhātamatthaṃ
analyzed: raṇam karontā ati hi cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam karontā ati atthaḥ evam attha vivaraṇam pi sadda saṅkhātam attham
translated: So the explanation of the meaning, which is called the “word,” is finished.

original: antoyeva katvā adhippāyatthavasena kataṃ, na dhātunānatthavasenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Atha
analyzed: antoyā iva katvā adhippāya ttha vasena katam na dhātu nānattha vasena ati daṭṭhabbam atha
translated: and it should be regarded as made by way of the intended meaning, not by way of the diversity of the elements.

original: vā dhātūnamatthātisayayogopi bhavati, tena evaṃ atthavivaraṇaṃ katantipi daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vā dhātūnam attha atisaya yogaḥ api bhavati tena evam attha vivaraṇam katam ti pi daṭṭhabbam
translated: Or else it should be regarded as made by way of the excess of meaning of the elements, and so the explanation of the meaning is made in this way.

original: Bhaṇa bhaṇane. Parittaṃ bhaṇati, vacanaṃ bhaṇati. Dīghabhāṇako, piyabhāṇī, bhāṇavāro. Ettha bhāṇavāroti –
analyzed: bhaṇa bhaṇane parittam bhaṇati vacanam bhaṇati dīgha bhāṇakaḥ piya bhāṇī bhāṇa vāraḥ ettha bhāṇa vāraḥ iti
translated: Bhaṇa is said to be derived from the verbal root bhan, to speak. He speaks little, he speaks words. He is a reciter of the long texts, he is a speaker of what is dear, it is the turn of the reciter. Herein, as to the reciter:

original: “Aṭṭhakkharā ekapadaṃ, ekā gāthā catuppadaṃ;
analyzed: aṭṭhakkharā eka padam ekā gāthā catuppadam
translated: Eight syllables make one foot, one verse has four feet;

original: Gāthā cekāmato gantho, gantho bāttiṃsatakkharo;
analyzed: gāthā ganthaḥ ganthaḥ
translated: One verse is one unit of text, a unit of text has thirty-two syllables;

original: Bāttiṃsakkharaganthānaṃ, paññāsaṃ dvisataṃ pana;🔽Bhāṇavāro mato eko, svaṭṭhakkharasahassako”ti.
analyzed: bāttiṃsa kharaganthānam paññāsam dvisatam pana  bhāṇa vāraḥ mataḥ ekaḥ
translated: Fifty-two units of text make one recitation, which has a thousand and thirty-two syllables.

original: Evaṃ aṭṭhakkharasahassaparimāṇo pāṭho vuccati.🔽Oṇaṃ apanayane. Oṇati.🔽Soṇa vaṇṇagatīsu. Soṇati, soṇo.
analyzed: evam aṭṭhakkhara sahassa parimāṇaḥ pāṭhaḥ vuccati  oṇam apanayane  soṇa vaṇṇagatīsu soṇati soṇaḥ
translated: So it is said that the text is measured in thousands of syllables.🔽Oṇa is said to be derived from the verbal root uṇa, to carry away. It carries away.

original: Soṇa siloṇa saṅghāte. Soṇati. Siloṇati.
analyzed: soṇa siloṇa saṅghāte soṇati siloṇati
translated: Soṇa is said to be derived from the verbal root soṇa, to be red. It reddens, it is red.🔽Soṇa is said to be derived from the verbal root soṇa, to be compact. It reddens, it is compact.

original: Ghiṇi ghuṇi ghaṇi gahaṇe. Ghiṇṇati. Ghuṇṇati. Ghaṇṇati.
analyzed: ghiṇi ghuṇi ghaṇi gahaṇe ghiṇṇati ghuṇṇati ghaṇṇati
translated: Ghiṇi is said to be derived from the verbal root ghaṇ, to seize. It seizes, it is seized.

original: Ghuṇa ghuṇṇa gamane. Ghoṇati. Ghuṇṇati.
analyzed: ghuṇa ghuṇṇa gamane ghoṇati ghuṇṇati
translated: Ghuṇa, ghuṇṇa, in the sense of going: ghuṇati, ghuṇṇati.

original: Paṇa byavahāre, thutiyañca. Paṇati vāṇijo, vohāraṃ karoti iccattho. Saddho buddhaṃ paṇati, thomayati iccattho, āpaṇaṃ, sāpaṇo gāmo.
analyzed: byavahāre thutiyam ca paṇati vāṇijaḥ vohāram karoti iccattho saddhaḥ buddham paṇati thomayati iccattho āpaṇam sa āpaṇaḥ gāmaḥ
translated: Paṇa, in the sense of business transaction and of praise: paṇati, a merchant does business, that is the meaning; saddho buddhaṃ paṇati, he praises, that is the meaning; āpaṇaṃ, sāpaṇo gāmo.

original: Gaṇa raṇa gatiyaṃ. Gaṇati. Raṇati.
analyzed: gaṇa raṇa gatiyam gaṇati raṇati
translated: Gaṇa, raṇa, in the sense of going: gaṇati, raṇati.

original: Caṇa saṇa dāne. Caṇati. Saṇati.
analyzed: caṇa saṇa dāne caṇati saṇati
translated: Caṇa, saṇa, in the sense of giving: caṇati, saṇati.

original: Phaṇa gatiyaṃ. Phaṇati. Phaṇaṃ.
analyzed: phaṇa gatiyam phaṇati phaṇam
translated: Phaṇa, in the sense of going: phaṇati, phaṇaṃ.

original: Veṇu ñāṇacintānisāmanesu. Veṇati.
analyzed: veṇu ñāṇa cintā nisā manesu veṇati
translated: Veṇu, in the sense of knowledge, thought, and meditation: veṇati.

original: Pīṇa pīṇane. Pīṇanaṃ paripuṇṇatā. Pīṇati. Pīṇo divā na bhuñjati, pīṇorakkhaṃsabāhu.
analyzed: pīṇa pīṇane pīṇanam paripuṇṇa tā pīṇati pīṇaḥ divā na bhuñjati
translated: Pīṇa, in the sense of filling: pīṇanaṃ paripuṇṇatā, pīṇati, pīṇo divā na bhuñjati, pīṇorakkhaṃsabāhu.

original: Miṇa hiṃsāyaṃ. Miṇati.
analyzed: miṇa hiṃsa ayam miṇati
translated: Miṇa, in the sense of harming: miṇati.

original: Duṇa gatiyañca. Hiṃsāpekkhako cakāro. Duṇati.
analyzed: gatiyam ca hiṃsā apekkhakaḥ cakāraḥ duṇati
translated: Duṇa, in the sense of going: duṇati.

original: Saṇa abyattasadde. Saṇati. Saṇateva brahmāraññaṃ. Saṇatevāti nadati viya.
analyzed: abyatta sadde saṇati saṇatā iva brahmā araññam saṇatā iva ati nadati viya
translated: Saṇa, in the sense of inarticulate sound: saṇati, saṇateva brahmāraññaṃ, saṇatevāti nadati viya.

original: Tuṇa koṭille. Toṇati.
analyzed: tuṇa koṭille toṇati
translated: Tuṇa, in the sense of a large number: toṇati.

original: Puṇa nipuṇe. Puṇati, nipuṇati. Nipuṇadhammo. Ettha ca nipuṇasaṇhasukhumasaddā vevacanasaddā kusalachekadakkhasaddā viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nipuṇe puṇati nipuṇati nipuṇa dhammaḥ ettha ca nipuṇa saṇha sukhuma saddā vevacana saddā kusala cheka dakkha saddā viyā ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Puṇa, in the sense of skill: puṇati, nipuṇati, nipuṇadhammo. And here nipuṇa, saṇa, sukhumā, vevacanā, kusala, cheka, dakkha, are words with the same meaning as sadda.

original: Muṇa paṭiññāṇe. Muṇati.🔽Kuṇa saddopakaraṇe. Koṇati.
analyzed: muṇa paṭiññāṇe muṇati  kuṇa sadda upakaraṇe koṇati
translated: In the sense of “having shaved off” (muṇati).🔽In the sense of “having made a tool” (kuṇa).

original: Cuṇa chedane. Coṇati.
analyzed: cuṇa chedane coṇati
translated: In the sense of “having cut” (cuṇa).

original: Maṇa cāge. Veraṃ maṇatīti veramaṇi.
analyzed: maṇa cāge veram maṇati iti veramaṇi
translated: In the sense of “having given up” (maṇa). “He gives up enmity” (veramaṇi).

original: Phuṇa vikiraṇe vidhunane ca. Phuṇati. Aṅgārakāsuṃ apare phuṇanti.
analyzed: phuṇa vikiraṇe vidhunane ca phuṇati aṅgārakāsum apare phuṇanti
translated: In the sense of “having scattered” or “having shaken” (phuṇa). “They scatter the embers” (phuṇanti).

analyzed: imāni ṇakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: These are the verbal roots with the nominal base in ṇ.

original: Samattāni.
analyzed: samattāni

analyzed: takāra anta dhātu
translated: The verbal roots with the nominal base in tak

translated: In the sense of “having protected” (te). “Protection” is “guarding.” “He protects” (tāyati). “Refuge” (tāṇa), “family” (gotta), “constellation” (nakkhatta). “He protects from evil” (aghassa tātā). “The wealth that is gained with difficulty,

original: bhogā, te tāto vidhami dhamaṃ. Tattha gottanti gaṃ tāyatīti gottaṃ. “Gotamo kassapo”ti
analyzed: bhogāḥ te tātaḥ vidhami dhamam tattha gottam ti gam tāyati iti gottam gotamaḥ kassapo ti
translated: he protects” (tātā). “He protects the family” (tātā). Herein, “family” is “that which protects the clan” (gaṃ tāyati). “The clan of Gotama Kassapa” (gotamassa kassapassa gottaṃ),

original: hi ādinā pavattamānaṃ gaṃ vacanaṃ buddhiñca tāyati ekaṃsikavisayatāya rakkhatīti
analyzed: hi ādinā pavattamānam gam vacanam buddhim ca tāyati ekaṃsika visaya tāya rakkhati iti
translated: thus the word and the idea that occur in this way protect the clan by making it the object of exclusive attention,

original: gottaṃ. Yathā hi buddhi ārammaṇabhūtena atthena vinā na vattati, tathā abhidhānaṃ
analyzed: gottam yathā hi buddhi ārammaṇa bhūtena atthena vinā na vattati tathā abhidhānam
translated: therefore it is a “family” . Just as the idea does not occur without the meaning that is its object, so too the expression

analyzed: abhidheyya bhūtena tasmā saḥ gotta saṅkhāto attho tāni tāyati rakkhati iti vuccati ko
translated: and it is the meaning called “ clan ” that is so called because it preserves, protects, those .🔽But what is that ?

original: pana soti? Aññakulaparamparāsādhāraṇaṃ tassa kulassa ādipurisasammuditaṃ taṃkulapariyāpannasādhāraṇaṃ sāmaññarūpaṃ.
analyzed: pana so ti añña kula paramparā sādhāraṇam tassa kulassa ādi purisa sammuditam taṃ kula pariyāpanna sādhāraṇam sāmañña rūpam
translated: It is the form of the monkhood shared in common by all who are included in that clan, and it is agreed upon by the first man in that clan.

original: Nakkhattanti visamagatiyā agantvā attano vīthiyāva gamanena nakkhanaṃ gamanaṃ tāyati🔽rakkhatīti nakkhattaṃ, taṃ pana assayujādivasena sattavīsatividhaṃ hoti. Tathā hi🔽assayujo bharaṇī kattikā rohaṇī migasiro addā punabbasu phusso assaliso māgho pubbaphagguṇī🔽uttaraphagguṇī hattho cittaṃ svāti visākhā anurādhā jeṭṭhā mūlaṃ pubbāsaḷhaṃ uttarāsaḷhaṃ
analyzed: nakkhattanti visama gatiyā a gantvā attanaḥ vīthiyā ava gamanena nakkhanam gamanam tāyati  rakkhati iti nakkhattam tam pana assayuja ādi vasena sattavīsatividham hoti tathā hi  assayujaḥ bharaṇī kattikā rohaṇī migasiraḥ addā punabbasu phussaḥ assalisaḥ māghaḥ pubbaphagguṇī  uttaraphagguṇī hatthaḥ cittam svāti visākhā anurādhā jeṭṭhā mūlam pubbāsaḷham uttarāsaḷham
translated: Star is what preserves, protects, the going by the path of the stars without going by the wrong way.

original: sāvaṇaṃ dhanasiṭṭhā satabhisattaṃ pubbabhaddapadaṃ uttarabhaddapadaṃ revatī cāti
analyzed: sāvaṇam dhanasiṭṭhā satabhisattam pubbabhaddapadam uttarabhaddapadam revatī ca ati
translated: But that is of twenty-seven kinds as Assa-yujā, Bharaṇī, Kattikā, Rohiṇī, Mṛga-sīra, Ādā, Punna-bhasu, Phusso, Assalāyano, Māgha, Pubba-phālguṇī, Uttarā-phālguṇī, Hasta, Citrā, Svāti, Viśākhā, Anurādhā, Jeṭṭhā, Mūla, Pubba-asāḷhā, Uttarā-asāḷhā, Sāvaṇṇā, Dhanisṭhā, Sattabhisatta, Pubba-bhaddapādā, Uttarā-bhaddapādā, and Revatī.

original: sattavīsati nakkhattāni. Tāni pana attano gamanaṭṭhānaṃ īsakampi na vijahanti kiñci
analyzed: sattavīsati nakkhattāni tāni pana attanaḥ gamana ṭhānam na vijahanti kiñci
translated: There are twenty-seven constellations. But they never leave their own course by so much as a hair’s breadth.

original: sīghaṃ kiñci dandhaṃ, kadāci sīghaṃ, kadāci dandhaṃ, etto ito cāti evaṃ visamagatiyā
analyzed: sīgham kiñci dandham kadāci sīgham kadāci dandham ettas itas ca ati evam visama gatiyā
translated: Some move quickly, some slowly, some quickly at one time and slowly at another, some slowly at one time and quickly at another.

original: agantvā yantacakke paṭipāṭiyā yojitāni viya samappamāṇagatiyā attano vīthiyāva gacchantāni
analyzed: a gantvā yanta cakke paṭipāṭiyā yojitāni viya samappamāṇa gatiyā attanaḥ vīthiyā ava gacchantāni
translated: Not going in this way with an uneven motion, they go in their own paths with an even motion as if they were yoked to a waterwheel.

original: maṇḍalākārena sineruṃ parivattanti. Evaṃ imāni nakkhanaṃ gamanaṃ tāyanti rakkhantīti
analyzed: maṇḍala ākārena sinerum parivattanti evam imāni nakkhanam gamanam tāyanti rakkhanti iti
translated: They revolve around Sineru in a circle. So they are called “constellations” , since they “constellate” , that is, protect, the stars’ motion.

original: nakkhattānīti vuccanti. Porāṇā pana kharadhātuvasena “nakkharanti na nassantīti nakkhattānī”ti
analyzed: nakkhattāni iti vuccanti porāṇā pana khara dhātu vasena nakkharanti na nassanti iti nakkhattāni iti
translated: But the ancients said, “They do not fall, they do not perish, thus they are constellations” .🔽“Constellation, light, star,🔽Star, star,🔽Star” are the names for the stars.

original: āvocuṃ, “nakkhattaṃ joti rikkhaṃ taṃ” iccetāni nakkhattatārakānaṃ nāmāni. “Uḷu tārā🔽tārakā”ti imāni pana sabbāsampi tārakānaṃ sādhāraṇanāmāni. Osadhīti pana tārakāvisesassa nāmaṃ.
analyzed: āvocuṃ nakkhattam joti rikkham tam icca etāni nakkhatta tārakānam nāmāni uḷu tārā 🔽tārakā ti imāni pana sabbāsam pi tārakānam sādhāraṇa nāmāni osadhī iti pana tārakā visesassa nāmam
translated: “Herb” is the name for a particular star.

original: Citi saññāṇe. Saññāṇaṃ cihanaṃ lakkhaṇakaraṇaṃ. Cetati. Cihanaṃ karotīti attho. Īkārantavasena
analyzed: citi saññāṇe saññāṇam cihanam lakkhaṇa karaṇam cetati cihanam karoti iti atthaḥ īkāra anta vasena
translated: The root ci means ‘to mark’. To mark is to make a sign, a distinguishing mark. He marks, he makes a distinguishing mark, is the meaning.

original: vuttattā asmā dhātuto saki saṅkāyanti dhātuto viya niggahītāgamo na hoti. Esa nayo
analyzed: vutta ttā asmā dhātutaḥ saki dhātutaḥ viya niggahīta āgamaḥ na hoti esa nayo
translated: Because it is stated with the vowel i, the vowel a of the word saṅkāya is not elided as in the case of the word dhātu.

original: aññesupi īdisesu ṭhānesu.🔽Pata gatiyaṃ. Patati. Papatati papātaṃ, papateyyahaṃ. Pāpattaṃ nirayaṃ bhusaṃ. Ahaṃsaddena
analyzed: aññesu pi īdisesu ṭhānesu  pata gatiyam patati papatati papātam papateyyaham nirayam bhusam ahaṃsaddena
translated: This is the method in other such instances.🔽The root pa means ‘to fall’. He falls, he falls down, he falls into an abyss, he might fall, he has fallen into hell, he has fallen into a pit, he has fallen into a pit, he is falling into hell, he is falling into a pit.

original: yojetabbaṃ, pāpattaṃ papatitosmīti attho. Pāpattha nirayaṃ bhusaṃ, sokumāroti yojetabbaṃ,
analyzed: yojetabbam pāpattam papatitaḥ asmi iti nirayam nirayam yojetabbam
translated: The word ahaṃ is to be construed with the words papatati, papattosmi, and papatito.🔽The words sokumāra and bhusaṃ are to be construed with the words pāpatta and pāpattha.🔽The words pāpatta and pāpattha are to be construed with the words papatati and papatito.

original: pāpattha papatitoti attho. Parokkhāpadañhietaṃ dvayaṃ. “Pāvadaṃ pāvadā”tiādīsu viya
analyzed: attho parokkhā padam hi etam dvayam pāvadam pāvadāti ādīsu viya
translated: This is a pair of words with a different order of words.

original: upasaggapadassa dīghabhāvo, tato aṃsaddassa ttaṃādeso, asaddassa ca tthādeso bhavati.
analyzed: upasagga padassa dīgha bhāvaḥ tatas aṃ saddassa ttaṃ ādesaḥ a saddassa ca ttha ādesaḥ bhavati
translated: The word upasagga becomes long, and then the vowel a of the word aṃ becomes the vowel tta, and the vowel a of the word as becomes the vowel ttha.

original: Acinteyyo hi pāḷinayo.
analyzed: a cinteyyaḥ hi pāḷinayaḥ
translated: The method of the text is inconceivable.

translated: The root at means ‘to go without a break’. To go without a break is to go without interruption. He goes. But because the word at is a word that expresses the meaning of going without a break,

analyzed: kathi koṭille kanthati  kattha silāghāyam katthati vikatthati katthanā vikatthanā tattha katthati iti
translated: Kathi, koṭṭhi, and koṭṭille are the same as kathi, koṭṭha, and koṭṭille. Kanthati means he is a chatterer.

original: pasaṃsati. Vikatthatīti virūpaṃ katthati abhūtavatthudīpanato. Ettha ca “bahumpi🔽so vikattheyya, aññaṃ janapadaṃ gato”ti ca “idhekacco katthī hoti vikatthī, so katthati
analyzed: pasaṃsati vikatthati iti virūpam katthati abhūta vatthu dīpanataḥ ettha ca  so vikattheyya aññam janapadam gato ti ca idha ekacco katthī hoti vikatthī so katthati
translated: Kattha, silāghāyaṃ, and silāghāyam are the same as kattha, silāghāya, and silāghāyam. Katthati and vikatthati mean he praises. Vikatthati also means he speaks ill, because he reveals what is not the case. Herein, the following are examples of the use of the words:

original: ‘ahamasmi sīlasampannoti vā vattasampannoti vā vikatthatī’ti” ca ādayo payogā.
analyzed: aham asmi sīla sampannaḥ iti vā vatta sampannaḥ iti vā vikatthati iti ca ādayaḥ payogāḥ
translated: “Though he speak much, he is a chatterer, gone to another country” , and “Here someone is a katthī, a vikatthī, he praises, he speaks ill, saying ‘I am perfect in virtue, perfect in conduct’ ” , and so on.

original: Byatha dukkhabhayacalanesu. Byathati. Bhantā byathitamānasā. Tato kumārābyathitā, sutvā luddassa bhāsitaṃ. Itthetaṃ dvayaṃ calañceva byathañca.
analyzed: dukkha bhaya calanesu byathati bhantā byathita mānasā tatas kumārā byathitā sutvā luddassa bhāsitam itthā itam dvayam calañca iva byathañca
translated: Byatha is used in the sense of pain, fear, and trembling. Byathati means he is afraid. “The prince was afraid and terrified, having heard the hunter’s words” . Herein, this pair is both trembling and afraid.

original: Sutha kutha katha hiṃsāyaṃ. Sothati. Kothati. Kathati.
analyzed: sutha kutha katha hiṃsā ayam sothati kothati kathati
translated: Sutha, kutha, katha, and hiṃsā are the same as sutha, kuṭṭha, katha, and hiṃsā. Sothati, kothati, and kathati are the same as soṭhī, kuṭṭhī, and kathī.

original: Patha gatiyaṃ. Pathati. Patho. Pathoti maggo. So duvidho mahājanena padasā paṭipajjitabbo🔽pakatimaggo ca paṇḍitehinibbānatthikehi paṭipajjitabbo paṭipadāsaṅkhāto ariyamaggo
analyzed: gatiyam pathati patho patho ti maggo so duvidhaḥ mahājanena padasā paṭipajjitabbo  pakati maggaḥ ca paṇḍitehi nibbānatthikehi paṭipajjitabbaḥ paṭipadā saṅkhātaḥ ariya maggaḥ
translated: In the sense of a path: he travels, the path, the path is travelled. It is of two kinds as the ordinary path travelled by people on foot🔽and as the noble path called the way, which is travelled by the wise who seek Nibbāna.

original: cāti. Tattha pakatimaggo uppannakiccākiccehi janehi pathiyati gacchiyatīti patho,
analyzed: ca ati tattha pakati maggaḥ uppanna kicca akiccehi janehi
translated: Herein, the ordinary path is so called because it is travelled by people who have arisen in the various kinds of destiny, that is, it is travelled by them.

original: paṭipadā pana amatamahāpuraṃ gantukāmehi kulaputtehi saddhāpātheyyaṃ gahetvā pathiyati🔽paṭipajjiyatīti patho. Atha vā pātheti kārakaṃ puggalaṃ gameti nibbānaṃ sampāpetīti
analyzed: paṭipadā pana amatamahāpuram gantu kāmehi kula puttehi saddhā pātheyyam gahetvā pathiyati  paṭipajjiyati iti pathaḥ atha vā pātheti kārakam puggalam gameti nibbānam sampāpeti iti
translated: But the way is so called because it is travelled by clansmen who have taken the faith-departure and have set out on the journey to the city of the Deathless.🔽Or alternatively, the way is so called because it carries the person who is its user along to the city of Nibbāna,

original: vā patho, paṭipadāyeva. Maggābhidhānaṃ curādigaṇe maggadhātukathanaṭṭhāne kathessāma.
analyzed: vā patho paṭipadāya iva magga abhidhānam curādi gaṇe magga dhātu kathana ṭṭhāne kathessāma
translated: or because it carries him along to the attainment of Nibbāna. Or the word magga is a name for the way only. We shall deal with the word magga in the section on the word magga in the “Treatise on the Elements” .

original: Katha nippāke. Kathati.
analyzed: nippāke kathati
translated: In the sense of telling: he tells,

original: Matha vilothane. Mathati.
analyzed: matha vilothane mathati
translated: In the sense of rubbing: he rubs.

original: Potha pariyāyanabhāve. Pothati. Pothako. Pothetīti ayaṃ curādigaṇepi vattati. Tena “samantā anupariyeyyuṃ, nippothentā catuddisā”ti payogo dissati.
analyzed: potha pariyāyana bhāve pothati pothako potheti iti ayam curādi gaṇe pi vattati tena samantā anupariyeyyum nippothentā catuddisā iti payogaḥ dissati
translated: In the sense of a book’s being a means of conveying the text, it has the form potha. Pothaka. Potheti. This is also found in the curādi class. Hence the expression samantā anupariyeyyuṃ nippothentā catuddisā is found .

original: Gottha vaṃse. Gotthati. Gotthulo, gotthu.
analyzed: vaṃse gotthati gotthulaḥ gotthu
translated: In the sense of a clan or family, it has the form gottha. Gotthulo, gotthu.

original: Puthu vitthāre. Pothati. Puthavī.🔽Thakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: puthu vitthāre pothati puthavī  thakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: In the sense of extensive, it has the form puthu. Pothati. Puthavī.

original: Dakārantadhātu
analyzed: dakāra anta dhātu
translated: The forms tha, kāranta, and dhātu are those of the present participle.🔽The forms dak, kāranta, and dhātu are those of the present participle.

original: Dā dāne. Āpubbo gahaṇe. Saddho dānaṃ dadāti deti, sīlaṃ ādadāti ādeti. Imāni suddhakattupadāni🔽taddīpakattā. Saddho assaddhaṃ dānaṃ dāpeti, sīlaṃ ādapeti, samādapeti. Ye dhammamevādapayanti
analyzed: dā dāne ā pubbaḥ gahaṇe saddhaḥ dānam dadāti deti sīlam ādadāti ādeti imāni suddha kattu padāni  tad dīpaka ttā saddhaḥ assaddham dānam dāpeti sīlam ādapeti samādapeti ye dhammam eva ādapayanti
translated: In the sense of giving, it has the form dā. Āpubbo in the sense of taking. Saddho dānaṃ dadāti deti, sīlaṃ ādadāti ādeti. These are pure verbal- noun forms.

original: santo. Imāni kāritapadāni hetukattupadānīti ca vuccanti taddīpakattā. Saddhena dānaṃ
analyzed: santaḥ imāni kārita padāni hetu kattu padāni iti ca vuccanti tad dīpaka ttā saddhena dānam
translated: They are called verbal-noun forms because they illustrate the verbal root. Saddho assaddhaṃ dānaṃ dāpeti, sīlaṃ ādapeti, samādapeti. Ye dhammamevādapayanti santas. These are called causative verbal-noun forms because they illustrate the causative verbal root. Saddhena dānaṃ

original: dīyati, sīlaṃ ādīyati, samādīyati, imāni kammapadāni taddīpakattā. Ayañca dā dāneti
analyzed: dīyati sīlam ādīyati samādīyati imāni kamma padāni tad dīpaka ttā ayam ca dāḥ dāna iti
translated: dīyati, sīlaṃ ādīyati, samādīyati. These are verbal-noun forms because they illustrate the verbal root. And this dā dāneti

original: dhātu sāsanānurūpasutivasena divādigaṇaṃ patvā supanakriyaṃ vadanto “dāyati niddāyati🔽niddā”ti sanāmapadāni suddhakattupadāni janayati. Dānamavakhaṇḍanañca vadanto “diyati
analyzed: dhātu sāsana anurūpa suti vasena divādi gaṇam patvā supana kriyam vadantaḥ  niddāti sa nāma padāni suddha kattu padāni janayati dānam avakhaṇḍanañca vadantaḥ diyati
translated: and so on, and when he is saying “He sleeps, he sleeps,” he generates the names “sleeping,” “sleeping,” and the pure verbal roots “sup,” “sup.”

original: dānaṃ dātta”nti sanāmapadāni suddhakattupadāni janayati. Suddhiṃvadanto “dāyati vedāyati🔽vodāna”nti sanāmapadāni suddhakattupadāni janayati, imasmiṃ pana bhūvādigaṇe dānaṃ🔽vadanto āpubbavasena gahaṇañca vadanto “dadāti deti ādadāti ādeti dānaṃ ādāna”nti🔽sanāmapadāni suddhakattupadāni janayati. Tathā kucchitagamanaṃ vadanto “dāti suddāti
analyzed: dānam sa nāma padāni suddha kattu padāni janayati suddhiṃvadantaḥ dāyati vedāyati  vodānanti sa nāma padāni suddha kattu padāni janayati imasmin pana bhūva ādi gaṇe dānam  vadantaḥ ā pubba vasena gahaṇam ca vadantaḥ dadāti deti ādadāti ādeti dānam ādānam iti  sa nāma padāni suddha kattu padāni janayati tathā kucchita gamanam vadantaḥ dāti suddāti
translated: And when he is saying “He gives, he gives,” he generates the names “giving,” “giving,” and the pure verbal roots “dad,” “dad.”🔽And when he is saying “He purifies, he purifies,” he generates the names “purifying,” “purifying,” and the pure verbal roots “vod,” “vod.”🔽But in the case of the group beginning with “ground” , when he is saying “giving,” he generates the names “giving,” “giving,” and the pure verbal roots “dad,” “dad,” by the method of prefixing ā-;🔽and when he is saying “he takes, he takes,” he generates the names “taking,” “taking,” and the pure verbal roots “ād,” “ād.”

original: suddo suddī”ti sanāmapadāni suddhakattupadāni janayatīti ayaṃ viseso daṭṭhabbo. Yathā
analyzed: suddo suddī iti sa nāma padāni suddha kattu padāni janayati iti ayam visesaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yathā
translated: And when he is saying “he goes into the womb, he goes into the womb,” he generates the names “going into the womb,” “going into the womb,” and the pure verbal roots “su,” “su,” by the method of prefixing ā-.🔽This is the difference to be seen here.

original: cettha, evamaññatrāpi yathāsambhavaṃ viseso upaparikkhitabbo nayaññūhi.
analyzed: ca ittha evam aññatra api yathāsambhavam visesaḥ upaparikkhitabbaḥ naya ññūhi
translated: And as here, so also elsewhere the difference should be sought according to the method.

original: Idānissa nāmapadāni tumantādīni brūma. “Dānaṃ, deyyaṃ, dātabbaṃ, brahmadeyyaṃ, dinnaṃ,
analyzed: nāma padāni tumanta ādīni brūma dānam deyyam dātabbam brahma deyyam dinnam
translated: Now we shall give the words for the noun. They are: “gift, should be given, should be given away, should be given as a gift, has been given,

original: dāyako, dāyikā, dakkhiṇā” iccādīni, “dātuṃ, padātuṃ, dātave, padātave, datvā, datvāna,
analyzed: dāyakaḥ dāyikā dakkhiṇā iccādīni dātum padātum dātave padātave datvā
translated: giver, giver of gifts, offering,” etc.; “to give, to give away, to give as a gift, to give away as a gift, having given, having given away,

original: dadātuna, daditvā, daditvāna, dadiya, dajjā, dadiyāna, ādātuṃ, ādāya, ādiya” iccādīni ca yojetabbāni.
analyzed: dadātuna daditvā daditvāna dadiya dajjā dadiyāna ādātum ādāya ādiya icca ādīni ca yojetabbāni
translated: giving, having given, having given away, having given as a gift, having given away as a gift, having given as a gift and given away as a gift, should give, should give away, should give as a gift, should give away as a gift, should give as a gift and give away as a gift, should be given, should be given away, should be given as a gift, should be given away as a gift, should be given as a gift and given away as a gift, having taken, having taken up, having taken as a gift, having taken away as a gift,” etc.

original: Tattha dānanti dātabbaṃ, dadanti etenāti atthe na deyyadhammo dānacetanā ca vuccati.
analyzed: tattha dānam ti dātabbam dadanti etena ati atthe na deyya dhammaḥ dāna cetanā ca vuccati
translated: Herein, “gift” is what should be given, and it is also called “generosity” in the sense of giving.

original: Kasmā pana tattha dinnasaddoyeva kathiyati, na dattasaddoti? Akathane kāraṇamatthi.
analyzed: kasmā pana tattha dinna saddaḥ yā iva kathiyati na datta saddaḥ ti a kathane kāraṇam atthi
translated: But why is only the word “given” used there and not the word “given away”? There is a reason for not using it.

original: “Dānaṃ dinna”ntiādīsu hi dinnasaddaṭṭhāne dattasaddo na dissati, tasmā na kathiyati.
analyzed: dānam dinna nti ādīsu hi dinna sadda ṭṭhāne datta saddaḥ na dissati tasmā na kathiyati
translated: For in such passages as “The gift is given” the word “given away” is not found in place of the word “given,” and that is why it is not used.🔽The word “given away” as a quality is not found

original: Guṇabhūto dattasaddo, na diṭṭho jinabhāsite;
analyzed: guṇa bhūtaḥ datta saddaḥ na diṭṭhaḥ jina bhāsite
translated: In the Conqueror’s speech, as in the phrase “given”

original: “Manasā dānaṃ mayā dinnaṃ”, iti dinnapadaṃ viya.
analyzed: manasā dānam mayā dinnam iti dinna padam
translated: In “The gift was given by me with the mind.”

original: “Devadatto yaññadatto, datto” iti ca ādiko;
analyzed: devadattaḥ yaññadattaḥ dattaḥ iti ca ādikaḥ
translated: And in such passages as “Devadatta, Yaññadatta, Datta,”

original: Paṇṇattivacane diṭṭho, samāsabyāsato pana.
analyzed: paṇṇatti vacane diṭṭhaḥ samāsa byāsataḥ pana
translated: It is seen in the expression of a name, But in the compound and the non-compound.

original: Tasmā “devadatto”tiādīsu “devena dinno”ti samāsaṃ katvā paṇṇattivacanattā dinnasaddassa
analyzed: tasmā devadattaḥ iti ādīsu devena dinnaḥ iti samāsam katvā paṇṇatti vacana ttā dinna saddassa
translated: Therefore, in “Devadatta” and so on, the word “given” is a name because it is made into a compound, “given by a god,”

original: dattādeso kātabbo sāsanānurūpena. Upari hi “dinnassa datto kvaci paṇṇattiya”nti lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: datta ādeso kātabbo sāsana anurūpena upari hi dinnassa dattaḥ kvaci lakkhaṇam
translated: and the substitution of “given” must be made in accordance with the Dispensation. For the characteristic “given by one who gives” is seen above in the expression of a name.

original: passissatha. Ayameva hi sāsane nīti avilaṅghanīyā. Idaṃ panettha vavatthānaṃ –🔽Sakkaṭe dattasaddova, dinnasaddo na dissati;
analyzed: passissatha ayam eva hi sāsane nīti a vilaṅghanīyā idam pana ittha vavatthānam  sakkaṭe datta saddaḥ iva dinna saddaḥ na dissati
translated: For this is the method in the Dispensation that must not be transgressed. But the definition here is this:🔽In the compound the word “given” is seen, But the word “given” is not seen in the non-compound;

original: Byāsamhi dinnasaddova, dattasaddo na pāḷiyaṃ.
analyzed: byāsamhi dinna saddaḥ iva datta saddaḥ na pāḷiyam
translated: In the non-compound the word “given” is seen, But the word “given” is not in the text.

original: “Manasā dānaṃ mayā dinnaṃ, dānaṃ dinno”tiādisu;
analyzed: manasā dānam mayā dinnam dānam
translated: In such passages as “The gift was given by me with the mind” and “The gift was given” and so on,

original: “Dhammadinnā mahāmāyā”, iccādīsu ca pāḷisu.
analyzed: dhammadinnā mahāmāyā iccādīsu ca pāḷisu
translated: And in such passages as “Dhammadinnā, Mahāmāyā” and so on.

original: Iti byāsasamāsānaṃ, vasā dvedhā pavattati;
analyzed: iti byāsa samāsānam vasā dvedhā pavattati
translated: Thus the two modes of the non-compound and the compound

original: Dinnasaddoti dīpeyya, na so sakkaṭabhāsite.
analyzed: dinna saddo iti dīpeyya na so sakkaṭa bhāsite
translated: Occur in two ways, signifying the word “given,” Not in the language of the Sakkas.

original: Guṇabhūto dattasaddo, asamāsamhi kevalo;
analyzed: guṇa bhūtaḥ datta saddaḥ asamāsamhi kevalo
translated: The word “given” as a quality is only in the non-compound,

original: Na dissati munimate, dinnasaddova kevalo.
analyzed: na dissati muni mate dinna saddaḥ iva kevalaḥ
translated: Not in the Sage’s doctrine is the word “given” alone seen.

original: Teneva dinnasaddassa, dattādeso kato mayā;
analyzed: tena iva dinna saddassa datta ādesaḥ kataḥ mayā
translated: Therefore the substitution of “given” for “given” was made by me,

original: “Dattaṃ sirappadāna”nti, kavayo pana abravuṃ.
analyzed: dattam sirappadānanti kavayaḥ pana abravuṃ
translated: “Brahmadatta gave the gift of the verse,” so say the poets.

original: Ediso pāḷiyaṃ natthi, nayo tasmā na so varo;
analyzed: ediso pāḷiyam natthi nayo tasmā na so varo
translated: This is not in the text, and so this method is not good.

original: “Datto”ti bhūridattassa, saññā paṇṇattiyaṃ gatā.
analyzed: datto ti bhūridattassa saññā paṇṇattiyam gatā
translated: “Datta” is the perception and designation of Bhūridatta.

original: “Brahmadatto buddhadatto, datto” iti hi sāsane;
analyzed: brahmadattaḥ buddhadattaḥ dattaḥ iti hi sāsane
translated: “Brahmadatta, Buddhadatta, Datta,” thus in the Dispensation,

original: Paṇṇattiyaṃ dattasaddo, asamāsasamāsiko.
analyzed: paṇṇattiyam datta saddaḥ a samāsa samāsikaḥ
translated: The word “Datta” is a designation in a compound and not a compound.

original: “Paradattabhojana”nti, evamādīsu pāḷisu;
analyzed: evamādīsu pāḷisu
translated: “Paradattabhojana,” thus in the text,

original: Samāse guṇabhūtoyaṃ, dattasaddo patiṭṭhito.
analyzed: samāse guṇa bhūtaḥ iyam datta saddaḥ patiṭṭhito
translated: Here the word “Datta” is established as a quality in a compound.

original: “Manasā dānaṃ mayā dinnaṃ, dānaṃ dinno”tiādisu;
analyzed: manasā dānam mayā dinnam dānam
translated: “Manasā dānaṃ mayā dinnaṃ, dānaṃ dinno,” thus in the text,

original: Guṇabhūto dinnasaddo, asamāsamhi dissati.
analyzed: guṇa bhūtaḥ dinna saddaḥ asamāsamhi dissati
translated: The word “dinna” is seen as a quality in a non-compound.

original: “Dinnādāyī dhammadinnā”, iccevamādīsu pana;
analyzed: dinnādāyī dhammadinnā icca evamādīsu pana
translated: “Dinnādāyī dhammadinnā,” thus in the text,

original: Samāse guṇapaṇṇatti-bhāvenesa padissati.
analyzed: samāse guṇa paṇṇatti bhāvena isa padissati
translated: Here it is seen as a designation of a quality in a compound.

original: Koci pana saddasatthavidū garu evaṃ saddaracanamakāsi –
analyzed: koci pana evam
translated: But some who are experts in the science of words have made this analysis of the word:

original: “Yassaṅkurehi jimutambujaloditehi,
analyzed: yaḥ saṅkurehi jimu tambu jala uditehi
translated: “By the sprouts, the water lilies and lotuses that have opened,

original: Vāteritehi patitehi suṇehi tehi.
analyzed: vāta īritehi patitehi suṇehi tehi
translated: That are shaken by the wind and fall down, by those that are heard,

original: Jenantacīvaramasobhatha brahmadattaṃ,
analyzed: brahmadattam
translated: The robe of the one whose mind is calmed shines forth, Brahmadatta,

original: Vandāmi taṃ caladalaṃ varabodhirukkha”nti.
analyzed: vandāmi tam cala dalam
translated: I pay homage to you, the noble Bodhi tree with its swaying leaves.”

original: Ettha ca brahmadattanti idaṃ sakkaṭabhāsāto nayaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ, na pāḷito. Pāḷinayañhipatvā
analyzed: ettha ca brahmadattam ti idam sakkaṭa bhāsātaḥ nayam gahetvā vuttam na pāḷitaḥ
translated: And here the form brahmadattī is given by taking the method from the vernacular, not from the texts. For in accordance with the method of the texts

original: “brahmadattiya”nti vā “brahmadinna”nti vā “devadattiya”nti vā “devadinna”nti vā rūpena
analyzed: brahmadattiyanti vā brahmadinnanti vā devadattiyanti vā devadinnanti vā rūpena
translated: it should be brahmadattiya or brahmadinna or devadattiya or devadinna.

original: bhavitabbaṃ. Tathā hi “bodhisatto ca maddī ca sammodamānā sakkadattiye assame vasiṃsū”ti
analyzed: bhavitabbam tathā hi bodhisatto ca maddī ca sammodamānā sakkadattiye assame vasiṃsu iti
translated: For the text reads thus: “The Bodhisattvas and Maddi lived in the hermitage of Sakkadattiya, rejoicing” .

original: pāḷinayānurūpo aṭṭhakathāpāṭho dissati. Tasmā etthevaṃ vadāma –
analyzed: pāḷi naya anurūpaḥ aṭṭhakathā pāṭhaḥ dissati tasmai ettha evam vadāma
translated: So the commentary reading is found to conform to the text. Therefore we say this:🔽The word for “given” has the form “dattiya”

original: “Dattasaddassa ṭhānamhi, “dattiya”nti ravo gato;
analyzed: datta saddassa ṭhānamhi dattiyanti ravaḥ gataḥ
translated: In the place of the word “given,”🔽And the hermitage of Devadatta

original: Devadattiyapatto ca, assamo sakkadattiyo”ti.
analyzed: devadattiya patto ca assamaḥ sakkadattiyaḥ ti
translated: Is called the hermitage of Sakkadattiya.

original: Ayaṃ nīti sādhukaṃ manasi kātabbā. Atra pana paripuṇṇāparipuṇṇavasena yathārahaṃ padakkamo bhavati.🔽Dadāti, dadanti. Dadāsi, dadātha. Dadāmi, dadāma. Dadātu, dadantu. Dadāhi, dadātha.
analyzed: ayam sādhukam manasi kātabbā atra pana paripuṇṇa a paripuṇṇa vasena yathāraham padakkamaḥ bhavati  dadāti dadanti dadāsi dada atha dadāmi dadāma dadātu dadantu dadāhi dada atha
translated: This is the method that should be carefully borne in mind. Herein, the order of the forms is appropriate in each case according to whether they are complete or incomplete.🔽Dadāti, dadanti. Dadāsi, dadātha. Dadāmi, dadāma. Dadātu, dadantu. Dadāhi, dadātha.

analyzed: evam vivaraṇam katam na iva ettha pana na tu eva  sattamī payoga vasena iva vivaraṇam evam dajjaṃpadassa vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  idāni parokkha ādi vasena padakkamo kathiyati dada dadū dadū iti ca idam nāradaḥ
