translated: in such passages as “I will seek another name, a better name, and the gender will disappear” .

original: viya. Asabhāvadhammabhūtaṃ nāmapaññattisaṅkhātaṃ atthesu saddappavattinimittampi
analyzed: viya a sabhāva dhamma bhūtam nāma paññatti saṅkhātam atthesu sadda ppavatti nimittam pi
translated: and so on. The sign for the occurrence of a sound in the case of a meaning is called a “name” in such passages as “The name and clan do not grow old. The sign of life is impermanent” .

original: vuccati “nāmagottaṃ na jīrati. Sataliṅgo”tiādīsu viya. Iti nāmasaddenapi liṅgasaddenapi🔽saddappavattinimittassa kathanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saddappavattinimittañca nāma lokasaṅketasiddho🔽taṃtaṃvacanatthaniyato sāmaññākāravisesoti gahetabbaṃ. So evaṃbhūtoyeva sāmaññākāraviseso
analyzed: vuccati nāma gottam na jīrati viya iti nāma saddena api liṅga saddena api  sadda pavatti nimittassa kathanam daṭṭhabbam sadda ppavatti nimittam ca nāma loka saṅketa siddhaḥ  tad taṃ vacana attha niyataḥ sāmañña ākāra visesaḥ ti gahetabbam saḥ evaṃbhūtaḥ yā iva sāmañña ākāra visesaḥ
translated: So the name-sound and the gender-sound should be regarded as the means for the occurrence of a sound.🔽And the sign for the occurrence of a sound is a particular universal that is determined as the meaning of this or that word and is established by social agreement.

original: nāma paññattīti pubbācariyā vadanti. So hi tasmiṃ tasmiṃ atthe saddaṃ nāmeti tassa
analyzed: nāma paññattī iti pubba ācariyāḥ vadanti saḥ hi tasmin tasmin atthe saddam nāma iti tassa
translated: It should be taken thus. The past teachers say that this particular universal, which is of this kind, is a “name” in the sense of a concept.

original: tassa atthassa nāmasaññaṃ karotīti nāmaṃ, pakārehi ñāpanato paññatti ca. Saviññattivikārassa
analyzed: tassa atthassa nāma saññam karoti iti nāmam pakārehi ñāpanataḥ paññatti ca sa viññatti vikārassa
translated: For it is a “name” in that it names a sound in this or that meaning, it makes the concept “name” for this or that meaning, and it is a “concept” in that it is known by its components.

original: pana saddassa sammutiparamatthasaccānaṃ pakārehi ñāpanato paññattibhāve vattabbameva
analyzed: pana saddassa sammuti paramattha saccānam pakārehi ñāpanato paññatti bhāve vattabbam eva
translated: But in the case of a sound that has intimation and modification, it is a concept in that it is known by its components in the sense of conventional and ultimate realities.

original: natthi. Saddasseva hi ekantena paññattibhāvo icchitabbo “niruttipaṭisambhidā parittārammaṇā”ti🔽ca “niruttipaṭisambhidā paccuppannārammaṇā”ti ca “niruttipaṭisambhidā bahiddhārammaṇā”ti
analyzed: natthi saddassa iva hi ekantena paññatti bhāvaḥ icchitabbaḥ nirutti paṭisambhidā paritta ārammaṇā ti  ca nirutti paṭisambhidā paccuppanna ārammaṇā ati ca nirutti paṭisambhidā bahiddha ārammaṇā ati
translated: since it is shown in the texts thus, “The discrimination of language has a limited object” ,🔽“The discrimination of language has a present object” ,

original: ca pāḷidassanato. Idha pana saddappavattinimittādhikārattā nāmavasena attho pakāsito.🔽Evaṃ anekavidhassa sāmaññākāravisesoti pubbācariyehi gahitassa nāmapaññattisaṅkhātassa
analyzed: ca pāḷi dassanataḥ idha pana sadda ppavatti nimitta adhikāra attā nāma vasena atthaḥ pakāsito  evam anekavidhassa sāmañña ākāra visesaḥ ti pubba ācariyehi gahitassa nāma paññatti saṅkhātassa
translated: “The discrimination of language has an external object” . But here the meaning is demonstrated by way of the name because of the pre-eminence of the cause for the occurrence of the sound.🔽So it should be understood that a single knowable object can be taken as having many genders by way of the cause for the occurrence of the sound, which is called a name and a designation, and which is of many kinds as a general characteristic and as a particular characteristic, as was taken by the teachers of the past.

original: saddappavattinimittassa vasena ekopi ñeyyattho anekaliṅgoti gahetabbo. Tenāha āyasmā
analyzed: sadda ppavatti nimittassa vasena ekaḥ api ñeyya tthaḥ aneka liṅgaḥ ti gahetabbaḥ tena āha
translated: That is why the venerable

original: suhemanto pabhinnapaṭisambhido –
analyzed: su hemantaḥ pabhinna paṭisambhidaḥ
translated: Suhemantagāmiyo Pabhinnapaṭisambhido said:🔽“The meaning has a hundred genders,

original: “Sataliṅgassa atthassa, satalakkhaṇadhārino;
analyzed: sata liṅgassa atthassa sata lakkhaṇa dhārinaḥ
translated: And it bears a hundred characteristics;🔽The fool sees only one aspect,

original: Ekaṅgadassī dummedho, satadassīva paṇḍito”ti.
analyzed: ekaṅga dassī dummedhaḥ sata dassī iva paṇḍito ti
translated: But the wise man sees a hundred.”

original: Evaṃ sabbābhidhānesupi iminā nayena yathārahaṃ attho vibhāvetabbo nayaññūhi.
analyzed: evam sabba abhidhānesu pi iminā nayena yathāraham atthaḥ vibhāvetabbaḥ naya ñūhi
translated: So the meaning should be demonstrated in all the Abhidhamma as appropriate by those who know the method.

original: Vidi avayave. Vindati. Yadi abhidhānamatthi, “vindo”ti dissati. Yathā kaṇḍati. Kaṇḍo.
analyzed: vidi avayave vindati yadi abhidhānam atthi vindo ti dissati yathā kaṇḍati kaṇḍo
translated: The root vid means ‘a part’; it is found in such words as vindati (finds), and if the word abhidhāna (denotation) exists, it is seen in the word vinda (finder). It is like the root kaṇḍ (to scratch), in the word kaṇḍo (itch).

original: Khidi avayaveti candaviduno vadanti. Tesaṃ mate “khindatī”ti rūpaṃ.
analyzed: avayava iti candavidunaḥ vadanti tesam mate khindati iti rūpam
translated: The grammarians say that the root khid means ‘a part’; in their opinion the form is khindati.

original: Nidi kucchāyaṃ. Kucchāsaddo garahattho. Nindati. Nindā.
analyzed: nidi kucchāyam kucchāsaddaḥ gara hatthaḥ nindati nindā
translated: The root ni means ‘in the belly’; the word kucchi (belly) has the meaning of contempt; it is found in the word nindati (condemns), and nindā (condemnation).

original: Porāṇametaṃ atula, netaṃ ajjatanāmiva;
analyzed: porāṇam etam atula netam ajjatanām iva
translated: This is an ancient saying, Atula, not just of today;

original: Nindanti tuṇhimāsīnaṃ, nindanti bahubhāṇinaṃ;
analyzed: nindanti tuṇhim āsīnam nindanti bahu bhāṇinam
translated: They condemn one who sits in silence, they condemn one who speaks much;

original: Mitabhāṇimpi nindanti, natthi loke anindito.
analyzed: mita bhāṇim pi nindanti natthi loke anindito
translated: They condemn one who speaks moderately, there is no one in the world who is not condemned.

original: Avaṇṇo aguṇo nindā, garahā ayasopi ca;
analyzed: a vaṇṇaḥ a guṇaḥ nindā gara hā ca
translated: Disrepute, lack of virtue, condemnation, censure, disgrace,

original: Asiloko akitti ca, asilāghā ca atthuti.
analyzed: asi lokaḥ akitti ca asi lāghā ca atthuti
translated: Bad reputation, infamy, bad repute, and blame.

original: Nanda samiddhiyaṃ. Akammikā dhātu. Nandati puttehi puttimā. Nandāya nuna maraṇena.🔽Nandasi sirivāhana. Nandanaṃ vanaṃ. Abhisaddayoge panāyaṃ sakammakopi. Abhinandanti
analyzed: nanda samiddhiyam akammikā dhātu nandati puttehi puttimā nandāya maraṇena  nandasi sirivāhana nandanam vanam abhisadda yoge pana ayam abhinandanti
translated: The root naṃd means ‘to be complete’; it is found in such words as nandati (rejoices), and puttimā (having children). It is found in the word nandāya (for the sake of rejoicing), and maraṇena (by death).

original: āgataṃ nābhinandanti maraṇaṃ.
analyzed: āgatam na abhinandanti maraṇam
translated: You rejoice, O you who are carried by glory. The forest Nandana. But in the compound abhisaddayoge (in the compound abhisaddaya), this root is also used with the meaning of ‘to do’. They rejoice in the one who has come. They do not rejoice in death.

original: Sirīva rūpiniṃ disvā, nanditaṃ āsi taṃ kulaṃ;
analyzed: sirī iva rūpinim disvā nanditam āsi tam kulam
translated: Having seen the beautiful one like glory, that family was delighted.

original: Tena nandāti me nāmaṃ, sundaraṃ pavaraṃ ahu.
analyzed: tena me nāmam sundaram pavaram
translated: Therefore my name is Nandā, Beautiful and excellent.

original: Rammaṃ veḷuvanaṃ yena, na diṭṭhaṃ sugatālayaṃ;
analyzed: rammam veḷu vanam yena na diṭṭham sugata ālayam
translated: The delightful Bamboo Wood, the Sugata’s abode,

original: Na tena nandanaṃ diṭṭhaṃ, iti maññe mahesayaṃ.
analyzed: na tena nandanam diṭṭham iti maññe mahesayam
translated: Not seen by one, I think, the Great Sage’s Nandana not seen.

original: Yena veḷuvanaṃ diṭṭhaṃ, naranandananandanaṃ;
analyzed: yena veḷuvanam diṭṭham nara nandana nandanam
translated: By one who has seen the Bamboo Wood, the delight of men, the delight of Nandana,

original: Sudiṭṭhaṃ nandanaṃ tena, amarindasunandanaṃ.
analyzed: su diṭṭham nandanam tena amarinda sunandanam
translated: Nandana well seen by him, the delight of the Lord of the Immortals.

original: Cadi hilādane dittiyañca. Hilādanaṃ sukhanaṃ. Ditti sobhā. Candati. Candano, cando.
analyzed: cadi hilādane dittiyam ca hilādanam sukhanam ditti sobhā candati candano cando
translated: Hilādanaṃ, sukhanaṃ, ditti, sobhā, candati, candano, cando.

original: Ettha ca candanassapi anekāni nāmāni – candanaṃ, gandhasāro, malayajo, suvaṇṇacandanaṃ,🔽haricandanaṃ, rattacandanaṃ, gosītacandanaṃ. Candayati hilādayati sītaguṇasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: ettha ca candanassa api anekāni nāmāni candanam gandhasāraḥ malayajaḥ suvaṇṇacandanam  haricandanam rattacandanam gosītacandanam candayati hilādayati sīta guṇa samaṅgi tāya
translated: And here there are many names for sandalwood: sandalwood, fragrant essence, Malaya-born, golden sandalwood,🔽yellow sandalwood, red sandalwood, cool cow sandalwood. It is sandalwood because it delights, it delights, it delights beings with the quality of coolness,

original: sattānaṃ paliḷāhaṃ vūpasamentaṃ sukhaṃ uppādetīti candanaṃ. Candoti somo, sopi candayati
analyzed: sattānam paliḷāham vūpasamentam sukham uppādeti iti candanam somaḥ saḥ api candayati
translated: and it produces the happiness of the cessation of the heat of passion. Cando means the moon. That also delights,🔽it delights, it delights beings with the abundance of the quality of coolness, and by the light of its own radiance, the cessation of the heat of passion,

original: hilādayati sītaguṇasampattiyā attano pabhāya sattānaṃ pariḷāhaṃ vūpasamento sukhaṃ
analyzed: hilādayati sīta guṇa sampattiyāḥ attanaḥ pabhāya sattānam pariḷāham vūpasamento sukham
translated: it produces happiness.

original: uppādetīti candoti vuccati. Atha vā candati dibbati siriyā virocatīti cando. Āgamaṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: uppādeti iti cando ti vuccati atha vā candati dibbati siriyā virocati iti cando āgama aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: He is called the moon because he generates . Or alternatively, he is the moon because he shines with beauty, shining, shining.🔽But in the Commentaries on the scriptures it is said, “He is the moon because he generates desire . ”

original: pana “chandaṃ janetīti cando”ti vuttaṃ. Tassāpi anekāni nāmāni –
analyzed: pana chandam janeti iti cando ti vuttam tassa api anekāni nāmāni
translated: He has many names, namely,

original: Cando nakkhattarājā ca, indu somo nisākaro;🔽Candimā mā nisānātho, osadhī so nisāpati.🔽Uḷurājā sasaṅko ca, himaraṃsi sasīpi ca;
analyzed: candaḥ nakkhatta rājā ca indu somaḥ nisākaro  candimā mā nisānātha u osadhī saḥ nisāpati  uḷurājā ca himaraṃsi sasīpi ca
translated: Moon, king of the stars, moon, Soma, the white one,🔽Moon, night, protector of the night, herb, lord of the night,🔽Great king, with hare, and also cold-rayed, hare-marked,

original: Dvijarājā sasadharo, tārāpati himaṃsu ca.🔽Kumudabandhavo ceva, migaṅko ca kalānidhi;
analyzed: ca  ca iva migaṅko ca
translated: King of the stars, with the hare, lord of the stars, cold-rayed,🔽Relative of the white water lily, and also the hare-marked, treasure of the arts,

original: Sudhaṃ sudhi dhūpi yūpa-rasmi ceva khamākaro;
analyzed: ca iva
translated: Good nectar, good knowledge, smoke, sacrificial post, and also ray, maker of space,

original: Nakkhatteso ca rajanī-karo subbhaṃsu eva ca.
analyzed: ca rajanīkaro subbhaṃsu eva ca
translated: Star, maker of night, and also well-risen.

original: Tadi cetāyaṃ. Tandati. Tandī.
analyzed: tadi cetā ayam tandati tandī
translated: If it is this, then it is tandati, tandī.

original: Kadi kaladi avhāne rodane ca. Kandati, pakkandati. Pakkanduṃ, kandanto, kalandako.
analyzed: kadi kaladi avhāne rodane ca kandati pakkandati pakkandum kandantaḥ kalandakaḥ
translated: Kadi, kaladi are used in the sense of crying and weeping. Kandati, pakkandati. Pakkandunti, kandanto, kalandako.

original: Kalidi paridevane. Kalindati.
analyzed: kalidi paridevane kalindati
translated: Kalidi is used in the sense of lamenting. Kalindati.

original: Khoda paṭighāte. Khodati.
analyzed: khoda paṭighāte khodati
translated: Khoda is used in the sense of striking. Khodati.

original: Khanda gatisosanesu. Khandati. Khando. Khando nāma eko devo, yo “kumāro sattidharo”ti ca vuccati.
analyzed: khanda gati sosanesu khandati khandaḥ khandaḥ nāma ekaḥ devaḥ yaḥ kumāro satti dharo ti ca vuccati
translated: In the sense of ‘breaking up’ and in the sense of ‘a state of being broken up’: it breaks up , a broken thing . A broken thing is a deity called ‘the boy with the spear’ .

original: Khudi āpavane. Khundati.🔽Sidi sītiye. Sītiyaṃ sītibhāvo. Sindati. Sosindo, sotatto.
analyzed: khudi āpavane khundati  sidi sītiye sītiyam sīti bhāvaḥ sindati sosindaḥ sotattaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘to be cool’: it cools .🔽In the sense of ‘coolness’: the state of being cool . It flows . A flowing thing , a heated thing .

original: Vanda abhivādanathutīsu. Vandati, abhivandati. Abhivandanā, vandanaṃ, vandako.
analyzed: vanda abhivādana thutīsu vandati abhivandati abhivandanā vandanam vandakaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘to worship’ and in the sense of ‘to pay homage’: it worships , it pays homage . Worship , homage , a worshipper .

original: Ettha pana vandatīti padassa namassati thometi vāti attho. Tathā hi suttantaṭīkākāro “vandeti vandāmi thomemi vā”ti āha.🔽Bhadi kallāṇe sokhiye ca. Kallāṇaṃ kalyāṇaṃ, sokhiyaṃ sukhino bhāvo, sukhamiccevattho. Bhandati. Bhandako, bhaddo, bhadro.
analyzed: ettha pana vandati iti padassa namassati thometi vā ati attho tathā hi suttanta ṭīkākāraḥ vandeti vandāmi thomemi vā iti āha  bhadi kallāṇe sokhiye ca kallāṇam kalyāṇam sokhiyam sukhinaḥ bhāvaḥ sukham icca evatthaḥ bhandati bhandakaḥ bhaddaḥ bhadraḥ
translated: Herein, the meaning of the word ‘worships’ is ‘honours’ or ‘praises’, for the commentator on the Suttas says ‘It worships, it honours, it praises’ .🔽In the sense of ‘good’ and in the sense of ‘happiness’: good , happiness . It shines . A shining thing , a good man , a good woman .

original: Madi thutimodamadasupanagatīsu. Mandati. Mando.
analyzed: madi thuti moda mada supana gatīsu mandati mando
translated: In the sense of ‘to praise’ and in the sense of ‘to be intoxicated with pride and vanity’: it praises . A fool .

original: Ettha pana mandoti aññāṇīpi bāladārakopi vuccati. Tattha aññāṇī mandati aññāṇabhāvena
analyzed: ettha pana mandaḥ ti aññāṇī api bāla dārakaḥ api vuccati tattha aññāṇī mandati aññāṇa bhāvena
translated: Herein, a fool is called ‘foolish’ because of the state of being foolish .

original: appasaṃsitabbampi puggalaṃ thometīti mando. Mandati amoditabbaṭṭhānepi modatīti mando.
analyzed: a pasaṃsitabbam pi puggalam thometi iti mandaḥ mandati a moditabba ṭṭhāne pi modati iti mandaḥ
translated: He is slow in the sense of being slow to be praised. He is slow in the sense of being slow to be gladdened.

original: Mandati dānasīlādipuññakriyāsu pamajjatīti mando. Mandati attano ca paresañca hitāhitaṃ
analyzed: mandati dāna sīla ādi puñña kriyāsu pamajjati iti mandaḥ mandati ca paresam ca hita ahitam
translated: He is slow in the sense of being slow to give gifts, to observe moral discipline, etc., and to perform meritorious deeds. He is slow in the sense of🔽not considering what is beneficial and harmful for himself and others.

original: acintento khādanīyabhojanīyādīhi attano kāyaṃ sañjātamedaṃ kurumāno supatīti mando.
analyzed: a cintentaḥ khādanīya bhojanīya ādīhi kāyam sañjātam edam kurumānaḥ supati iti mandaḥ
translated: He is slow in the sense of sleeping well, having made his body a breeding ground for worms by eating and drinking.

original: Mandati ayuttaṃ paresaṃ kriyaṃ diṭṭhānugatiāpajjanena gacchati gaṇhātīti mando. Atha🔽vā mandati punappunaṃ paṭisandhiggahaṇavasena gabbhaṃ gacchatīti mando. Vuttañhi🔽bhagavatā “punappunaṃ gabbhamupeti mando”ti. Bāladārako pana mandati yuttāyuttamajānanto
analyzed: mandati ayuttam paresam kriyam diṭṭhānugati āpajjanena gacchati gaṇhāti iti mandaḥ atha  vā mandati punappunam paṭisandhi ggahaṇa vasena gabbham gacchati iti mandaḥ vuttam hi  bhagavatā punappunam gabbham upeti bāla dārako pana mandati yutta ayuttam a jānantaḥ
translated: He is slow in the sense of going along with and accepting the actions of others that are improper. Or else,🔽he is slow in the sense of going to the womb again and again to be reborn. For it is said by the Blessed One:🔽“Again and again he goes to the womb, the slow one” . The foolish person is slow in the sense of sleeping well, lying on his back or on his side, without knowing what is proper and improper.

original: uttānaseyyaṃparivattanaseyyaṃ vā supatīti mando. Tathā hi –🔽“Nonītasukhumālaṃ maṃ, jātapallavakomalaṃ;
analyzed: uttānaseyyaṃparivattanaseyyam vā supati iti mandaḥ tathā hi  mam jāta pallava komalam
translated: For it is said:🔽“They placed me, so tender and delicate,🔽so soft and nurtured by soft things,🔽The slow one, lying on my back,

original: Mandaṃ uttānasayanaṃ, pisācabhayatajjitā.
analyzed: mandam uttāna sayanam pisāca bhaya tajjitā
translated: terrified by the demon of fear,🔽At the feet of the Great Seer,

original: Pādamūle mahesissa, sāyesuṃ dīnamānasā;
analyzed: pāda mūle mahesissa dīna mānasā
translated: with sorrowful minds,

original: Idaṃ dadāma te nātha, saraṇaṃ hohi nāyakā”ti
analyzed: idam dadāma te nātha saraṇam hohi nāyaka ati
translated: We give this to you, Lord, be our refuge, O Leader.”

original: Vuttaṃ, iti uttānasayanato paṭṭhāya yāva mandadasakaṃ, tāva “mando”ti “dārako”ti
analyzed: vuttam iti uttāna sayanataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva manda dasakam tāva mando ti dārako ti
translated: Thus from the time of the lying-down in the womb up to the group of ten words beginning with “slow” the word “slow” should be taken as “child.”

original: daṭṭhabbo. Appatthavācakopi pana mandasaddo hoti, so pāṭipadikattā idha nādhippeto,
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ appattha vācakaḥ api pana manda saddaḥ hoti saḥ pāṭipadika ttā idha na adhippetaḥ
translated: But the word “slow” also denotes one who has little desire, and that is not intended here.

original: atha vā mandati appabhāvena gacchati pavattatīti nipphannapāṭipadikavasenapi gahetabbo.🔽Muda hāse. Hasanaṃ hāso tuṭṭhi. Modati, pamodati. Sammodati. Sammodako. Sammodamānā gacchanti muditā. Mudā.
analyzed: atha vā mandati appa bhāvena gacchati pavattati iti nipphanna pāṭipadika vasena api gahetabbaḥ  muda hāse hasanam hāso tuṭṭhi modati pamodati sammodati sammodako sammodamānāḥ gacchanti muditāḥ mudā
translated: Or alternatively, it can be taken as “slow” in the sense of “it goes, it occurs, with little brightness.”🔽Muda is laughter. Laughter is joy. He is glad, he is very glad. He is glad together. He is a gladdener. They go glad and joyful. Gladness.

original: Hada karīsossagge. Karīsossaggo nāma karīsassa ossajjanaṃ vissajjanaṃ. Hadati. Uhadati. Hadano.
analyzed: karīsa ussagge karīsa ussaggaḥ nāma karīsassa ossajjanam vissajjanam hadati uhadati
translated: Hada is the letting go of excrement. The letting go of excrement is the giving up, the abandoning, of excrement. He is glad. He is very glad. He is glad.

original: Ettha ca “yesaṃ no santhate dārakā uhadantipi ummihantipī”ti ayaṃ pāḷi nidassanaṃ,
analyzed: ettha ca yesam no dārakāḥ uhadanti pi ummihanti iti ayam nidassanam
translated: And here this passage is an instance: “They let the children go and they let them look” .

original: tatra uhadantipīti vaccampi karonti. Ummihantipīti passāvampi karonti. Pacchimapadassattho
analyzed: tatra vaccam pi karonti ummihanti pi iti passāvam pi karonti
translated: And here “they let them go” means they make them speak; “they let them look” means they let them urinate. The meaning of the last word is this:

original: miha secaneti dhātuvasena daṭṭhabbo. Ayaṃ pana curādigaṇepi vattati dvigaṇikattā.

analyzed: āha anutthuna saddo sa kammaka vasena payujjati purāṇāni anutthunanti ādīsu ayaṃ ca ittha
translated: The word anutthunana is used causatively in the sense of ‘to weep,’ as in the expressions ‘old tears’ and ‘to weep.’ This

original: payogoti iminā gāthāya anutthunanaṃ rudanaṃ adhippetanti dassetī”ti.🔽Dalidda duggatiyaṃ. Dukkhassa gati patiṭṭhāti duggatīti ayaṃ attho “apāyaṃ duggatiṃvinipātaṃ
analyzed: iminā gāthāya an utthunanam rudanam adhippetanti dasseti iti  dalidda duggatiyam dukkhassa gati patiṭṭhāti duggati iti ayam atthaḥ apāyam duggatiṃvinipātam
translated: is the application here.” By this he shows that the word anutthunana in the verse refers to weeping.

original: nirayaṃ upapajjatī”tiādīsu yujjati, idha pana idaṃ atthaṃ aggahetvā añño attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: nirayam upapajjati iti ādīsu yujjati idha pana idam attham aggahetvā aññaḥ atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: “Poor” : the meaning of duggati is “the going of suffering, the state of suffering.” This meaning is appropriate in such passages as “he is reborn in the plane of misery, in a state of suffering, in perdition, in hell.” But here another meaning should be taken.

original: Kathaṃ duggatīti? Dukkhena kicchena gati gamanaṃ annapānādilābho duggatīti. Daliddati.🔽Daliddo, daliddī, dāliddiyaṃ. Tattha daliddatīti sabbaṃ icchiticchitaṃ paraṃ yācitvā
analyzed: katham duggati iti dukkhena kicchena gati gamanam anna pāna ādi lābhaḥ duggati iti  daliddaḥ daliddī dāliddiyam tattha daliddatī iti sabbam icchiticchitam param yācitvā
translated: How is it a bad destination? It is a bad destination because it is a destination reached with difficulty and suffering, and because it is the obtaining of food, drink, etc., that is difficult. It is poor.🔽Poor, poorish, poverty. Herein, poor means that all that is desired is reached with difficulty, by begging from others, not without begging.

original: eva dukkhena adhigacchati, na ayācitvāti attho. Duliddoti duggatamanusso. Daliddīti
analyzed: eva dukkhena adhigacchati na a yācitvā ati attho duliddo ti duggata manussaḥ daliddī iti
translated: The meaning is that a poor person is one who has a bad destination. Poorish means

original: duggatā nārī. Daliddassa bhāvo dāliddiyaṃ. Ettha ca sabbameva “daliddatī”ti lokikappayogadassanato🔽“daliddatī”ti kriyāpadaṃ vibhāvitaṃ. Sāsane pana taṃ kriyāpadaṃ na āgataṃ, “daliddo
analyzed: duggatā nārī daliddassa bhāvaḥ dāliddiyam ettha ca sabbam eva daliddati iti lokika ppayoga dassanato  daliddatī iti kriyā padam vibhāvitam sa āsane pana tam kriyā padam na āgatam daliddaḥ
translated: a woman who has a bad destination. Poverty is the state of a poor person. And here all the words poor, poorish, poverty are analyzed as a verbal noun poor means to reach with difficulty,

original: daliddī”ti nāmapadāniyeva āgatāni. Anāgatampi taṃ “nāthatī”ti padamiva sāsanānulomattā🔽gahetabbameva. Garū pana kaccāyanamatavasena dala duggatimhīti duggativācakadaladhātuto
analyzed: daliddī iti āgatāni anāgatam pi tam padam iva  gahetabbam eva pana kaccāyana mata vasena dala duggatimhi iti duggati vācaka dala dhātutaḥ
translated: because of the way in which it is used in the world. But in the scriptures the verbal noun is not found. Only the nouns poor, poorish are found. And although the verbal noun is not found, it should be taken as though it were found, because it conforms to the scriptures,🔽like the verbal noun in “he protects.” But the grammarians, by taking the root dal to mean “a bad destination,” and by making it a condition for idd,

original: iddapaccayaṃ katvā “daliddo”ti nāmapadaṃ dassesuṃ.
analyzed: idda paccayam katvā daliddaḥ iti nāmapadam dassesuṃ
translated: have shown the noun poor.

original: Tuda byathane. Tudati, vitudati. Kammani “tujjati, vitujjamāno, vedanābhibhunno”ti rūpāni.
analyzed: tuda byathane tudati vitudati kammani tujjati vitujjamānaḥ vedanā abhibhunnoti rūpāni
translated: Tuda byathane. Tudati, vitudati. Kammani: “tujjati, vitujjamāno, vedanābhibhunno”ti rūpāni.

original: Tudanti vācāhi janā asaññatā,
analyzed: tudanti vācāhi janāḥ asaññatā
translated: People with no self-control torment him

original: Sarehi saṅgāmagataṃva kuñjaraṃ;
analyzed: sarehi saṅgāma gatam iva kuñjaram
translated: As in a battle they torment an elephant;

original: Sutvāna vākyaṃ pharusaṃ udīritaṃ,
analyzed: sutvāna vākyam pharusam udīritam
translated: Having heard the harsh words spoken,

original: Adhivāsaye bhikkhu aduṭṭhacitto;
analyzed: adhivāsaye bhikkhu a duṭṭha cittaḥ
translated: The monk should endure with an untroubled mind.

original: Nuda peraṇe. Peraṇaṃ cuṇṇikaraṇaṃ pisanaṃ, nudati, panudati. Panudanaṃ.
analyzed: nuda peraṇe peraṇam cuṇṇi karaṇam pisanam nudati panudati panudanam
translated: Nuda peraṇe. Peraṇaṃ cuṇṇikaraṇaṃ pisanaṃ, nudati, panudati. Panudanaṃ.

original: Vidi lābhe. Vindati. Uṭṭhātā vindate dhanaṃ. Govindo.
analyzed: vidi lābhe vindati uṭṭhātā vindate dhanam govindo
translated: Vidi lābhe. Vindati. Uṭṭhātā vindate dhanaṃ. Govindo.

original: Khadi parighāte. Parighātaṃ samantato hananaṃ. Khandati.
analyzed: parighāte parighātam samantataḥ hananam khandati
translated: Khadi parighāte. Parighātaṃ samantato hananaṃ. Khandati.

original: Dakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: dakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: Dakārantadhāturūpāni.

original: Dhakārantadhātu
analyzed: dhakāra anta dhātu
translated: Dhakārantadhātu

original: Dhā dhāraṇe. Dadhāti, vidadhāti. Yaṃ paṇḍito nipuṇaṃ saṃvidheti. Nidhiṃ nidheti.
analyzed: dhāḥ dhāraṇe dadhāti vidadhāti yam paṇḍitaḥ nipuṇam saṃvidheti nidhim nidheti
translated: Dhā dhāraṇe. Dadhāti, vidadhāti. Yaṃ paṇḍito nipuṇaṃ saṃvidheti. Nidhiṃ nidheti.

original: Nidhi nāma nidhīyati. Tāva sunihito santo. Yato nidhiṃ parihari. Nidahati. Kuhiṃ
analyzed: nidhi nāma nidhīyati su nihitaḥ santaḥ yatas nidhim nidahati kuhiṃ
translated: Nidhi nāma nidhīyati. Tāva sunihito santo. Yato nidhiṃ parihari. Nidahati. Kuhiṃ

original: deva nidahāmi. Paridahati. Yo vattaṃ paridahissati. Dhassati. Paridhassati. Bāloti
analyzed: deva nidahāmi paridahati yaḥ vattam paridahissati dhassati paridhassati bālo ti
translated: deva nidahāmi. Paridahati. Yo vattaṃ paridahissati. Dhassati. Paridhassati. Bāloti

original: paraṃ padahati. Sakyā kho ambaṭṭha rājānaṃ ukkākaṃ pitāmahaṃ dahanti. Saddahati tathāgatassa
analyzed: param padahati sakyā kho ambaṭṭha rājānam ukkākam pitāmaham dahanti saddahati tathāgatassa
translated: he scorches another. The Sakyans, Ambattha, scorch the king, their grandfather. He has faith in the Awakening of the Realised One.

original: bodhiṃ. Saddhā, saddahanā, saddhātabbaṃ, saddahitabbaṃ, saddhāyiko, paccayiko. Saddheyyavacasā
analyzed: bodhim saddhā saddahanā saddhātabbam saddahitabbam saddhāyikaḥ paccayikaḥ saddheyya vacasā
translated: Faith, having faith, should be had faith in, should be had faith, having faith, having a cause. One who has trustworthy speech.

original: upāsikā. Saddahituṃ, saddahitvā. Visesādhānaṃ. Sotāvadhānaṃ. Sotaṃ odahati. Ohitasoto.
analyzed: upāsikā saddahitum saddahitvā visesa ādhānam sota avadhānam sotam odahati ohita soto
translated: A female lay follower who has faith. To have faith, having had faith. A special undertaking. Giving ear. He scorches the ear. With ear applied.

original: Sotaṃ odahitvā. Maccudheyyaṃ, māradheyyaṃ, nāmadheyyaṃ, dhātu, dhātā, vidhātā. Vidhi.
analyzed: sotam odahitvā maccudheyyam māradheyyam nāmadheyyam dhātu dhātā vidhātā vidhi
translated: The realm of death, the realm of Mara, the realm of name, the realm, the one who realms, the one who arranges. Arrangement.

original: Abhidhānaṃ, abhidheyyaṃ, nidhānavatī vācā, ādhānagāhī, sandhi. Aññānipi yojetabbāni.
analyzed: abhidhānam abhidheyyam nidhānavatī vācā ādhāna gāhī sandhi aññāni pi yojetabbāni
translated: Designation, the one to be designated, speech that has a store, the one who takes up the basis, a connection. Other should be connected.

original: Vipubbo dhā karotyatthe, abhipubbo tu bhāsane;
analyzed: vipubbaḥ dhā karoti atthe abhipubbaḥ tu bhāsane
translated: The root dhā makes vipubba in the sense of ‘to make manifold’, but abhipubba in the expression (of praise);

original: Nyāsaṃpubbo yathāyogaṃ, nyāsāropanasandhisu.
analyzed: yathāyogam nyāsa āropana sandhisu
translated: Nyāsaṃpubba in the appropriate way, in the placing, the placing, and the connections.

original: Imasmā pana dhādhātuto pubbassa api iccupasaggassa akāro kvaci niccaṃ lopaṃ pappoti,
analyzed: imasmā pana dhā dhātutaḥ pubbassa api i cc upasaggassa akāraḥ kvaci niccam lopam pappoti
translated: But in this root dhādhātu, the letter a of the prefix icc is sometimes always lost,

original: kvaci niccaṃ lopaṃ na pappoti. Atra lopo vuccate, dvāraṃ pidahati, dvāraṃ pidahanto,
analyzed: kvaci niccam lopam na atra lopaḥ vuccate dvāram pidahati dvāram pidahantaḥ
translated: “He closes the door”, “he is closing the door”, “he will close the door”,🔽“having closed the door” — in this way there is the omission of the vowel a.

original: pidahituṃ, pidahitvā, evaṃ akāralopo bhavati. Dvāraṃ apidahitvā, evaṃ akāralopo na
analyzed: pidahitum pidahitvā evam akāra lopaḥ bhavati dvāram a pidahitvā evam akāra lopaḥ na
translated: “Having not closed the door” — in this way there is not the omission of the vowel a.

original: bhavati. Ettha hi akāro apiupasaggassa avayavo na hoti. Kinti ce? Paṭisedhatthavācako
analyzed: bhavati ettha hi akāraḥ api upasaggassa avayavaḥ na hoti kinti ce paṭisedha ttha vācakaḥ
translated: For here the vowel a is not a part of the prefix api. What then? It is a particle🔽which expresses prohibition. But the prefix is not seen as a part of the prefix.

original: nipātoyeva, upasaggāvayavo pana adassanaṃ gato, ayaṃ niccālopo. Evaṃ dhādhātuto pubbassa
analyzed: nipātaḥ yā iva upasagga avayavaḥ pana adassanam gataḥ ayam nicca ālopaḥ evam dhā dhātutaḥ pubbassa
translated: This is the omission of the vowel a which is always. In this way, the vowel a of the prefix

original: api iccupasaggassa akāro kvaci niccaṃ lopaṃ pappoti, kvaci niccaṃ lopaṃ na pappoti.
analyzed: api i t c upasaggassa akāraḥ kvaci niccam lopam pappoti kvaci niccam lopam na pappoti
translated: api which precedes the dhātu and the dhātu, sometimes has omission of the vowel a, and sometimes does not have omission of the vowel a.

original: Idaṃ acchariyaṃ idaṃ abbhutaṃ. Yatra hi nāma bhagavato pāvacane evarūpapopi nayo
analyzed: idam acchariyam idam abbhutam yatra hi nāma bhagavataḥ
translated: This is wonderful, this is marvellous, that in the Dispensation of the Blessed One, such a method

original: sandissati viññūnaṃ hadayavimhāpanakaro, yo ekasmiṃyeva dhātumhi ekasmiṃyeva upasagge
analyzed: sandissati viññūnam hadaya vimhāpana karaḥ yaḥ ekasmiṃ yeva dhātumhi ekasmiṃ yeva upasagge
translated: is seen, which causes the hearts of the wise to tremble, which in one dhātu, in one prefix,

original: ekasmiṃyevatthe kvaci lopālopavasena vibhajituṃ labbhati. Idāni mayaṃ sotūnaṃ paramakosallajananatthaṃ
analyzed: ekasmin yevatthe kvaci lopa alopa vasena vibhajitum labbhati idāni mayam
translated: in one meaning, can be divided by way of the omission and non-omission of the vowel a. Now, in order to generate the highest skill in the listeners,

original: tadubhayampi ākāraṃ ekajjhaṃ karontā tadākāravatiṃ jinavarapāḷiṃ ānayāma –
analyzed: tad ubhayam pi ākāram ekajjham karontā tad ākāravatim jina vara pāḷim ānayāma
translated: and we bring in the text of the Victor, which has that Mode, by combining both of them together:

original: “Gaṅgaṃ me pidahissanti, na taṃ sakkomi brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: gaṅgam me pidahissanti na tam sakkomi brāhmaṇa
translated: “They will dam up the Ganges for me, brahmin, I cannot do that;

original: Apidhetuṃ mahāsindhuṃ, taṃ kathaṃ so bhavissati;
analyzed: apidhetum mahā sindhum tam katham saḥ bhavissati
translated: How will it be possible to dam up the great ocean?

original: Na te sakkomi akkhātuṃ, atthaṃ dhammañca pucchito.
analyzed: na te sakkomi akkhātum attham dhammam ca pucchito
translated: Asked about the meaning and the True Idea, I cannot tell you;

original: Cittatthasādhaniṃ etaṃ, gāthaṃ sambhavajātake;
analyzed: etam gātham sambhava jātake
translated: This verse, which is the means of fulfilling the wish, is in the Sambhava Jātaka;

original: Paññāsambhavamicchanto, kare citte sumedhaso”ti.
analyzed: paññā sambhavam icchantaḥ kare citte sumedhasaḥ ti
translated: The wise one, wishing for the arising of understanding, should make it in the mind.”

original: Dhu gatitheriyesu. Gati gamanaṃ, theriyaṃ thirabhāvo. Dhavati. Dhuvaṃ.
analyzed: dhu gati theriyesu gati gamanam theriyam thira bhāvaḥ dhavati dhuvam
translated: Dhu gatitheriyesu. Gati is going. Theriyaṃ is firmness. Dhavati. Dhuvaṃ.

original: Ettha ca dhuvanti thiraṃ. “Nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo”tiādīsu viya, tasmā
analyzed: ettha ca thiram niccaḥ dhuvaḥ sassataḥ a vipariṇāma dhammaḥ ti ādīsu viya tasmā
translated: And here dhuvaṃ is firm. As in such passages as “Permanent, firm, eternal, not subject to change” ,

original: dhuvanti thiraṃ kiñci dhammajātaṃ. Atha vā dhuvanti idaṃ gatitheriyatthavasena nibbānasseva
analyzed: dhuvanti thiram kiñci dhamma jātam atha vā dhuvanti idam gati theriya ttha vasena nibbānassa iva
translated: so dhuvaṃ is a certain kind of state that is firm. Or alternatively, dhuvaṃ is a designation for extinction itself,

original: adhivacanaṃ bhavitumarahati. Tañhi jātijarābyādhimaraṇasokādito muccitukāmehi dhavitabbaṃ
analyzed: adhivacanam bhavitum arahati tat hi jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa soka āditaḥ muccitu kāmehi dhavitabbam
translated: in the sense of the state of the Elder Nun Gati. For that is what those who desire to be freed from birth, ageing, disease, death, sorrow, and so on, should go to .

original: gantabbanti dhuvaṃ, uppādavayābhāvena vā niccasabhāvattā dhavati thiraṃ sassataṃ
analyzed: gantabbanti dhuvam uppāda vayā bhāvena vā nicca sabhāva ttā dhavati thiram sassatam
translated: Or it is “constant” because it is always of a nature to occur and then cease.

original: bhavatīti dhuvaṃ. Yañhi sandhāya bhagavatā “dhuvañca vo bhikkhave desessāmi dhuvagāminiñca
analyzed: bhavati iti dhuvam yat hi sandhāya bhagavatā dhuvam ca vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi dhuva gāminim ca
translated: For it is said by the Blessed One: “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the constant and the way leading to the constant” .

original: paṭipada”nti vuttaṃ. Dhuvasaddo “vacanaṃ dhuvasassata”nti ettha thire vattati. “Dhuvañca🔽bhikkhave desessāmī”ti ettha nibbāne. “Dhuvaṃ buddho bhavissasī”ti ettha pana ekaṃse
analyzed: paṭipadanti vuttam dhuva saddaḥ vacanam dhuva sassatanti ettha thire vattati dhuvam ca  bhikkhave desessāmi iti ettha nibbāne dhuvam buddhaḥ bhavissasi iti ettha pana ekaṃse
translated: Herein, the word “constant” is used in the sense of firm in the passage, “The constant and the eternal word” ,🔽in the sense of Nibbāna in the passage, “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the constant” ,

original: nipātapadabhāvena vattatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nipāta pada bhāvena vattati iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: and in the sense of certainty in the passage, “You will become a Buddha, constant” .🔽Dhū is derived from dhū, which means “to shake” . The vowel u is lengthened.

original: Dhū vidhūnane. Ūkārassa ūvattaṃ. Dhūvati. Dhūvitā, dhūvitabbaṃ. Rassatte “dhuto, dhutavā” iccapi rūpāni bhavanti.🔽Dhe pāne. Dhayati, dhīyati. Dhena.
analyzed: vidhūnane ūkārassa ūvattam dhūvati dhūvitā dhūvitabbam rassatte dhutaḥ dhutavā iti ca api rūpāni bhavanti  dhe pāne dhayati dhīyati dhena
translated: Dhe is derived from dhi, which means “to drink” .

original: Ettha ca dhenūti dhayati pivati ito khīraṃ potakoti dhenu, “godhenu, assadhenu, migadhenū”ti
analyzed: ettha ca dhenū iti dhayati pivati itas khīram potakā uti dhenu go dhenu assa dhenu miga dhenū ti
translated: Herein, dhenu is derived from dhayati, which means “a suckling drinks milk from it,” thus it is a dhenu . “A cow dhenu, a mare dhenu, a deer dhenu” .

original: dhenusaddo sāmaññavasena sapotikāsu tiracchānagatitthīsu vattati, evaṃ santepi yebhuyyena
analyzed: dhenu saddo sāmañña vasena sa potikāsu tiracchānaga titthīsu vattati evam sante pi yebhuyyena
translated: The word dhenu is used in the sense of the general class in the case of the female animals beginning with the cow.

original: gāviyaṃ vattati. Tathā hi “satta dhenusate datvā”ti pāḷi dissati.
analyzed: gāviyam vattati tathā hi satta dhenu sate dissati
translated: Nevertheless, it is used mostly in the sense of the cow. For the text reads: “Having given away seven hundred cows” .

original: Sidhu gatiyaṃ sedhati, nisedhati, paṭisedhati. Siddho, pasiddho, nisiddho, paṭisiddho,
analyzed: sidhu gatiyam sedhati nisedhati paṭisedhati siddhaḥ pasiddhaḥ nisiddhaḥ paṭisiddhaḥ
translated: Sedhati in the sense of going: nisedhati, paṭisedhati. Siddho, pasiddho, nisiddho, paṭisiddho,

original: paṭisedhito, paṭisedhako, paṭisedho, paṭisedhituṃ, paṭisedhitvā. Idha acinteyyabalattā
analyzed: paṭisedhitaḥ paṭisedhakaḥ paṭisedho paṭisedhitum paṭisedhitvā idha acinteyya balattā
translated: paṭisedhito, paṭisedhako, paṭisedho, paṭisedhituṃ, paṭisedhitvā. Here, because of the inconceivable power of the prefix,

original: upasaggānaṃ taṃyoge sidhudhātussa nānappakārā atthā sambhavanti, aññesampi evameva.
analyzed: upasaggānam taṃyoge sidhu dhātussa nānappakārāḥ atthāḥ sambhavanti aññesam pi evam eva
translated: many meanings of the root dhā are possible in combination with the prefix si: so too in the case of other prefixes.

original: Sidhu satthe maṅgalye ca. Satthaṃ sāsanaṃ, maṅgalyaṃ pāpavināsanaṃ vuddhikāraṇaṃ vā. Sedhati. Siddho, pasiddho, pasiddhi.
analyzed: sidhu satthe maṅgalye ca sattham sa āsanam maṅgalyam pāpa vināsanam vuddhi kāraṇam vā sedhati
translated: Sedhati in the sense of a vehicle and in the sense of auspicious: a vehicle is the doctrine; auspicious is that which destroys evil or is a cause of increase. Siddho, pasiddho, pasiddhi.

original: Dadha dhāraṇe. Janassa tuṭṭhiṃ dadhateti dadhi. Dhakārassa hakāratte “dahatī”ti rūpaṃ.
analyzed: dadha dhāraṇe janassa tuṭṭhim dadhatā iti dadhi dhakārassa dahati iti rūpam
translated: Dadhati in the sense of holding: they hold the people’s delight, thus curd . The form is “dahati” when the d becomes h.

original: Ayaṃ itthī imaṃ itthiṃ ayyikaṃ dahati. Ime purisā imaṃ purisaṃ pitāmahaṃ dahanti.
analyzed: ayam itthī imam itthim ayyikam dahati ime purisāḥ imam purisam pitāmaham dahanti
translated: This woman is burning this woman who is her mother. These men are burning this man who is their grandfather.

original: Cittaṃ samādahātabbaṃ. Samādahaṃ cittaṃ.
analyzed: cittam samādahātabbam samādaham cittam
translated: The mind should be set on fire. I set the mind on fire.

original: Edha vuddhiyaṃ lābhe ca. Edhati. Edho, sukhedhito. Gambhīre gādhamedhati.
analyzed: lābhe ca edhati su khedhitaḥ gambhīre gādham edhati
translated: Edha is burning, in growth, and in gain. It burns. Edho is burning, in the sense of burning with pleasure. Gādhamedhati is burning what is fixed in a pit.

original: Ettha ca edhoti edhati. Vaḍḍhati etena pāvakoti edho. Indanaṃ, upādānaṃ. Sukhedhitoti sukhena edhito, sukhasaṃvaḍḍhitoti attho. Gādhamedhatīti gādhaṃ patiṭṭhitaṃ edhati labhati.
analyzed: ettha ca edho ti edhati vaḍḍhati etena pāvako ti edho indanam upādānam sukha īdhitaḥ iti sukhena edhitaḥ sukha saṃvaḍḍhitaḥ iti atthaḥ gādham edhati iti gādham patiṭṭhitam edhati labhati
translated: And here edho is burning, in the sense of burning by this, it grows. Indhana is fuel. Sukhedhito is burned with pleasure, the meaning is: grown with pleasure. Gādhamedhati is burning what is fixed in a pit, it obtains.

original: Baddha saṃharise. Saṃhariso vinibaddhakriyā. Baddhati, vinibaddhati. Vinibaddhā.
analyzed: saṃharisaḥ saṃharisaḥ vinibaddha kriyā vinibaddhā
translated: Baddha is bound, in the sense of bound, in the sense of bound action. It binds, it is bound. It is bound.

original: Gādha patiṭṭhānissayagandhesu. Gādhati. Gādhaṃ kattā. Gambhīrato agādhaṃ.
analyzed: patiṭṭhā nissaya gandhesu gādhati gādham kattā gambhīrataḥ agādham
translated: Gādha is fixed, in the sense of fixed, in the sense of smell. It fixes. Gādha is a fixer. Gambhīrato is not fixed in a pit.

original: Bādha viloḷane bādhati, vibādhati. Ābādho. Ābādhati cittaṃ viloḷetīti ābādho.
analyzed: bādha viloḷane bādhati vibādhati ābādhaḥ ābādhati cittam viloḍeti iti ābādhaḥ
translated: Bādha is shaking, in the sense of shaking. It shakes, it shakes much. Ābādho is shaking. Ābādhati cittaṃ viloḷetīti ābādho.

original: Nādha yācanādīsu. Nādhati. Nādhanaṃ.
analyzed: na adha yācana ādīsu na adhati na adhanam
translated: Nādha is asking, etc. It asks. Nādhana is asking.

original: Bandha bandhane bandhati. Bandhanako, bandho, bandhāpito, paṭibandho, bandhanaṃ, bandho, sambandhanaṃ, sambandho, pabandho, bandhu.🔽Tattha bandhananti bandhanti satte etenāti bandhanaṃ, saṅkhalikādi. “Ayaṃ amhākaṃ
analyzed: bandha bandhane bandhati bandhanakaḥ bandhaḥ bandhāpito paṭibandhaḥ bandhanam bandho sambandhanam sambandho pabandhaḥ bandhu  tattha bandhanan ti bandhanti satte etena ati bandhanam saṅkhalikā ādi ayam amhākam
translated: Bandha, bandhane, bandhati, bandhanako, bandho, bandhāpito, paṭibandho, bandhanaṃ, bandho, sambandhanaṃ, sambandho, pabandho, bandhu.🔽Herein, bandhanaṃ is that by means of which creatures are bound, namely a chain, etc.;

original: vaṃso”ti sambandhitabbaṭṭhena bandhu, theragāthāsaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ pana “pemabandhanena bandhū”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vaṃso ti sambandhitabba ṭṭhena bandhu thera gāthā saṃvaṇṇanāyam pana pema bandhanena bandhu iti vuttam
translated: “This is our family tradition” , and so on. In the commentary to the Theragāthā it is said: “They are relatives by the bond of affection” .

original: Dadhi asīghacāre. Asīghacāro asīghappavatti. Dandhati. Dandho, dandhapañño. Yo dandhakāle tarati, taraṇīye ca dandhati.
analyzed: dadhi a sīgha cāre a sīgha cāraḥ a sīgha ppavatti dandhati dandhaḥ dandha pañño yaḥ dandha kāle tarati taraṇīye ca dandhati
translated: Dadhi, asīghacāre. Asīghacāro is asīghappavatti. Dandhati. Dandho, dandhapañño. Yo dandhakāle tarati, taraṇīye ca dandhati.

original: Vaddha vaddhane. Vaddhati. Vaddhi, vuddhi, vaddho, vuddho, jātivuddho, guṇavuddho, vayovuddho.
analyzed: vaddha vaddhane vaddhati vaddhaḥ vuddhaḥ jāti vuddhaḥ guṇa vuddhaḥ vayaḥ vuddhaḥ
translated: Vaddha, vaddhane. Vaddhati. Vaddhi, vuddhi, vaddho, vuddho, jātivuddho, guṇavuddho, vayovuddho.

original: Ye vuddhamapacāyanti, narā dhammassa kovidā;
analyzed: ye vuddham apacāyanti narāḥ dhammassa kovidā
translated: Those who honour the elder, The men who are skilled in Dhamma,

original: Diṭṭheva dhamme pāsaṃsā, samparāye ca suggatiṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhā iva dhamme pāsaṃsā samparāye ca suggatim
translated: Are praised in this very life, And have a good destination in the next.

original: Sadhu saddakucchiyaṃ. Sadhati.
analyzed: sadhu saddakucchiyam sadhati
translated: Sadhu, saddakucchiyaṃ. Sadhati.

original: Piḷadhi alaṅkāre. Piḷandhati. Piḷandhanaṃ.
analyzed: piḷadhi alaṅkāre piḷandhati piḷandhanam
translated: Piḷadhi, alaṅkāre. Piḷandhati. Piḷandhanaṃ.

original: Piḷandhanamalaṅkāro, maṇḍanañca vibhūsanaṃ;
analyzed: piḷandhanam alaṅkāraḥ maṇḍanam ca vibhūsanam
translated: Ornament, adornment, decoration, and embellishment

original: Pasādhanañcābharaṇaṃ, pariyāyā ime matā.
analyzed: pariyāyāḥ ime matā
translated: Are synonyms for “ornament” (piḷandhana).

original: Medha hiṃsāyaṃ saṅgame ca. Medhati. Medhā, medhāvī. Atra medhāti asani viya siluccaye
analyzed: saṅgame ca medhati medhāḥ medhāvī atra medhāti asani siluccaye
translated: Medha is violence and also a gathering. It shines (medhati). It is medhā, a wise person. Here, medhā is like a lightning flash in a rain cloud.

original: kilese medhati hiṃsatīti medhā. Medhati vā siriyā sīlādīhi ca sappurisadhammehi saha
analyzed: kilese medhati hiṃsati iti medhā medhati vā siriyā sīla ādīhi ca sappurisa dhammehi saha
translated: It shines (medhati) and it is violent (hiṃsatī) towards defilements, thus it is medhā. Or it shines (medhati) and it goes (gacchati) along with glory and the good qualities of a noble person such as virtue, etc.,

original: gacchati na ekikā hutvā tiṭṭhatīti medhā, paññāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Tathā hi –
analyzed: gacchati naḥ ekikā hutvā tiṭṭhati iti medhā paññāya etam nāmam tathā hi
translated: not remaining alone, thus it is medhā, this is a name for wisdom. For it is said:

original: “Paññā hi seṭṭhā kusalā vadanti,
analyzed: paññā hi seṭṭhā kusalā vadanti
translated: “The wise say that wisdom is the best,

original: Nakkhattarājāriva tārakānaṃ;
analyzed: tārakānam
translated: Like the king of the stars among the stars;

original: Sīlaṃ sirī cāpi satañca dhammo,
analyzed: sīlam sirī ca api
translated: Virtue, glory, and the good Dhamma

original: Anvāyikā paññavato bhavantī”ti
analyzed: anvāyikā paññavataḥ bhavanti iti
translated: Follow one who has wisdom.”

original: Vuttaṃ. Medhāvīti dhammojapaññāya ca samannāgato puggalo.
analyzed: vuttam medhāvī iti dhamma oja paññāya ca samannāgataḥ puggalo
translated: Thus it is said. A person who possesses the wisdom of the Dhamma is a wise person (medhāvī).

original: Sadhu madhu unde. Sadhati. Madhati. Madhu.
analyzed: sadhu madhu unde sadhati madhati madhu
translated: It is good (sadhu), it is honey (madhu), it is drunk (unde). It shines (sadhati). It shines (madhati). It is honey (madhu).

original: Budha bodhane. Bodhati. Buddho. Abhisambuddhāno. Sambuddhaṃ. Asambuddhaṃ. Bodhi.
analyzed: budha bodhane bodhati buddhaḥ sambuddham asambuddham
translated: It is a buddha (buddha), it is enlightenment (bodhana). It shines (bodhati). It is a buddha (buddha). It is one who has fully awakened (abhisambuddhāno). It is the fully awakened one (sambuddhaṃ). It is the unawakened one (asambuddhaṃ). It is enlightenment (bodhi).

original: Divādigaṇepi ayaṃ dissati. Tatrahi “bujjhatī”ti rūpaṃ, idha pana “bodhatī”ti rūpaṃ.
analyzed: divā ādi gaṇe pi ayam dissati tatrahi bujjhati iti rūpam idha pana bodhati iti rūpam
translated: In the Divā-group it is found as “it awakens” . Here it is found as “it causes to awaken” .

original: “Yo nindaṃ apabodhatī”ti pāḷi dissati. Kārite pana “bodheti” iccādīni.
analyzed: yaḥ nindam apabodhati iti dissati kārite pana bodha iti icca ādīni
translated: The reading “he who causes to awaken blame” is found. But in the formed “he causes to awaken” , etc., it is found.

original: Yudha sampahāre. Yodhati. Yodho. Yodhetha māraṃ paññāvudhena. Yuddhaṃ. Caraṇāyudho, caraṇāvudho vā. Āvudhaṃ. Divādigaṇikassa panassa “yujjhatī”ti rūpaṃ.🔽Dīdhi dittivedhanesu. Dīdhati. Dīdhiti. Ettha ca dīdhitīti rasmi. Anekāni hi rasmināmāni.
analyzed: sampahāre yodhati yodhaḥ yodhetha māram paññāvudhena yuddham caraṇāyudhaḥ caraṇāvudhaḥ vā āvudham divādigaṇikassa panassa yujjhati iti rūpam  dīdhi ditti vedhanesu dīdhati dīdhiti ettha ca dīdhiti iti rasmi anekāni hi rasmi nāmāni
translated: In the sense of “fighting” : yodhati, yodho, yodhetha māraṃ paññāvudhena, yuddhaṃ, caraṇāyudho, caraṇāvudho, āvudhaṃ. But in the Divā-group it is found as “it is yoked” .🔽In the sense of “shining” : dīdhati, dīdhiti. And here dīdhiti is a ray. For there are many names for a ray.

original: Rasmi ābhā pabhā raṃsi, ditti bhā ruci dīdhiti;🔽Marīci juti bhāṇva’su, mayūkho kiraṇo karo;
analyzed: rasmi ābhā pabhā raṃsi ditti bhā ruci dīdhiti  marīci juti mayūkhaḥ kiraṇo karo
translated: Ray, light, radiance, ray, shining, light, beauty, shining,🔽Light, lustre, sun, peacock’s ornament, ray, orb,

original: Nāgadhāmo ca āloko, iccete rasmivācakā.
analyzed: nāgadhāmaḥ ca ālokaḥ i t ca ite rasmi vācakā
translated: And also “world’s lamp” are words that express a ray.

original: Cakārantarūpāni.
analyzed: cakāra anta rūpāni
translated: The forms with the ending -ā are feminine.

original: Nakārantadhātu
analyzed: nakāra anta dhātu
translated: The verbal roots with the ending -ā are masculine.

original: Nī naye. Neti, nayati, vineti. Vineyya hadaye daraṃ. Āneti. Ānayati. Netā. Vinetā.
analyzed: nī naye nā iti nayati vinā iti vineyya hadaye daram āneti ānayati netā vinetā
translated: In the sense of “leading” : neti, nayati, vineti. Vineyya hadaye daraṃ. Āneti. Ānayati. Netā. Vinetā.

original: Nāyako. Neyyo. Veneyyo. Venayiko. Vinīto puriso. Nīyamāne pisācena, kinnu tāta udikkhati.🔽Nīyanto. Nettaṃ. Netti. Bhavanetti samūhatā. Nettiko. Udakañhi nayanti nettikā. Nettā.
analyzed: nāyakaḥ neyyaḥ veneyyaḥ venayikaḥ vinītaḥ purisaḥ nīyamāne pisācena kinnu tāta udikkhati  nīyantaḥ nettam netti bhavanetti samūhatā nettikaḥ udakam hi nayanti nettikāḥ nettā
translated: Leader. One to be led. One to be trained. One who trains. A person who is trained. When a ghost was leading him, “What is it, dear, that you are looking at?”🔽One who is being led. Guide. Guide. The guide to becoming is destroyed. A guide. For guides lead water by means of a guide. Guides.

original: Nette ujuṃ gate sati. Nayo. Vinayo. Āyatanaṃ. Netuṃ. Vinetuṃ. Netvā. Vinetvā iccādīni.
analyzed: ujum gate sati nayaḥ vinayaḥ āyatanam netum vinetum netvā vinetvā icca ādīni
translated: When the guides are gone straight, there is a guide. Discipline. Sense base. To lead. To train. Having led. Having trained. And so on.

original: Tattha nettanti samavisamaṃ dassentaṃ attabhāvaṃ netīti nettaṃ, cakkhu. Nettīti nenti🔽etāya satteti netti, rajju. Bhavanettīti bhavarajju, taṇhāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Tāya hi sattā🔽goṇā viya gīvāya bandhitvā taṃ taṃ bhavaṃ niyyanti, tasmā bhavanettīti vuccati. Nettikāti
analyzed: tattha nettam ti sama visamam dassentam atta bhāvam neti iti nettam cakkhu netti iti nenti  etāya sattā iti netti rajju bhava netti iti bhava rajju taṇhāya itam nāmam tāya hi sattā  goṇāḥ viya gīvāya bandhitvā tam tam bhavam niyyanti tasmā bhavanettī iti vuccati nettikā ati
translated: Herein, a guide is an eye that guides one’s own being by showing what is equal and what is unequal. It guides .

original: kassakā. Nettāti gavajeṭṭhako yūthapati. Nayoti nayanaṃ gamanaṃ nayo, pāḷigati. Atha
analyzed: kassakā nettā ati gavajeṭṭhakaḥ yūthapati nayo ti nayanam gamanam nayo pāḷigati atha
translated: A guide is a rope by which one guides creatures . The guide to becoming is craving, which is the name for the rope of becoming. For by that creatures are led to this or that becoming, as oxen are, and so it is called the guide to becoming. Guides are ploughmen. A guide is the bull, the leader of the herd. Leading is the going, the progress, of the text. Then

original: vā tattha tattha netabboti nayo, sadisabhāvena netabbākāro. Nīyatīti nayo, tathattanayādi.
analyzed: vā tattha tattha netabbaḥ uti nayaḥ sadisa bhāvena netabba ākāraḥ nīyati iti nayaḥ tathatta naya ādi
translated: It is a method because it is what is to be gone by ;

original: Nīyati etenāti nayo, antadvayavivajjananayādi.🔽Tathā hi chabbidho nayo tathattanayo pattinayo desanānayo antadvayavivajjananayo🔽acinteyyanayo adhippāyanayoti. Tesu tathattanayo antadvayavivajjananayena nīyati,
analyzed: nīyati etena ati nayaḥ anta dvaya vivajjana naya ādi  tathā hi chabbidhaḥ nayaḥ tathatta nayaḥ patti nayaḥ desanā nayaḥ anta dvaya vivajjana nayaḥ  acinteyya nayaḥ ti tesu tathatta nayaḥ anta dvaya vivajjana nayena nīyati
translated: for example, the method of the two extremes, etc.🔽It is a method because it is what goes ;🔽for example, the method of the two extremes, etc.🔽For the method is of six kinds as method of the two extremes, method of attainment, method of teaching, method of non-excess, method of the inconceivable, and method of the purport.

original: pattinayo acinteyyanayena, desanānayo adhippāyanayena nīyati. Etthādimhi tividho🔽nayo kammasādhanena nīyatīti “nayo”ti vuccati, pacchimo pana tividho nayo karaṇasādhanena
analyzed: patti nayaḥ acinteyya nayena desanā nayaḥ adhippāya nayena nīyati ettha ādimhi tividhaḥ  nayo kamma sādhanena nīyati iti nayo ti vuccati pacchimaḥ pana tividhaḥ nayo karaṇa sādhanena
translated: Herein, the method of the two extremes is gone by by the method of the two extremes,🔽the method of attainment is gone by by the method of the inconceivable, and the method of teaching is gone by by the method of the purport.🔽Herein, the first three methods are called “method” because they are what is to be gone by by the method of accomplishment.

original: nīyati etena tathattādinayattayamiti “nayo”ti vuccati. Imasmiṃ atthe papañciyamāne🔽ganthavitthāro siyāti vitthāro na dassito.🔽Aparopi catubbidho nayo ekattanayo nānattanayo abyāpāranayo evaṃdhammatānayoti.
analyzed: nīyati etena tathattā ādinayattayam iti vuccati imasmin atthe 🔽gantha vitthāraḥ siyā ti vitthāraḥ na dassito 🔽aparaḥ api catubbidhaḥ nayaḥ ekatta nayaḥ nānatta nayaḥ abyāpāra nayaḥ evaṃdhamma tā nayaḥ ti
translated: But the last three methods are called “method” because they are what goes by the method of doing.

original: Vineti satte ettha, etenāti vā vinayo. Kāyavācānaṃ vinayanatopi vinayo. Āyatananti🔽anamatagge saṃsāre pavattaṃ atīva āyataṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ yāva na nivattati, tāva nayateva
analyzed: vinā iti satte ettha etena ati vā vinayaḥ kāya vācānam vinayanataḥ pi vinayaḥ  anamatagge saṃsāre pavattam atīva āyatam saṃsāra dukkham yāva na nivattati tāva nayata iva
translated: Or alternatively, it is discipline because it disciplines, it trains, beings here in this , in this , thus it is discipline. And it is discipline because it disciplines, it restrains, bodily and verbal action.🔽The world is a place of suffering, and it is a place of suffering for as long as one is not turned away from it, for as long as one does not turn away from it.

original: pavattatevāti āyatanaṃ.
analyzed: pavattatā iva ati āyatanam
translated: It is a place of suffering because it is a place of suffering for as long as one is not turned away from it, for as long as one does not turn away from it.

original: Ayaṃ panettha atthuddhāro. “Āyatananti assānaṃ kambojo āyatanaṃ, gunnaṃ dakkhiṇāpatho āyatana”nti ettha sañjātiṭṭhānaṃ āyaanaṃ nāma. “Manorame āyatane, sevanti naṃ vihaṅgamā.🔽Chāyaṃ chāyatthino yanti, phalatthaṃ phalabhojino”ti ettha samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. “Pañcimāni
analyzed: ayam pana ittha atthuddhāraḥ āyatananti assānam kambojaḥ āyatanam gunnam dakkhiṇāpathaḥ āyatananti ettha sañjātiṭṭhānam nāma manorame āyatane sevanti nam vihaṅgamāḥ  chāyam chāyatthinaḥ yanti phalattham phala bhojino ti ettha samosaraṇa ṭṭhānam pañcimāni
translated: This is the explanation of the meaning here. In the passage, “The Kamboja country is a place for horses, the southern country is a place for cattle” , the place of birth is called a place. In the passage, “Birds frequent a pleasant place,

original: bhikkhave vimuttāyatanānī”ti ettha kāraṇaṃ. Aññepi pana payogā yata patiyataneti ettha pakāsitā.
analyzed: bhikkhave vimutta āyatanāni iti ettha kāraṇam aññe pi pana payogā ettha pakāsitā
translated: Those who want shade go to the shade, those who want fruit go to the fruit” , it is a place of resort. In the passage, “Bhikkhus, there are these five places of release” , it is a cause. Other usages are evident in such passages as “The place where the Blessed One was walking up and down” .

original: Nī pāpane. Neti, nayati. Nayanaṃ.
analyzed: nī pāpane neti nayati nayanam
translated: Nī is a negative particle. Neti is to lead. Nayana is leading.

original: Nu thutiyaṃ. Noti, navati. Nuto.
analyzed: nu thutiyam noti navati nutaḥ
translated: Nu is an expression of praise. No is ninety. Nuto is led.

original: Thana pana dhana sadde. Thanati. Panati. Dhanati.
analyzed: thana pana dhana sadde thanati panati dhanati
translated: Thana is a verbal noun formed from the verb dhana, to be rich. Thanati is to be rich. Panati is to be rich. Dhanati is to be rich.

original: Kana dittikantīsu. Kanati. Kaññā. Kanakaṃ.
analyzed: kana ditti kantīsu kanati kaññā kanakam
translated: In the case of the words kaññā, kanakaṃ, and vana, the meaning is “to shine” (kanati).

original: Ettha ca yobbanibhāve ṭhitattā rūpavilāsena kanati dippati virocatīti kaññā. Atha🔽vā kaniyati kāmiyabhi abhipatthiyati purisehītipi kaññā, yobbanitthī. Kanakanti kanati,
analyzed: ettha ca yobbani bhāve ṭhita ttā rūpa vilāsena kanati dippati virocati iti kaññā atha  vā kaniyati abhipatthiyati purisehi itipi kaññā yobbanitthī kanakanti kanati
translated: Herein, a girl is called a kaññā because she shines, glows, and radiates with the beauty of youth.🔽Or alternatively, a girl is called a kaññā because she is sought by men for sexual intercourse.🔽Kanakaṃ is gold because it shines (kanati) or because it is sought (kani-yati) by people.

original: kanīyatīti vā kanakaṃ, suvaṇṇaṃ. Suvaṇṇassa hi anekāni nāmāni.
analyzed: kanīyati iti vā kanakam suvaṇṇam suvaṇṇassa hi anekāni nāmāni
translated: For gold has many names,

original: Suvaṇṇaṃ kanakaṃ hemaṃ, kañcanaṃ haṭakampi ca;
analyzed: suvaṇṇam kanakam hemam kañcanam haṭakam pi ca
translated: Gold, kanaka, hema, kañcana, and haṭaka,

original: Jātarūpaṃ tapanīyaṃ, vaṇṇaṃ tabbhedakā pana;
translated: Jātarūpa, tapanīya, vaṇṇa, and tabbhheda,

original: Jambunadaṃ siṅgikañca, cāmikaranti bhāsitā.
analyzed: jambunadam siṅgikam ca bhāsitā
translated: Jambunada, siṅgika, and cāmika are also said.

original: Vana sana sambhattiyaṃ. Vanati. Vanaṃ. Sanati.
analyzed: vana sana sambhattiyam vanati vanam sanati
translated: In the case of the words vana and vana, the meaning is “to assemble” (vanati).

original: Tattha vananti. Taṃ sambhajanti mayūrakokilādayo sattāti vanaṃ, araññaṃ. Vanati sambhajati saṃkilesapuggalanti vanaṃ, taṇhā.
analyzed: tattha vananti tam sambhajanti mayūra kokila ādayo sattā ati vanam araññam vanati sambhajati saṃkilesa puggalanti vanam taṇhā
translated: Herein, a forest is called a vana because birds such as peacocks and cuckoos assemble there (vananti) and because it is assembled by people who are defiled.

original: Mana abbhāse. Manati. Mano.
analyzed: manaḥ ap bhāse manati manaḥ
translated: In the case of the words mano and vana, the meaning is “to shine” (manati).

original: Māna vīmaṃsāyaṃ, vīmaṃsati. Vīmaṃsā.
analyzed: māna vīmaṃsā ayam vīmaṃsati vīmaṃsā
translated: In the case of the words māna and vīmaṃsā, the meaning is “to investigate” (vīmaṃsati).

original: Jana suna sadde. Janati. Sunati.
analyzed: jana suna sadde janati sunati

original: Sumbha bhāsane ca. Cakāro hiṃsāpekkhako. Sumbhati. Sumbho. Kusumbho.

translated: Sumbha is for the meaning of “to shine.” The syllable ca is in the sense of “to look for hurting.” It shines. A sumbha. A kusumbha.

original: Ettha sumbhoti āvāṭo. “Sumbhaṃ nikkhanāhī”ti idamettha nidassanaṃ. Kusumbhoti khuddakaāvāṭo, “pabbatakandarapadarasākhāparipūrā kusumbhe paripūrentī”ti idamettha nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: ettha sumbhaḥ iti āvāṭaḥ sumbham nikkhanāhi iti idam ettha nidassanam kusumbhaḥ ti khuddaka āvāṭaḥ pabbata kandara pada rasa ākhā paripūrā kusumbhe paripūrenti iti idam ettha nidassanam
translated: Herein, a ‘pit’ is a hole. The example here is ‘Come out of the pit’. A ‘pool’ is a small pit. The example here is ‘Filling up the pools and the pits in the gullies and clefts of the hills’.

original: Abbha vabbha mabbha gatiyaṃ. Abbhati. Abbho. Vabbhati. Mabbhati.
analyzed: abbha vabbha mabbha gatiyam abbhati abbhaḥ vabbhati mabbhati
translated: Abbha, vabbha, and mabbha are verbs meaning ‘to go’. Abbhati, vabbhati, mabbhati.

original: Ettha abbhoti megho. So hi abbhati anekasatapaṭalo hutvā gacchatīti “abbho”ti vuccati.
analyzed: ettha abbho ti megho so hi abbhati aneka sata paṭalaḥ hutvā gacchati iti abbho ti vuccati
translated: Herein, a ‘cloud’ is an abbha. For that goes, having become a mass of many hundreds of layers, thus it is called an abbha.

original: “Vijjumālī satakkakū”ti vuttaṃ. Satakkakūti ca anekasatapaṭalo. Ettha ca abbhasaddo
analyzed: vijjumālī sa takkakūti vuttam sa takkakūti ca aneka sata paṭalaḥ ettha ca abbha saddo
translated: ‘With lightning flashes and a hundred peals’ is said. And a ‘hundred peals’ is many hundreds of layers. And here the word abbha

original: tiliṅgiko daṭṭhabbo. Tathā hi ayaṃ “abbhuṭṭhitova sa yāti, sa gacchaṃ na nivattatī”ti🔽ettha pulliṅgo. “Abbhā, mahikā, dhūmo, rajo, rāhū”ti ettha itthiliṅgo. “Abbhāni candamaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: tiliṅgikaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ tathā hi ayam abbhuṭṭhitaḥ iva sa yāti sa gaccham na nivattati iti  ettha pulliṅgaḥ abbhā mahikā dhūmaḥ rajaḥ ettha itthi liṅgaḥ abbhāni canda maṇḍalam

original: chādentī”ti ettha napuṃsakaliṅgo.
analyzed: chādenti iti ettha napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ
translated: it is masculine. In the passage ‘The abbhās, the mahikās, the dhūmas, the rajas, the rāhūs’ it is feminine. In the passage ‘The abbhās are hiding the moon’s disk’ it is neuter.

original: Imāni pana meghassa nāmāni –
analyzed: imāni pana meghassa nāmāni
translated: But these are the names for a cloud:🔽Cloud, rain-cloud, rain-maker,

original: Megho valāhako laṅghi, jīmūto ambudo ghano;
analyzed: meghaḥ valāhakaḥ laṅghi jīmūtaḥ ambudaḥ ghanaḥ
translated: cloud, water-cloud, mass.

original: Dhārādharo ambudharo, pajjunno himagabbhako.
translated: The rain-maker, the cloud-maker, Pajjunna, the one with a snow-filled womb.

original: Yabha methune. Mithunassa janadvayassa idaṃ kammaṃ methūnaṃ, tasmiṃ methune yabhadhātu vattati. Yabhati. Yābhassaṃ.
analyzed: methune mithunassa jana dvayassa idam kammam methūnam tasmin methune yabha dhātu vattati yabhati yābhassam
translated: Yabhati in the sense of sexual intercourse. This is the action of a couple, of two people, and the syllable yabhati occurs in the sense of sexual intercourse. Yabhati. Yābhassaṃ.

original: Ettha ca “methuna”nti esā sabbhivācā, lajjāsampannehi puggalehi vattabbabhāsābhāvato.🔽Tathā hi “methuno dhammo na paṭisevitabbo”ti ca “na me rājā sakhā hoti, na rājā hoti🔽methuno”ti ca sobhane vācāvisaye ayaṃ bhāsā āgatā. “Yabhatī”tiādikā pana bhāsā “sikharaṇī”tiādikā
analyzed: ettha ca methunam ti esā sabbhivācā lajjā sampannehi puggalehi vattabba bhāsā abhāvato  tathā hi methunaḥ dhammaḥ na paṭisevitabbaḥ ti ca na me rājā sakhā hoti na rājā hoti  ca sobhane vācā visaye ayam bhāsā āgatā pana bhāsā sikharaṇī iti ādikā
translated: And here “methuna” is a word that should be spoken only by people who are modest, because it is a form of speech that is not to be used.

original: bhāsā viya asambhivācā. Na hi hirottappasampanno lokiyajanopi īdisiṃ vācaṃ bhāsati.🔽Evaṃ santepi adhimattukkaṃsagatahirottappopi bhagavā mahākaruṇāya sañcoditahadayo
analyzed: bhāsā viya a sambhivācā na hi hira uttappa sampannaḥ lokiya janaḥ api īdisim vācam bhāsati  evam sante pi bhagavā mahā karuṇāya sañcodita hadayaḥ
translated: For thus it is said: “Sexual intercourse is not to be engaged in” and “The king is not my friend, the king is not my companion in sexual intercourse” . This form of speech has come down in the beautiful sphere of speech. But the form of speech beginning with “yabhati” is not a form of speech that is to be used, like the form of speech beginning with “sikharaṇī” . For even a worldly person who is endowed with a sense of shame and moral dread does not speak such words.

original: lokānukampāya parisamajjhe abhāsi. Aho tathāgatassa mahākaruṇāti.

translated: Even so, the Blessed One, who is endowed with a sense of shame and moral dread that is of the highest degree, spoke in the midst of the assembly out of compassion for the world, his heart being moved by his great compassion. Ah! The great compassion of the Tathāgata!

original: Imāni pana methunadhammassa nāmāni –

analyzed: sañcalane khobhati saṅkhobhati hatthi nāge nagaram tadā khobhā saṅkhobhaḥ
translated: It is used for trembling and for shaking. It trembles, it shakes. When the elephant was submerged, the city trembled. Trembling, shaking.

analyzed: sambha vissāse sambhati sambhatti sambhatto  vimohane lobhati palobhati thulla kumārī palobhanam kārite pana

analyzed: kiṭā iti gamā iti kriyā ādi vibhāgam tam vā anavasesa pariyādānato keṭentaḥ gamentaḥ obheti

original: pūretīti keṭutaṃ kiṭaubhadhātuvasena. Ubbhati ubbheti pūretīti ubbhaṃ, pūraṇanti
analyzed: pūreti iti keṭutam kiṭaubha dhātu vasena ubbhati ubbheti pūreti iti ubbham pūraṇanti
translated: The meaning of the word ubbha is “one who fills up,” thus it is “a filler” (ubbha).

original: attho. Cariyāpiṭakepi hi īdisī saddagati dissati, taṃ yathā? “Mahādānaṃ pavattesi,
analyzed: atthaḥ cariyāpiṭake pi hi īdisī saddagati dissati tam yathā mahādānam pavattesi
translated: For in the Cariyāpiṭaka also such a usage of the word is seen, as in the passage: “He caused to flow a great gift,

original: accubbhaṃ sāgarūpama”nti. Tattha ca accubbhanti ativiya yācakānaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ pūraṇaṃ.
analyzed: accubbham tattha ca accubbhanti ativiya yācakānam ajjhāsayam pūraṇam
translated: like the ocean, a filler of the wish.”🔽And here “a filler of the wish” means “a filler of the wish of the supplicants beyond measure.”

original: Akkhumbhantipi pāṭho. Kumbhoti kaṃ vuccati udakaṃ, tena ubbhetabboti kumbho, so eva
analyzed: akkhumbham tipi pāṭhaḥ kumbhaḥ iti kam vuccati udakam tena ubbhetabbaḥ iti kumbhaḥ saḥ eva
translated: The reading “akkhumbha” is also found. The word kumbha means “water,” and that which is to be filled with that is kumbha.

original: itthiliṅgavasena kumbhī. Ettha ca “kumbhī dhovati onato”ti payogo.
analyzed: kumbhī ettha ca kumbhī dhovati payogo
translated: That is kumbhī in the feminine form. And here the usage is “kumbhī washes, bending down.”🔽The word kumbha is to be known by the wise who see the method

original: Kumbhasaddo ghaṭe hatthi-siropiṇḍe dasambaṇe;
analyzed: kumbha saddaḥ ghaṭe hatthi siro piṇḍe dasambaṇe
translated: As occurring in the sense of a pot, the top of an elephant’s head, and a measure of ten.

original: Pavattatīti viññeyyo, viññunā nayadassinā.🔽Bhakārantadhāturūpāni.🔽Makārantadhātu
analyzed: pavattati iti viññeyyaḥ viññunā naya dassinā  bhakāra anta dhātu rūpāni  makāra anta dhātu
translated: The word mā is found in the sense of “pride” and “sound.”

original: Mā māne sadde ca. Māti. Mātā. Ettha mātāti janikā vā cūḷamātā vā mahāmātā vā.
analyzed: mā māne sadde ca mā ati mātā ettha mātā ati janikā vā cūḍa mātā vā mahā mātā vā
translated: The word mā is found in the sense of “mother” and “pride.” Here “mother” means one’s own mother, or one’s mother’s sister, or one’s father’s sister, or one’s father’s full brother’s wife.

original: Mū bandhane. Mavati. Kiyādigaṇassa panassa “munātī”ti rūpaṃ.
analyzed: mū bandhane mavati kiyā ādi gaṇassa panassa munāti iti rūpam
translated: In the sense of binding, as in “He binds” (mavati). But its form is “he frees” (munāti) in the sense of “he frees from the defilements” (kiyādigaṇassa panassa “munātī”ti rūpaṃ).

original: Me paṭidānaādānesu. Meti, mayati. Medhā.
analyzed: me paṭidāna ādānesu mā iti mayati medhā
translated: In the sense of giving and taking, as in “He gives” (mayati). The word medhā is derived from the root ma.

original: Ettha medhāti paññā. Sā hi sukhumampi atthaṃ dhammañca khippameva meti ca dhāreti
analyzed: ettha medhā ati paññā sā hi sukhumam pi attham dhammam ca khippam eva mā iti ca dhārā iti
translated: Here medhā is wisdom. For that quickly grasps and holds even a subtle meaning and thing,

original: cāti medhāti vuccati. Ettha pana metīti gaṇhāti. Tathā hi aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ vuttaṃ “asani
analyzed: ca ati medhā iti vuccati ettha pana mā iti iti gaṇhāti tathā hi aṭṭhasāliniyam vuttam
translated: and so it is called medhā. But here medhati is taken to mean “it grasps” . For it is said in the Atthasālinī:

analyzed: kilese medhati hiṃsati iti medhā khippam gahaṇa dhāraṇa ṭṭhena vā  saṅgamattha vācakassa pana medha dhātussa vasena medhati sīla samādhi ādīhi saddhammehi
translated: “It destroys defilements as a lightning flash destroys a tree, thus it is medhā. Or it is medhā in the sense of quick grasping and holding” .

original: siriyā ca saṅgacchatīti medhāti attho gahetabbo. Etthetaṃ vuccati –🔽“Dvidhātuyekadhātuyā, dviratthavatiyāpi ca;
analyzed: siriyā ca saṅgacchati iti medhā ati atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ ettha etam vuccati  dvi dhātuyā ika dhātuyā ca
translated: But the meaning can be taken as “it is associated with the good things of the Dispensation, such as virtue, concentration, etc., and with glory, by means of the element of wisdom that expresses the meaning of association” . This is what is said:🔽“In the scriptures of the Well-Farer,🔽One should know the derivation of the word medhā🔽As twofold by the two elements and the one,

original: Medhāsaddassa nipphattiṃ, jaññā sugatasāsane”ti.
analyzed: medhā saddassa nipphattim jaññā sugata sāsanā iti
translated: And also by the two meanings it has.”

original: Omā sāmatthiye. Sāmatthiyaṃ samatthabhāvo. Aluttantoyaṃ dhātu, omāti, omanti.
analyzed: omā sāmatthiye sāmatthiyam samattha bhāvaḥ dhātu omā ati omanti
translated: In the sense of ability, as in “He is able” (omanati). Ability is the state of being able . This element is not low, it is om . They are oṃ .

original: Atrāyaṃ pāḷi “omāti bhante bhagavā iddhiyā manomayena kāyena brahmalokaṃ upasaṅkamitu”nti. Tattha omātīti pahoti sakkoti.
analyzed: atra ayam pāḷi omā ati bhante bhagavā iddhiyā manaḥ mayena kāyena brahma lokam upasaṅkamitunti tattha omā ati iti sakkoti
translated: Here is the text: “It is possible, venerable sir, by psychic power, with a mind-made body, to go to the Brahmā-world.” Herein, it is possible is pahoti, which is the same as sakkoti .

original: Timu addabhāve. Addabhāvo tintabhāvo. Temati. Tinto, temiyo. Temitukāmā temiṃsu.
analyzed: timu adda bhāve adda bhāvaḥ tinta bhāvaḥ temati tintaḥ temiyaḥ temitu kāmā temiṃsu
translated: Timu is a form of addhabhāva . Addhabhāva is tintabhāva . He temeti . He is tinto , temiya . Those who want to temeti teṃsu .

original: Ettha temiyoti evaṃnāmako kāsirañño putto bodhisatto. So hi rañño ceva mahājanassa ca hadayaṃ temento addabhāvaṃ pāpento sītalabhāvaṃ janento jātoti “temiyo”ti vuccati.
analyzed: ettha temiyoti evaṃnāmako kāsi rañño putto bodhisatto so hi rañño ca iva mahājanassa ca hadayam tementaḥ adda bhāvam pāpentaḥ sītala bhāvam janentaḥ jātaḥ iti temiyoti vuccati
translated: Herein, the being who is called temiya was the son of the king of Kāsi. He was called temiya because he was born causing the king’s and the people’s hearts to tremble and become alarmed and causing them to become cool .

original: Nitami kilamane. Nitammati. Hadayaṃ dayhate nitammāmi.
analyzed: nitami kilamane nitammati hadayam dayhate nitammāmi
translated: Nitami is a form of kilamane . He nitammati . The heart burns, I nitammāmi .

original: Camu chamu japu jhamu umu jimu adane. Camati. Camū. Camūti senā. Chamati. Jamati. Jhamati. Umati. Jemati.

translated: Camu chamu japu jhamu umu jimu are forms of adana . He camati . He is camū . Camū is an army. He chamati . He jamati . He jhamati . He umati . He jemati .

original: Kamu padavikkhepe. Padavikkhepo padasā gamanaṃ. Idaṃ pana vohārasīsamattaṃ vacanaṃ,

translated: Kamu is a form of padavikkhepe . Padavikkhepa is padasā gamanaṃ . But this is a mere head of a derivation,
