analyzed: ramati viramati paṭiviramati uparamati ārati virati paṭivirati  uparati veramaṇi viramaṇam rati ramaṇam rataḥ ārataḥ virataḥ paṭivirataḥ uparataḥ uparamaḥ ārāmaḥ
translated: He plays, he delights, he desists, he desists completely, he desists from, he delights in, he desists, he desists completely, he desists from.🔽He desists, he is one who abstains, he is abstaining, he delights, he is one who delights, he is delighted, he is one who has desisted, he is one who has desisted completely, he is one who has desisted from, he is one who has desisted, he is desisting.

original: Vamu uggiraṇe. Vamati. Vamathu. Vammiko.🔽Dhīratthu taṃ visaṃ vantaṃ, yamahaṃ jīvitakāraṇā;
analyzed: uggiraṇe vamati vamathu  tam visam vantam yam aham jīvita kāraṇā
translated: He vomits, he vomits, he vomits, he vomits, he vomits.🔽I’ll vomit it up again, though it be to my death,

original: Vantaṃ paccāvamissāmi, mataṃ me jīvitā varaṃ.
analyzed: vantam paccāvamissāmi matam me jīvitā varam
translated: Rather than die for the sake of life.

original: Tattha vammikoti vamatīti, vantakoti, vantussayoti, vantasinehasambandhoti vammiko.🔽So hi ahinakulaundūragharagoḷikādayo nānappakāre pāṇake vamatīti vammiko. Upacikāhi
analyzed: tattha vammiko ti vamati iti vantako ti vantussayo ti vanta sineha sambandho ti vammiko  so hi ahi nakula aundūra ghara goḷikā ādayaḥ nānappakāre pāṇake vamati iti vammikaḥ
translated: Herein, he vomits is a vomiter; he vomits is a vomiter; he is about to vomit is a vomiter; he is connected with the vomit-slime is a vomiter.🔽For he vomits various creatures such as snakes, lizards, rats, and so on, thus he is a vomiter. He is a vomiter

original: vantakoti vammiko. Upacikāhi vamitvā mukhatuṇḍakena ukkhittapaṃsucuṇṇena kaṭippamāṇenapi
analyzed: vantako ti vammikaḥ upacikāhi vamitvā mukha tuṇḍakena ukkhitta paṃsu cuṇṇena kaṭi ppamāṇena api
translated: because he is built up with the dust and powder thrown up by the mouth-tips of the termites that have vomited.

original: porisappamāṇenapi ussitoti vammiko. Upacikāhi vantakheḷasinehena ābaddhatāya sattasattāhaṃ
analyzed: porisa ppamāṇena api ussitaḥ ti vammikaḥ vanta kheḷa sinehena ābaddha tāya satta satta aham
translated: He is a vomiter because he is built up with the termite-slime that has been held together for seven days by the termites that have vomited.

original: deve vassantepi na vippakirayati, nidāghepi tato paṃsumuṭṭhiṃ gahetvā tasmiṃ muṭṭhinā
analyzed: deve vassante api na vippakirayati nidāghe pi tatas paṃsu muṭṭhim gahetvā tasmim muṭṭhinā
translated: and he did not scatter it when it rained, and when it was dry he took a handful of dust and scattered it on the shrine.

original: pīḷiyamāne sinehova nikkhamati, evaṃ vantasinehasambandhoti vammiko.
analyzed: pīḷiyamāne sinehaḥ uva nikkhamati evam vanta sineha sambandho ti vammiko
translated: and when it rains, the rain does not penetrate it, and when it is hot, he takes a handful of dust in his hand and presses it down on the anthill, and the oil comes out like oil from a seed-oil plant, so it is called an anthill.

original: Ettha pana “bhagavā, himavā”tiādīni padāni na kevalaṃ vantupaccayavaseneva nipphādetabbāni,🔽atha kho vamudhātuvasenapi nipphādetabbāni, tenāha visuddhimaggakārako “yasmā pana
analyzed: ettha pana bhagavā himavāti ādīni padāni na kevalam vantu paccaya vasena iva nipphādetabbāni  atha kho vamu dhātu vasena api nipphādetabbāni tena āha visuddhi magga kārakaḥ yasmā pana
translated: Herein, the words “the Blessed One, the Himalaya” are not to be produced only by way of the condition of vomiting,🔽but they are to be produced by way of the element of vomiting too, and so it is said in the Visuddhimagga commentary: “But since the going called craving has been vomited by him in the three kinds of becoming, therefore,

original: tīsu bhavesu taṇhāsaṅkhātaṃ gamanamanena vantaṃ, tasmā “bhavesu vantagamano’ti vattabbe
analyzed: tīsu bhavesu taṇhā saṅkhātam gamanam anena vantam tasmā bhavesu vantagamanā ti vattabbe
translated: when it should be said ‘the one who has vomited going in becoming,’

original: bhavasaddato bhakāraṃ, gamanasaddato gakāraṃ, vantasaddato vakārañca dīghaṃ katvā
analyzed: bhava sad dataḥ bhakāram gamana sad dataḥ gakāram vanta sad dataḥ vakāram ca dīgham katvā
translated: taking the syllable bha from the word bhava , the syllable ga from the word gamanam , and the syllable va from the word vantam , and making them long,

original: ādāya bhagavāti vuccati, yathā loke ‘mehanassa khassa mālā’ti vattabbe mekhalā”ti
analyzed: ādāya bhagavā iti vuccati yathā loke mehanassa khassa mālā ati vattabbe mekhalā ati
translated: he is called the Blessed One, just as in the world when it should be said ‘the girdle of the plough’🔽the syllable me is taken from the word mehana , the syllable kha from the word khara , and the syllable la from the word mala , and making them long,

original: vadatā niruttinayena saddasiddhi dassitā.
analyzed: vadatā nirutti nayena dassitā
translated: the word mekhalā is said by the method of etymology.”

original: Ettha, siyā “visamamidaṃ nidassanaṃ, yena ‘mehanassa khassa mālā’ti ettha mekārakhakāralākārānaṃ
analyzed: ettha siyā visamam idam nidassanam yena mehanassa khassa ettha mekāra khakāra lākārānam
translated: Here it may be objected: “This is an uneven illustration, since in the case of ‘the garland of the mehanassa khassa’ the k- and kh- of the same sound

original: kamato gahaṇaṃ dissati, “bhavesu vantagamano’ti ettha pana bhakāravakāragakārānaṃ
analyzed: kamataḥ gahaṇam dissati bhavesu ettha pana bhakāra vakāra gakārānam
translated: are seen to be taken as kammadhāraya, but in the case of ‘bhavesu vantagamano’ the b- and g- of the same sound

original: kamato gahaṇaṃ na dissatī”ti? Saccaṃ, idha pana “aggāhito, vijjācaraṇasampanno”tiādīsu
analyzed: kamatas gahaṇam na dissati iti saccam idha pana aggāhitaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: are not seen to be taken as kammadhāraya.” It is true, but here, as in the case of ‘aggāhito, vijjācaraṇasampanno,’

original: viya guṇasaddassa paranipātavasena “bhavesu gamanavanto”ti vattabbepi evamavatvā
analyzed: viya guṇa saddassa para nipāta vasena bhavesu gamanavanto ti vattabbe pi evam a vatvā
translated: although it should be said ‘bhavesu gamanavanto’ by the method of adding the suffix -an to the quality word, nevertheless,

original: saddasatthe yebhuyyena guṇasaddānaṃ pubbanipātabhvassa icchitattā saddasatthavidūnaṃ
analyzed: sadda satthe yebhuyyena guṇa saddānam pubba nipāta bhvassaḥ icchita ttā sadda sattha vid ūnam
translated: because the majority of quality words in the dictionary are given by the method of placing the suffix -an first,🔽in order to please the minds of some wise men who are experts in the dictionary,

original: kesañca viññūnaṃ manaṃ tosetuṃ “bhagavā”ti pade akkharakkamaṃ anapekkhitvā atthamattanidassanavasena
analyzed: kesam ca viññūnam manam tosetum bhagavā ati pade akkharakkamam an apekkhitvā attha matta nidassana vasena
translated: the word ‘bhagavā’ is shown by the method of indicating the meaning without regard to the order of the syllables,

original: “āhitaggi, sampannavijjācaraṇo”tiādīni viya pubbanipātavasena “bhavesu vantagamano”ti
analyzed: āhitaggi sampanna vijjā caraṇa iti ādīni viya pubba nipāta vasena bhavesu vanta gamanaḥ ti
translated: as though it were ‘bhavesu vantagamano’ by the method of placing the suffix -an first, as in the case of ‘āhitaggi, sampannavijjācaraṇo,’ etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Īdisasmiñhi ṭhāne “āhitaggī”ti vā “aggāhito”ti vā “chinnahattho”ti vā “hatthacchinno”ti
analyzed: vuttam īdisasmin hi ṭhāne āhitaggī iti vā agga āhitaḥ iti vā chinna hatthaḥ iti vā hattha chinnaḥ iti
translated: This is said. For in such a case as this, whether one says “āhitaggī” or “aggāhito,” “chinnahattho” or “hatthacchinno,”

original: vā padesu yathā tathā ṭhitesupi atthassa ayutti nāma natthi aññamaññaṃ samānatthattā tesaṃ saddānaṃ.
analyzed: vā padesu yathā tathā ṭhitesu pi atthassa ayutti nāma natthi aññam aññam samāna attha ttā tesam saddānam
translated: there is no difference in meaning, since the words are synonymous.

original: Vedajātotiādīsu pana ṭhānesu atthevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evaṃ visuddhimagge “bhagavā”ti🔽padassa vamudhātuvasenapi nipphatti dassitā, taṭṭīkāyampi ca dassitā “bhage vamīti🔽bhagavā. Bhāge vamīti bhagavā”ti. Nibbacanaṃ pana evaṃ veditabbaṃ – bhagasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: veda jātaḥ ti ādīsu pana ṭhānesu atthā iva āti daṭṭhabbam evam visuddhi magge bhagavā ti  padassa vamu dhātu vasena api nipphatti dassitā taṭṭīkā āyam pi ca dassitā bhage vamī ti  bhagavā bhāge vamīti bhagavā iti nibbacanam pana evam veditabbam bhaga saṅkhātam
translated: But in such a case as “vedajāto,” etc., there is a difference in meaning, and this should be understood.

original: siriṃ issariyaṃ yasañca vami uggiri kheḷapiṇḍaṃ viya anapekkho chaḍḍayīti bhagavā.
analyzed: sirim issariyam yasam ca vami uggiri kheḷapiṇḍam viya anapekkhaḥ chaḍḍayīti bhagavā
translated: Thus the derivation of the word “bhagavā” is shown in the Visuddhimagga by the element vam, and it is also shown in the subcommentary: “Bhagavā is one who has vomited , spat out, discarded without concern, like a gob of phlegm, the fortune, sovereignty, and fame called bhagā.

original: Atha vā bhāni nāma nakkhattāni, tehi samaṃ gacchanti pavattantīti bhagā, sineruyugandharauttarakuruhimavantādibhājanalokā,
analyzed: atha vā bhāni nāma nakkhattāni tehi samam gacchanti pavattanti iti bhagā sineru yugandhara auttarakuru himavanta ādi bhājana lokā
translated: Or alternatively, bhagā are the stars; he goes, moves, together with them, thus he is bhagavā. The world-receptacle consisting of Sineru, the Yugandhara, Uttarakuru, Himālaya, etc.,🔽is called bhagā. He goes, moves, together with that, thus he is bhagavā.

original: visesasannissayasobhākappaṭṭhiyabhāvato. Tepi bhagavā vami tannivāsisattāvāsasamatikkamanato
analyzed: visesa sannissaya sobhā kappaṭṭhiya bhāvataḥ te pi bhagavā tad nivāsi sattā vāsa samatikkamanato
translated: because of the state of being the basis for the beauty of the special reliance.🔽The Blessed One, by surmounting the abodes of beings who live in the world of earth,

original: tappaṭibaddhachandarāgappahānena pajahīti bhagavā.🔽Cakkavattisiriṃ yasmā, yasaṃ issariyaṃ sukhaṃ;
analyzed: tad paṭibaddha chanda rāga ppahānena pajahi iti bhagavā  cakkavatti sirim yasmai yasam issariyam sukham
translated: said: “Abandon” by abandoning the desire and lust bound up with the earth.🔽Because he abandoned the glory of a world-ruling monarch,

original: Pahāsi lokacittañca, sugato bhagavā tato.
analyzed: pahāsi loka cittam ca sugataḥ bhagavā tatas
translated: fame, sovereignty, and happiness, and the world’s esteem, the Blessed One is called “Sugata.”

original: Tathā khandhāyatanadhātādibhede dhammakoṭṭhāse sabbaṃ papañca sabbaṃ yogaṃ sabbaṃ🔽ganthaṃ sabbaṃ saṃyojanaṃ samucchinditvā amataṃ dhātuṃ samadhigacchanto vami uggiri
analyzed: tathā khandha āyatana dhāta ādi bhede dhamma koṭṭhāse sabbam papañca sabbam yogam sabbam  gantham sabbam saṃyojanam samucchinditvā amatam dhātum samadhigacchantaḥ uggiri
translated: Likewise, by cutting off all mental proliferation, all bondage, all fetters, all ties, in the categories of states classed as the aggregates, bases, elements, etc.,🔽and by attaining the deathless element, the Blessed One said: “Throw out” by throwing out without looking back,🔽“Abandon” by abandoning without reserve. Or alternatively,🔽all wholesome and unwholesome states, all reprehensible and blameless states, all states that are inferior and superior, all states that are dark and bright,🔽the Blessed One, by the method of the knowledge of the noble path, said: “Throw out” by throwing out without looking back,

original: anapekkho chaḍḍayi na paccāvamīti bhagavā. Atha vā sabbepi kusalākusale sāvajjānavajje
analyzed: anapekkhaḥ chaḍḍayi na paccāvamīti bhagavā atha vā sabbe pi kusala akusale sāvajja anavajje
translated: “Abandon” by abandoning without reserve.🔽Because the Great Sage threw out the dark and bright

original: hīnappaṇīte kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāge dhamme ariyamaggañāṇamukhena vami uggiri anapekkho
analyzed: hīna ppaṇīte kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāge dhamme ariya magga ñāṇa mukhena vami anapekkhaḥ
translated: categories of states classed as the aggregates, bases, elements, etc.,

original: pariccaji pajahīti bhagavā.🔽Khandhāyatanadhātādī, dhammabhedā mahesinā;🔽Kaṇhasukkā yato vantā, tatopi bagavā mato.
analyzed: pariccaji pajahi iti bhagavā 🔽khandha āyatana dhātā ādī dhamma bhedāḥ mahesinā 🔽kaṇhasukkāḥ yatas vantā tatas pi bagavā mataḥ
translated: therefore he is called “the Blessed One.”

original: Jātakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana himavāti padassa vamudhātuvasenapi nipphatti dassitā. Tathā
analyzed: jātaka ṭṭhakathā ayam pana himavāti padassa vamu dhātu vasena api nipphatti dassitā tathā
translated: But in the commentary on the Jātaka it is shown that the word Himavā is also a derivation from the root vam, meaning “to vomit.”

original: hi sambhavajātakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ “himavāti himapātasamaye himayuttoti himavā. Gimhakāle
analyzed: hi himavā ati hima pāta samaye hima yuttaḥ ti himavā gimha kāle
translated: For in the commentary on the Sambhava Jātaka it is said: “Himavā means ‘having snow’ (hima) at the time of snowfall. In the hot season🔽he vomits snow (hima), thus he is Himavā.”

original: himaṃ vamatīti himavā”ti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ jātakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ “himavā”ti padassa vamudhātuvasenapi🔽nipphatti dassitā, ayaṃ nayo īdisesu ṭhānesupi netabbo. “Guṇavāgaṇavā”tiādīsu pana
analyzed: himam vamati iti himavā ti vuttam evam jātaka ṭṭhakathāyam himavā ti padassa vamu dhātu vasena api  nipphatti dassitā ayam nayaḥ īdisesu ṭhānesu pi netabbaḥ guṇavā gaṇavā ti ādīsu pana
translated: So in the commentary on the Jātaka it is shown that the word Himavā is also a derivation from the root vam, meaning “to vomit.” This method should be applied in similar instances.🔽But it should not be applied in such words as guṇavā and gaṇavā.

original: na netabbo. Yadi nayeyya, “guṇavā gaṇavā”ti padānaṃ “nigguṇo parihīnaguṇo”ti evamādiattho
analyzed: na netabbaḥ yadi nayeyya guṇavā gaṇavā ati padānam nigguṇaḥ parihīna guṇaḥ iti evamādi attho
translated: If it were, the words guṇavā and gaṇavā would have the meaning “devoid of virtue” and “devoid of a group” respectively.

original: bhaveyya, tasmā ayaṃ nayo sabbatthapi na netabbo. Ettha siyā “yadi “bhagavā’tiādipadānaṃ
analyzed: bhaveyya tasmai ayam nayo sabbattha api na netabbaḥ ettha siyā yadi bhagavā ati ādi padānam
translated: Therefore this method should not be applied everywhere.

original: vamudhātuvasena nipphatti hoti, kathaṃ “bhagavanto, bhagavanta”ntiādīni sijjhantī”ti?
analyzed: vamu dhātu vasena katham bhagavantaḥ sijjhanti iti
translated: Here it may be asked: “If the words bhagavā, etc., are derivations from the root vam, meaning ‘to vomit,’ how is it that such forms as bhagavanto and bhagavanta are possible?”

original: Yathā “bhagavā”ti padaṃ niruttinayena sijjhati, tathā tānipi teneva sijjhanti. Acinteyyo
analyzed: yathā padam nirutti nayena sijjhati tathā tāni api tena iva sijjhanti acinteyyaḥ
translated: Just as the word bhagavā is possible by the method of derivation, so too are those words possible by the same method.

original: hi niruttinayo kevalaṃ atthayuttipaṭibandhamattova, atthayuttiyaṃ sati nipphādetumasakkuṇeyyānipi
analyzed: hi nirutti nayaḥ kevalam attha yutti paṭibandham attā uva attha yuttiyam sati
translated: For the purpose of the exposition is only the connection with the meaning, and forms that cannot be produced when there is a meaning can be produced by this very means.

original: rūpāni aneneva sijjhanti. Ettha ca yaṃ niruttilakkhaṇaṃ āharitvā dassetabbaṃ siyā,
analyzed: rūpāni anena iva sijjhanti ettha ca yam nirutti lakkhaṇam āharitvā dassetabbam siyā
translated: And here, what is to be shown by bringing in the characteristic of the exposition,

original: taṃ upari rūpanipphādanādhikāre udāharaṇehi saddhiṃ pakāsessāma.
analyzed: tam upari rūpa nipphādana adhikāre udāharaṇehi saddhim pakāsessāma
translated: that we shall show with examples in the section on the production of forms above.

original: Idha sāramate munirājamate,🔽Paramaṃ paṭutaṃ sujano pihayaṃ;🔽Vipulatthadharaṃ dhaninītimimaṃ,
analyzed: sāra mate muni rāja mate  paramam  vipulattha dharam dhaninī tim imam
translated: Herein, the wise should always resort to this🔽Which is the king of meters, the best, the most excellent,🔽Which is the most extensive of meanings, the most wealthy of meanings,

original: Satataṃ bhajataṃ matisuddhakaraṃ.
analyzed: satatam bhajatam mati suddha karam
translated: Which is the most pure of meanings.

original: Iti navaṅge sāṭṭhakathe piṭakattaye byappathagatīsu viññunaṃ
analyzed: iti navaṅge sa aṭṭhakathe piṭa kattaye byappatha gatīsu viññunam
translated: Thus, in the nine-part, six-part discourse, in the three baskets, in the various ways,

original: Kosallatthāya kate saddanītippakaraṇe
analyzed: kosallatthāya kate saddanīti pakaraṇe
translated: In the section on the rules of grammar composed for the skill of the wise,

original: Saravaggapañcakantiko nāma dhātuvibhāgo
analyzed: sara vagga pañcakantikaḥ nāma dhātu vibhāgaḥ
translated: The analysis of elements called the five-part section on the Saravagga

original: Pannarasamo paricchedo.
analyzed: pannarasamaḥ paricchedaḥ
translated: Is the fifteenth chapter.

original: 16. Bhūvādigaṇikapariccheda🔽Ito paraṃ avaggantā, missakā ceva dhātuyo;
analyzed: i taḥ param avagga ntāḥ missakāḥ ca iva dhātuyaḥ
translated: The chapter on the groups beginning with the earth element🔽From here on, I will explain the mixed

original: Vakkhāmi dhātubhedādi-kusalassa matānugā.
analyzed: vakkhāmi dhātu bheda ādi kusalassa mata anugā
translated: Elements, following the opinion of the skilled in the divisions of elements and so on,🔽For the sake of those who wish to understand.

original: Yakārantadhātu
analyzed: yakāra anta dhātu
translated: The element ending in the syllable ya

original: Yā gatipāpuṇesu. Yāti, yanti. Yātu, yantu. Yeyya, yeyyuṃ, anupariyeyyuṃ. Yathāsambhavaṃ
analyzed: yā gati pāpuṇesu yāti yanti yātu yantu anupariyeyyum yathāsambhavam
translated: The forms of the base yā are: yāti, yanti, yātu, yantu, yeyya, yeyyuṃ, anupariyeyyuṃ.

original: padamālā yojetabbā. Yanto puriso. Yantī itthī. Yantaṃ kulaṃ. Yānaṃ, upayānaṃ, uyyānaṃ
analyzed: pada mālā yojetabbā yantaḥ purisaḥ yantī itthī yantam kulam yānam upayānam uyyānam
translated: The series of words should be construed as appropriate. Yanto puriso, yantī itthī, yantaṃ kulaṃ, yānaṃ, upayānaṃ, uyyānaṃ, etc.

original: iccādīni. Divādigaṇikassa panassa “yāyati, yāyantī”tiādīni rūpāni bhavanti.🔽Tatra yānantiādīsu yanti etenāti yānaṃ, rathasakaṭādi. Upayanti etena issarassa vā
analyzed: icca ādīni divā ādi gaṇikassa panassa rūpāni bhavanti  tatra yāna nti ādīsu yanti etena ati yānam ratha sakaṭa ādi upayanti etena issarassa vā
translated: But the forms of the base divā, etc., are yāyati, yāyantī, etc.🔽Herein, in yānaṃ, etc., yanti etena, thus it is a vehicle, a carriage, a cart, etc. Upayanti etena, thus it is a conveyance, a document, because by means of it one goes into the presence of a king or of one’s beloved or of one’s enemy.

original: piyamanāpassa vā santikaṃ gacchantīti upayānaṃ, paṇṇākāraṃ. “Upayānāni me dajjuṃ,🔽rājaputta tayi gate”ti ettha hi paṇṇākārāni “upayānānī”ti vuccanti. Sampannadassanīyapupphaphalāditāya
analyzed: piya manāpassa vā santikam gacchanti iti upayānam paṇṇa ākāram upayānāni me dajjum  rāja putta tayi gate iti ettha hi paṇṇa ākārāni upayānāni iti vuccanti sampanna dassanīya puppha phala ādi tāya
translated: “Give me conveyances,🔽when you, prince, have gone,”🔽where conveyances are called “conveyances” because they are documents.🔽Because they go, they go, looking up at the sky, because it is furnished with beautiful flowers, fruits, etc.,

original: uddhaṃ olokentā yanti gacchanti etthāti uyyānaṃ.
analyzed: uddhaṃ olokentāḥ yanti gacchanti ettha ati uyyānam
translated: thus it is a pleasure park.

original: Byā ummīsane. Byāti, byanti. Byāsi, byātha. Byāmi, byāma. Yathāsambhavaṃ padamālā
analyzed: ummīsane ummīsane byāti byanti byāsi byāmi byāma yathāsambhavam pada mālā
translated: The base byā is derived from the verbal root vyā , to open. The forms are: byāti, byanti, byāsi, byātha, byāmi, byāma. The series of words should be construed as appropriate.

original: yojetabbā. Tatra panāyaṃ pāḷi “yāva byāti nimmīsati, tatrāpi rasatibbayo”ti. Tattha🔽yāva byātīti yāva ummīsati, purāṇabhāsā esā, ayañhi yasmiṃ kāle bodhisatto cūḷabodhiparibbājako
analyzed: yojetabbā tatra pana ayam pāḷi yāva byāti nimmīsati tatra api  yāva byāti iti yāva ummīsati purāṇa bhāsā esā ayan hi yasmin kāle bodhisatto cūḍabodhi paribbājako
translated: and it should be construed thus. Here is the text: “As long as it swells up, there the relish is most keen” .

original: ahosi, tasmiṃ kāle manussānaṃ vohāro.
analyzed: ahosi tasmin kāle manussānam vohāro
translated: Herein, as long as it swells up is an ancient locution for as long as it is swollen. For this was the usage of men at the time when the Bodhisatta was the wanderer Cūḷa-Bodhi.🔽Yu is a particle and missati is the present tense of the verb misati, to mix.🔽The verb misati has the following forms:

original: Yu missane gatiyañca. Yoti, yavati. Āyu, yoni.🔽Tattha “āyū”ti āsaddo upasaggo. Āyavanti missībhavanti sattā etenāti āyu. Atha vā
analyzed: yu missane gatiyañca yoti yavati āyu yoni  tattha āyu iti āsaddaḥ upasaggaḥ āyavanti missībhavanti sattāḥ etena ati āyu atha vā
translated: yavati, āyu, yoni.

original: āyavanti āgacchanti pavattanti tasmiṃ sati arūpadhammāti āyu. Tathā hi aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ
analyzed: āyavanti āgacchanti pavattanti tasmin sati arūpa dhammā ati āyu tathā hi aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: Herein, āyu is a prefix meaning “near” . It is life because beings are mixed up with it. Or alternatively, it is life because when it exists, immaterial states come near to it, come into association with it. For this is said in the Aṭṭhasālinī:

original: vuttaṃ “āyavanaṭṭhena āyu. Tasmiñhi sati arūpadhammā āyavanti āgacchanti pavattanti,🔽tasmā āyūti vuccatī”ti. “Āyu, jīvitaṃ, pāṇo” iccete pariyāyā lokavohāravasena. Abhidhammavasena
analyzed: vuttam āyavana ṭṭhena āyu tasmin hi sati arūpa dhammāḥ āyavanti āgacchanti pavattanti  tasmai āyu iti vuccati iti āyu jīvitam pāṇo icca ete pariyāyāḥ loka vohāra vasena abhidhamma vasena
translated: “Life is so called because of the sense of ‘coming near’ . For when it exists, immaterial states come near to it, come into association with it,🔽therefore it is called life” . And “life,” “lifespan,” “life faculty,” are synonyms for it in the sense of current usage. But in the Abhidhamma it has the synonyms “endurance,” “preservation,” “maintenance,” “life faculty” .

original: pana “ṭhiti yapanā yāpanā jīvitindriyaṃ” iccetepi teheva saddhiṃ pariyāyā. Yonīti
analyzed: pana yapanā yāpanā jīvitindriyam tehi iva saddhim pariyāyā yonī iti
translated: Yoni is a prefix meaning “going” .

original: aṇḍajādīnaṃ aṇḍajādīhi saddhiṃ yāya missībhāvo hoti, sā yoni. Idaṃ panettha nibbacanaṃ
analyzed: aṇḍaja ādīnam aṇḍaja ādīhi saddhim yāya missībhāvaḥ hoti sā yoni idam pana ittha nibbacanam
translated: The womb is the state of being mixed up with those born from eggs, etc., that is common to those born from wombs, etc. The explanation here is this:

original: “yavanti ettha sattā ekajātisamanvayena aññamaññaṃ missakā hontīti yoni” iti. Ettha
analyzed: yavanti ettha sattāḥ eka jāti samanvayena aññam aññam missakāḥ honti iti iti ettha
translated: “The womb is the state of being mixed up with one another by the common characteristic of being born from a womb.”🔽And the meaning of the word “womb” is to be construed thus.

original: ca yonisaddassa atthuddhāro nīyate. Yonīti khandhakoṭṭhāsassapi kāraṇassapi passāvamaggassapi
analyzed: ca yoni saddassa attha uddhāraḥ nīyate yoni iti khandha koṭṭhāsassa api kāraṇassa api passa avamaggassa api
translated: For the word “womb” is a name for a part of the aggregates, for a cause, and for the urethra.

original: nāmaṃ. “Catasso nāgayoniyo. Catasso supaṇṇayoniyo”ti ettha hi khandhakoṭṭhāso yoni🔽nāma. “Yoni hesā bhūmija phalassa adhigamāyā”ti ettha kāraṇaṃ. “Na cāhaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ
analyzed: nāmam catasso nāga yoniyo catasso supaṇṇa yoniyo ti ettha hi khandha koṭṭhāsaḥ yoni  nāma yoni hesā bhūmija phalassa adhigamāya ati ettha kāraṇam na ca aham brāhmaṇam
translated: For in the passage, “There are four kinds of nāga wombs, four kinds of supaṇṇa wombs” , it is a part of the aggregates that is called “womb” .🔽In the passage, “This is the womb for the attainment of the fruit of earth” , it is a cause.🔽In the passage, “I do not call a man a brahmin because of his mother or father” , it is the urethra.

original: brūmi, yonijaṃ mattisambhava”nti ettha passāvamaggo. Etthetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: brūmi yoni jam ettha passa avamaggo ettha etam vuccati
translated: This is what is said:🔽In a part of the aggregates,

original: Khandhānañcāpi koṭṭhāse, muttamagge ca kāraṇe;
analyzed: khandhānam ca api koṭṭhāse mutta magge ca kāraṇe
translated: In a cause, and in the urethra,🔽In these three meanings

original: Imesu tīsu atthesu, yonisaddo pavattati.🔽Bye saṃvaraṇe. Byāyati.
analyzed: imesu tīsu atthesu yoni saddo pavattati  bye saṃvaraṇe byāyati
translated: The word “womb” occurs.🔽“Womb” is derived from the verb bīyati , to be covered by an egg-shell.

original: Bye pavattiyaṃ. Byeti sahabyo.
analyzed: bye pavattiyam byeti sahabyaḥ
translated: “Womb” is derived from the verb bīyati , to be born.

original: Ettha sahabyoti saha byeti saha pavattatīti sahabyo, sahāyo, ekabhavūpago vā. Tathā hi “tāvatiṃsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapanno”tiādīsu ekabhavūpago “sahabyo”ti vuccati.
analyzed: ettha sahabyaḥ iti saha byeti saha pavattati iti sahabyaḥ sahāyaḥ eka bhava upagaḥ vā tathā hi tāvatiṃsānam devānam sahabyatam upapannaḥ iti ādīsu eka bhava upagaḥ sahabyaḥ iti vuccati
translated: Herein, the word sahabyataṃ is formed from saha and bya; bya is the same as bhava, and the meaning is “he occurs together with” or “he has the same existence as.” For in such passages as “He has reappeared in the company of the Tāvatiṃsa devas” , one who has the same existence is called “a companion” .🔽Haya is a horse. It is called “haya” because it goes quickly (hayati).

original: Haya gatiyaṃ. Hayati. Hayo. Hayoti asso. So hi hayati sīghaṃ gacchatīti hayoti vuccati. Imāni panassa nāmāni –🔽Asso turaṅgo turago, vājī vāho hayopi ca;
analyzed: haya gatiyam hayati hayaḥ hayoti assaḥ saḥ hi hayati sīgham gacchati iti hayaḥ iti vuccati imāni panassa nāmāni  assaḥ turaṅgaḥ turagaḥ vājī vāhaḥ hayaḥ api ca
translated: These are its names:🔽Horse, steed, charger, courser, steed,

original: Tabbhedā sindhavo ceva, gojo assataropi ca.
analyzed: tad bhedā sindhavaḥ ca iva gojaḥ assataraḥ api ca
translated: And its varieties are also called “steed,” “swift-runner,” and “mule.”

original: Kāraṇākāraṇaññū tu, ājānīyo hayuttamo;🔽Ghoṭako tu khaḷuṅkasso, vaḷavoti ca vuccati;
analyzed: kāraṇa akāraṇaññū tu ājānīyaḥ hayuttamaḥ  ghoṭako tu khaḷuṅkassaḥ vaḷavaḥ ti ca vuccati
translated: But the best of horses is the one that knows the difference between good and bad,🔽And the one that is slow is called a “dunce,” a “blockhead,” or a “mule.”

original: Assapoto kisoroti, khaḷuṅkotipi vuccati;
analyzed: assapoto kisoro ti khaḷuṅko tipi vuccati
translated: The colt is called a “foal,” and the dunce is also called a “blockhead.”

original: Hariya gatigelaññesu. Hariyati.
analyzed: hariya gati gelaññesu hariyati
translated: Hariya is a swift runner. It is called “hariya” because it runs quickly (hariyati).

original: Aya vaya paya maya taya caya raya gatiyaṃ. Ayati. Vayati. Payati. Mayati. Tayati.
analyzed: aya vaya paya maya taya caya raya ayati vayati payati mayati tayati
translated: Aya, vaya, paya, maya, taya, caya, raya are swift runners. They are called “swift runners” because they run quickly (ayati, vayati, payati, mayati, tayati, cayati, rayati).

original: Cayati. Rayati. Ayo, samayo, vayo, payo, rayo. Mayatayacayadhātūnaṃ nāmikapadāni upaparikkhitabbāni.🔽Tattha ayoti kāḷalohaṃ, ayati nānākammārakiccesu upayogaṃ gacchatīti ayo. Vayoti
analyzed: cayati rayati ayaḥ samayaḥ vayaḥ payaḥ rayaḥ maya taya caya dhātūnam nāmika padāni upaparikkhitabbāni  tattha ayaḥ ti kāḷa loham ayati nānā kammāra kiccesu upayogam gacchati iti ayaḥ
translated: Cayati, rayati, ayati, samaya, vayo, payo, rayo. The names of the roots cay, ray, and ay should be investigated.

original: paṭhamavayādiāyukoṭṭhāso, vayati parihāniṃ gacchatīti vayo. Payoti khīrassapi udakassapi
analyzed: paṭhama vayā ādi āyu koṭṭhāsaḥ vayati parihānim gacchati iti vayo khīrassa api udakassa api
translated: Herein, a is black iron; it goes to use in various kinds of smith’s work, thus it is ay . Vayo is the section of life beginning with the first stage; it goes by decline, thus it is vayo . Payo is the name for milk of cows, etc.,

original: nāmaṃ, payati janena pātabbabhāvaṃ gacchatīti payo. Rayoti vego, yo “javo”tipi vuccati,
analyzed: nāmam payati janena pātabba bhāvam gacchati iti payaḥ vegaḥ yaḥ vuccati
translated: and for water; it goes to be drunk by people, thus it is payo . Rayo is speed, which is also called javana ;

original: tasmā rayanaṃ javanaṃ rayo. Ettha samayasaddassa atthuddhāro vuccate aha nibbacanena. Samayasaddo –

analyzed: samavāye khaṇe kāle samaye hetu diṭṭhisu
translated: In occasion, cause, and view,🔽In acquisition, in abandoning,

translated: And in penetration it is seen.

analyzed: tathā hi appā iva nāma sve pi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāya ati evamādīsu
translated: For in such passages as “Perhaps we might approach him tomorrow, taking time and occasion into account” ,

analyzed: samavāyaḥ atthaḥ ekaḥ iva kho bhikkhave khaṇaḥ ca samayaḥ ca brahmacariya vāsāya ati ādīsu
translated: “The meaning of ‘occasion’ is ‘coming together.’ In such passages as ‘Bhikkhus, there is only one occasion for the life of purity’

analyzed: khaṇo uṇha samayaḥ pariḷāha samayaḥ iti ādīsu kālaḥ mahā samayaḥ samūhaḥ
translated: ‘Occasion’ is time. In such passages as ‘A time of heat, a time of fever,’ ‘A great occasion in the wood,’

original: “Samayopi kho te bhaddāli appaṭividdho ahosī”tiādīsu hetu. “Tena samayena uggāhamāno
analyzed: samayaḥ api kho te bhaddāli appaṭividdhaḥ ahosi itiādīsu hetu tena samayena uggāhamānaḥ
translated: ‘Occasion’ is cause. In such passages as ‘But, Bhaddāli, the occasion for you to understand was not given,’

analyzed: paribbājakaḥ samaṇamuṇḍikā putto samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme
translated: ‘At that time the wanderer Uggāhamāna, the son of Muṇḍiya, was staying in the Mallikā’s Park of the wanderers, in the Single-Fruit banyan grove,

translated: a place for secluded meditation’ ‘Occasion’ is view. In such passages as🔽‘The meaning that is here and now,🔽And the meaning that is in the life to come,

analyzed: diṭṭhe dhamme ca yaḥ atthaḥ yaḥ ca ttho samparāyiko  attha abhisamayā dhīro paṇḍito ti pavuccati iti
translated: The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,

original: Ādīsu paṭilābho. “Sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā”tiādīsu pahānaṃ. “Dukkhassa
analyzed: ādīsu paṭilābhaḥ sammā māna abhisamayāḥ dukkhassa ati ādīsu pahānam dukkhassa
translated: The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,🔽The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,

original: pīḷanaṭṭho saṅkhataṭṭho santāpaṭṭho abhisamayaṭṭho”tiādīsu paṭivedho. Ettha ca upasaggānaṃ
analyzed: pīḷana ṭṭhaḥ saṅkhata ṭṭhaḥ santāpa ṭṭhaḥ abhisamaya ṭṭhaḥ ti ādīsu paṭivedhaḥ ettha ca upasaggānam
translated: The meaning that is in the world’s welfare,

original: jotakamattattā tassa tassa atthassa vācako samayasaddo evāti samayasaddassa atthuddhārepi🔽saupasaggo abhisamayasaddo vutto.🔽Tattha sahakārīkāraṇatāya sannijjhaṃ sameti samavetīti samayo, samavāyo. Sameti samāgacchati🔽maggabrahmacariyaṃ ettha tadādhārapuggaloti samayo, khaṇo. Samenti ettha, etena vā
analyzed: jotaka matta ttā tassa tassa atthassa vācakaḥ samaya saddaḥ eva ati samaya saddassa attha uddhāre pi  sa aupasaggaḥ abhisamaya saddaḥ vuttaḥ  tattha sahakārī kāraṇatāya sannijjham sameti samaveti iti samayaḥ samavāyaḥ sameti samāgacchati  magga brahmacariyam ettha tad ādhāra puggalo ti samayaḥ khaṇo ettha etena vā
translated: The term ‘ occasion ’ is a term that expresses the meaning of this or that by way of mere indication, and so the term ‘ penetration ’ is said to be ‘ with a remainder ’ in the interpretation of the meaning of the term ‘ occasion ’.

original: saṅgacchanti dhammā sahajātadhammehi uppādādīhi vāti samayo, kālo. Dhammappavattimattatāya
analyzed: saṅgacchanti dhammā sahajāta dhammehi uppāda ādīhi vā ati samayaḥ kālaḥ dhamma ppavattimattatāya
translated: Herein, it is a conjunction because it is a co-operating cause, and so it is an occasion , a conjunction, because it is what is conjoined, and it is an occasion , a moment, because the life of purity, the path, is conjoined with it, and it is an occasion , a time, because the states are conjoined with it, or it is by means of this that they are conjoined, with the states that arise together with them, by arising, etc.,

original: atthato abhūtopi hi kālo dhammappavattiyā adhikaraṇaṃ karaṇaṃ viya ca parikappanāmattasiddhena
analyzed: atthataḥ abhūtaḥ api hi kālaḥ dhamma ppavattiyāḥ adhikaraṇam karaṇam viya ca parikappanā matta siddhena
translated: And although the time is not actually the occasion in the sense of the states’ being conjoined with it, still it is spoken of figuratively as the occasion because it is the basis for the states’ occurrence, as a tool, etc., is for the work’s being done.

original: rūpena vohariyatīti. Samaṃ, saha vā avayavānaṃ ayanaṃ pavatti avaṭṭhānanti samayo,
analyzed: rūpena vohariyati iti samam saha vā avayavānam ayanam pavatti avaṭṭhānam ti samayaḥ
translated: And it is an occasion , a collection, because the occurrence, the going , of the components is together , or it is an occasion , a collection, because the components go together , do not go separately,🔽like a ‘ collection ’ . For a collection is just the going together of the components.

original: samūho, yathā “samudāyo”ti. Avayavasahāvaṭṭhānameva hi samūho. Paccayantarasamāgame
analyzed: samūhaḥ yathā samudāyaḥ ti avayava saha avaṭṭhānam eva hi samūhaḥ paccaya antara samāgame
translated: And it is an occasion , a concurrence, because of the concurrence of other conditions.

original: eti phalaṃ etasmā uppajjati pavattati cāti samayo, hetu, yathā “samudayo”ti. Sameti
analyzed: eti phalam etasmai uppajjati pavattati ca ati samayaḥ hetu yathā samudaya uti sameti
translated: It is a season in the sense of a cause, as “origin” ;

original: saṃyojanabhāvato sambandhā eti attano visaye pavattati, daḷhaggahaṇabhāvato vā saṃyuttā🔽ayanti pavattanti sattā yathābhinivesaṃ etenāti samayo, diṭṭhi. Diṭṭhisaṃyojanena
analyzed: saṃyojana bhāvataḥ sambandhā eti attanaḥ visaye pavattati daḷha ggahaṇa bhāvataḥ vā saṃyuttā  ayanti pavattanti sattāḥ yathā abhinivesam etena ati samayaḥ diṭṭhi diṭṭhi saṃyojanena
translated: it is a season in the sense of a bond, as “bond” ;

original: hi sattā ativiya bajjhanti. Samiti saṅgati samodhānanti samayo, paṭilābho. Samassa
analyzed: hi sattāḥ ativiya bajjhanti samiti saṅgati samodhānan ti samayaḥ paṭilābhaḥ samassa
translated: it is a season in the sense of a meeting, as “meeting” ;

original: nirodhassa yānaṃ, sammā vā yānaṃ apagamo appavattīti samayo, pahānaṃ. Ñāṇena abhimukhaṃ🔽sammā etabbo adhigantabboti samayo, dhammānaṃ aviparīto sabhāvo, abhimukhabhāvena
analyzed: nirodhassa yānam sammā vā yānam apagamaḥ appavatti iti samayaḥ pahānam ñāṇena abhimukham  sammā etabbaḥ adhigantabbaḥ ti samayaḥ dhammānam aviparītaḥ sabhāvaḥ abhimukha bhāvena
translated: it is a season in the sense of a vehicle, as “cessation” ;🔽it is a season in the sense of a right approach, as “penetration” ;

original: sammā eti gacchati bujjhatīti samayo. Yathābhūtasabhāvāvabodho. Evaṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ
analyzed: sammā eti gacchati bujjhati iti samayaḥ yathā bhūta sabhāva avabodhaḥ evam tasmin tasmin
translated: it is a season in the sense of a right arrival, as “the true nature of states” .

original: atthe samayasaddassa pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: atthe samaya saddassa pavatti veditabbā
translated: The word “season” should be understood to be used in these various senses.

original: Nanu ca atthamattaṃ pati saddā abhinivisantīti na ekena saddena aneke atthā abhidhīyantīti?🔽Saccametaṃ saddavisese apekkhite. Saddavisese hi apekkhamāne ekena saddena anekatthābhidhānaṃ
analyzed: nanu ca attha mattam pati saddāḥ abhinivisanti iti na ekena saddena aneke atthāḥ abhidhīyanti iti  saccam etam sadda visese apekkhite sadda visese hi apekkhamāne ekena saddena aneka attha abhidhānam
translated: But do not sounds occur in dependence on the mere meaning? So is it not the case that many meanings are expressed by a single sound?

original: na sambhavati. Na hi yo kālattho samayasaddo, soyeva samūhādiatthaṃ vadati. Ettha
analyzed: na sambhavati na hi yaḥ kāla atthaḥ samaya saddo samūha ādi attham vadati ettha
translated: This is true, when a distinction of sound is not intended. For when a distinction of sound is intended, it is not possible for many meanings to be expressed by a single sound. For the word “occasion” in the sense of time does not express the meaning “collection,” etc. But here the expression “many meanings” is used of the word “occasion”

original: pana tesaṃ tesaṃ atthānaṃ samaya saddavacanīyatā sāmaññamupādāya anekatthatā samayasaddassa
analyzed: pana tesam tesam atthānam samaya sadda vacanīya tā sāmaññam upādāya aneka attha tā samaya saddassa
translated: because of the similarity of the fact that each of those meanings is denotable by the word “occasion.”

original: vuttā. Evaṃ sabbattha atthuddhāre adhippāyo veditabbo.🔽Ito yāto ayato ca, nipphattiṃ samudīraye;
analyzed: vuttāḥ evam sabbattha attha uddhāre adhippāyaḥ veditabbaḥ  itas yātaḥ a yataḥ ca nipphattim samudīraye
translated: This is how the intention should be understood in all such cases.🔽One who knows the word “occasion”

original: Viññū samayasaddassa, samavāyādivācino.
analyzed: viññū samaya saddassa samavāya ādi vācinaḥ
translated: As expressing a combination, etc.,🔽Should understand the word “occasion”🔽As used in the sense of “gone from here” and “not gone.”🔽The word “occasion” is used

original: Ito yāto ayato ca, samānatthehi dhātuhi;
analyzed: i taḥ ya a taḥ a y a taḥ ca samāna atthehi dhātuhi
translated: In the sense of “gone from here” and “not gone”🔽By means of the verbal roots yā and ā,🔽And it is used in the sense of “similarity”

original: Evaṃ samānarūpāni, bhavantīti ca īraye.
analyzed: evam samāna rūpāni bhavanti iti ca īraye
translated: By means of the verbal roots samā and bhū.

original: Naya rakkhaṇe ca. Cakāro gatipekkhako. Nayati. Nayo. Nayoti nayanaṃ gamananti nayo, pāḷigati. Nayanti vā rakkhanti atthaṃ etenāti nayo, tathattanayādi.
analyzed: rakkhaṇe ca cakāraḥ gati pekkhakaḥ nayati nayaḥ nayo ti nayanam gamanan ti nayo nayo nayo nayo iti nayanam gamanan ti nayo nayo nayo nayo iti nayanam gamanan ti nayo nayo nayo nayo ti nayanam gamanan ti nayo nayanti vā rakkhanti attham etena ati nayo tathatta naya ādi
translated: And in the sense of guarding the way. The particle ca is one that looks for a complement. It goes , thus it is a way ; a way is a going, a course of the text. Or alternatively, it is a way in the sense that it is what they go by, what they are guarded by, for the meaning of nayati is “he guards” .

original: Daya dānagatihiṃsādānarakkhāsu. Dayati. Dayā.
analyzed: dāna gati hiṃsā dāna rakkhāsu dayati dayā
translated: In the sense of giving, of a course, of harming, of giving, of guarding. It gives , thus it is pity ;

original: Dayāti mettāpi vuccati karuṇāpi. “Dayāpanno”ti ettha hi mettā “dayā”ti, mettacittataṃ
analyzed: dayāti mettā api vuccati karuṇā api dayā āpannaḥ ti ettha hi mettā dayāti metta citta tam
translated: pity is also called lovingkindness and also compassion. For in the passage, “Endowed with pity” , it is lovingkindness that is called “pity” , the meaning being that he has reached lovingkindness,

original: āpannoti hi attho. “Adayāpanno”ti ettha pana karuṇā “dayā”ti vuccati. Nikkaruṇataṃ
analyzed: āpannaḥ ti hi atthaḥ adayā āpannaḥ ti ettha pana karuṇā dayā ati vuccati nikkaruṇatam
translated: has attained to lovingkindness. But in the passage, “Not endowed with pity” , it is compassion that is called “pity” , the meaning being that he has not reached

original: āpannoti hi attho. Evaṃ dayāsaddassa mettākaruṇāsu pavatti veditabbā. Tathā hi abhidhammaṭīkāyaṃ
analyzed: āpannaḥ ti hi atthaḥ evam dayā saddassa mettā karuṇāsu pavatti veditabbā tathā hi abhidhammaṭīkā ayam
translated: compassion, has not attained to compassion. This is how the word “pity” should be understood to occur in the two senses of lovingkindness and compassion. For this is said in the Abhidhamma Commentary:

original: vuttaṃ “dayāsaddo yattha yattha pavattati, tattha tattha adhippāyavasena yojetabbo.
analyzed: vuttam dayā saddaḥ yattha yattha pavattati tattha tattha adhippāya vasena yojetabbo
translated: “Wherever the word ‘pity’ occurs, it should be construed in each instance according to the intention.

original: Dayāsaddo hi anurakkhaṇatthaṃ antonītaṃ katvā pavattamāno mettāya ca karuṇāya ca pavattatī”ti.
analyzed: dayā saddaḥ hi anurakkhaṇa attham antonītam katvā pavattamānaḥ mettāya ca karuṇāya ca pavattati iti
translated: For the word ‘pity’ occurs in the sense of lovingkindness and in the sense of compassion when it is used in the sense of protecting by taking into one’s own heart” .

original: Vacanattho panettha evaṃ veditabbo – dayati dadāti sattānaṃ abhayaṃ etāyāti dayā.
analyzed: vacana atthaḥ pana ittha evam veditabbaḥ dayati dadāti sattānam abhayam etāya ati dayā
translated: The word-meaning here should be understood as follows. It gives, it bestows, non-fear on beings, thus it is kindness .

original: Dayati gacchati vibhāgaṃ akatvā pāpakalyāṇajanesu samaṃ vattati, sītena samaṃ pharantaṃ
analyzed: dayati gacchati vibhāgam a katvā pāpa kalyāṇa janesu samam vattati sītena samam
translated: It gives, it goes, it goes without making a distinction, it behaves equally towards evil and good people, like water that spreads equally and

original: rajomalañca pavāhentaṃ udakamivātipi dayā, mettā. Dayati vā hiṃsati kāruṇikaṃ yāva
analyzed: rajaḥ malam ca udakam iva atipi dayā mettā dayati vā hiṃsati kāruṇikam
translated: washes away dust and stains, thus it is kindness , loving-kindness . Or alternatively, it is kindness in that it gives, it harms, the compassionate one,

original: yathādhippetaṃ parassa hitanipphattiṃ na pāpuṇāti, tāvāti dayā. Dayati anuggaṇhāti🔽pāpajanampi sajjano etāyātipi dayā. Dayati attano sukhampi pahāya khedaṃ gaṇhāti
analyzed: yathā adhippetam parassa hita nipphattim na pāpuṇāti tāvā ati dayā dayati anuggaṇhāti  pāpa janam pi dayā dayati sukham pi pahāya khedam gaṇhāti
translated: as long as it does not reach the fulfilment of the welfare of another according to the intention, thus it is kindness . It is kindness in that it gives, it supports,🔽the good man, by means of this, thus it is kindness . It is kindness in that it gives, it takes,

original: sajjano etāyāti dayā. Dayanti gaṇhanti etāya mahābodhisattā buddhabhāvāya abhinīhārakaraṇakāle
analyzed: sat janaḥ etāya ati dayā dayanti gaṇhanti etāya mahā bodhisattāḥ buddha bhāvāya abhinīhāra karaṇa kāle
translated: the good man, by means of this, his own happiness too, it takes on the weariness, thus it is kindness . It is kindness in that the great Bodhisattvas give, they take,

analyzed: hattha gatam pi arahatta phalam chaḍḍetvā saṃsāra sāgarato satte samuddharitu kāmāḥ anassāsa karam

original: atibhayānakaṃ mahantaṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ, pacchimabhave ca saha amatadhātupaṭilābhena
analyzed: ati bhayānakam mahantam saṃsāra dukkham pacchima bhave ca saha amata dhātu paṭilābhena
translated: and they desire to rescue beings from the ocean of the round of rebirths, the great suffering of the round of rebirths that is terrifying and without respite,🔽and in their last existence, together with the acquisition of the deathless element,

analyzed: aneka guṇa samalaṅkatam dayā karuṇā karuṇā mūlakāḥ hi sabbe buddha guṇāḥ
translated: and the knowledge of omniscience adorned with many special qualities.🔽Another method: It is by means of this that beings are looked after, or it itself is looked after, or it is just the state of being looked after, thus it is kindness ; and it is both loving-kindness and compassion. translated: Another method: It is by means of this that beings are looked after, or it itself is looked after, or it is just the state of being looked after, thus it is kindness ; and it is both loving-kindness and compassion. For all the special qualities of a Buddha have compassion as their root.

analyzed: dayā mettā ca iva karuṇā ca kiñci kathayāma sā iyyathā api gahapati  gijjhaḥ vā kaṅkaḥ vā kulalaḥ vā maṃsa pesim ādāya dayeyya puttesu maddī dayesi sassuyā

For all the special qualities of a Buddha have compassion as their root.🔽Another method: It is by means of this that beings are looked after, or it itself is looked after, or it is just the state of being looked after, thus it is kindness ; and it is both loving-kindness and compassion. For all the special qualities of a Buddha have compassion as their root.

original: sasuramhi ca. Dayitabbo rathesabha”. Tattha dayeyyāti uppatitvā gaccheyya, gatyatthavasenetaṃ
analyzed: ca dayitabbaḥ rathesabha tattha dayeyya ati uppatitvā gaccheyya gati attha vasena itam
translated: Another method: It is by means of this that beings are looked after, or it itself is looked after, or it is just the state of being looked after, thus it is kindness ; and it is both loving-kindness and compassion. original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dayesīti mettacittaṃ kareyyāsi. Dayitabboti piyāyitabbo. Ubhayampetaṃ🔽vivaraṇaṃ rakkhaṇatthaṃ antogadhaṃ katvā adhippāyatthavasena katanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam dayesi iti metta cittam kareyyāsi dayitabbaḥ iti piyāyitabbaḥ  vivaraṇam rakkhaṇa attham antogadham katvā adhippāya attha vasena katanti veditabbam
translated: Another method: It is by means of this that beings are looked after, or it itself is looked after, or it is just the state of being looked after, thus it is kindness ; and it is both loving-kindness and compassion.
