original: Ūyī tantasantāne. Ūyati. Ūto, ūtavā.
analyzed: ūyī tanta santāne ūyati
translated: Another method: It is by means of this that beings are looked after, or it itself is looked after, or it is just the state of being looked after, thus it is kindness ; and it is both loving-kindness and compassion. For all the special qualities of a Buddha have compassion

original: Pūyī visaraṇe duggandhe ca. Pūyati. Pūto, pūtavā. Pūtimacchaṃ kusaggena, yo naro upanayhati.
analyzed: visaraṇe duggandhe ca pūyati pūtaḥ pūtavā pūtimat cham kusaggena yaḥ naraḥ upanayhati
translated: Pūyati in flowing out and in stinking. Pūyati. Pūto, pūtavā. Pūtimacchaṃ kusaggena, yo naro upanayhati.

original: Kanuyī sadde. Kanuyati. Kanuto, kanutavā.
analyzed: sadde kanuyati kanutavā
translated: Kanuyī in sound. Kanuyati. Kanuto, kanutavā.

original: Khamāya vidhūnane. Khamāyati. Khamāto, khamātavā.
analyzed: khamāya vidhūnane khamāyati khamāto khamātavā
translated: Khamāyati in blowing. Khamāyati. Khamāto, khamātavā.

original: Phāyi pāyi vuddhiyaṃ. Phāyati. Phīto, phatavā.
analyzed: phāyi pāyi
translated: Phāyati in growing. Phāyati. Phīto, phatavā.

original: Tattha tatavantupaccayā, yakāralopo, dhātvantassa sarassa ikārādeso ca daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: tattha yakāra lopaḥ dhātu antassa sarassa ikāra ādeso ca daṭṭhabbo
translated: Herein, the presence of the syllable ta should be seen as a condition for the elision of the ya, and for the change of the final a of the verbal root to i.

original: Esa nayo “pūto pūtavā”tiādīsupi yathāsambhavaṃ daṭṭhabbo. Pāyati. Pāyo. Apāyo. Ettha
analyzed: esa nayo pūto pūtavāti ādīsu pi yathāsambhavam daṭṭhabbo pāyati pāyo apāyaḥ ettha
translated: The same method should be seen as applicable to pūto pūtavā, etc., as appropriate. Pāyati. Pāyo. Apāyo. Herein,

original: ca natthi pāyo vuddhi etthāti apāyo. Atha vā pana ayato sukhato apetoti apāyotipi
analyzed: ca natthi pāyo ettha ati apāyaḥ atha vā pana ayataḥ sukhataḥ apeto ti apāyaḥ tipi
translated: there is no pāyo, growth, here, thus it is apāyo. Or alternatively, it is apa, away, from ayato, comfort, thus it is apāyo.

original: nibbacanīyaṃ. Apāyoti ca nirayo tiracchānayoni pettivisayo asurakāyoti cattāro apāyā.
analyzed: nibbacanīyam apāyo ti ca nirayo tiracchānayoni pettivisayo asurakāyo ti cattāro apāyā
translated: It can be taken as a negative compound in this way. And apāyo is the four states of loss, namely, hell, the animal realm, the realm of ghosts, and the asura state.

original: Tāyu santānapālanesu. Tāyati. Tāyanaṃ. Divādigaṇe pana tā pālaneti dhātuṃ passatha,
analyzed: santāna pālanesu tāyati tāyanam divādi gaṇe pana tā pālanā iti dhātum passatha
translated: Tāyati in the continuance of a series. Tāyati. Tāyanaṃ. But in the word divā, etc., you should see the verbal root tā in the sense of protection.

original: tassa “tāyati tāṇa”nti rūpāni. Ubhayesaṃ kriyāpadaṃ samaṃ. Akārayakārapaccayamatteneva
analyzed: tassa rūpāni ubhayesam kriyā padam samam akāra yakāra paccaya mattena iva
translated: and “it is stretched out” (tāyati) , thus it is visible form (rūpa). The verbal root is the same in both cases.🔽

original: nānattaṃ, nāmikapadāni pana visadisāni “tāyanaṃ, tāṇa”nti.🔽Cāyu pūjānisāmanesu. Pūjā pūjanā. Nisāmanaṃ olokanaṃ savanañca vuccati. “Iṅgha maddi🔽nisāmehi. Nisāmayatha sādhavo”ti ca ādīsu hi olokanasavanāni nisāmanasaddena vuttāni.🔽Apica ñāṇena upaparikkhaṇampi nisāmanamevāti gahetabbaṃ. Cāyati, apacāyati. Anagāre
analyzed: nānattam nāmika padāni pana visadisāni tāyanam tāṇanti  pūjā nisāmanesu pūjā pūjanā nisāmanam olokanam savanam ca vuccati iṅgha maddi  nisāmehi nisāmayatha sādhavaḥ ti ca ādīsu hi olokana savanāni nisāmana saddena vuttāni  apica ñāṇena upaparikkhaṇam pi nisāmanam eva ati gahetabbam cāyati apacāyati anagāre
translated: Its meaning is “it is stretched out,” and so it is “form.” The two verbs are the same. The difference is only in the causative and non-causative forms.🔽The nominal expressions are different, namely, “the stretching out” and “the stretch.”

original: pabbajite, apace brahmacāriye. Ye vuddhamapacāyanti. Apacitiṃ dasseti. Niccaṃ vuddhāpacāyino.
analyzed: pabbajite apace brahmacāriye ye vuddham apacāyanti apacitim dasseti niccam vuddha apacāyino
translated: Cāyati, apacāyati. One who has gone forth as a homeless one, a celibate. “They who respect the elders” . He shows respect. “They who always respect the elders” .

original: Yakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: yakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: Yakārantadhāturūpāni.

original: Rakārantadhātu
analyzed: rakāra anta dhātu
translated: Rakārantadhātu

original: Rā ādāne. Rāti.
analyzed: raḥ ādāne rāti
translated: Rā ādāne. Rāti.

original: Ri santāne. Reti. Reṇu. Reṇūti rajo.
analyzed: ri santāne reti reṇu rajaḥ
translated: Ri santāne. Reti. Reṇu. Reṇūti rajo.

original: Ru gatiyaṃ rosane ca. Ravati, viravati.
analyzed: ru gatiyam rosane ca ravati viravati
translated: Ru gatiyaṃ rosane ca. Ravati, viravati.

original: Ru sadde. Roti, ravati. Ravo, uparavo. Rutamanuññaṃ ruciyā ca piṭṭhi. Rutanti ravanaṃ rutaṃ, saddo.
analyzed: ru sadde roti ravati ravaḥ uparavaḥ rutam anuññam ruciyā ca piṭṭhi rutanti ravanam rutam saddo
translated: In the case of the sound ru, it is ruhati, ravati. Ravo, uparavo. Rutamanuññaṃ ruciyā ca piṭṭhi. Rutanti ravanaṃ rutaṃ, saddo.

original: Re sadde. Rāyati. Rā. Ratti. Ettha ca rāti saddo. Rattīti nisāsaṅkhāto sattānaṃ saddassa vūpasamakālo. Rā tiyyati ucchijjati etthāti ratti.
analyzed: re sadde rāyati rā ratti ettha ca rāti saddaḥ ratti iti nisā saṅkhāto sattānam saddassa vūpasama kālaḥ tiyyati ucchijjati ettha ati ratti
translated: In the case of the sound re, it is rāyati. Rā, ratti. Rāti saddo. Rattīti nisāsaṅkhāto sattānaṃ saddassa vūpasamakālo. Rā tiyyati ucchijjati etthāti ratti.

original: Brū viyattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ. Api hantvā hato brūti.
analyzed: brū viyattiyam vācā ayam api hantvā hataḥ brūti
translated: In the case of the sound brū, it is viyattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ. Api hantvā hato brūti.

original: Bravīti, brunti. Brūsi, brūtha. Brūmi, brūma. Brūte, bruvante. Brūse, bruvhe. Bruve, brumhe.
analyzed: bravīti brunti brūsi brūtha brūmi brūma brūte bruvante brūse bruvhe bruve brumhe
translated: It is bravīti, brunti. Brūsi, brūtha. Brūmi, brūma. Brūte, bruvante. Brūse, bruvhe. Bruve, brumhe.

original: Brūtu, bruvitu, bruvantu. Brūhi, brūtha. Brūmi, brūma. Brūtaṃ, bruvantaṃ.
analyzed: brūtu bruvitu bruvantu brūhi brūtha brūmi brūma brūtam bruvantam
translated: It is brūtu, bruvitu, bruvantu. Brūhi, brūtha. Brūmi, brūma. Brūtaṃ, bruvantaṃ.

original: Ettha ca ambaṭṭhasutte “puna bhavaṃ gotamo bruvitū”ti pāḷidassanato “bruvitū”ti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ sabbatthāpi upaparikkhitvā nayo gahetabbo.
analyzed: ettha ca ambaṭṭha sutte puna bhavam gotamaḥ bruvitu iti pāḷi dassanataḥ bruvitu iti vuttam evam sabbattha api upaparikkhitvā nayaḥ gahetabbo
translated: And in the case of the words “puna bhavaṃ gotamo bruvitū” in the Ambattha Sutta, the form “bruvitū” is used because of the reading in the text. So the method should be grasped by investigating in all instances.

original: Bruveyya, bruve, bruveyyuṃ. Bruveyyāsi, bruveyyātha. Bruveyyāmi, bruveyyāma. Bruvetha, bruveraṃ. Bruvetho, bruveyyāvho. Bruveyyaṃ. Bruveyyāmhe.
analyzed: bruveyya bruve bruveyyum bruveyyāsi bruveyyātha bruveyyāmi bruveyyāma bruvetha bruveram bruvethaḥ bruveyyāvhaḥ bruveyyam bruveyyāmhe
translated: He would say, they would say. You would say, you all would say. I would say, we would say. You all would say, they would say. You would say, we would say. I would say, we would say.

original: Pabrūti. Anubrūti. Pabrūtu, anubrūtu. Pabruveyya, anubruveyya. Evaṃ sabbattha paanuupasaggehipi yathāsambhavaṃ padamālā yojetabbā.
analyzed: pabrūti anubrūti pabrūtu anubrūtu pabruveyya anubruveyya evam sabbattha yathāsambhavam pada mālā yojetabbā
translated: He says, he recites. They say, they recite. Let him say, let them say. Let him say, let them say. Let him say, let them recite. Thus in all cases, the series of words should be combined according to the context, as appropriate, with the prepositions pa and anu.

original: Āha, āhu. Brave, bravittha, bravire. Bravittho, bravivho. Braviṃ, bravimhe. Parokkhāvasena vuttāni.🔽Abravā, abravū. Abravo, abravattha. Abravaṃ, abravamhā. Abravattha, abravatthuṃ. Abravase, abravhaṃ. Abraviṃ, abravimhase. Hiyyattanīvasena vuttāni.
analyzed: āha āhu brave bravittha bravire bravitthaḥ bravivhaḥ bravim bravimhe parokkhā vasena vuttāni  abravā abravū abravaḥ abravattha abravam abravamhāḥ abravattha abravatthum abravase abravham abravim abravimhase hiyyattanī vasena vuttāni
translated: He says, they say. You say, you all say, they say. You all said, you all said. I said, we said. These are spoken in the remote past.

original: Abravi, abravuṃ. Abravo, abravittha. Abraviṃ, abravimhā. Abravā, abravū. Abravase, abravivhaṃ. Abravaṃ, abravimhe. Ajjatanīvasena vuttāni.
analyzed: abravi abravum abravaḥ abravittha abravim abravimhāḥ abravau abravase abravivham abravam abravimhe ajjatanīvasena vuttāni
translated: He said, they said. I said, we said. You all said, you all said. You all said, they said. You said, I said. We said, we said. These are spoken in the immediate past.🔽He said, they said. I said, we said. You said, you all said. I said, we said. You said, we said. I said, we said. These are spoken in the present.

original: Bruvissati, bruvissanti. Abravissā, abravissaṃsu. Sesaṃ sabbaṃ netabbaṃ. Kammapadaṃ appasiddhaṃ. Sace pana siyā, “brūyatī”ti siyā “luyati, lūyatī”ti padāni viya.
analyzed: bruvissati bruvissanti abravissāḥ abravissaṃsu sesam sabbam netabbam kamma padam appasiddham sace pana siyā brūyati iti siyā luyati lūyati iti padāni viya
translated: Bruvissati, bruvissanti. Abravissā, abravissaṃsu. The rest is to be construed in all three persons. The verb form is not well known. But if it were, it might be like the verb forms luyati, lūyati.

original: Jīra brūhane. Brūhanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ. Jīrati. Jīraṃ. Jīramāno. Jīraṇaṃ. Appassutāyaṃ puriso, balibaddova jīrati.
analyzed: jīra brūhane brūhanam vaḍḍhanam jīrati jīram jīramānaḥ jīraṇam appassuta ayam purisaḥ balibaddaḥ iva jīrati
translated: Jīra brūhane. Brūhanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ. Jīrati. Jīraṃ. Jīramāno. Jīraṇaṃ. Appassutāyaṃ puriso, balibaddova jīrati.

original: Pūra pūraṇe. Pūrati. Pūratova mahodadhi. Sabbe pūrentu saṅkappā. Pūrituṃ, pūritvā,
analyzed: pūra pūraṇe pūrati pūrataḥ uva mahā udadhi sabbe pūrentu saṅkappā pūritum pūritvā
translated: Pūra pūraṇe. Pūrati. Pūratova mahodadhi. Sabbe pūrentu saṅkappā. Pūrituṃ, pūritvā,

original: pūraṃ, pūritaṃ. Puṇṇaṃ, paripuṇṇaṃ. Sampuṇṇaṃ, pūraṇaṃ. Pūraṇo kassapo. Kārite “pāramiyo
analyzed: pūram pūritam puṇṇam paripuṇṇam sampuṇṇam pūraṇam pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ kārite pāramiyaḥ
translated: pūraṃ, pūritaṃ. Puṇṇaṃ, paripuṇṇaṃ. Sampuṇṇaṃ, pūraṇaṃ. Pūraṇo kassapo. Kārite “pāramiyo

original: pūreti, pūrayati, pūrāpeti, pūrāpayati. Pūretvā, pūrayitvā, pūrāpetvā, pūrāpayitvā,
analyzed: pūra iti pūrayati pūrāpa iti pūrāpayati pūretvā pūrayitvā pūrāpetvā pūrāpayitvā
translated: pūreti, pūrayati, pūrāpeti, pūrāpayati. Pūretvā, pūrayitvā, pūrāpetvā, pūrāpayitvā,

original: paripūretvā” iccādīni bhavanti.🔽Ghora gatipaṭighāte. Gatipaṭighātaṃ gatipaṭihananaṃ. Ghorati.
analyzed: paripūretvā i ca ādīni bhavanti  ghora gati paṭighāte gati paṭighātam gati paṭihananam
translated: paripūretvā” and so on.🔽Ghora gatipaṭighāte. Gatipaṭighātaṃ gatipaṭihananaṃ. Ghorati.

original: Dhora gaticāturiye. Gaticāturiyaṃ gatichekabhāvo. Dhoreti.
analyzed: dhora gati cāturiye gati cāturiyam gati cheka bhāvaḥ dhora iti
translated: Dhora gaticāturiye. Gaticāturiyaṃ gatichekabhāvo. Dhoreti.

original: Sara gatiyaṃ. Sarati, visarati, ussarati. Ussāraṇā. Saro. Saṃsāro iccādīni. Tattha saroti rahado. Saṃsāroti vaṭṭaṃ, yo “bhavo”tipi vuccati.🔽Cara caraṇe. Carati, vicarati, anucarati, sañcarati.🔽Cara gatibhakkhanesu. Carati, vicarati, anucarati, sañcarati, paṭicarati. Cariyā. Caritā. Cāro. Vicāro. Anuvicāro. Upavicāro. Caraṇaṃ. Cārako. Ocarako. Brahmacariyaṃ iccādīni.
analyzed: gatiyam sarati visarati ussarati ussāraṇā saro saṃsāro iccādīni tattha saroti rahadaḥ saṃsāro ti vaṭṭam yaḥ vuccati  cara caraṇe carati vicarati anucarati sañcarati  cara gati bhakkhanesu carati vicarati anucarati sañcarati paṭicarati cariyā caritā cāraḥ vicāraḥ anuvicāraḥ upavicāraḥ caraṇam cārako ocarakaḥ brahmacariyam iccādīni
translated: The root sara means to flow, to spread, to rise up. The noun ussāraṇā is derived from the verb ussarati. The noun saro is derived from the verb sarati. The noun saṃsāra is derived from the verb saṃsarati. Herein, saro means a lake. Saṃsāra means the round of rebirths, which is also called “becoming” .

original: Tattha caratīti gacchati, bhakkhati vā. Tathā hi caranti padassa gacchanto khādanto🔽cāti atthaṃ vadanti garū. Paṭicaratīti paṭicchādeti. Cārakoti taṃpavesitānaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: tattha carati iti gacchati bhakkhati vā tathā hi caranti padassa gacchantaḥ khādantaḥ  ca ati attham vadanti garū paṭicarati iti paṭicchādeti cārako ti taṃpavesitānam sattānam
translated: The root cara means to move, to walk. The noun caraṇa is derived from the verb carati. The noun cariyā is derived from the verb caranti. The noun caritā is derived from the verb carati. The noun cāro is derived from the verb carati. The noun vicāro is derived from the verb vicarati. The noun anuvicāro is derived from the verb anuvicarati. The noun upavicāro is derived from the verb upavicarati. The noun caraṇa is derived from the verb carati. The noun cārako is derived from the verb carati. The noun ocarako is derived from the verb ocarati. The noun brahmacariyaṃ is derived from the verb carati.

original: sukhaṃ carati bhakkhatīti cārako, rodho. Ocarakoti adhocārī. Brahmacariyanti dānampi
analyzed: sukham carati bhakkhati iti cārakaḥ adhocārī dānam pi
translated: Herein, cara means to go, or to eat. Thus the teachers say that the meaning of the root cara is “to go” and “to eat.” Paṭicara means to conceal. Cārako means one who goes for the sake of pleasure and food. Ocarako means one who goes for the sake of food. Brahmacariyaṃ means generosity,

original: veyyāvaccampi sikkhāpadampi brahmavihāropi dhammadesanāpi methunaviratipi sadārasantosopi
analyzed: veyyāvaccampi sikkhāpadampi brahmavihāro api dhamma desanā api methuna virati pi sa dāra santoso api
translated: the going forth, the training precepts, the divine abidings, teaching the Dhamma, refraining from sexual intercourse, the satisfaction of a wife,

original: uposathopi ariyamaggopi sakalaṃ sāsanampi ajjhāsayopi vuccati.🔽Kinte vataṃ kiṃ pana brahmacariyaṃ,
analyzed: uposathaḥ api ariya maggaḥ api sakalam sāsanam pi ajjhāsayaḥ api vuccati  kinte vatam kim pana brahmacariyam
translated: the observance-day ceremony, the Noble Eightfold Path, the whole dispensation, and the heart’s desire are called “a vow.”🔽“What is this vow? But what is the holy life?

original: Kissa suciṇṇassa ayaṃ vipāko;
analyzed: kissa su ciṇṇassa ayam vipākaḥ
translated: What is the result of its practice?

original: Iddhijutibalavīriyūpapatti,
analyzed: iddhi juti bala vīriyū papatti
translated: The attainment of psychic power, radiance, strength, and energy,

original: Idañca te nāga mahāvimānaṃ.
analyzed: idam ca te nāga mahā vimānam
translated: And this your great mansion, O nāga.

original: Ahañca bhariyā ca manussaloke,
analyzed: ahañca bhariyā ca manussa loke
translated: I and my wife in the human world,

original: Saddhā ubho dānapatī ahumhā;
analyzed: saddhā ubho dānapatī ahumhā
translated: We were both faithful and generous donors.

original: Opānabhūtaṃ me gharaṃ tadāsi,
analyzed: opāna bhūtam me gharam tadā asi
translated: My house was open to all,

original: Santappitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca.
analyzed: santappitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca
translated: And I satisfied ascetics and brahmins.

original: Taṃ me vataṃ taṃ pana brahmacariyaṃ,
analyzed: tam me tam pana brahmacariyam
translated: That was my vow, and that was the holy life,

original: Tassa suciṇṇassa ayaṃ vipāko;
analyzed: tassa su ciṇṇassa ayam vipākaḥ
translated: The result of its practice

original: Iddhijutibalavīriyūpapatti,
analyzed: iddhi juti bala vīriyū papatti
translated: Is the attainment of psychic power, radiance, strength, and energy,

original: Idañca me dhīra mahāvimāna”nti
analyzed: idam ca me dhīra mahā vimānanti
translated: And this my great mansion, O wise one.”

original: Imasmiñhi puṇṇakajātake dānaṃ “brahmacariya”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: imasmin hi puṇṇaka jātake dānam brahmacariyan ti vuttam
translated: In this Puṇṇaka Jātaka, generosity is called “the holy life.”

original: “Kena pāṇi kāmadado, kena pāṇi madhussavo;
analyzed: kena pāṇi kāmadadaḥ kena pāṇi madhussavaḥ
translated: “By what hand do you give sensual pleasures? By what hand do you give honey?🔽By what holy life of yours

original: Kena te brahmacariyena, puññaṃ pāṇimhi ijjhati.
analyzed: kena te brahmacariyena puññam pāṇimhi ijjhati
translated: Does merit come to your hand?

original: Tena pāṇi kāmadado, tena pāṇi madhussavo;
analyzed: tena pāṇi kāmadadaḥ tena pāṇi madhussavaḥ
translated: By that hand, the giver of desire, by that hand, the sweet-voiced one,

original: Tena me brahmacariyena, puññaṃ pāṇimhi ijjhatī”ti🔽Imasmiṃ aṅkurapetavatthumhi veyyāvaccaṃ “brahmacariya”nti vuttaṃ. “Idaṃ kho taṃ bhikkhave
analyzed: tena me brahmacariyena puññam pāṇimhi ijjhati iti  imasmin aṅkura peta vatthumhi veyyāvaccam brahmacariyanti vuttam idam kho tam bhikkhave
translated: By that celibate life, merit is successful in my hand.

original: tittiriyaṃ nāma brahmacariyaṃ ahosī”ti imasmiṃ tittirajātake sikkhāpadaṃ “brahmacariya”nti🔽vuttaṃ. “Taṃ kho pana pañcasikha brahmacariyaṃ neva nibbidāya na virāgāya…pe… yāvadeva
analyzed: tittiriyam nāma brahmacariyam ahosi iti imasmin tittira jātake sikkhāpadam brahmacariyanti  vuttam tam kho pana pañcasikha brahmacariyam na iva nibbidāya na virāgāya pe yāvat eva
translated: In this story of the Aṅkura ghost, the service is called “celibate life.” In this Tittiri Jātaka, the training rule is called “celibate life.”

original: brahmalokūpapattiyā”ti imasmiṃ mahāgovindasutte brahmavihārā “brahmacariya”nti vuttā.
analyzed: brahma loka upapattiyā ati imasmin mahāgovindasutte brahmavihārāḥ brahmacariyanti vuttā
translated: In this Mahāgovinda Sutta, the divine abodes are called “celibate life.”

original: “Ekasmiṃ brahmacariyasmiṃ, sahassaṃ maccuhāyino”ti ettha dhammadesanā “brahmacariya”nti🔽vuttā. “Pare abrahmacārī bhavissanti, mayamettha brahmacārino bhavissāmā”ti sallekhasutte
analyzed: ekasmim brahmacariyasmim sahassam maccuhāyinaḥ ti ettha dhamma desanā brahmacariyanti  vuttā pare abrahmacārī bhavissanti mayam ettha brahmacārinaḥ bhavissāma ati sallekha sutte
translated: In this Dhamma teaching, the teaching of the Dhamma is called “celibate life.” In this Sallekha Sutta,

original: methunavirati “brahmacariya”nti vuttā.
analyzed: methuna virati brahmacariyanti vuttā
translated: the avoidance of sexual intercourse is called “celibate life.”

original: Mayañca bhariyā nātikkamāma,
analyzed: mayam ca bhariyāḥ na atikkamāma
translated: We do not transgress our wives,

original: Amhe ca bhariyā nātikkamanti;
analyzed: amhe ca bhariyāḥ na atikkamanti
translated: And wives do not transgress us;

original: Aññatra tāha brahmacariyaṃ carāma;
analyzed: aññatra tāha brahmacariyam carāma
translated: Except for you we live the holy life.

original: Tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare”ti
analyzed: tasmai hi amham daharā na
translated: Therefore we do not die young.”

original: Mahādhammapālajātake sadārasantoso “brahmacariya”nti vutto.
analyzed: mahādhammapāla jātake sa dāra santoso brahmacariya nti vutto
translated: In the Mahādhammapāla Jātaka the contentment of the householder and his wife is called “the holy life.”

original: Hīnena brahmacariyena, khattiye upapajjati;
analyzed: hīnena brahmacariyena khattiye upapajjati
translated: “By the lower holy life one is reborn among the Khattiyas;🔽By the middle one among the gods;

original: Majjhimena ca devesu, uttamena visujjhatī”ti
analyzed: majjhimena ca devesu uttamena visujjhati iti
translated: By the higher one is purified.”

original: Evaṃ nimijātake avītikkamavasena kato uposatho “brahmacariya”nti vutto. “Idaṃ kho
analyzed: evam nimi jātake avītikkama vasena kataḥ uposathaḥ brahmacariyanti vuttaḥ idam kho
translated: In the Nimi Jātaka the observance of the Uposatha with its eight precepts is called “the holy life.”

original: pana pañcasikha brahmacariyaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya…pe… ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko
analyzed: pana pañcasikha brahmacariyam ekanta nibbidāya virāgāya ape ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgiko
translated: “This holy life, Pañcasikha, is for complete dispassion, for the fading away of lust, for the destruction of craving, for the attainment of the peace of Nibbāna.”

original: maggo”ti mahāgovindasuttasmiṃyeva ariyamaggo “brahmacariya”nti vutto. “Tayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: maggo ti ariya maggaḥ brahmacariyanti vuttaḥ tayā idam brahmacariyam
translated: In the Mahāgovinda Sutta the Noble Eightfold Path is called “the holy life.”

original: iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ yāvadeva manussehi suppakāsita”nti
analyzed: iddham ca iva phītam ca vitthārikam bāhujaññam puthubhūtam yāvat eva manussehi suppakāsitanti
translated: “This holy life, Pañcasikha, is prosperous, flourishing, wide-spread, popular, far-famed, and well proclaimed among devas and men.”

original: pāsādikasutte sikkhattayasaṅgahaṃ sakalaṃ sāsanaṃ “brahmacariya”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pāsādika sutte sikkhattaya saṅgaham sakalam sāsanam brahmacariyanti vuttam
translated: In the Pāsādikasutta the whole dispensation with its three trainings is called “the holy life.”

original: “Api ataramānānaṃ, phalāsāva samijjhati;
analyzed: api a taramānānam samijjhati
translated: “Even though one does not wish for fruit, it comes to one who lives the life;

original: Vipakkabrahmacariyosmi, evaṃ jānāhi gāmaṇī”ti
analyzed: vipakka brahmacariyaḥ asmi evam jānāhi gāmaṇi iti
translated: I have lived the life to perfection, so know this, O village headman.”

original: Ettha ajjhāsayo “brahmacariya”nti vutto. Iccevaṃ –
analyzed: ettha ajjhāsayaḥ brahmacariyanti vuttaḥ iti ca evam
translated: Herein, the life is called “the life of virtue.” So in this way:

original: Dānaṃ veyyāvaṭiyañca, sikkhā brahmavihārakā;🔽Dhammakkhānaṃ methunatā-virati ca uposatho.
analyzed: dānam veyyāvaṭiyam ca sikkhā brahmavihārakā  dhamma kkhānam methuna tā virati ca uposathaḥ
translated: Giving, and also service, training, the divine abidings,🔽The exposition of the Dhamma, and abstinence from sex, and the Uposatha,

original: Sadāresu ca santoso, ariyamaggo ca sāsanaṃ;
analyzed: sa dāresu ca santosaḥ ariya maggo ca sāsanam
translated: And contentment with one’s own wife, and the Noble Path, and the Dispensation,

original: Ajjhāsayo cime brahma-cariyasaddena vuccare.
analyzed: ajjhāsayaḥ cime brahmacariya saddena vuccare
translated: Are called by the word “the life of virtue” in the sense of being the life’s support.

original: Hura koṭille. Hurati.
analyzed: hura koṭille hurati
translated: Hura, koṭille. Hurati.

original: Sara saddopatāpesu. Sarati. Saro, saraṇaṃ.
analyzed: sara sadda upatāpesu sarati saraṇam
translated: Sara, in the sense of sound, of distress, and of going. Sarati. Saro, saraṇaṃ.

original: Ettha ca saroti saddopi vuccati usupi. Saraṇanti sarati upatāpeti hiṃsati saraṇagatānaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca saraḥ ti saddo api vuccati saraṇanti sarati upatāpeti hiṃsati saraṇa gatānam
translated: And here saro is also said to be sound, and usupi. Saraṇaṃ is that which goes to, which causes distress, which harms, those who have gone for refuge.

original: teneva saraṇagamanena bhayaṃ santāpaṃ dukkhaṃ duggatiṃ parikilesañcāti saraṇaṃ, buddhādiratanattayaṃ.
analyzed: tena iva saraṇa gamanena bhayam santāpam dukkham duggatim parikilesam ca ati saraṇam
translated: Because of that going for refuge, there is fear, distress, suffering, an unhappy destination, and defilement, thus it is a refuge, the Triple Gem of the Buddha, etc.

original: Atha vā saddhā pasannā manussā “amhākaṃ saraṇamida”nti saranti cintenti, taṃ tattha
analyzed: atha vā saddhā pasannāḥ manussāḥ amhākam saraṇam idanti saranti cintenti tam tattha
translated: Or else, people who have faith and confidence “think” saraṇamidaṃ amhākaṃ , “This is our refuge.”

original: ca vācaṃ niccharanti gacchanti cātipi saraṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca vācam niccharanti gacchanti ca atipi saraṇam
translated: and speech issues forth and goes out, thus it is a refuge.

original: Sara cintāyaṃ. Sarati, susarati iccapi payogo. Appakkharānañhi bahubhāvo aññathābhāvo
analyzed: sara cintā ayam sarati su sarati iti api payogaḥ appakkharānam hi bahu bhāvaḥ aññathābhāvaḥ
translated: The word sara is used in the sense of remembering. It is used in the sense of remembering well, too. For the meaning of many is the meaning of few in another way,

original: ca hoti, yathā “dve, duve, taṇhā tasiṇā, pamhaṃ, pakhuma”nti. Anussarati, paṭissarati.
analyzed: ca hoti yathā dve duve taṇhā tasiṇā pamham pakhumanti anussarati paṭissarati
translated: just as “two” is “two” and “thirst” is “craving.” One remembers, one remembers back.

original: Saranti etāya sattā, sayaṃ vā sarati, saraṇamattameva vā etanti sati. Anussati, paṭissati.
analyzed: saranti etāya sattā sayam vā sarati saraṇa mattam eva vā etat iti sati anussati paṭissati
translated: Beings remember by means of it, or it remembers itself, or it is just remembering, thus it is mindfulness . One remembers, one remembers back.

original: Saratīti sato. Punappunaṃ saratīti paṭissato.
analyzed: sarati iti sataḥ punappunam sarati iti paṭissataḥ
translated: One who remembers is mindful . One who remembers again and again is fully aware .

original: Dvara saṃvaraṇe. Saṃvaraṇaṃ rakkhaṇā. Dvarati. Dvāraṃ. Dvisaddūpapadaaradhātuvasenapi
analyzed: saṃvaraṇe saṃvaraṇam rakkhaṇā dvāram dvi sat dūpa pada ara dhātu vasena api
translated: In the sense of guarding the doors: guarding is protecting. It is a door because it goes , it goes forth, it occurs, by the method of the reduplicated aorists dvara and dvāra.

original: idaṃ rūpaṃ sijjhati. Tatrimāni nibbacanāni – dvaranti saṃvaranti rakkhanti etenāti
analyzed: idam rūpam sijjhati tatra imāni nibbacanāni dvaranti saṃvaranti rakkhanti etena ati
translated: This word is formed thus. Its etymologies are these: it is a door because it guards , it protects , it keeps off , by this,

original: dvāraṃ, atha vā dve kavāṭā aranti gacchanti pavattanti etthātipi dvāranti. Gehadvārampi
analyzed: dvāram atha vā dve kavāṭāḥ gacchanti pavattanti geha dvāram pi
translated: or alternatively, it is a door because two panels go , occur, here. A house door, too,

original: kāyadvārādīnipi upāyopi dvāranti vuccati. Pāḷiyaṃ tu “dvāraṃ dvārā”ti ca itthinapuṃsakavasena
analyzed: upāyaḥ api dvāranti vuccati pāḷiyam tu dvāram ca itthi napuṃsaka vasena
translated: The body door, etc., are also a means and a door. But in the texts the word “door” is used in the feminine and neuter as “dvāraṃ” and “dvārā” .

original: dvārasaddo vutto. Tathā hi “dvārampi surakkhitaṃ hotī”ti ca “dvārāpesā”ti ca tassa dviliṅgatā vuttā.
analyzed: dvāra saddo vutto tathā hi dvāram pi su rakkhitam hoti iti ca ca tassa dvi liṅga tā vuttā
translated: For the dual-genderedness of the word is stated thus: “The door is well guarded” and “these are doors” .

original: Gara ghara secane. Garati. Gharati. Gharaṃ.
analyzed: gara ghara secane garati gharati gharam
translated: Gara, ghara, in the sense of “sprinkling”: garati, gharati; gharaṃ .

original: Dhūra hucchane. Hucchana koṭillaṃ. Dhūrati.
analyzed: dhūra hucchane hucchana koṭillam dhūrati
translated: Dhūra, hucchana: hucchana is a kind of koṭilla . Dhūrati.

original: Tara plavanasaraṇesu. Tarati. Taraṇaṃ. Titthaṃ. Tiṇṇo. Uttiṇṇo. Otiṇṇo iccādīni.
analyzed: plavana saraṇesu tarati taraṇam tittham tiṇṇaḥ uttiṇṇaḥ otiṇṇaḥ icca ādīni
translated: Tara, in the sense of “floating” and “crossing over”: tarati; taraṇaṃ ; titthaṃ ; tiṇṇo ; uttiṇṇo ; otiṇṇo , etc.

original: Tattha taraṇaṃ vuccati nāvā, tarati udakapiṭṭhe plavati, taranti uttaranti vā nadiṃ etenāti atthena.
analyzed: tattha taraṇam vuccati nāvā tarati udaka piṭṭhe plavati taranti uttaranti vā nadim etena ati atthena
translated: Herein, a boat is called a taraṇaṃ ; it floats on the surface of the water, and it is by means of it that they cross over or go across the river, thus it is a taraṇaṃ .

original: Nāvā plavo taraṃ poto, taraṇaṃ uttaraṃ tathā;
analyzed: nāvā taram poto taraṇam uttaram tathā
translated: A boat, a raft, a crossing, a ship, a ferry,

original: Jalayānanti etāni, nāvānāmāni honti tu.
analyzed: etāni nāvānāmāni honti tu
translated: And a ford are the names for these.

original: Tara sambhame. Sambhamo anavaṭṭhānaṃ. Tarati. Tarito. Turaṅgo.
analyzed: tara sambhame sambhamaḥ an avaṭṭhānam tarati taritaḥ turaṅgaḥ
translated: Tara, in the sense of “confusion”: sambhamo is non-stopping. Tarati; tarito; turaṅgo .

original: Ettha ca “so māsakhettaṃ tarito avāsari”nti pāḷi nidassanaṃ. Tattha taritoti turito sambhamanto. Avāsarinti upagacchiṃ upavisiṃ vā.
analyzed: ettha ca saḥ māsa khettam taritaḥ avāsarinti nidassanam tattha taritaḥ ti sambhamantaḥ avāsarinti upagacchim upavisim vā
translated: And here the text “He, having crossed the field of the month, entered” is an instance. Herein, having crossed means having crossed quickly, having gone quickly. Entered means I have approached, I have sat down.

original: Jara roge. Ettha jararogoyeva “rogo”ti adhippeto payogavasena. Jarasaddassa hi jararoge
analyzed: jara roge ettha adhippeto payoga vasena jara saddassa hi jara roge
translated: Old age, disease. Herein, only old age and disease are intended by “disease” by way of application. For the word “old age” occurs

original: pavattaniyamanatthaṃ “roge”ti vuttaṃ. Tena añño rogo idha rogasaddena na vuccati.
analyzed: pavatta niyamana attham roga iti vuttam tena aññaḥ rogaḥ idha roga saddena na vuccati
translated: in the sense of old age and disease. Therefore another disease is not spoken of here by the word “disease.”

original: Jarati. Jaro. Sajjaro. Pajjararogo. Jarena pīḷitā manussā. Yattha tu ayaṃ vayohānivācako,
analyzed: jarati jaraḥ sajjaraḥ pajjara rogaḥ jarena pīḍitāḥ manussāḥ tu ayam vayaḥ hāni vācako
translated: One grows old, old age, having old age, having old age and disease, oppressed by old age. But where this word is a synonym for “age,”

original: tattha payoge “jīrati, jarā”ti cassa rūpāni bhavanti.
analyzed: tattha payoge jīrati jarāti ca assa rūpāni bhavanti
translated: then in the application “he grows old, old age” its forms are so.

original: Dara bhaye. Darati. Darī. “Bīlāsayā darīsayā”ti nidassanaṃ. Tattha darīti bhāyitabbaṭṭhena darī.
analyzed: bhaye darati darī bīlāsayā darīsayā iti nidassanam tattha darī iti bhāyitabba ṭṭhena darī
translated: To tremble, fear. He trembles, trembling, “The trembling of the hole, the trembling of the den” is an instance. Herein, trembling means trembling in the sense of being afraid.

original: Dara ādarānādaresu. Darati, ādarati, anādarati. Ādaro, anādaro.
analyzed: daraḥ ādara anādaresu darati ādarati an ādarati ādaraḥ an ādaraḥ
translated: To tremble, to respect, to disrespect. He trembles, he respects, he disrespects. Respect, disrespect.

original: Ettha ca daratīti daraṃ karotīti ca anādaraṃ karotīti ca attho. Yathā hi ārakāsaddo
analyzed: ettha ca darati iti daram karoti iti ca anādaram karoti iti ca atthaḥ yathā hi ārakā saddaḥ
translated: And here the meaning is “he trembles” = “he makes fear,” = “he makes disrespect.” For just as the word “far”

original: dūrāsannavācako, tathāyampi daradhātu ādarānādaravācako daṭṭhabbo. Darasaddo ca kāyadarathe
analyzed: dūra āsanna vācakaḥ tathā ayam pi dara dhātu ādara anādara vācakaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ dara saddo ca kāya darathe
translated: The word “fear” is used in the sense of bodily fear,

original: cittadarathe kilesadarathe ca vattati. Ayañhi –
analyzed: citta darathe kilesa darathe ca vattati
translated: mental fear, and fear of defilement. For this is said:

original: Ādittaṃ vata maṃ santaṃ, ghatasittaṃva pāvakaṃ;
analyzed: ādittam vata mam santam pāvakam
translated: “As though a burning clod of fire,🔽I quench it with a flood of tears.

original: Vārinā viya osiñci, sabbaṃ nibbāpaye dara”nti
analyzed: vārinā viya osiñci sabbam nibbāpaye daranti
translated: And with water as with oil,🔽Extinguish all the flames of lust.

original: Ettha kāyadarathe cittadarathe ca vattati. “Vītaddaro vītasoko vītasallo, sayaṃ abhiññāya🔽abhāsi buddho”ti ettha pana kilesadarathe vattati. Vītaddaroti hi aggamaggena sabbakilesānaṃ
analyzed: ettha kāya darathe citta darathe ca vattati vīta ddaraḥ vīta sokaḥ vīta sallo sayam abhiññāya  abhāsi buddhaḥ ti ettha pana kilesa darathe vattati vīta ddaro ti hi aggamaggena sabba kilesānam
translated: Here it is used in the sense of bodily fear and mental fear. But in the passage: “Fearless, sorrowless, rid of dart,🔽The Enlightened One has told of it himself” ,

original: samucchinnattā vigatakilesadarathoti attho.
analyzed: attho
translated: it is used in the sense of fear of defilement. For the meaning of “fearless” is that he is rid of the fear of defilement because he has cut off all defilements by means of the path that is the supreme refuge.

original: Nara nayane. Narati. Naro, nārī.🔽Ettha naroti puriso. So hi narati netīti naro. Yathā paṭhamapakatibhūto satto datarāya
analyzed: nara nayane narati naraḥ nārī  ettha puriso saḥ hi narati neti iti naraḥ yathā paṭhama pakati bhūto satto
translated: Nara, nayane. Narati. Naro, nārī.

original: pakatiyā seṭṭhaṭṭhena puri uccāṭṭhāne seti pavattatīti purisoti vuccati, evaṃ nayanaṭṭhena
analyzed: pakatiyā seṭṭha ṭṭhena puri uccāṭṭhāne sa iti pavattati iti puriso ti vuccati evam nayana ṭṭhena
translated: Herein, nara is a man. He is called nara because he narrates , he leads . Just as a being who is in the first stage of existence is called a purisa because he is set in the highest place by nature, since he is set in the highest place by the path that is the supreme refuge, so too he is called a nara because he is set in the highest place by the eye that is the supreme refuge.

original: naroti vuccati. Puttabhātubhūtopi hi puggalo mātujeṭṭhabhaginīnaṃ netuṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: naraḥ ti vuccati putta bhātu bhūtaḥ api hi puggalaḥ mātu jeṭṭha bhaginīnam netu ṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati
translated: “Man” is said. For a person who is a son or a brother also stands in the place of a mother or an elder sister,

original: pageva itaro itarāsaṃ. Nārīti narena yogato, narassāyanti vā nārī. Aparampettha narasaddassa🔽nibbacanaṃ, nariyati sakena kammena niyyatīti naro, satto manusso vā. “Kammena niyyateo
analyzed: pagā iva itaraḥ itarāsam nārī iti narena yogataḥ vā nārī aparam pa ittha nara saddassa  nibbacanam sakena kammena niyyati iti naraḥ sattaḥ manussaḥ vā kammena
translated: all the more so the other for the others. “Woman” is from the male, or a woman is what is desired by a man. Another explanation of the word “man” is this:

original: loko”ti hi vuttaṃ. Tattha narasaddassa tāva purisavacane “narā ca atha nāriyo”ti
analyzed: loko ti hi vuttam tattha nara saddassa tāva purisa vacane narā ca atha nāriyā ti
translated: he is a man because he is led by his own kamma, a being or a human being. For it is said, “The world is led by kamma.” Herein, as to the word “man” in the sense of male, there is the instance in the passage, “Men and women” .

original: nidassanaṃ. Sattamanussavacane pana “buddho ayaṃ edisako naruttamo. Āmoditā naramarū”ti🔽ca nidassanaṃ, tasmā “naroti puriso, naroti satto, naroti manusso”ti tattha tattha
analyzed: nidassanam satta manussa vacane pana buddhaḥ ayam edisakaḥ naruttamaḥ āmoditā  ca nidassanam tasmā naroti purisaḥ naroti satto naroti manusso ti tattha tattha
translated: But as to the word “man” in the sense of being and human being, there is the instance in the passage, “This Buddha is the best of men. The gods and men rejoice” .

original: yathāsambhavaṃ attho saṃvaṇṇetabbo.
analyzed: yathāsambhavam atthaḥ saṃvaṇṇetabbaḥ
translated: Therefore the meaning should be construed in each instance as appropriate as “man” in the sense of male, “man” in the sense of being, and “man” in the sense of human being.

original: Hara haraṇe. Haraṇaṃ pavattanaṃ. Harati. Sāvatthiyaṃ viharati. Vihāsi. Vihaṃsu. Viharissati.
analyzed: hara haraṇe haraṇam pavattanam harati sāvatthiyam viharati vihāsi vihaṃsu viharissati
translated: “To carry” is to carry off. “To carry off” is to cause to occur. He carries. He lives in Savatthi. He lived. They lived. He will live.

original: Appamatto vihissati. Voharati. Saṃvoharati. sabbo harati vā. Rūpiyasaṃvohāro, rūpiyasabbohāro
analyzed: appamattaḥ vihissati voharati saṃvoharati sabbaḥ harati vā rūpiya saṃvohāraḥ rūpiya sabbohāro
translated: He will live heedful. He speaks. He speaks together. He speaks all. Dealing in silver, dealing in silver and gold.

original: vā. Pāṭihāriyaṃ. Pītipāmojjahāro. Vihāro. Vohāro. Abhihāro. Cittaṃ abhinīharati.
analyzed: vā pāṭihāriyam vihāraḥ vohāraḥ abhihāraḥ cittam abhinīharati
translated: A marvel. He speaks with joy and gladness. He lives. He speaks. He speaks forth. He directs his mind.

original: Sāsane viharaṃ, viharanto, viharamāno. Vihātabbaṃ, viharituṃ. Viharitvā. Aññānipi yojetabbāni.
analyzed: sāsane viharam viharantaḥ viharamānaḥ vihātabbam viharitum viharitvā aññāni api yojetabbāni
translated: He lives in the Dispensation, living, living in a monastery. He should live, to live. Having lived. Others should be construed too.

original: Tattha pāṭihāriyanti samāhite citte vigatūpakkilese katakiccena pacchā haritabbaṃ🔽pavattetabbanti pāṭihāriyaṃ. Paṭīti hi ayaṃ saddo “pacchā”ti etassa atthaṃ bodheti
analyzed: tattha pāṭihāriyanti samāhite citte vigata upakkilese kata kiccena pacchā haritabbam  pavattetabbanti pāṭihāriyam paṭi iti hi ayam saddo pacchā ati etassa attham bodheti
translated: Herein, a marvel is what should be brought forth, should be made to occur, after the mind has become concentrated, rid of hindrances, and done its work.

original: “tasmiṃ paṭipaviṭṭhamhi, añño āgañchi brāhmaṇo”tiādīsu viya. Vihāroti ṭhānanisajjādinā
analyzed: tasmin paṭipaviṭṭhamhi aññaḥ āgañchi brāhmaṇaḥ ti ādīsu viya vihāro ti ṭhāna nisajja ādinā
translated: For this word pāṭihāriya informs about the meaning of pacchā, as in such passages as “When he had gone away another brahmin came” .

original: viharanti etthāti vihāro, bhikkhūnaṃ āvāso. Viharaṇaṃ vā vihāro, viharaṇakriyā. Vohāroti
analyzed: viharanti ettha ati vihāraḥ bhikkhūnam āvāsaḥ viharaṇam vā vihāraḥ viharaṇa kriyā vohāraḥ ti
translated: A monastery is a place for living, thus it is a monastery ; it is a dwelling for bhikkhus. Or a monastery is the living, the action of living. Speaking is

analyzed: byavahāraḥ api paṇṇatti pi vacanam api cetanā api tattha
translated: also dealing, description, speech, and volition. Herein,

original: Yo hi koci manussesu, vohāraṃ upajīvati;
analyzed: yaḥ hi koci manussesu vohāram upajīvati
translated: Whoever in the world makes a living by trade,

original: Evaṃ vāseṭṭha jānāti, vāṇijo so nabrāhmaṇo”ti.
analyzed: evam jānāti vāṇijaḥ saḥ na brāhmaṇaḥ iti
translated: Thus, Vasettha, he knows, he is a trader, not a brahmin.

original: Ayaṃ byavahāravohāro nāma. “Saṅkhā samaññā paññatti vohāro”ti ayaṃ paṇṇattivohāro
analyzed: ayam byavahāra vohāraḥ nāma saṅkhā samaññā paññatti vohāro ti ayam paṇṇatti vohāro
translated: This is called the usage of usage. “Designation, common usage, description, usage” is called the usage of designation.

analyzed: nāma tathā tathā voharanti parāmasanti iti ayam vacana vohāraḥ nāma aṭṭha ariya vohārā

translated: In usage, in speech, in designation, in intention,

analyzed: vohāra saddo catūsu imesu atthesu dissati
translated: The word usage is seen in these four meanings.

original: Hara apanayane. Apanayanaṃ nīharaṇaṃ. Dosaṃ harati. Nīharati. Nīhāro, pariharati.
analyzed: apanayane apanayanam nīharaṇam dosam harati nīharati pariharati
translated: Hara, in removing. Removing is taking away. He removes hate. He takes away. The removal, he avoids.

original: Parihāro. Rajoharaṇaṃ. Sabbadosaharo dhammo. Bhagavato ca sāsanassa ca paṭipakkhe🔽titthiye haratīti pāṭihāriyaṃ. Mattāvaṇṇabhedenettha “pāṭiheraṃ pāṭihīraṃ pāṭihāriya”nti
analyzed: parihāraḥ rajaḥ haraṇam sabba dosa haraḥ dhammaḥ bhagavataḥ ca sāsanassa ca paṭipakkhe  titthiye harati iti pāṭihāriyam mattā vaṇṇa bhedena ittha pāṭiheram pāṭihīram pāṭihāriyanti
translated: The avoidance. The removal of dust. The Dhamma removes all hate. And the opponent of the Blessed One’s Dispensation🔽removes the sectarians, thus it is a marvel. The three word-forms here, “pāṭiheraṃ pāṭihīraṃ pāṭihāriya,”

original: Jāgaraniddakkhaye jāgarati. Jāgaro, jāgaraṇaṃ, jāgaraṃ. Dīghā jāgarato ratti. Jāgaramāno. Ayañca dhātu tanādigaṇaṃ patvā “jāgaroti, paṭijāgarotī”ti rūpāni janeti.
analyzed: jāgara nidda kkhaye jāgarati jāgaraḥ jāgaraṇam jāgaram dīghā jāgarataḥ jāgaramānaḥ ayam ca dhātu tanādi gaṇam patvā jāgaroti paṭijāgaroti iti rūpāni janeti
translated: He is awake in the destruction of sleep. He is awake, he is awake, he is awake. The night is long for the one who is awake. He is awake. This element, having come into the group beginning with tan, generates forms such as “he is awake,” “he is awake.”

original: Īra vacane gatikampanesu ca. Īrati. Īritaṃ. Eritaṃ. Samīraṇo. Jinerito dhammo. Kuppanti vātassapi eritassa.
analyzed: vacane gati kampanesu ca īrati īritam eritam samīraṇaḥ jina īritaḥ dhammo kuppanti vātassa api eritassa
translated: Īra is in the sense of speaking, going, and trembling. He goes. He is gone. He is gone. He is a blower. The Dhamma is gone over. They are upset by the gone-ness of the wind.

original: Tattha samīraṇoti vāto. So hi samīrati vāyati, samīreti ca rukkhasākhāpaṇṇādīni suṭṭhu kampetīti “samīraṇo”ti vuccati.
analyzed: tattha samīraṇo ti vāto so hi samīrati vāyati samīreti ca rukkha sākhā paṇṇa ādīni suṭṭhu kampeti iti samīraṇo ti vuccati
translated: There, a blower is a wind. For it is said that it blows, it blows well, it blows well and it shakes the branches, leaves, etc., of trees well, thus it is called a blower.

original: Hare lajjāyaṃ. Aluttantoyamekāranto dhātu, gile pītikkhayeti dhātu viya. Harāyati. Harāyanaṃ. Aṭṭīyāmi harāyāmi.
analyzed: dhātu dhātu viya harāyati harāyanam aṭṭīyāmi harāyāmi
translated: Hare is in the sense of shame. It is an element with one base without a prefix, like the element gile in the sense of delight and trembling. He is ashamed. He is ashamed. I am ashamed, I am ashamed.

original: Ettha harāyatīti lajjati, hiriṃ karotīti attho.
analyzed: ettha harāyati iti lajjati hirim karoti iti
translated: Herein, he is ashamed means he is ashamed, he is embarrassed, is the meaning.

original: Para pālanapūraṇesu. “Parati, paramo”timassa rūpāni, nara nayaneti dhātussa “narati naro”ti rūpāni viya.
analyzed: para pālana pūraṇesu parati paramotimassa rūpāni nara nayaneti dhātussa rūpāni viya
translated: Para is in the sense of protecting and filling. “He is protected, he is the highest” are its forms, like “he delights, he is a man” are forms of the element nara in the sense of seeing.

original: Tattha paratīti pāleti, pūrati vā. Suddhakattuvasenidaṃ padaṃ vuttaṃ. Hetukattuvasena🔽hi “pāreti pārayatī”tiādīni rūpāni bhavanti. Paramoti pālako pūrako vā. Ettha ca🔽“pāramī”ti padaṃ etassatthassa sādhakaṃ. Tathā hi pāramīti parati, pāreti cāti paramo,
analyzed: tattha parati iti pāleti pūrati vā suddha kattu vasena idam padam vuttam hetu kattu vasena  hi pāra iti pārayati iti ādīni rūpāni bhavanti paramaḥ ti pālakaḥ vā ettha ca  pāramī iti padam etassa atthassa sādhakam tathā hi pāramī iti parati pāreti ca ati paramaḥ
translated: Herein, the word pāra is derived from the verb pāleti , “he causes to go,” or from the verb pūreti , “he fills up.” The former derivation is in the sense of the pure root ,🔽while the latter is in the sense of the causal root .🔽The word parama is derived from the verb pālako , “he protects,” or from the verb pūrako , “he fills up.” Herein,

original: dānādīnaṃ guṇānaṃ pālako pūrako ca mahābodhisatto. Paramassa idaṃ, paramassa vā bhāvo,🔽kammaṃ vā pāramī, dānādikriyā. Garūhi pana “pūretīti paramo, dānādīnaṃ guṇānaṃ pūrako
analyzed: dāna ādīnam guṇānam pālako pūrako ca mahā bodhisatto paramassa idam paramassa vā bhāvo  vā pāramī dāna ādi kriyā pūrakaḥ
translated: the word pāramī is a proof of the meaning. For it is said: “Pāra is derived from the verb pāreti , ‘he causes to go,’ or from the verb pāleti , ‘he protects,’ and it is also derived from the verb pūreti , ‘he fills up.’ The Great Being is called parama because he protects and fills up the virtues of giving, etc.🔽The word pāramī is derived from the word parama .

original: pālako cā”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ vīmaṃsitabaṃ.
analyzed: pālakaḥ ca ati vuttam tat vīmaṃsitabam
translated: Or pāramī is an action, the doing of giving, etc. But the grammarians say: “Pāra is derived from the verb pūreti , ‘he fills up.’ The Great Being is called parama because he fills up and protects the virtues of giving, etc.” This statement should be examined.

original: Vara varaṇe. Varati. Vāraṇo, varuṇo.
analyzed: vara varaṇe varati vāraṇaḥ varuṇaḥ
translated: The word vara is derived from the verb varati , “he chooses.” The word varuṇa is derived from the verb varati , “he chooses.”

original: Gira niggiraṇo. Niggiraṇaṃ paggharaṇaṃ. Girati, giri.
analyzed: gira niggiraṇaḥ niggiraṇam paggharaṇam girati giri
translated: The word girā is derived from the verb niggiraṇo , “he causes to flow out.” Niggiraṇa is derived from the verb niggiraṇa , “he causes to flow out.” The word girā is derived from the verb girati , “he speaks.”

original: Ettha girīti pabbatā, yo ‘selo”tiādīhi anekehi nāmehi kathiyati. So hi sandhisaṅkhātehi
analyzed: ettha giri iti pabbatā yaḥ sela iti ādīhi anekehi nāmehi kathiyati saḥ hi sandhi saṅkhātehi
translated: Herein, girā is a mountain, which is spoken of by many names such as “selo” , etc. It is called girā because it is a place of meeting .

original: pabbehi citattā pabbamassa atthīti pabbato. Himavamanādivasena jalassa sārabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: pabbehi cita ttā pabbamassa atthi iti pabbataḥ hima vamana ādi vasena jalassa sāra bhūtānam
translated: It is a mountain because it has peaks (pabbhā) or because it is a mountain (pabbato).🔽It is the Himalaya, etc., because it is the abode of snow (hima), etc.

original: bhesajjādivatthūnañca giraṇato girīti vuccati.
analyzed: bhesajja ādi vatthūnam ca giraṇataḥ girī iti vuccati
translated: It is a mountain because it is made of rocks. It is called a mountain because it is the source of the best things such as medicinal herbs, etc., as if it were their womb.

original: Imāni panassa nāmāni –
analyzed: imāni panassa nāmāni
translated: These are its names:

original: Pabbato acalo selo, nago giri mahīdharo;
analyzed: pabbataḥ acalaḥ selaḥ nagaḥ giri mahīdharo
translated: A mountain, a rock, a crag, a peak, a hill, a mountain, a great mountain,

original: Addi siluccayo cāti, giripaṇṇattiyo imā.
analyzed: addi siluccayaḥ ca ati giri paṇṇattiyaḥ imāḥ
translated: A heap of stone, a mass of stone, a range of hills: these are the names for a mountain.🔽In the sense of ‘to shine’ (sur) and in the sense of ‘to rule’ (issariya) and in the sense of ‘to give’ (ditthi),

original: Sura issariyadittīsu. Surati. Suro, asuro.
analyzed: suraḥ issariya dittīsu surati suraḥ asuraḥ
translated: ‘To shine’ (surati) is a god. ‘To shine’ (suro) and ‘not to shine’ (asuro).

original: Tatra saroti surati īsati devissariyaṃ pāpuṇāti virocati cāti suro. Sundarā rā vācā🔽assāti vā suro, devo. Devābhidhānāni divādigaṇe pakāsessāma. Asuroti devo viya na
analyzed: tatra surati īsati devissariyam pāpuṇāti virocati vācā  assa ati vā suraḥ devaḥ deva abhidhānāni divādi gaṇe pakāsessāma asuraḥ ti devaḥ viya na
translated: Herein, one who shines (surati), rules (īsati), attains (pāpuṇāti) and shines (virocati) with the sovereignty of a god is a god (suro). Or alternatively, one who shines (surati) with beautiful speech (sundarā vācā)

original: surati na īsati na virocati cāti asuro. Surānaṃ vā paṭipakkho mittapaṭipakkhā amittā🔽viyāti asuro, dānavo, yo “pubbadevo”tipi vuccati. Tathā hi kumbhajātake vuttaṃ –
analyzed: surati naḥ īsati na virocati ca ati asuraḥ surānam vā paṭipakkhaḥ mitta paṭipakkhāḥ amittā  viyāti asuraḥ dānavaḥ yaḥ pubbadevaḥ ti pi vuccati tathā hi kumbhajātake vuttam
translated: is a god (suro). Or alternatively, one who does not shine (na surati) like a god (deva), does not rule (na īsati), does not shine (na virocati) is a demon (asuro). Or alternatively, a demon (asuro) is an enemy (paṭipakkho) of gods (surānaṃ), like an enemy (amittā) is an opponent (paṭipakkhā) of a friend (mittā).

original: “Yaṃ ve pivitvā pubbadevā pamattā,
analyzed: yam ve pivitvā pubbadevā pamattā
translated: Thus it is said: “In the past, the gods, being heedless, drank the beer,

original: Tidivā cutā sassatiyā samāyā;
analyzed: tidivā cutā sassatiyā samāyā
translated: And after a hundred years had passed, they fell from the heavenly world.”

original: Taṃ tādisaṃ majjamimaṃ niratthaṃ,
analyzed: tam tādisam majjam imam nirattham
translated: This sort of liquor is useless,

original: Jānaṃ mahārāja kathaṃ piveyyā”ti.
analyzed: jānam mahā rāja katham piveyya ati
translated: Knowing this, great king, how could one drink it?”

original: Sagāthāvaggasaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ pana “na suraṃ pivimha, na suraṃ pivimhā’ti āhaṃsu, tato paṭṭhāya asurā nāma jātā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sa gāthā vagga saṃvaṇṇanāyam pana na suram pivimha na suram pivimha ati āhaṃsu tatas paṭṭhāya asurāḥ nāma jātā iti vuttam
translated: But in the commentary to the Sagathavagga it is said: “They said ‘We do not drink liquor, we do not drink liquor.’ From then on they were called asuras.”

original: Imāni tadabhidhānāni –
analyzed: imāni tad abhidhānāni
translated: These are the names for them:

original: Asuro pubbadevo ca, dānavo devatāri tu;
analyzed: asuraḥ pubbadevaḥ ca dānavaḥ devatāri tu
translated: An asura, a former god, a dānava, and a foe of the gods,

original: Nāmāni asurānanti, imāni niddise vidū.🔽Pāko iti tu yaṃ nāmaṃ, ekassa asurassa tu;
analyzed: nāmāni asurānanti imāni niddise vidū  pāko iti tu yam nāmam ekassa asurassa tu
translated: These are the names for asuras, so the wise ones have explained.🔽But the name pāka is that of a single asura,

original: Paṇṇattītipi ekacce, garavo pana abravuṃ.
analyzed: ekacce garavaḥ pana abravum
translated: Some say it is a designation, but others say it is a term of respect.

original: Kura sadde akkose ca. Kurati. Kuraro, kurarī. Kummo, kummī.
analyzed: kura sadde akkose ca kurati kuraraḥ kurarī kummaḥ kummī
translated: Kura is a sound, and a scolding. It cuts: kurati. A curlew: kuraro, kurarī. A crab: kummo, kummī.

original: Khura chedane vilekhane ca. Khurati. Khuro.
analyzed: khura chedane vilekhane ca khurati khuro
translated: Khura is a cutting, and a scratching. It cuts: khurati. A hoof: khuro.

original: Mura saṃveṭhane. Murati. Muro, moro.
analyzed: saṃveṭhane murati muraḥ moro
translated: Mura is a rolling. It rolls: murati. A lump: muro, moro.

original: Ghura abhimatta saddesu. Ghurati. Ghoro.
analyzed: ghura abhimatta saddesu ghurati ghoro
translated: Ghura is a loud sound. It sounds: ghurati. A deep sound: ghoro.

original: Pura aggagamane. Aggagamanaṃ nāma padhānagamanaṃ, paṭhamameva gamanaṃ vā. Purati. Puraṃ, purī. Avāpurati. Avāpuretaṃ amatassa dvāraṃ. Avāpuraṇaṃ ādāya gacchati.
analyzed: pura aggagamane aggagamanam nāma padhāna gamanam paṭhamam eva gamanam vā purati puram purī avāpurati avāpuretam amatassa dvāram avāpuraṇam ādāya gacchati
translated: In front, in the van: the van is the leading, or the going in front. It puris. A city is puris. They avāpuris. This is the door to the deathless. He goes taking the avāpuris.

original: Tattha puranti rājadhānī. Tathā hi “nagaraṃ puraṃ purī rājadhānī”ti ete pariyāyā.
analyzed: tattha rājadhānī tathā hi nagaram puram purī rājadhānī iti ete pariyāyā
translated: Herein, a capital city is puris. For these are synonyms: “city, town, capital city, royal city.”

original: “Eso āḷāriko poso, kumārī puramantare”tiādīsu pana gehaṃ “pura”nti vuccati. Padhānatāya
analyzed: eso āḷāriko poso kumārī puram antarā iti ādīsu pana geham puranti vuccati padhāna tāya
translated: But in such passages as “This man of Alara, the young girl in the city” (Sn 1051), a house is called “city.”🔽It is puris because it is to be gone to in front, in front, by reason of pre-eminence.

original: purato purato gamanena gantabbanti puraṃ, rājadhānī ceva gehañca. Avāpuraṇanti avāpuranti
analyzed: puratas puratas gamanena gantabbanti puram rājadhānī ca iva geham ca avāpuraṇanti avāpuranti
translated: It is puris, a capital city and a house, because it is avāpuris.🔽The avāpuris is the means by which they avāpuris, that is, open, the door. It is what is called a “key” and a “lock.”

original: vivaranti dvāraṃ etenāti avāpuraṇaṃ, yaṃ “kuñcikā”tipi “tāḷo”tipi vuccati. Avāpuratītiādīsu
analyzed: dvāram etena ati avāpuraṇam yam vuccati avāpurati iti ādīsu
translated: In the words avāpuris, etc.,

original: ava āiccubho upasaggāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: avaḥ ā it cubhaḥ upasaggā iti daṭṭhabbā
translated: ava is a prefix and āiccubho is the verbal base.

original: Phara pharaṇe. Pharaṇaṃ nāma byāpanaṃ gamanaṃ vā. Samaṃ pharati sītena. Āhāratthaṃ pharati. Pharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: pharaṇe pharaṇam nāma byāpanam gamanam vā samam pharati sītena āhāra attham pharati pharaṇam
translated: Phara, in the sense of spreading: spreading is the covering or going over. He pharas evenly with the cold. He pharas for the sake of food. The phara.

original: Gara uggame. Garati. Garu.
analyzed: garaḥ uggame garati garu
translated: Gara, in the sense of rising: it garas. It is garu.

original: Garūti mātāpitādayo gāravayuttapuggalā. Te hi garanti uggacchanti uggatā pākaṭā hontīti
analyzed: mātā pitā ādayaḥ gārava yutta puggalā te hi garanti uggacchanti uggatā pākaṭāḥ honti iti
translated: The “venerable” are one’s parents, etc., who are persons worthy of respect. For they are called “venerable” because they are “venerated” , because they are “risen above” , because they are “risen up” and “become manifest” .

original: garūti vuccanti. Apica pāsāṇacchattaṃ viya bhāriyaṭṭhena garūti vuccanti. Garusaddo
analyzed: garū ti vuccanti apica pāsāṇa chattam viya bhāriya ṭṭhena garu ti vuccanti garu saddo
translated: Besides, they are called “venerable” in the sense of being “heavy” , like a stone umbrella. The word “venerable”

original: “idamāsanaṃ atra bhavaṃ nisīdatu, bhavañhi me aññataro garūna”nti ettha mātāpitūsu
analyzed: idam āsanam atra bhavam nisīdatu bhavan hi me aññataraḥ ettha mātā pitūsu
translated: is found in such passages as “This seat, sir, is for the venerable one. The venerable one may sit down” , where it refers to parents,

original: dissati. “Sanarāmaralokagaru”nti ettha sabbalokācariye sabbaññumhi. Apica garusaddo
analyzed: dissati sa nara amara loka garun ti ettha sabba loka ācariye sabbaññumhi api ca garu saddo
translated: and in such passages as “Honoured of gods and men” , where it refers to the omniscient one, the teacher of the whole world. Besides,

original: aññesvatthesupi dissati. Sabbametaṃ ekato katvā atridaṃ vuccati –🔽Mātāpitācariyesu, dujjare alahumhi ca;
analyzed: aññesu atthesu pi dissati sabbam etam ekatas katvā atri idam vuccati  mātā pitā cariyesu dujjare a lahumhi ca
translated: the word “venerable” is found in other senses as well. Taking all these together, it is said:🔽With parents, teachers, and the like,🔽With the difficult-to-tame, and with the lowly,

original: Mahante cuggate ceva, nichekādikaresu ca;
analyzed: mahante cuggate ca iva nicheka ādi karesu ca
translated: With the great, the risen, and the risen up,🔽With the lowly, and so on, it occurs.

original: Tathā vaṇṇavisesesu, garusaddo pavattati.
analyzed: tathā vaṇṇa visesesu garu saddo pavattati
translated: And with the different kinds of colours.

original: Keci panācariyā “garu garū”ti ca dvidhā gahetvā bhāriyavācakatte garusaddo ṭhito.
analyzed: keci pana ācariyāḥ garu ca dvidhā gahetvā bhāriya vācaka tte garu saddo ṭhitaḥ
translated: But some teachers, taking “venerable” in two ways as “heavy” and “venerable,” say that the word “venerable” is used in the sense of “heavy,”

original: Ācariyavācakatte pana gurusaddoti vadanti, taṃ na gahetabbaṃ. Pāḷivisaye hi sabbesampi
analyzed: ācariya vācaka tte pana guru saddo ti vadanti tam na gahetabbam pāḷi visaye hi sabbesam pi
translated: and that the word “venerable” is used in the sense of “teacher.” But that should not be accepted. For in the Pali language

original: yathāvuttānaṃ atthānaṃ vācakatte garusaddoyeva icchitabbo, akārassa ākārabhāve “gārava”nti🔽savuddhikassa taddhitantapadassa dassanato. Sakkaṭabhāsāvisaye pana gurusaddoyeva
analyzed: yathāvuttānam atthānam vācaka tte garu saddaḥ yā iva icchitabbaḥ akārassa ākāra bhāve  sa vuddhikassa taddhi tanta padassa dassanato sakkaṭa bhāsā visaye pana guru saddaḥ yeva
translated: The word “heavy” is to be desired for the denotation of the meanings stated, because of the showing of the word ending in -tva as having increase by the vowel a in “gārava” .🔽But in the language of the Sakkas the word “great” is to be desired,

original: icchitabbo, ukārassa vuddhibhāve aññathā taddhitantapadassa dassanato.
analyzed: icchitabbaḥ ukārassa vuddhi bhāve aññathā taddhi tanta padassa dassanato
translated: because of the showing of the word ending in -tva as having increase by the vowel u in “guru” .

original: Mara pāṇacāge. Marati. Mattuṃ. Maritvā. Hetukattari “puriso purisaṃ māreti, mārayati.
analyzed: mara marati mattum maritvā hetu kattari purisaḥ purisam māreti mārayati
translated: Mara, pāṇacāge. Marati. Mattuṃ. Maritvā. Hetukattari “puriso purisaṃ māreti, mārayati.

original: Puriso purisena purisaṃ mārāpeti, mārāpayati. Puriso purisaṃ māretuṃ māretvā” iccādīni
analyzed: purisaḥ purisena purisam mārāpeti mārāpayati purisaḥ purisam māretum māretvā icca ādīni
translated: Puriso purisena purisaṃ mārāpeti, mārāpayati. Puriso purisaṃ māretuṃ māretvā” iccādīni

original: rūpāni. Macco. Maru. Maraṇaṃ, maccu. Maṭṭu. Māro.
analyzed: rūpāni macco maru maraṇam maccu maṭṭu māro
translated: rūpāni. Macco. Maru. Maraṇaṃ, maccu. Maṭṭhu. Māro.

original: Tattha mattunti marituṃ. Tathā hi alīnasattujātake “yo mattumicche pituno pamokkhā”ti🔽pāḷi dissati. Maccoti maritabbasabhāvatāya “macco”ti laddhanāmo satto. Marūti dīghāyukopi
analyzed: tattha mattum ti maritum tathā hi alīna sattu jātake yaḥ mattum icche pitunā  dissati macco ti maritabba sabhāva tāya macco ti laddha nāmo satto marūti dīgha āyukaḥ api
translated: There mattanti marituṃ . Thus in the Alīnasattu Jātaka: “Yo mattumicche pituno pamokkhā” .

original: samāno maraṇasīloti maru, devo. Maraṇanti cuti.
analyzed: samānaḥ devaḥ
translated: Macco: a being who has received the name “macco” because of the state of being liable to death. Maru: though long-lived, he is “maru” , a god, because of the habit of dying. Maraṇaṃ: death.

original: Maraṇaṃ antako maccu, hindaṃ kālo ca maṭṭu ca;🔽Nikkhepo cuti cetāni, nāmāni maraṇassa ve.🔽Māroti sattānaṃ kusalaṃ māretīti māro, kāmadevo.🔽Imānissa nāmāni –
analyzed: maraṇam antakaḥ kālo ca ca  nikkhepaḥ cuti cetāni nāmāni maraṇassa ve  sattānam kusalam māreti iti māraḥ kāmadevaḥ  imāni issa nāmāni
translated: Death, the Ender, the Destroyer,🔽The Terminator, the Annihilator,🔽These are the names of Death, indeed.🔽Mara is so called because he kills beings’ wholesome thoughts. He is a god of the sense-sphere.🔽These are his names:

original: Māro namuci kaṇho ca, vasavatti pajāpati;🔽Pamattabandhu maddano, pāpimā dabbakopi ca;🔽Kandappo ca ratipati, kāmo ca kusumāyudho.🔽Aññe aññānipi nāmāni vadanti, tāni sāsanānulomāni na hontīti idha na dassitāni. Aṭṭhakathāsu pana “māro, namuci, kaṇho, pamattabandhū”ti cattārova nāmāni āgatāni.🔽Ettha ca māroti devaputtamārena saddhiṃ pañca mārā kilesamāro khandhamāro abhisaṅkhāramāro maccumāro devaputtamāroti.🔽Dhara avatthāne. Dharati.🔽Bhara posane. Bharati. Bharito, bhattā.🔽Thara santharaṇe. Tharati, santharati. Santharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: māraḥ namuci kaṇhaḥ ca vasavatti pajāpati 🔽pamattabandhu maddanaḥ pāpimā dabbakaḥ api ca 🔽kandappaḥ ca ratipati kāmaḥ ca kusumāyudhaḥ 🔽aññe aññāni api nāmāni vadanti tāni sāsana anulomāni na honti iti idha na dassitāni aṭṭhakathāsu pana māraḥ namuci kaṇhaḥ pamattabandhu iti cattāro va nāmāni āgatāni 🔽ettha ca māro ti devaputta mārena saddhim pañca mārā kilesa māraḥ khandha māraḥ abhisaṅkhāra māraḥ maccu māraḥ devaputta māro ti 🔽dhara avatthāne dharati 🔽bhara posane bharati bharitaḥ bhattā 🔽thara santharaṇe tharati santharati santharaṇam

original: Dara vidāraṇe. Bhūmiṃ darati. Kudālo.
analyzed: dara vidāraṇe bhūmim darati kudālo
translated: The root dar means to pierce; the plough pierces the ground; hence kudālo, a plough.

original: Dara dāhe. Kāyo darati. Daro, daratho.
analyzed: dāhe kāyaḥ darati daraḥ
translated: The root dar means to burn; the body burns; hence dāru, a body, and daratho, a carriage.

original: Tira adhogatiyaṃ. Tirati. Tiracchāno, tiracchā vā.
analyzed: tira adhogatiyam tirati tiracchāno tiracchā vā
translated: The root tir means to go downwards; hence tiracchāno, an animal, and tiracchā vā, animal-wise.

original: Ara gatiyaṃ. Arati. Atthaṃ, attho, utu.
analyzed: ara gatiyam arati attham attho utu
translated: The root ar means to go; hence atthaṃ, the meaning, and attho, a meaning, and utu, a season.

original: Ettha atthaṃ vuccati nibbānaṃ. Taṃ taṃ sattakiccaṃ arati vattetīti utu.🔽Rakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: ettha attham vuccati nibbānam tam tam satta kiccam arati vatteti iti utu  rakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: Herein, nibbāna is called atthaṃ, the meaning; it is what is to be gone by each one for his own benefit, thus it is utu.🔽The roots rak, kaṃ, and ru mean to colour.

original: Lakārantadhātu
analyzed: lakāra anta dhātu
translated: The root lak means to colour.

analyzed: ādāne lāti lānam garuḷaḥ sīhaḷaḥ rāhulaḥ kusalam bālaḥ mahallakaḥ mahallikā  tatra garuḍaḥ iti garum ādadāti gaṇhāti iti garuḍaḥ supaṇṇaḥ dija adhipaḥ

original: karoṭī”ti ca vuccati. Sīhaḷoti sīhaṃ lāti ādadāti gaṇhātīti sīhaḷo, pubbapuriso.

translated: Sīhaḷo is one who takes a lion, who takes, seizes, a lion; hence sīhaḷo is a man of the island of Tambapaṇṇi.

original: Tabbaṃse jātā etarahi sabbepi sīhaḷā nāma jātā.

translated: As regards rāhulo, etc., rāhulo is one who takes like Rāhu, who seizes like Rāhu; who is that? The venerable Rāhulabhaddanta, who desires training.

translated: While the Bodhisattvas were playing in the park, the Bodhisattvas heard this and said: “Rahu has been born, and bondage has been born.”

original: ca saṅkhalikādibandhanena bandhaṃ viya hoti muccituṃ appadānatoti “rāhu jāto bandhanaṃ🔽jāta”nti āha. Rājā “kiṃ me putto avacā”ti pucchitvā taṃ vacanaṃ sutvā “ito paṭṭhāya

analyzed: bila patitthambhe bilati
translated: Bila means “to stand” . Bilati.

original: Nīla vaṇṇe. Nīlavatthaṃ.
analyzed: nīla vaṇṇe nīlavattham
translated: Nīla means “colour” . Nīlavatthaṃ .

original: Sīla samādhimhi. Sīlati. Sīlaṃ, sīlanaṃ.
analyzed: sīla samādhimhi sīlati sīlam sīlanam
translated: Sīla means “concentration” . Sīlati. Sīlaṃ, sīlanaṃ .

original: Ettha sīlanti sīlanaṭṭhena sīlaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ visuddhimagge “sīlanti kenaṭṭhena sīlaṃ?
analyzed: ettha sīlanti sīlana aṭṭhena sīlam vuttam ha etam visuddhi magge sīlanti kena aṭṭhena sīlam
translated: Herein, sīla is so called because of the characteristic of sīlana . For this is said in the Visuddhimagga: “What is the characteristic of sīla?

original: Sīlanaṭṭhena sīlaṃ, kimidaṃ sīlanaṃ nāma? Samādhānaṃ vā kāyakammādīnaṃ susīlyavasena
analyzed: sīlana ṭṭhena sīlam kim idam sīlanam nāma samādhānam vā kāya kamma ādīnam susīlya vasena
translated: Sīla is so called because of the characteristic of sīlana . What is this sīlana? It is the state of being well-ordered of bodily action, etc., by means of concentration,

original: avippakiṇṇatāti attho. Upadhāraṇaṃ vā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ patiṭṭhānavasena ādhārabhāvoti
analyzed: a vippakiṇṇa tā ti attho upadhāraṇam vā kusalānam dhammānam patiṭṭhāna vasena ādhāra bhāvaḥ ti
translated: or it is the state of being unscattered. Or it is the state of being a support by means of being a foundation for profitable ideas.

original: attho. Etadeva hi ettha atthadvayaṃ saddalakkhaṇavidū anujānanti. Aññe pana ‘siraṭṭho
analyzed: attho etat eva hi ettha attha dvayam sadda lakkhaṇa vidū anujānanti aññe pana siraṭṭho
translated: This is the meaning. For those who know the characteristics of the word “sīla” allow only these two meanings. But others explain the meaning here in this way: “The meaning of ‘head’ (si-ra),

original: sīlaṭṭho, sītalaṭṭho sīlaṭṭho’ti evamādinā nayenettha atthaṃ vaṇṇentī”ti. Tattha🔽“atthadvayaṃ saddalakkhaṇa vidū anujānantī”ti idaṃ “sīla samādhimhi sīla upadhāraṇe”ti
analyzed: sīlaṭṭhaḥ sītalaṭṭhaḥ sīlaṭṭhaḥ iti evamādinā nayena ittha attham vaṇṇenti iti tattha  attha dvayam sadda lakkhaṇa vidū anujānanti iti idam sīla samādhimhi sīla upadhāraṇā iti
translated: the meaning of ‘virtue’ (sīla), the meaning of ‘cool’ (sītala), the meaning of ‘virtue’ (sīla),” and so on. Herein,🔽“Those who know the characteristics of the word ‘sīla’ allow only these two meanings,” this is said with reference to the meaning of the sīla-element in the dyad “sīla and concentration,”

original: dvigaṇikassa sīladhātussa atthe sandhāya vuttaṃ. Imassa hi curādigaṇaṃ pattassa upadhāraṇe
analyzed: dvigaṇikassa sīla dhātussa atthe sandhāya vuttam imassa hi curādi gaṇam pattassa upadhāraṇe
translated: for one who has reached the stage of the curu-group, etc., in the recollection

original: “sīleti, sīlayatī”ti rūpāni bhavanti, upadhāretītipi tesaṃ attho. Idha pana bhūvādigaṇikattā
analyzed: sīleti sīlayati iti rūpāni bhavanti tesam atthaḥ idha pana
translated: “Sīla means it causes to be cool (sīlayati),” forms are produced, and the meaning of those is “it causes to be recollected.” But here, because of the bhū-group, etc.,

original: samādhānatthe “sīlatī”ti rūpaṃ bhavati, samādhiyatīti tassa attho. Punapi ettha sotūnaṃ
analyzed: samādhāna atthe sīlati iti rūpam bhavati samādhiyati iti tassa atthaḥ punapi ettha sotūnam
translated: the form “sīla means it causes to be concentrated (samādhāyati),” occurs in the sense of concentration, and the meaning of that is “it causes to be concentrated.” Again, here, in order to facilitate the understanding of the listeners,

original: sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ nibbacanāni vuccante. Sīlati samādhiyati kāyakammādīnaṃ susīlyavasena
analyzed: sukha ggahaṇa attham nibbacanāni vuccante sīlati kāya kamma ādīnam susīlya vasena
translated: the etymologies are stated. “Sīla means it causes to be concentrated (samādhāyati) by means of good virtue in bodily action, etc.,

original: na vippakiratīti sīlaṃ. Atha vā sīlanti samādahanti cittaṃ etenāti sīlaṃ. Imāni bhūvādigaṇikavasena
analyzed: na vippakirati iti sīlam atha vā sīlanti samādahanti cittam etena ati sīlam imāni bhūvādi gaṇika vasena
translated: It does not scatter: thus it is virtue . Or alternatively, it is virtue in the sense of it is virtuous , in the sense of it is virtuous that the mind is steadied by this . These are the etymologies according to the method of the Bhūvādi class.

original: nibbacanāni. Curādigaṇikavasena pana sīleti kusale dhamme upadhāreti patiṭṭhābhāvena
analyzed: nibbacanāni curādi gaṇika vasena pana sīleti kusale dhamme upadhāreti patiṭṭhā bhāvena
translated: But according to the method of the Curu class, it is virtue in the sense of it is virtuous that it holds firmly , in the sense of it is virtuous that it holds firmly by becoming the support for profitable ideas.

original: bhuso dhāretīti sīlaṃ. Sīlenti vā etena kusale dhamme upadhārenti bhuso dhārenti
analyzed: bhusaḥ dhāreti iti sīlam sīlenti vai etena kusale dhamme upadhārenti bhusaḥ dhārenti
translated: Or alternatively, it is virtue in the sense of it is virtuous that it holds firmly , in the sense of the virtuous hold firmly by this .

original: sādhavoti sīlanti nibbacanāni.
analyzed: sādhavaḥ ti nibbacanāni
translated: These are the etymologies.

original: Kila bandhe. Kilati. Kilaṃ.
analyzed: kila bandhe kilati kilam
translated: Kila means to bind. It binds: kilaṃ .

original: Kūla āvaraṇe. Kulati. Kūlaṃ. Vahe rukkhe pakūlaje. Kūlaṃ bandhati. Nadīkūle vasāmahaṃ. Kūlati āvarati udakaṃ bahi nikkhamituṃ na detīti kūlaṃ.
analyzed: kūle āvaraṇe kulati kūlam vahe rukkhe pa kūla je kūlam bandhati nadī kūle vasāmaham kūlati āvarati udakam bahi nikkhamitum na deti iti kūlam
translated: Kūla means a covering. It covers: kūlaṃ . A tree outside is called a kūla . It binds the kūla : I live on the river bank . The water covers and does not allow it to go out: thus kūla is a bank .

original: Sūla rujāyaṃ. Sūlati. Sūlaṃ. Kaṇṇasūlaṃ na janeti.
analyzed: sūla rujā ayam sūlati sūlam kaṇṇa sūlam na janeti
translated: Sūla means pain. It pains: sūlaṃ . It does not cause earache.

original: Tūla nikkarīse. Nikkarīsaṃ nāma karīsamattenapi aminetabbato lahubhāvoyeva. Tūlati. Tūlaṃ bhaṭṭhaṃva māluto.
analyzed: tūla nikkarīse nikkarīsam nāma karīsa mattena api tūlati tūlam
translated: Tūla means cotton fluff. Cotton fluff is called tūla because it cannot be weighed even by as much as a grain, being so light. It fluffs: tūlaṃ . The cotton fluff is like a bird: māluto .

original: Pula saṅghāte. Pulati. Pañcapuli.
analyzed: pula saṅghāte pulati pañcapuli
translated: Pula means to gather. It gathers: puli . Five puli.

original: Mūla patiṭṭhāyaṃ mūlati. Mūlaṃ. Mūlasaddo “mūlāni uddhareyya antamaso ussīranāḷimattānipī”tiādīsu
analyzed: mūla mūlati mūlam mūla saddaḥ mūlāni uddhareyya antamasaḥ
translated: The root in the root-base. The root. The word “root” is found in the sense of root-root in such passages as “He should pull out the roots, even to the tips of the grass blades” ,

original: mūlamūle dissati. “Lobho akusalamūla”ntiādīsu asādhāraṇahetumhi. “Yāvamajjhanhike
analyzed: mūla mūle dissati lobhaḥ akusala mūlam ti ādīsu asādhāraṇa hetumhi yāvamajjhanhike
translated: in the sense of uncommon cause in such passages as “Greed is an unwholesome root” ,

original: kāle chāyā pharati, nivāte paṇṇāni patanti, ettāvatā rukkhamūla”ntiādīsu samīpe. Atridaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: kāle chāyā pharati nivāte paṇṇāni patanti ettāvatā rukkha mūla nti ādīsu samīpe atridam vuccati
translated: and in the sense of vicinity in such passages as “When the shadow of the mountain has gone a yoke’s length, when the leaves of the trees have stopped stirring, then the root of the tree is the place” . Herein,

original: Mūlamūle mūlasaddo, padissati tatheva ca;
analyzed: mūla mūle mūla saddo padissati tathā iva ca
translated: The word “root” is found in the sense of root-root,

original: Asādhāraṇahetumhi, samīpamhi ca vattati.🔽Phala nibbattiyaṃ. Rukkho phalati. Rukkhaphalāni bhuñjantā. Mahapphalaṃ mahānisaṃsaṃ. Sotāpattiphalaṃ. Tattha phalanti mahānibbattikaṃ.
analyzed: asādhāraṇa hetumhi samīpamhi ca vattati  nibbattiyam rukkhaḥ phalati rukkha phalāni bhuñjantā mahapphalam mahā nisaṃsam sotāpatti phalam tattha phalanti mahā nibbattikam
translated: And also in the sense of uncommon cause, And in the sense of vicinity.🔽In the sense of fruit-production. The tree bears fruit. They eat the tree’s fruit. It has great fruit, great advantages. The fruit of stream-entry. There they bear fruit, the great rebirth.

original: Phala bhede. Phalati. Muddhā te phalatu sattadhā. Pādā phaliṃsu. Tattha phalatūti bhajjitu.
analyzed: phala bhede phalati muddhā te phalatu sattadhā pādā phaliṃsu tattha phalatu uti bhajjitu
translated: In the sense of a class of fruit. It bears fruit. May your head split into seven pieces. His feet were split. There “may it split” means “may it break up.”

original: Phala abyattasadde. Asanī phalati. Dveme bhikkhave asaniyā phalantiyā na santasanti. Phalantiyāti saddaṃ karontiyā.🔽Culla hāvakaraṇe. Hāvakaraṇaṃ vilāsakaraṇaṃ. Cullati.🔽Phulla vikasanabhedesu. Phullati. Phullaṃ. Phullito kiṃsuko. Suphullitamaravindavanaṃ.
analyzed: abyatta sadde asanī phalati dve me bhikkhave asaniyā phalantiyā na santasanti phalantiyā ati saddam karontiyā  culla hāva karaṇe hāva karaṇam vilāsa karaṇam cullati  vikasana bhedesu phullati phullam kiṃsukaḥ su phullitam aravinda vanam
translated: In the sense of fruit that is not ripe: “The lightning flashes.”🔽In the sense of a small making: “The making is small.”🔽In the sense of blossoming and bursting open: “It blossoms,” “blossomed,” “the kiṃsuka tree is in blossom,” “the lotus grove is in full blossom.”🔽

original: Asītihatthamubbedho, dīpaṅkaro mahāmuni;🔽Sobhati dīparukkhova, sālarājāva phullito.🔽Khaṇḍaphullapaṭisaṅkharaṇaṃ.🔽Cilla seṭhille. Siṭhilabhāvo seṭhillaṃ. Cillati.🔽Velu celu kelu khelu pelu belu selu sala tila gatiyaṃ. Velati. Celati. Kelati. Khelati. Pelati. Belati. Selati. Salati. Tilati. Celaṃ, belako. Ettha celanti vatthaṃ. Pelakoti saso.🔽Khala calane. Khalati. Khalo. Khaloti dujjano asādhu asappuriso pāpajano.
analyzed: asīti hattham ubbedhaḥ dīpaṅkaraḥ mahā muni 🔽sobhati dīpa rukkhaḥ uva sālarājā ava phullitaḥ 🔽khaṇḍa phulla paṭisaṅkharaṇam 🔽cilla seṭhille siṭhila bhāvaḥ seṭhillam cillati 🔽velu celu kelu khelu pelu belu selu sala tila gatiyam velati celati kelati khelati pelati belati selati salati tilati celam belako ettha celanti vattham saso 🔽khala calane khalati khalaḥ khalo ti dujjanaḥ asādhu asappurisaḥ pāpa janaḥ
