original: Khala sañcinane. Khalati. Khalaṃ. Khalanti vīhiṭṭhapanokāsabhūtaṃ bhūmimaṇḍalaṃ.
analyzed: sañcinane khalati khalam khalanti bhūmi maṇḍalam
translated: In a threshing-floor. It threshes. A threshing-floor. They thresh. It is a place for threshing rice.

original: Tañhi khalanti sañcinanti rāsiṃ karonti ettha dhaññānīti khalanti vuccati. “Khalaṃ🔽sālaṃ pasuṃ khettaṃ, gantā cassa abhikkhaṇa”nti payogo.
analyzed: tat hi khalanti sañcinanti rāsim karonti ettha dhaññāni iti khalanti vuccati khalam  sālam pasum khettam gantā ca assa payogo
translated: In the sense of heaping up, as in “The threshing-floor” . It is threshed there, thus it is a threshing-floor ; it is a threshing-floor because they thresh, that is, heap up, grain there. The construction is: “The threshing-floor, the hall, the cattle shed, the field, he goes to them, he threshes them” .

original: Gila ajjhoharaṇe. Gilati. Gilamakkhaṃ puriso na bujjhati.🔽Gala adane. Galati. Galo. Galanti adanti ajjhoharanti etenāti galo. Galoti gīvā vuccati.
analyzed: ajjhoharaṇe gilati gilamakkham purisaḥ na bujjhati  gala adane galati galaḥ galanti adanti ajjhoharanti etena ati galaḥ galo ti gīvā vuccati
translated: In the sense of swallowing, as in “He swallows” . A man does not understand the swallowing of a morsel.🔽In the sense of eating, as in “He eats” . He eats, thus it is a mouth ; it is a mouth because they eat, that is, swallow, with it. The word “throat” is said to be a synonym for “mouth” .

original: Sala salla āsugatiyaṃ. Āsugati sīghagamanaṃ. Salati. Sallati. Sallaṃ. Ettha ca “sallaṃ usu saro sallo kaṇḍo tejano”ti pariyāyā ete.
analyzed: sala sallaḥ āsugatiyam āsugati sīgha gamanam salati sallati sallam ettha ca sallam usu saraḥ sallo kaṇḍo tejano ti pariyāyāḥ ete
translated: In the sense of going quickly, as in “He goes quickly” . Going quickly is swift going. He goes quickly, thus it is a road ; it is a road because they go quickly on it. And here the following are synonyms: road, path, track, way, thoroughfare.

original: Khola gatipaṭighāte. Kholati.
analyzed: khola gati paṭighāte kholati
translated: In the sense of obstructing going, as in “It obstructs” .

original: Gile pītikkhaye. Gilāyati. Gilāno, gelaññaṃ. Gilānoti akallako. Vinayepi hi vuttaṃ “nāhaṃ akallako”ti. Aṭṭhakathāyañca “nāhaṃ akallakoti nāhaṃ gilāno”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: gile pīti khaye gilāyati gilānaḥ gelaññam gilānoti akallakaḥ vinaye pi hi vuttam na aham akallako ti aṭṭhakathāyam ca na aham akallako ti na aham gilānoti vuttam
translated: In the sense of the exhaustion of rapture, as in “He is afflicted” . He is afflicted, thus he is afflicted; he is afflicted, thus he is sick; he is afflicted, thus he is ill. For in the Vinaya-Piṭaka it is said, “I am not afflicted” , and in the Commentary to that it is said, “I am not afflicted” means “I am not sick” .

original: Mile gattavināme. Milāyati. Milāyano, milāyanto, milāyamāno.🔽Kele mamāyane. Mamāyanaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhivasena “mama ida”nti gahaṇaṃ. Kelāyati. Tvaṃ kaṃ kelāyati.
analyzed: mile gatta vināme milāyati milāyanaḥ milāyantaḥ milāyamānaḥ  kele mama ayane mama ayanam taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena mama kelāyati tvam kam kelāyati
translated: Milāyati, milāyano, milāyanto, milāyamāno.🔽Kelāyati, kelāyati, kelāyanti, kelāyase, kelāyavhe, kelāyavha, kelāyāma, kelāyāmhe, kelāyāmha.

original: Sala calane saṃvaraṇe ca, vala valla calane ca. Saṃvaraṇāpekkhāyaṃ cakāro. Salati. Kusalaṃ. Valati. Vallati. Vallūro.
analyzed: calane saṃvaraṇe ca vala valla calane ca saṃvaraṇa apekkhā ayam salati kusalam valati vallati vallūro
translated: Salati, kusalaṃ, valati, vallati, vallūro.

original: Tattha kusalanti kucchite pāpadhamme salayati calayati kampeti viddhaṃsetīti kusalaṃ.
analyzed: tattha kusalanti kucchite pāpa dhamme salayati calayati kampeti viddhaṃseti iti kusalam
translated: Herein, kusala means that which shakes off , moves, agitates, and destroys evil states that are collected together.

original: Kucchitaṃ apāyadvāraṃ salanti saṃvaranti pidahanti sādhavo etenāti kusalaṃ. Vallanti
analyzed: kucchitam apāya dvāram salanti saṃvaranti pidahanti sādhavaḥ etena ati kusalam vallanti
translated: Or alternatively, the good shake off , restrain, and block the door to the states of loss; thus it is kusala.

original: saṃvaranti rakkhanti ito kākasenādayo satte akhādanatthāyāti vallūro.
analyzed: saṃvaranti rakkhanti itas kākasena ādayo satte a khādana tthāya ati vallūro
translated: The crow-army and so on shake off , restrain, and guard beings from being eaten; thus it is a crow-army .

original: Mala malla dhāraṇe. Malati. Malaṃ. Mallati. Mallo.
analyzed: mala malla dhāraṇe malati malam mallati mallo
translated: Malati, malaṃ, mallati, mallo.

original: Bhala bhalla paribhāsanahiṃsādānesu. Bhalati. Bhallati.
analyzed: bhala bhalla paribhāsana hiṃsā dānesu bhalati bhallati
translated: Bhalati, bhallati.

original: Kala saṅkhyāne. Kalati. Kalā, kālo.
analyzed: kala saṅkhyāne kalati kalā kālo
translated: Kalati, kalā, kālo.

original: Ettha kalāti soḷasabhāgādibhāgo. Kāloti “ettako atkkanto”tiādinā kalitabbo saṅkhātabboti kālo, pubbaṇhādisamayo.
analyzed: ettha kalā ati soḷasa bhāga ādi bhāgo kālo ti ettako atkkanto iti ādinā kalitabbo saṅkhātabbo iti kālo pubbaṇha ādi samayo
translated: Herein, kal is a part consisting of sixteen parts, etc. Kāla is what should be reckoned, calculated, as to how much has elapsed, etc.; it is the time, morning, etc.

original: Kalla asadde. Asaddo. Nissaddo. Kallati.
analyzed: kalla asadde asaddaḥ nissaddaḥ kallati
translated: Kalla is in the sense of “no sound.” Asaddo. Nissaddo. Kallati.

original: Jala dittiyaṃ. Jalati. Jalaṃ, jalanto, pajjalanto, jalamāno.
analyzed: dittiyam jalati jalam jalantaḥ pajjalantaḥ jalamānaḥ
translated: Jala is in the sense of “seeing.” Jalati. Jalaṃ, jalanto, pajjalanto, jalamāno.

original: Ko eti siriyā jalaṃ. Jalaṃva yasasā aṭṭhā, devadattoti me sutaṃ. Saddhammapajjoto jalito.
analyzed: kaḥ eti siriyā jalam jalaṃva yasasā devadatto ti me sutam saddhamma pajjotaḥ jalito
translated: Ko eti siriyā jalaṃ. Jalaṃva yasasā aṭṭhā, devadattoti me sutaṃ. Saddhammapajjoto jalito.

original: Hula calane. Hulati. Halo. Haloti phālo, so hi holeti bhūmiṃ bhindanto mattikakhaṇḍaṃ cāletīti “halo”ti vuccati ukārassa akāraṃ katvā.
analyzed: calane so hi holeti bhūmim bhindantaḥ mattika khaṇḍam cāleti iti halo ti vuccati ukārassa akāram katvā
translated: Hula is in the sense of “moving.” Hulati. Halo. Halo is a plough, for it is said that it is called “halo” because it “holes” the ground, that is, moves the clods of earth, the o being elided.

original: Cala kampane. Calati. Calito, acalo. Mahanto bhūmicālo. Calanaṃ, cālo.
analyzed: kampane calati calitaḥ acalaḥ mahantaḥ calanam cālo
translated: Cala is in the sense of “shaking.” Calati. Calito, acalo. Mahā bhūmicālo. Calanaṃ, cālo.

original: Jala dhaññe. Jalati. Jalaṃ.
analyzed: jala dhaññe jalati jalaṃ
translated: Jala is in the sense of “grain.” Jalati. Jalaṃ.

original: Ṭala ṭula velambe. Ṭalati. Ṭulati.
analyzed: velambe ṭalati ṭulati
translated: Ṭala is in the sense of “a rope for tying an elephant’s tusk.” Ṭalati. Ṭulati.

original: Thala ṭhāne. Thalati. Thalo. Thaloti nirudakappadeso. Pabbajjānibbānesupi taṃsadisattā
analyzed: ṭhāne thalati thalo thalo iti nirudaka ppadesaḥ pabbajja a nibbānesu pi
translated: Thala is in the sense of “standing.” Thalati. Thalo. Thalo is a place without water. It is so called because it is similar to the state of going forth and to Nibbāna.

original: tabbohāro. Yathā hi loke udakoghena anottharaṇaṭṭhānaṃ “thalo”ti vuccati, evaṃ kilesoghena
analyzed: tad bohāraḥ yathā hi loke udaka oghena an uttharaṇa ṭṭhānam thalo ti vuccati evam kilesa oghena
translated: and that is the derivation. For just as in the ordinary usage what is not flooded by a flood of water is called “dry land” , so too, because of the unflooding by the flood of defilements,

original: anottharaṇīyattā pabbajjā nibbānañca “thalo”ti vuccati, “tiṇṇo pāraṅgato thale tiṭṭhati
analyzed: an uttharaṇīya ttā pabbajjā nibbānam ca thalo ti vuccati pāraṅgato thale tiṭṭhati
translated: going forth and Nibbāna are called “dry land” . For this is said: “He has crossed to the further shore, he stands on the dry land,

original: brāhmaṇo”ti hi vuttaṃ.🔽Phāla vilekhane. Phālati bhūmiṃ vilekhati bhindatīti phālo.
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ iti hi vuttam  vilekhane phālati bhūmim vilekhati bhindati iti
translated: he is a brāhmaṇa” .🔽The plough is the implement for ploughing the earth, for cutting it up.

original: Nala ganthe. Nalati.
analyzed: nala ganthe nalati
translated: The reed is the implement for binding grass, etc., together.

original: Bala pāṇane. Iha pāṇanaṃ jīvanaṃ sasanañca. Balati. Balaṃ, bālo.🔽Ettha balanti jīvitaṃ kappenti etenāti balaṃ, kāyabalabhogabalādikaṃ balaṃ. Atha🔽vā balanti sammājīvanaṃ jīvanti etenāti balaṃ, saddhādikaṃ balaṃ. Āgamaṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽pana “assaddhiye na kampatīti saddhābala”ntiādi vuttaṃ, taṃ daḷhaṭṭhena balanti vattabbānaṃ
analyzed: bala pāṇane iha pāṇanam jīvanam sasanam ca balati balam bālo  ettha jīvitam kappenti etena ati balam kāya bala bhoga bala ādikam balam atha  vā sammājīvanam jīvanti etena ati balam saddhā ādikam balam āgama aṭṭhakathāyam  pana assaddhiye na kampati iti saddhā bala ntiādi vuttam tam daḷha ṭṭhena balanti vattabbānam
translated: The strength is the implement for living, for supporting. It is what is called “strength” .

original: saddhādīnaṃ akampanabhāvadassanatthaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Atha vā dhātūnaṃ atthātisayayogato
analyzed: saddhā ādīnam akampana bhāva dassana attham vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam atha vā dhātūnam attha atisaya yogato
translated: Herein, strength is what they make use of for living, thus it is strength . It is strength of body, strength of wealth, and so on. Or alternatively, strength is what they live by, thus it is strength . It is strength of faith, and so on. But in the Commentary on the Fives it is said: “It does not waver owing to non-faith, thus it is the strength of faith” , and so on. That should be regarded as said in order to show the unwaverability of the faith, etc., which should be called “strength” in the sense of firmness. Or alternatively, because of the excess of meaning in the elements, the words “strength of faith” and so on are said in order to show the unwaverability of the faith, and so on.

original: assaddhiyādīnaṃ abhibhavanena saddhādibalānaṃ abhibhavanatthopi gahetabbo “abalā
analyzed: assaddhiyā ādīnam abhibhavanena saddhā ādi balānam abhibhavana tthaḥ api gahetabbaḥ abalā
translated: and it can be taken as meaning “they overpower the weak faculties of faith, etc., by over- powering the non-faith, etc.,” as in the passage “They overpower the weak and the strong” .

original: naṃ baliyantī”ti ettha viya. Bāloti balati assasati ceva passasati cāti bālo, assasitapassasitamattena🔽jīvati, na seṭṭhena paññājīvitenāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ “balantīti
analyzed: nam baliyanti iti ettha viya bālaḥ ati balati assasati ca iva passasati ca ati bālaḥ assasita passasita mattena  jīvati na seṭṭhena paññā jīvitena ati vuttam hoti tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam
translated: A fool is a “fool” because he breathes and breathes out with the weak faculties of faith, etc.,

original: bālā, assasitapassasitamattena jīvanti, na paññājīvitenāti attho”ti. Paññājīvinoyeva
analyzed: bālāḥ assasita passasita mattena jīvanti na paññā jīvitena ati attho ti
translated: he lives by mere breathing in and out, not by the best kind of living, which is living by understanding. For this is said in the commentary: “They breathe , thus they are fools ; the meaning is that they live by mere breathing in and out, not by living by understanding. ”

original: hi jīvitaṃ seṭṭhaṃ nāma. Tenāha bhagavā “paññājīviṃ jīvitamāhu seṭṭha”nti.
analyzed: hi jīvitam seṭṭham nāma tena āha bhagavā paññā jīvim jīvitam āhu seṭṭhanti
translated: For living by understanding is the best kind of living. Hence the Blessed One said: “Living by understanding is called the best kind of living” .

original: Pula mahatte. Pulati. Vipulaṃ.
analyzed: mahat te pulati vipulam
translated: Pula means “to be great” .

original: Kula saṅkhāne bandhumhi ca. Kolati. Kulaṃ, kolo.
analyzed: kula saṅkhāne bandhumhi ca kolati kulam kolo
translated: Kula means “to be reckoned” and “to be related” .

original: Sala gamane. Salati.
analyzed: sala gamane salati
translated: Sala means “to go” .

original: Kila pītiya kīḷanesu. Pītassa bhāvo pītiyaṃ yathā dakkhiyaṃ. Kīḷanaṃ kīḷāyeva. Kilati.
analyzed: kila pītiya kīḷanesu pītassa bhāvaḥ pītiyam yathā dakkhiyam kīḷanam kīḷāya iva kilati
translated: Kila means “to be glad” and “to be amused” . The state of one who is glad is gladness . Amusement is mere amusement .

original: Ila kampane. Ilati. Elaṃ, elā. Ettha elaṃ vuccati doso. Kenaṭṭhena? Kampanaṭṭhena. Dosoti cettha aguṇo veditabbo, na paṭigho. “Nelaṅgo setapacchādo”ti idamettha nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: kampane ilati elam elā ettha elam vuccati doso kena aṭṭhena kampana ṭṭhena doso ti ca ittha aguṇaḥ veditabbaḥ na paṭighaḥ na ilaṅgo seta pacchādo ti idam ettha nidassanaṃ
translated: “Ila” is shaking. “Ila” is “ela.” Herein, “ela” is hate. In what sense? In the sense of shaking. And here “hate” should be understood as a vice, not as resistance. The illustration here is “He is dark-hued, with white behind” .

original: Apica elaṃ vuccati udakaṃ. Tathā hi “elambujaṃ kaṇṭakiṃ vārijaṃ yathā”ti imissā pāḷiyā
analyzed: apica elam vuccati udakam tathā hi elambujam kaṇṭakim vārijam yathā iti imissā pāḷiyā
translated: Moreover, “ela” is water. For in the passage “Like a water-lily, like a lotus, so is the world” ,

original: atthaṃ niddisanto āyasmā sāriputto “elaṃ vuccati udaka”nti āha. Elāti lālā vuccati🔽“elamūgo”ti ettha viya. Apica elāti kheḷo vuccati “sutvā nelapatiṃ vācaṃ, vāḷā panthā
analyzed: attham niddisantaḥ āyasmā sāriputto elam vuccati udakanti āha elā ati lālā vuccati  ettha ettha apica elā ati kheḷaḥ vuccati sutvā na ila patim vācam vāḷā panthā
translated: commenting on the meaning of the words “like a water-lily,” the venerable Sāriputta said: “‘Ela’ is water” . “Ela” is saliva,🔽as in the passage “The dumb man with the drivelling mouth” . Moreover, “ela” is spittle,

original: apakkamu”nti ettha viya. Ettha nelapatiṃ vācanti kheḷabindunipātavirahitaṃ vacananti🔽attho. Lālākheḷavācakassa tu elāsaddassa aññaṃ pavattinimittaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Anekappavattinimittā
analyzed: ettha ettha ettha na ilapatim vācanti kheḷa bindu nipāta virahitam  atthaḥ lālā kheḷa vācakassa tu elā saddassa aññam pavatti nimittam pariyesitabbam aneka ppavatti nimittā
translated: as in the passage “Having heard the speech of the drivelling man, the path is blocked for the one who is going away” . Herein, the meaning is that the speech of the drivelling man is speech devoid of the falling of drops of spittle.🔽But the reason for the occurrence of the word “ela” as a term for saliva should be sought elsewhere.🔽For words have many reasons for their occurrence.

original: hi saddā. Kiṃ vā aññena pavattinimittena, ila kampaneti evaṃ vuttaṃ kampanaṃ eva
analyzed: hi kim vā aññena pavatti nimittena kampana iti evam vuttam kampanam eva
translated: Or what need has it for another reason for its occurrence? It is just shaking itself that is called “ila” in the passage “Ila, shaking.”

original: lālākheḷavācakassa elāsaddassa pavattinimittaṃ, tasmā ilanti jigucchitabbabhāvena
analyzed: lālā kheḷa vācakassa elā saddassa pavatti nimittam tasmai ilanti jigucchitabba bhāvena
translated: the cause of the occurrence of the sound “e” in “eka” (one), which is the sign of the sound “l” in “lāla” (saliva),🔽

original: kampenti hadayacalanaṃ pāpuṇanti janā etthāti elāti attho gahetabbo. Samānapavattinimittāyeva
analyzed: kampenti hadaya calanam pāpuṇanti janāḥ ettha ati elā ati atthaḥ gahetabbo samāna pavatti nimittāya iva
translated: The sound “ela” is the sign of the occurrence of the sound “ila,” which denotes saliva and spittle. Therefore the meaning “they make one shudder” should be taken as follows: “People shudder, their hearts tremble, at this.”🔽For sounds that have the same sign of occurrence

original: hi saddā lokasaṅketavasena nānāpadatthavācakāpi bhavanti. Taṃ yathā? Hinoti gacchatīti
analyzed: hi saddāḥ loka saṅketa vasena nānā padattha vācakā api bhavanti tam yathā hinoti gacchati iti
translated: are also denotative of different word-meanings according to the world’s conventional use of them. For example:

original: hetu, sappati gacchatīti sappo, gacchatīti goti. Tathā asamānappavattinimittāyeva
analyzed: hetu tathā asamāna ppavatti nimittāya iva
translated: “He goes” is “hetu” ; “he creeps” is “sappa” ; “he goes” is “go” .🔽And sounds that have different signs of occurrence🔽are also denotative of the same word-meaning. For example:

original: samānapadatthavācakāpi bhavanti. Taṃ yathā? Rañcatīti rājā, bhūmiṃ pāletīti bhūmipālo,
analyzed: bhavanti tam yathā rañcati iti rājā bhūmim pāla iti iti bhūmipālaḥ
translated: “He shines” is “rājan” ; “he protects the earth” is “bhūmipāla” ;

original: nare indatīti narindoti. Esa nayo sabbatthāpi vibhāvetabbo.
analyzed: nare indati iti narindaḥ iti esa nayaḥ sabbattha api vibhāvetabbaḥ
translated: “he rules men” is “narinda” . This method should be illustrated in all instances.

original: Ila gatiyaṃ. Ilati.
analyzed: ila gatiyam ilati
translated: Ila is derived from the verb ilati in the sense of “going.”

original: Hila hāvakaraṇe. Helati.
analyzed: hila hāva karaṇe helati
translated: Hila is derived from the verb helati in the sense of “making a sound.”

original: Sila uñche. Silati.
analyzed: silaḥ uñche silati
translated: Sila is derived from the verb silati in the sense of “begging.”

original: Tila sinehane. Tilati. Tilaṃ, telaṃ, tilo.
analyzed: tila sinehane tilati tilam telam
translated: Tila is derived from the verb tilati in the sense of “anointing.” Tilam, telaṃ, tilo are synonyms.

original: Cila vasane. Cilati.
analyzed: cila vasane cilati
translated: Cila is derived from the verb cilati in the sense of “clothing.”

original: Vala vilāsane. Valati.🔽Pila gahaṇe. Pilati.
analyzed: vala vilāsane valati  pila gahaṇe pilati
translated: Vala is derived from the verb valati in the sense of “displaying.”🔽Pila is derived from the verb pilati in the sense of “grasping.”

original: Mila sinehane. Milati.
analyzed: mila sinehane milati
translated: Mila is derived from the verb milati in the sense of “anointing.”

original: Phula sañcale pharaṇe ca. Phulati.
analyzed: phula sañcale pharaṇe ca phulati
translated: Phula, sañcale, pharaṇe ca. It blooms.

original: Lakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: lakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: Lakārantadhāturūpāni.

original: Vakārantadhātu
analyzed: vakāra anta dhātu
translated: Vakārantadhātu

original: Vā gatigandhanesu. Vāti. Vāto.
analyzed: vā gati gandhanesu vāti vātaḥ
translated: Vā gatigandhanesu. It blows. Wind.

original: Vī pajanakanti asanakhādana gatīsu. Pajanaṃ calanaṃ. Kanti abhiruci. Asanaṃ bhattaparibhogo. Khādanaṃ pūvādibhakkhanaṃ. Gati gamanaṃ. Veti.
analyzed: vī pajana kanti asana khādana gatīsu pajanam calanam kanti abhiruci asanam bhatta paribhogaḥ khādanam pūva ādi bhakkhanam gati gamanam veti
translated: Vī pajanakanti asanakhādana gatīsu. People, movement, liking, food, eating, going. It goes.

original: Ve tantasantāne. Vāyati. Tantavāyo.
analyzed: tanta santāne vāyati tantavāyo
translated: Ve tantasantāne. It blows. Thread-wind.

original: Ve sosane. Vāyati.
analyzed: ve sosane vāyati
translated: Ve sosane. It blows.

original: Dhivu khivu nidassane. Dhevati. Khevati.
analyzed: dhivu khivu nidassane dhevati khevati
translated: Dhivu khivu nidassane. It shines. It shines.

original: Thivu dittiyaṃ. Thevati. Madhumadhukā thevanti.
analyzed: thivu dittiyam thevati madhu madhukāḥ thevanti
translated: Thivu dittiyaṃ. It shines. The honey-bees shine.

original: Jīva pāṇadhāraṇe. Jīvati. Jīvitaṃ, jīvo, jīvikā. Atthi no jīvikā deva, sā ca yādisakīdisā. Jīvitaṃ kappeti.
analyzed: jīva pāṇa dhāraṇe jīvati jīvitam jīvaḥ jīvikā atthi no jīvikā deva sā ca yādisakīdisā jīvitam kappeti
translated: Jīva pāṇadhāraṇe. It lives. Life, living, livelihood. We have a livelihood, Your Majesty, and it is of this kind. It maintains life.

original: Piva miva tiva niva thūliye. Pivati. Pivaro. Mivati. Tivati. Nivati.
analyzed: thūliye pivati pivaraḥ mivati tivati nivati
translated: Piva miva tiva niva thūliye. It drinks. Drinker, it drinks, it drinks, it drinks.

original: Ettha ca pivaroti kacchapo, yo koci vā thūlasarīro. Tathā hi “pivaro kacchape thūle”ti pubbācariyehi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca pivaro ti kacchapaḥ yaḥ koci vā thūla sarīro tathā hi pivaro kacchape thūla iti pubba ācariyehi vuttam
translated: And here pivaro means a tortoise, or anyone with a bulky body. For thus it is said by the teachers of the past: “pivaro, tortoise, bulky.”

original: Ava pālane. Avati. Buddho mama avataṃ.
analyzed: ava pālane avati buddhaḥ mama avatam
translated: Ava = to protect. It avails. The Buddha avails me.

original: Bhava gatiyaṃ. Savati.
analyzed: bhava gatiyam savati
translated: Bhava = to go. It goes.

original: Kava vaṇṇe. Kavati.
analyzed: kava vaṇṇe kavati
translated: Kava = to colour. It colours.

original: Khivu made. Khivati.
analyzed: khivu made khivati
translated: Khivu = to be intoxicated. It intoxicates.

original: Dhovu dhovane. Dhovati.
analyzed: dhovu dhovane dhovati
translated: Dhovu = to wash. It washes.

original: Devu deva devane. Devati ādevati, paridevati, ādevo, paridevo, ādevanā, paridevanā, ādevitattaṃ, paridevitattaṃ.
analyzed: devu deva devane devati ādevati paridevati ādevo paridevo ādevanā paridevanā ādevitattam paridevitattam
translated: Devu = to lament. It laments, it bewails, lamentation, bewailing, having lamented, having bewailed.

original: Sevu kevu khevu gevu gilevu mevu milevu secane. Sevati. Kevati. Khevati. Gevati. Gilevati. Mevati milevati.
analyzed: secane sevati kevati khevati gevati gilevati mevati milevati
translated: Sevu = to sprinkle. It sprinkles. Kevu = to sprinkle. It sprinkles. Khevu = to sprinkle. It sprinkles. Gevu = to sprinkle. It sprinkles. Gilevu = to sprinkle. It sprinkles. Mevu = to sprinkle. It sprinkles. Milevu = to sprinkle. It sprinkles.

original: Devu plutagatiyaṃ. Plutagati pariplutagamanaṃ. Devati.
analyzed: devu plutagatiyam plutagati paripluta gamanam
translated: Devu = to cross over. It crosses over.

original: Dhātu gatisuddhiyaṃ. Dhāvati, vidhāvati. Ādhāvati, paridhāvati. Dhāvako.🔽Civu ādānasaṃvaresu. Civati.
analyzed: dhāvati vidhāvati ādhāvati paridhāvati dhāvakaḥ  civu ādāna saṃvaresu civati
translated: Dhātu = to run. It runs, it runs away, it runs to, it runs about, a runner.🔽Civu = to bind. It binds.

original: Cevi cetanātulye. Cevati.🔽Vakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: cevi cetanā tulye cevati  vakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: Cevi = to will. It wills.

original: Sakārantadhātu
analyzed: sakāra anta dhātu
translated: Vakārantadhāturūpāni = the elements that have a cause.

original: Sā pāke. Sāti.
analyzed: sā pāke sāti
translated: Sā pāke. It cooks.

original: Si sevāyaṃ. Sevati. Sevanā, sevako, sevito, sivo, sivaṃ.🔽Nihīyati puriso nihīnasevī,🔽Na ca hāyetha kadāci tulyasevī;
analyzed: si sevā ayam sevati sevanā sevakaḥ sevitaḥ sivaḥ sivam 🔽nihīyati purisaḥ nihīna sevī 🔽na ca hāyetha kadācid tulya sevī
translated: Si sevāyaṃ. It serves. A servant, one who is served, auspicious, auspiciousness.

original: Seṭṭhamupagamaṃ udeti khippaṃ,
analyzed: seṭṭham upagamam udeti khippam
translated: The best is quickly reached by going to the best,

original: Tasmā attano uttaritaraṃ bhajetha;
analyzed: tasmai attanaḥ uttaritaram bhajetha
translated: Therefore one should resort to one better than oneself.

original: Si gatibuddhīsu. Seti, atiseti. Atisituṃ, atisitvā, setu.
analyzed: si gati buddhīsu seti atiseti atisitum atisitvā setu
translated: Seti, atiseti, atisitum, atisitvā, setu.

original: Sī saye. Sayo supanaṃ. Seti. Sayati. Senaṃ. Sayanaṃ.
analyzed: sī saye sayo supanam seti sayati senam sayanam
translated: Sī is for saye. Sayo is sleeping. Seti. Sayati. Senaṃ. Sayanaṃ.

original: Su gatiyaṃ. Savati. Pasavati. Pasuto, suto.
analyzed: su gatiyam savati pasavati pasutaḥ sutaḥ
translated: Su is for gati. Savati. Pasavati. Pasuto, suto.

original: Ettha sutoti dūto, “vittiñhi maṃ vindati suta disvā”ti “devasuto ca mātalī”ti ca imāni tattha payogāni.
analyzed: ettha suta iti dūtaḥ vittim hi mam vindati suta disvā iti deva suto ca mātali iti ca imāni tattha payogāni
translated: Here suto means “heard,” “a messenger,” “I find that I am found by the seen and the heard,” “the divine messenger Mātali.” These are the usages there.

original: Su savane. Savanaṃ sandanaṃ. Savati. Āsavo.
analyzed: su savane savanam sandanam savati āsavaḥ
translated: Su is for savana. Savana is hearing. Savati. Āsavo.

original: Sū pasave. Pasavo jananaṃ. Savati, pasavati. Suttaṃ.
analyzed: su pasave pasavaḥ jananam savati pasavati suttam
translated: Sū is for pasave. Pasavo is generation. Savati, pasavati. Suttaṃ.

original: Ettha pana suttanti atthe savati janetīti suttaṃ, tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ, tadaññampi vā hatthisuttādi suttaṃ.
analyzed: ettha pana sutta nti atthe savati janeti iti suttam tepiṭakam buddha vacanam tad aññam pi vā hatthi sutta ādi suttam
translated: Here, however, suttanti atthe savati janetīti suttaṃ, the Tipiṭaka Buddha Word, or other suttas such as the Hatthisutta.

original: Sū pāṇagabbhavimocanesu. Sūti. Pasūti. Pasūto.
analyzed: pāṇa gabbha vimocanesu
translated: Sū is for pāṇagabbhavimocane. Sūti. Pasūti. Pasūto.

original: Su peraṇe. Suti.
analyzed: su peraṇe suti
translated: Su is for peraṇa. Suti.

original: Se khaye. Sīyati. Ekārassīyādeso.
analyzed: se khaye sīyati ekāraḥ sīya ādesaḥ
translated: Se is for khaya. Sīyati. Ekārassīyādeso.

original: Se pāke. Seti.
analyzed: se pāke sā iti
translated: Se is for pāka. Seti.

original: Se gatiyaṃ. Seti. Setu.
analyzed: se gatiyam seti setu
translated: Se is for gati. Seti. Setu.

original: Hiṃsa hiṃsāyaṃ. Hiṃsati. Hiṃsako, hiṃsanā, hiṃsā.
analyzed: hiṃsa hiṃsa ayam hiṃsati hiṃsakaḥ hiṃsanā hiṃsā
translated: Hiṃsa, hiṃsāyaṃ. Hiṃsati. Hiṃsako, hiṃsanā, hiṃsā.

original: Issa issāyaṃ. Issati. Purisaparakkamassa devā na issanti. Issā, issāyanā.
analyzed: issaḥ issāyam issati purisa parakkamassa devāḥ na issanti issāḥ issāyanā
translated: Issa, issāyaṃ. Issati. Devā na issanti purisaparakkamassa. Issā, issāyanā.

original: Namassa vandanānatiyaṃ. Vandanānati nāma vandanāsaṅkhātaṃ namanaṃ, sakammakoyevāyaṃ dhātu, na namudhātu viya sakammako ceva akammako ca. Namassati.
analyzed: namassa vandanānatiyam vandanānati nāma vandanā saṅkhātam namanam dhātu na namu dhātu viya sa kammakaḥ ca iva akammakaḥ ca namassati
translated: Namassa, vandanātiyaṃ. Vandanaṃ nāma namanaṃ, sakammako eva ayaṃ dhātu, na namudhātu viya sakammako ceva akammako ca. Namassati.

original: Ghusa sadde. Ghusati, ghosati. Paṭighoso, nigghoso, vacīghoso.
analyzed: sadde ghusati ghosati paṭighosaḥ nigghosaḥ vacīghoso
translated: Ghusa, sadde. Ghusati, ghosati. Paṭighoso, nigghoso, vacīghoso.

original: Cusa pāne. Cusati.
analyzed: cusa pāne cusati
translated: Cusa, pāne. Cusati.

original: Pusa buddhiyaṃ. Pusati. Poso. Sampīḷe mama posanaṃ. Posananti vaḍḍhanaṃ.
analyzed: buddhiyam pusati poso sampīḍe mama posanam vaḍḍhanam
translated: Pusa, buddhiyaṃ. Pusati. Poso. Sampīḷe mama posanaṃ. Posananti vaḍḍhanaṃ.

original: Musa theyye. Thenanaṃ theyyaṃ corikā. Musati. Duddikkho cakkhumusano. Musalo.
analyzed: musa theyye thenanam theyyam corikā musati duddikkhaḥ cakkhumusanaḥ musalo
translated: Musa, theyye. Thenanaṃ theyyaṃ corikā. Musati. Duddikkho cakkhumusano. Musalo.

original: Pusa pasave. Pusati.
analyzed: pusa pasave pusati
translated: Pusa, pasave. Pusati.

original: Vāsi bhūsa alaṅkāre. Vāsati. Bhūsati, vibhūsati. Bhūsanaṃ, vibhūsanaṃ.
analyzed: vāsi bhūsa alaṅkāre vāsati bhūsati vibhūsati bhūsanam vibhūsanam
translated: Vāsi, bhūsa, alaṅkāre. Vāsati. Bhūsati, vibhūsati. Bhūsanaṃ, vibhūsanaṃ.

original: Usa rujāyaṃ. Usati.
analyzed: rujā ayam usati
translated: Usa, rujāyaṃ. Usati.

original: Isa ucche. Esati. Isi.
analyzed: isaḥ ucche esati isi
translated: Isa, ucche. Esati. Isi.

original: Ettha pana sīlādayo guṇe esantīti isayo, buddhādayo ariyā tāpasapabbajjāya ca pabbajitā narā. “Isi tāpaso jaṭilo jaṭī jaṭādharo”ti ete tāpasapariyāyā.🔽Kasa vilekhane. Kasati, kassati. Kassako, ākāso.
analyzed: ettha pana sīla ādayaḥ guṇe esanti iti isayaḥ buddha ādayaḥ ariyā tāpasa pabbajjāya ca pabbajitāḥ narāḥ tāpasaḥ jaṭilaḥ jaṭī jaṭādharaḥ iti ete tāpasa pariyāyā  vilekhane kasati kassati kassakaḥ ākāsaḥ
translated: Herein, they are seers because they seek out the special qualities of virtue, etc., and they are men because they have gone forth in the Noble Ones’ going-forth of purity, and they are ascetics because they have gone forth in the going-forth of the ascetics’ ten moralities. “Ascetic,” “one who is austere,” “one who wears his hair in a topknot,” “one who wears a topknot,” “one who wears a topknot and matted hair,” “one who wears matted hair” are synonyms.

original: Ettha kassakoti kasikārako. Ākāsoti nabhaṃ. Tañhi na kassatīti ākāso. Kasituṃ vilekhituṃ na sakkāti attho. Imāni tadabhidhānāni –
analyzed: ettha kassako ti kasi kārakaḥ ākāso ti nabham tat hi na kassati iti ākāsaḥ kasitum vilekhitum na sakkā iti attho imāni tad abhidhānāni
translated: Kasa is derived from the verbal root kas, to scratch. It has the meaning of “he scratches,” “he scratches” . The derived noun is kassaka, a ploughman, and ākāsa, space. For ākāsa is so called because it is not scratched by the plough, that is, it cannot be scratched, cannot be ploughed. These are the synonyms:

original: Ākāso ambaraṃ abbhaṃ, antalikkha’maghaṃ nabhaṃ;🔽Vehāso gaganaṃ devo, kha’mādiccapathopi ca.
analyzed: ākāsaḥ ambaram abbham antalikkham agham nabham  vehāsaḥ gaganam ca
translated: Space, sky, the firmament, the upper region, the cloudless region, the atmosphere,🔽The air, the heavens, the god-world, the path of the sun and moon,🔽The path of the stars, the path of the constellations, the path of the sun,

original: Tārāpatho ca nakkhatta-patho ravipathopi ca;🔽Vehāyasaṃ vāyupatho, apatho anilañjasaṃ.
analyzed: tārāpatho ca nakkhattapatho ravipatho pi ca  vehāyasam vāyu pathaḥ a pathaḥ anilañjasam
translated: The path of the birds, the path of the wind, the path of the gods, the path of the Gandhabbas.

original: Kasa sisa jasa jhasa vasa masa disa jusa yusa hiṃsatthā. Kasati. Sisati. Jasati. Jhasati. Vasati. Masati. Masako. Omasati, omasavādo. Disati. Jusati. Yūsati.
analyzed: kasa sisa jasa jhasa vasa masa disa jusa yusa hiṃsatthā kasati sisati jasati jhasati vasati masati masakaḥ omasati omasavādaḥ disati jusati yūsati
translated: Kasa, to scratch; sisa, to be tired; jasa, to praise; jhasa, to be angry; vasa, to dwell; masa, to despise; masaka, a despiser; omasati, to despise; omasavāda, despising speech; disati, to see; jusati, to eat; yūsati, to drink.

original: Tattha omasatīti vijjhati. Omasavādoti paresaṃ sūciyā viya vijjhanavādo. Masakoti makaso.
analyzed: tattha omasati iti paresam sūciyā viya vijjhana vādaḥ masakaḥ iti makasaḥ
translated: Herein, he reviles is he who insults. Reviling is insulting talk, like piercing others with a needle. He mocks is he who jeers.

original: Bhassa bhassane. Bhassanti kathanaṃ vuccati “āvāso gocaro bhassaṃ. Bhassakāraka”ntiādīsu viya. Bhassati. Bhaṭṭhaṃ. Bhaṭṭhanti bhāsitaṃ, vacananti attho. Ettha pana –
analyzed: bhassa bhassane bhassanti kathanam vuccati āvāsaḥ gocaraḥ bhassam bhassakārakam ti ādīsu viya bhassati bhaṭṭham bhaṭṭhanti bhāsitam vacananti atthaḥ ettha pana
translated: Bhassa is said of speaking. Bhassati is said of speaking, as in such passages as “A dwelling place, a grazing ground, and speaking, and the one who speaks” . Bhassati. Bhaṭṭhaṃ. Bhaṭṭhanti is said of what is spoken, the meaning being “what is said.” Herein,

original: “Subhāsitā atthavatī, gāthāyo te mahāmuni;
analyzed: su bhāsitāḥ atthavatī gāthāyaḥ te mahā muni
translated: “Well spoken, meaningful, Are your verses, Great Sage;

original: Nijjhattomhi subhaṭṭhena, tvañca me saraṇaṃ bhavā”ti
analyzed: nijjhattaḥ asmi su bhaṭṭhena tvam ca me saraṇam bhavāti
translated: I am satisfied with the good speech, And you are my refuge.”

original: Pāḷi nidassanaṃ. Tattha nijjhattoti nijjhāpito dhammojapaññāya paññattigato amhi. Subhaṭṭhenāti subhāsitena.
analyzed: nidassanam tattha nijjhattaḥ ti nijjhāpitaḥ dhammoja paññāya paññatti gataḥ amhi su bhaṭṭhena ati su bhāsitena
translated: This is a citation from the texts. Herein, I am satisfied is I am satisfied with the knowledge of the Dhamma that has reached the state of being formulated. With the good speech is with the good speaking.

original: Jisu nisu visu misu vassa secane. Jesati. Nesati. Vesati. Mesati. Devo vassati.
analyzed: secane secane devaḥ vassati
translated: Jisu is said of sprinkling. Jesati. Nesati. Vesati. Mesati. The god rains.

original: Marisu sahane ca. Cakāro secanāpekkhako. Marisati.
analyzed: marisu sahane ca cakāro secana apekkhakaḥ marisati
translated: Marisu is said of enduring and of looking for sprinkling. Marisati.

original: Pusa posane. Posati. Poso. Kammacittautuāhiārehi posiyatīti poso. “Aññepi devo posetī”ti dassanato pana curādigaṇepi imaṃ dhātuṃ vakkhāma.🔽Pisu silisu pusu palusu usu upadāhe. Pesati. Silesati. Sileso. Posati. Palosati. Osati. Usu.🔽Ghasu saṃharise. Saṃhariso saṅghaṭṭanaṃ. Ghassati.🔽Hasu āliṅge. Āliṅgo upagūhanaṃ. Hassati.
analyzed: posa posane posati poso posiyati iti poso aññe pi devaḥ poseti iti dassanato pana curādi gaṇe pi imam dhātum vakkhāma  upadāhe pesati silesati silesaḥ posati palosati osati usu  ghasu saṃharise saṃharisaḥ saṅghaṭṭanam ghassati  āliṅge āliṅgaḥ upagūhanam
translated: In the word posa, the meaning is “one who nourishes.” It is one who nourishes, thus it is a nourisher . “Another god nourishes” is said, and therefore we shall also mention the word curādigaṇa .🔽In the word pisu, the meaning is “one who burns.” It burns, thus it is a burner . In the word silisu, the meaning is “one who moves.” It moves, thus it is a mover . In the word pusu, the meaning is “one who grows.” It grows, thus it is a grower . In the word palusu, the meaning is “one who strikes.” It strikes, thus it is a striker . In the word usu, the meaning is “one who burns.” It burns, thus it is a burner .🔽In the word ghasu, the meaning is “one who gathers.” It gathers, thus it is a gatherer . In the word saṃhariso, the meaning is “one who gathers together.” It gathers together, thus it is a gatherer together .🔽In the word hasu, the meaning is “one who embraces.” It embraces, thus it is an embracer .

original: araññagataṃ vā rukkhamūlagataṃ vā suññāgāragataṃ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā uhasati”
analyzed: arañña gatam vā rukkha mūla gatam vā suññāgāra gatam vā mātugāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā uhasati
translated: Or a woman or a girl comes to him in the forest or at the foot of a tree or in an empty place and teases him,

analyzed: iti ca saḥ mātugāmena iti ca hāsaḥ iti hasanam vā somanassam vā hāsaḥ
translated: and he is teased by a woman or a girl” , and “He is teased by a woman or a girl” .

original: me upapajjathā”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: me upapajjatha atiādīsu viya
translated: Laughter is laughing or joy, as in the passage beginning, “Let laughter arise in me” .🔽Tusa is laughing, as in “Tusati, hasati, hisati, rasati, rasitaṃ” . Here is a text:🔽“Let all drums beat, let all lutes play” .

original: Tusa hasa hisa rasa sadde. Tusati, hasati, hisati, rasati, rasitaṃ. Atrāyaṃ pāḷi “bheriyo sabbā vajjantu, vīṇā sabbā rasantu tā” iti.🔽Rasa assādane. Rasati. Raso.🔽Rasa assādasinehesu. Rasati. Raso.
analyzed: tusa hasa hisa rasa sadde tusati hasati hisati rasati rasitam atra ayam bheriyaḥ sabbāḥ vajjantu vīṇā sabbāḥ rasantu tāḥ iti  rasa assādane rasati raso  rasa assāda sinehesu rasati
translated: Rasa is tasting, as in “Rasati” . Rasa is taste.🔽Rasa is in the sense of enjoyment, as in “Rasati” . Rasa is taste.

original: Rasa hāniyaṃ. Rasati. Rasanaṃ, raso.
analyzed: rasa rasati rasanam
translated: Rasa is in the sense of loss, as in “Rasati” . Rasa is taste.

original: Atrāyaṃ pāḷi –
analyzed: atra ayam pāḷi
translated: Here is a text:

original: “Naheva ṭhita nā’sīnaṃ, na sayānaṃ na paddhaguṃ;
analyzed: nahā iva ṭhita na āsīnam na sa yānam na paddhagum
translated: “Not standing, not sitting, not lying down, not walking,

original: Yāva byāti nimīsati, tatrāpi rasatibbayo”ti.
analyzed: yāva byāti nimīsati tatra api
translated: As long as he blinks, there too the taste is lost” .

original: Tattha rasatibbayoti so so vayo rasati parihāyati, na vaḍḍhatīti attho.
analyzed: tattha so saḥ vayaḥ rasati parihāyati na vaḍḍhati iti attho
translated: Herein, the taste is lost means that each age is lost, it fails, it does not increase, is the meaning.

original: Lasa silesanakīḷanesu. Lasati. Lāso. Lasī ca te nippalitā. Lasi vuccati matthaluṅgaṃ. Nippalitāti nikkhantā.
analyzed: si lesana kīḷanesu lasati lāsaḥ lasī ca te nippalitā lasi vuccati matthaluṅgam nippalitā ati nikkhantā
translated: In the sense of playing a trick, etc., it is lasati. Lāso is a trick. Lasī is a trickster. Lasi is the brain. Nippalitā means gone out.

original: Nisa samādhimhi. Samādhi samādhānaṃ cittekaggatā. Nesati.
analyzed: samādhimhi samādhānam citta ekagga tā
translated: In the sense of concentration, it is nesati. Samādhi is the fixing of the mind, unification of mind.

original: Misa masa sadde rose ca. Mesati. Masati. Meso. Masako.
analyzed: misa masa sadde rose ca mesati masati mesaḥ masakaḥ
translated: In the sense of sound, it is mesati and masati. Meso is a sound. Masako is a sound.

original: Pisi pesu gatiyaṃ. Pisati. Pesati.
analyzed: pisi pesu gatiyam pisati pesati
translated: In the sense of going, it is pisati and pesati.

original: Sasu hiṃsāyaṃ. Sasati. Satthaṃ. Satthaṃ vuccati asi.🔽Saṃsa thutiyañca. Cakāro hiṃsāpekkhāya. Saṃsati, pasaṃsati. Pasaṃsā, pasaṃsanā. Pasattho
analyzed: sasu hiṃsa ayam sasati sattham sattham vuccati asi  saṃsa thutiyam ca cakāraḥ hiṃsā apekkhāya saṃsati pasaṃsati pasaṃsā pasaṃsanā pasatthaḥ
translated: In the sense of violence, it is sasati. Satthaṃ is a weapon. Satthaṃ is a sword.

original: bhagavā. Pasaṃsamāno, pasaṃsito, pasaṃsako, pasaṃsitabbo, pasaṃsanīyo, pāsaṃso, pasaṃsitvā iccādīni.
analyzed: bhagavā pasaṃsamānaḥ pasaṃsitaḥ pasaṃsakaḥ pasaṃsitabbaḥ pasaṃsanīyaḥ pāsaṃsaḥ pasaṃsitvā iccādīni
translated: In the sense of praise, it is saṃsati. The particle ca shows that it is also used in the sense of violence. Pasaṃsati is to praise. Pasaṃsā is praise. Pasaṃsanā is praise. Pasaṃsitabbo is one who should be praised. Pasaṃsanīyo is one who should be praised. Pāsaṃso is praise. Pasaṃsitvā is having praised.

original: Disa pekkhane. Etissā pana nānārūpāni bhavanti – “dissati padissati” iccādi akammakaṃ. “Passati dakkhati”iccādi sakammakaṃ.
analyzed: disa pekkhane etissā pana nānārūpāni bhavanti dissati padissati iccādi akammakam passati dakkhati iccādi sakammakam
translated: In the sense of seeing, it is dissati. But it has many different forms: dissati, padissati, etc., without an object; passati, dakkhati, etc., with an object.

original: Dissatu, passatu, dakkhatu. Disseyya, passeyya, dakkheyya. Disse, passe, dakkhe.
analyzed: dissatu passatu dakkhatu disseyya passeyya dakkheyya disse passe dakkhe
translated: Let him see, let him look, let him behold. He might see, he might look, he might behold. He saw, he looked, he beheld.

original: Dissa, passa, dakkha. Adissā, apassā. Addā sīdantare nage. Addakkhā, addakkhuṃ, adassuṃ.
analyzed: dissa passa dakkha a dissāḥ a passāḥ addā sīdantare nage addakkhāḥ addakkhum adassum
translated: He saw, he looked, he beheld. He did not see, he did not look. He saw in the middle of the water. He saw, they saw, they saw.

original: Adassi, apassi, adakkhi.
analyzed: adassi apassi adakkhi
translated: He saw, he looked, he beheld.

original: Dassissati, passissati, dakkhissati. Adassissā, apassissā, dakkhissā. Evaṃ vattamānapañcamiyādivasena
analyzed: dassissati passissati dakkhissati a dassissā a passissā dakkhissā evam vattamāna pañcamiyā ādi vasena
translated: He will see, he will look, he will behold. He will not see, he will not look. He will behold. Thus, in the present tense, etc.,

original: vitthāretabbāni. Kārite “dasseti dassayatī”ti rūpāni. Kamme “passiyati” iccādīni.
analyzed: vitthāretabbāni kārite dasseti dassayati iti rūpāni kamme iccādīni
translated: they should be extended. The forms “he shows, he causes to see” are made in the passive. The forms “he looks” , etc., are made in the passive in the present participle.

original: Disā. Passo. Passaṃ. Passitā. Dassetā. Dassanaṃ. Vipassanā, ñāṇadassananti nāmikapadāni.
analyzed: disā passaḥ passam passitā dassetā dassanam vipassanā ñāṇa dassanan ti nāmika padāni
translated: The words “direction,” “looking,” “looking,” “having looked,” “showing,” “seeing,” “insight,” “knowledge and vision” are nouns.

original: Tadatthe pana tumatthe ca “dakkhitāye”ti rūpaṃ. “Āgatāmha imaṃ dhammasamayaṃ, dakkhitāye
analyzed: tad atthe pana tum atthe ca dakkhitāya iti rūpam āgatāmha imam dhammasamayam dakkhitāya
translated: But the form “dakkhitāye” is made in the passive in the present participle in the sense of that and in the sense of the vocative. For the text has the passage: “We have come to this Dhamma-gathering, to see

analyzed: aparājita saṅghanti hi pāḷi imasmin pana pāḷi ppadese dakkhitāya iti idam tad atthe
translated: the invincible Saṅgha” . But in this text passage, this “dakkhitāye” is in the sense of that🔽and in the sense of the vocative.

original: tumatthe vā catutthiyā rūpaṃ. Tathā hi dakkhitāyeti imassa dassanatthāyāti vā passitunti
analyzed: tumun atthe vā catutthiyāḥ rūpam tathā hi dakkhitāya iti imassa dassana tthāya ati vā passitun ti
translated: Or it is visible form in the sense of “what is to be seen,” as in the passage: “For the purpose of seeing visible forms” , or “for the purpose of looking at visible forms” .

original: vā attho yojetabbo. Disātiādīsu pana puratthimādibhedāpi disāti vuccati. Yathāha –
analyzed: vā atthaḥ yojetabbaḥ disā ati ādīsu pana puratthima ādi bhedā api disā ati vuccati yathā āha
translated: But in the passage beginning, “The east, the west, the north, the south” , the word “direction” is used in the sense of the cardinal points, east, etc.,🔽as is shown by the following passage:

original: “Disā catasso vidisā catasso,
analyzed: disā catassaḥ vidisā catassaḥ
translated: “The four quarters and the four in-between directions,

original: Uddhaṃ adho dasa disatā imāyo;
analyzed: uddham adhas dasa disatāḥ
translated: The zenith and the nadir—these ten directions:

original: Katamaṃ disaṃ tiṭṭhati nāgarājā,
analyzed: katamam disam tiṭṭhati nāga rājā
translated: In which direction does the king of serpents stand?

original: Yamaddasā supine chabbisāṇa”nti.
analyzed: yamaddasā supine chabbisāṇanti
translated: Yama saw him in a dream with six fangs” .

analyzed: mātā pitā disā pubbā ācariyāḥ dakkhiṇāḥ disā
translated: Teachers the southern direction;🔽Wife and children are the western direction,

translated: Monks and brahmans the upper direction;🔽One should honor these directions

translated: The forms jessati, nessati, etc., are to be construed according to the rules of sandhi.

original: “Yathā āraññakaṃ nāgaṃ, dantiṃ anveti hatthinī;
analyzed: yathā āraññakam nāgam dantim anveti hatthinī
translated: As a she-elephant follows a wild bull elephant

original: Jessantaṃ giriduggesu, samesu visamesu cā”ti
analyzed: jessantam giri duggesu samesu visamesu ca ati
translated: Roaring in the mountain caves, on level ground and uneven ground.

original: Pāḷi nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: pāḷi nidassanaṃ
translated: This is an example from the texts.

original: Desu hesu abyattasadde. Desati. Hesati.🔽Kāsa saddakucchāyaṃ. Kāsati, ukkāsati. Kāso. Kāsaṃ sāsaṃ daraṃ balyaṃ, khīṇamedho nigacchati.
analyzed: desu hesu abyatta sad de de sati he sati  kāsa saddakucchāyam kāsati ukkāsati kāsaḥ kāsam sāsam daram balyam khīṇa medhaḥ nigacchati
translated: Desati, hesati.🔽Kāsa in the sense of cough: kāsati, ukkāsati; kāso, kāsaṃ sāsaṃ daraṃ balyaṃ, khīṇamedho nigacchati.

original: Kāsu bhāsu dittiyaṃ. Dittīti pākaṭatā, virājanatā vā. Kāsati, pakāsati. Pakāsati tejo. Dūre santo pakāsenti. Bhāsati. Pabhāsati midaṃ byamhaṃ. Pakāso. Kāsu obhāso.
analyzed: kāsu bhāsu dittiyam dittīti pākaṭa tā virājana tā vā kāsati pakāsati pakāsati tejaḥ dūre santaḥ pakāsenti bhāsati pabhāsati midam pakāsaḥ kāsu obhāsaḥ
translated: Kāsu in the sense of shining: kāsati, pakāsati; pakāsati tejo; dūre santo pakāsenti; bhāsati; pabhāsati midaṃ byamhaṃ; pakāso; kāsu obhāso.

original: Tatra pakāsatīti pakāso, pākaṭo hotīti attho. Tucchabhāvena puñjabhāvena vā kāsati pakāsati pākaṭā hotīti kāsu. “Kāsu” iti āvāṭopi vuccati rāsipi.
analyzed: tatra pakāsati iti pakāsaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti iti attho tuccha bhāvena puñja bhāvena vā kāsati pakāsati pākaṭā hoti iti kāsu kāsu iti āvāṭaḥ api vuccati

It is a “pit” because it is dug out by the hollow or the digging out ; the meaning is that it is made evident, made manifest. “Kāsu” is also a name for a pit and for a heap.🔽“Are you digging a pit, charioteer,

analyzed: kiṃnu santaramānā uva kāsum khanasi sārathi
translated: For someone to fall in, I wonder?🔽When asked, good man, tell me,

analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ me samma akkhāhi kiṃkāsuyā karissasi iti
translated: What will you do with the pit?”🔽Herein, a pit is called a “pit” .🔽“Others plunge into a pit of embers,

original: Ettha hi āvāṭo kāsu nāma. “Aṅgārakāsuṃ apare phuṇanti, narā rudantā paridaḍḍhagattā”ti
analyzed: ettha hi āvāṭaḥ kāsu nāma aṅgārakāsum apare phuṇanti narāḥ rudantā paridaḍḍha gattā ati
translated: Crying, their bodies all aflame” .

original: ettha rāsi. Kārite – pakāsetīti pakāsako. Obhāsetīti obhāsako. Kamme pakāsiyatīti🔽pakāsito. Evaṃ bhāsito. Bhāve – kāsanā. Saṅkāsanā. Pakāsanā. Tumantāditte “pakāsituṃ,
analyzed: ettha rāsi kārite pakāseti iti pakāsako obhāseti iti obhāsako kamme pakāsiyati iti  pakāsitaḥ evam bhāsitaḥ bhāve kāsanā saṅkāsanā pakāsanā pakāsitum

analyzed: pakāsetum obhāsitum obhāsetum pakāsitvā pakāsetvā obhāsitvā obhāsetvā ati rūpāni 🔽bhavanti taddhite bhāsu etassa atthi iti bhāsuraḥ pabhassaraḥ yaḥ koci bhāsuraḥ ti vā

original: kesarasīho. Imasmiṃ atthe bhāsusaddo “rāja dittiya”nti ettha rājasaddo viya virājanavācako
analyzed: imasmin atthe bhāsu saddaḥ rāja dittiyanti ettha rāja saddaḥ viya virājana vācakaḥ
translated: The lion of the Keśa clan. In this meaning the word bhāsu is a word for shining, like the word rāja in the passage “Rāja ditthiya” .

original: siyā, tasmā rūpasiriyā virājanasampannatāya bhāsu virājanatā etassa atthīti bhāsuroti nibbacanaṃ ñeyyaṃ.
analyzed: siyā tasmā rūpa siriyā virājana sampanna tāya bhāsu virājana tā etassa atthi iti bhāsurā iti nibbacanam ñeyyam
translated: Therefore the derivation should be understood as follows: “It has bhāsu, shining, because it is endowed with the shining of beauty of form.”

original: Nāsu rāsu sadde. Nāsati. Rāsati. Nāsā, nāsikā.
analyzed: nāsu rāsu sadde nāsā nāsikā
translated: Nāsā is a sound. It is derived from the root nās, to smell. It is derived from the root rās, to collect. Nāsā is the nose.

original: Tatra nāsāti hatthisoṇḍāpi nāsāti vuccati “sace maṃ nāganāsūrū, olokeyya pabhāvatī”tiādīsu
analyzed: tatra nāsā ati hatthi soṇḍā api nāsā ati vuccati sace mama nāga nāsūrū olokeyya pabhāvatī itiādīsu
translated: Herein, nāsā is also a trunk, as in the passage “If Pabhāvatī were to look at me with her trunk-like nose” .

original: viya. Manussādīnaṃ nāsikāpi nāsāti vuccati “yo te hatthe ca pāde ca, kaṇṇanāsañca
analyzed: viya manussa ādīnam nāsikā api nāsā ti vuccati yaḥ te hatthe ca pāde ca kaṇṇa nāsam ca
translated: It is also the nose of human beings, etc., as in the passage “He who cut off your hands and feet, your ears and nose” .

original: chedayī”tiādīsu viya. Nāsanti abyattasaddaṃ karonti etāyāti nāsā. Nāsā eva nāsikā.
analyzed: chedayi iti ādīsu viya nāsanti abyatta saddam karonti nāsā nāsā eva nāsikā
translated: It is called nāsā because it makes a sound of distress, like nāsati . Nāsā is the same as nose.

original: Yattha nibbacanaṃ na vadāma, tattha taṃ suviññeyyattā appasiddhattā vā na vuttanti
analyzed: yattha nibbacanam na vadāma tattha tam su viññeyya ttā appasiddha ttā vā na vuttan ti
translated: Where we do not give a derivation, it should be regarded as being either easy to understand or well known, or as not being given because it does not exist,

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ, avuttampi payogavicakkhaṇehi upaparikkhitvā yojetabbaṃ. Atridaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam a vuttam pi payoga vicakkhaṇehi upaparikkhitvā yojetabbam atra idam vuccati
translated: and it should be construed by those who are skilled in the analysis of usage. Herein, the following is said:

original: Nāsā soṇḍā karo hattho,
analyzed: nāsā soṇḍā karaḥ hattho
translated: The nose is a trunk, the hand is a trunk,

original: Hatthidabbe samā matā;
analyzed: hatthi dabbe samā matā
translated: The words hatthidabba and samā are the same as matā.

original: Nāsā ca nāsikā ca dve,
analyzed: nāsā ca nāsikā ca dve
translated: The words nāsā and nāsikā are the same as dve.

original: Narādīsu samā matā”ti.🔽Nasa koṭille. Nasati.
analyzed: nara ādīsu samā matā ati  nasa koṭille nasati
translated: The words narā and dīsu are the same as samā.

original: Bhisi bhaye. Bhiṃsati. Bhiṃsanako. Tadāsi yaṃ bhiṃsanakaṃ. Bhesmākāyo.
analyzed: bhisi bhaye bhiṃsati bhiṃsanakaḥ tadā asi yam bhiṃsanakam
translated: The word nasati is derived from the root nas ‘to be in the nostrils’; the word bhisi is derived from the root bhiṃs ‘to be afraid’; the word bhesmākāyo is derived from the word bhiṃsanaka ‘frightful’, which is derived from the root bhiṃs ‘to be afraid’.

original: Āsisi icchāyaṃ. Āpubbo sisi icchāyaṃ vattati. Āsisati. Āsisateva puriso. Āsisanā. Āsisattaṃ. Āsisanto, āsisamāno, āsamāno. “Suggatimāsamānā”ti pāḷi ettha nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: icchā ayam āpubbaḥ sisi icchā ayam vattati āsisati āsisatā iva purisaḥ āsisanā āsisattam āsisantaḥ āsisamānaḥ āsamānaḥ suggatim āsamānā iti ettha nidassanam
translated: The word āsisati is derived from the root ās ‘to desire’; the word āpubbo is derived from the root ās ‘to desire’; the words āsisanā, āsisattaṃ, āsisanto, āsisamāno, āsamāno are derived from the root ās ‘to desire’; the passage suggatimāsamānā is cited as an example here.

original: Gasu adane. Gasati.
analyzed: gasu adane gasati
translated: The word gasati is derived from the root gas ‘to eat’.

original: Ghusī kantikaraṇe. Īkārantoyaṃ, tena ito na niggahītāgamo. Ghusati.
analyzed: ghusī kanti karaṇe īkāra antaḥ yam tena i taḥ na niggahīta āgamaḥ ghusati
translated: The word ghusati is derived from the root ghus ‘to make beautiful’; the word ghusī is derived from the root ghus ‘to make beautiful’; the word ghusati is derived from the root ghus ‘to make beautiful’.

original: Paṃsu bhaṃsu avasaṃsane. Paṃsati. Bhaṃsati.
analyzed: paṃsu bhaṃsu avasaṃsane paṃsati bhaṃsati
translated: The word paṃsati is derived from the root paṃsu ‘to be scattered’; the word bhaṃsati is derived from the root bhaṃsu ‘to be scattered’.

original: Dhaṃsu gatiyaṃ. Dhaṃsati. Rajo nuddhaṃsati uddhaṃ.
analyzed: dhaṃsu gatiyam dhaṃsati rajaḥ nu dhaṃsati uddhaṃ
translated: The word dhaṃsati is derived from the root dhaṃsu ‘to go’; the word rajo is derived from the root uddhaṃsati ‘to be scattered upwards’.

original: Pasa vitthāre. Pasati. Pasu.
analyzed: pasa vitthāre pasati pasu
translated: The word pasati is derived from the root pasa ‘to spread out’; the word pasu is derived from the root pasa ‘to spread out’.

original: Kusa avhāne rodane ca. Kosati, pakkosati. Pakkosako, pakkosito, pakkosanaṃ.
analyzed: kusa avhāne rodane ca kosati pakkosati pakkosakaḥ pakkositaḥ pakkosanam
translated: The word kosati is derived from the root kus ‘to call’; the word pakkosati is derived from the root kus ‘to call’; the words pakkosako, pakkosito, pakkosanaṃ are derived from the root kus ‘to call’.

original: Kassa gatiyaṃ. Kassati, parikassati. Paṭikassati. Mūlāya paṭikasseyya. Paṭikasseyyāti ākaḍḍheyya, mūlāpattiyaṃyeva patiṭṭhāpeyyāti attho.🔽Asa dityādānesu ca. Cakāro gatipekkhako. Asati.
analyzed: kassa gatiyam kassati parikassati paṭikassati mūlāya paṭikasseyya paṭikasseyya ati ākaḍḍheyya mūla āpattiyam yeva patiṭṭhāpeyya ati attho  asa d iti ādānesu ca cakāraḥ gati pekkhakaḥ asati
translated: In the case of what? He goes, he goes around, he goes back, he would go back to the beginning. He would go back: he would drag back, the meaning is, he would establish in the very first offence.🔽And in the case of as, etc.,🔽the particle ca is one looking for a case. He is not.

original: Disa ādānasaṃvaraṇesu. Dissati puriso.
analyzed: disaḥ ādāna saṃvaraṇesu dissati purisaḥ
translated: In the case of disa, in taking and in covering: He is seen.

original: Dāsu dāne. Dāsati.
analyzed: dāsu dāne dāsati
translated: In the case of dāsu, in giving: He gives.

original: Rosa bhaye. Rosati. Rosako.
analyzed: rosa bhaye rosati
translated: In the case of rosa, in fear: He is afraid. He is afraid.

original: Bhesu calane. Bhesati.
analyzed: bhesu calane bhesati
translated: In the case of bhesu, in shaking: He shakes.

original: Pasa bādhanaphassanesu. Pasati. Pāso, nāgapāso, hatthapāso.
analyzed: pasa bādhana phassanesu pasati pāsaḥ nāga pāsaḥ hattha pāsaḥ
translated: In the case of pasa, in obstructing and in feeling: He feels. A snare, a snake’s snare, a hand’s snare.

original: Lasa kantiyaṃ. Lasati, abhilasati, vilasati. Lāso, vilāso, vilasanaṃ.
analyzed: lasa kantiyam lasati abhilasati vilasati lāsaḥ vilāsaḥ vilasanam
translated: In the case of lasa, in liking: He likes, he longs, he shines. A trick, a shine, shining.

original: Casa bhakkhaṇe. Casati.
analyzed: casa bhakkhaṇe casati
translated: In the case of casa, in eating: He eats.

original: Kasa hiṃsāyaṃ. Kasati.
analyzed: kasa hiṃsa ayam kasati
translated: In the case of kasa, in harming: He harms.

original: Tisa tittiyaṃ. Titti tappanaṃ paripuṇṇatā suhitatā. Tisati. Titti.
analyzed: tisa tittiyam titti tappanam paripuṇṇa tā su hita tā tisati titti
translated: In the case of tisa, in satisfaction: Satisfaction is satiation, fulfilment, well-being. He is satisfied. Satisfaction.

original: Vasa nivāse. Vasati, vasiyati, vacchati. Vatthu, vatthaṃ, parivāso, nivāso, āvāso, upavāso, uposatho, vippavāso, cirappavāsī, cirappavuttho, vasitvā, vattuṃ, vasituṃ iccādīni.
analyzed: nivāse vasati vasiyati vacchati vatthu vattham parivāsaḥ nivāsaḥ āvāsaḥ upavāsaḥ uposathaḥ vippavāsaḥ cirappavāsī cirappavutthaḥ vasitvā vattum vasitum iccādīni
translated: In the sense of dwelling: He dwells, he dwells in, he dwells on. A dwelling, a cloth, probation, dwelling, abode, a day of observance, a day of separation, one who has dwelt for a long time, one who has dwelt for a long time and returned, having dwelt, to dwell, to dwell on, and so on.

original: Atra upavāsoti annena vajjito vāso upavāso. Uposathoti upavasanti etthāti uposatho,
analyzed: atra upavāsaḥ iti annena vajjitaḥ vāsaḥ upavāsaḥ uposatho ti upavasanti ettha ati uposatho
translated: Herein, a day of observance is a dwelling that is guarded by food. A day of observance is so called because they observe it there.

original: upavasanti sīlena vā anasanena vā upetā hutvā vasantīti attho. Ayaṃ panettha atthuddhāro🔽– “āyāmāvuso kappina uposathaṃ gamissāmā”tiādīsu pātimokkhuddeso uposatho. “Evaṃ🔽aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato kho visākhe uposatho upavuttho”tiādīsu sīlaṃ. “Suddhassa ve sadā
analyzed: upavasanti sīlena vā anasanena vā upetāḥ hutvā vasanti iti atthaḥ ayam pana ittha atthuddhāro  āyāma avuso kappinaḥ uposatham gamissāma ati ādīsu pātimokkha uddesaḥ uposathaḥ evam  aṭṭhaṅga samannāgato kho visākhe uposathaḥ upavutthaḥ ti ādīsu sīlam suddhassa ve sadā
translated: The meaning is that they observe it by being endowed with virtue or by fasting. This is the analysis of the meaning here:

original: phaggu, suddhassuposatho sadā”tiādīsu upavāso. “Uposatho nāma nāgarājā”tiādīsu paññatti.
analyzed: phaggu suddhassa uposatho sadā ti ādīsu upavāso uposatho nāma nāga rājā ati ādīsu paññatti
translated: in such passages as “Let us go, friends, to the observance-day ceremony,” the observance-day ceremony is the recitation of the Pāṭimokkha. In such passages as “Now, Visākhā, the observance day that is endowed with these eight factors,” it is virtue. In such passages as “The pure one’s observance day is always pure, The pure one’s observance day is always bright,” it is the observance. In such passages as “The king of dragons called Observance Day,” it is a designation.

original: “Na bhikkhave tadahuposathe sabhikkhukā āvāsā”tiādīsu upavasitabbadivasoti.
analyzed: na bhikkhave tadahuposathe sa bhikkhukāḥ āvāsa ati ādīsu upavasitabba divaso ti
translated: In such passages as “Bhikkhus, on that observance day, in an inhabited region, in a monastery with bhikkhus,” it is the day on which the observance should be observed.

original: Vasa kantiyaṃ. Vacchati. Jinavacchayo.🔽Sasa susane. Sasati. Saso.
analyzed: vasa kantiyam  sasa susane sasati saso
translated: In the sense of ‘to dwell’ (vasa). It is said (vacchati). The Buddha’s son (jinavacchayo).🔽In the sense of ‘to be’ (sasati). The hare (saso).

original: Sasa pāṇane. Sasati. Satova assasati, satova passasati. Saso, sasanaṃ. Assāso passāso assasanto passasanto.
analyzed: pāṇane sasati sataḥ uva assasati sataḥ uva passasati sasaḥ sasanam assāsaḥ passāsaḥ assasantaḥ passasantaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘to breathe’ (pāṇati). It is said (sasati). One who breathes in mindfully (satova assasati), one who breathes out mindfully (satova passasati). The hare (saso), the teaching (sasanaṃ). Breathing in (assāso), breathing out (passāso), breathing in mindfully (assasanto), breathing out mindfully (passasanto).

original: Asa bhuvi. Atthi. Asa.🔽Ettha atthīti ākhyātapadaṃ. Na atthi khīrā brāhmaṇī. Atthitā, atthibhāvo, “yaṃ kiñci
analyzed: asa bhuvi atthi asa  ettha atthi iti ākhyāta padam na atthi khīrā brāhmaṇī atthi tā atthi bhāvaḥ yam kiñci
translated: In the sense of ‘earth’ (bhuvi). It exists (atthi). The hare (asa).

original: ratanaṃ atthī”tiādīsu viya nipātapadaṃ. Tasmā atthīti padaṃ ākhyātanipātavasena duvidhanti
analyzed: ratanam atthi iti ādīsu nipāta padam tasmai atthi iti padam ākhyāta nipāta vasena
translated: Herein, the word ‘exists’ (atthi) is a verbal expression. There is no milk in the brahmin woman. The state of existing (atthitā), the state of existing (atthibhāvo), as in the words ‘whatever treasure exists’ (yaṃ kiñci ratanaṃ atthi), it is a particle. Therefore the word ‘exists’ should be understood as twofold, as a verbal expression and a particle.

original: veditabbaṃ. Asaiti avibhattikaṃ nāmikapadaṃ. Ettha ca “asasmīti hotī”ti pāḷi nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbam asaiti avibhattikam nāmika padam ettha ca asasmi iti hoti iti nidassanam
translated: The word ‘hare’ (asa) is a nominal base without a case ending. And here the text ‘I am’ (asasmīti hotī) is an example.

original: Tattha atthīti asa, niccassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Iminā sassatadiṭṭhi vuttā.
analyzed: tattha atthi iti asa niccassa itam adhivacanam iminā vuttā
translated: Herein, ‘exists’ (atthi) is the hare (asa), this is a synonym for eternalism. By this the eternalist view is expressed.

original: Tatrāyaṃ padamālā – “atthi, santi. Asi, attha. Asmi, asma, amhi, amha” iccetāni pasiddhāni.
analyzed: tatra ayam pada mālā atthi santi asi attha asmi asma amhi amha icca etāni
translated: Herein, this is the word-garland: ‘exists’ (atthi), ‘there are’ (santi), ‘it is’ (asi), ‘it exists’ (attha), ‘I am’ (asmi), ‘we are’ (asma), ‘I am’ (amhi), ‘we are’ (amha) – these are well-known.

original: “Atthu, santu. Āhi, attha. Asmi, asma amhi, amha” iccetāni ca, “siyā, assa, siyuṃ,
analyzed: atthu santu attha asmi asma amhi amha icca etāni ca siyā assa siyum
translated: “Atthu, santu, āhi, attha, asmi, asma, amhi, amha” are the forms of the present tense.

original: assu, siyaṃsu. Assa, assatha. Siyaṃ, assa, assāma” iccetāni ca pasiddhāni.
analyzed: assu siyaṃsu assa assatha siyam assa assāma iti etāni ca pasiddhāni
translated: “Siyā, assa, siyuṃ, assu, siyaṃsu, assa, assatha, siyaṃ, assa, assāma” are the forms of the future tense.

original: Ettha pana “tesañca kho bhikkhave samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ…pe… siyaṃsu dve bhikkhū
analyzed: ettha pana tesam ca kho bhikkhave samaggānam sammodamānānam pe dve bhikkhū

original: abhidhamme nānāvādā”ti pāḷi nidassanaṃ. Tattha siyaṃsūti bhaveyyuṃ. Abhidhammeti visiṭṭhe dhamme.

translated: Isu is derived from the word icchā. He desires , thus he is a man (puriso). The word sampaṭicchana is a choice. The words icchā, abhicchā, icchā, icchāma are synonyms.

original: Vesu dāne. Vecchati, pavecchati, paveccheti. Pavecchaṃ, pavecchanto.
analyzed: dāne vecchati pavecchati paveccha iti paveccham
translated: Vesu is derived from the word dāna. He chooses , thus he is a man (puriso). The words pavecchati, paveccheti, pavecchaṃ, pavecchanto are synonyms.

original: Nisa baddhāyaṃ. Baddhāti vinibaddho, ahaṅkārassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Nisati.

translated: Nisa is derived from the word baddhāyaṃ. Baddhāti vinibaddho is a synonym for selfhood. He is bound , thus he is a man (puriso).

original: Jusi pītisevanesu. Josati.

original: Dāhu niddakkhaye. Dāhati.

original: Idāni pana viññūnaṃ sāṭṭhakathe tepiṭake buddhavacane paramakosallajananatthaṃ sappayogaṃ🔽padamālaṃ kathayāma. Seyyathidaṃ? So gacchati, te gacchanti, gacchare. analyzed: gati iti gati gati nibbatti gabhi ajjhāsaya gati vibhava gati nipphatti gati ñāṇa gati iti bahuvidhā gati nāma
translated: “Course” is a name for the many kinds of course, such as the course of rebirth, the course of generation, the course of destiny, the course of inclination, the course of accumulation, the course of fruition, the course of knowledge.

original: Tattha “taṃ gatiṃ pecca gacchāmī”ti ca “yassa gatiṃ na jānanti, devā gandhabbamānusā”ti🔽ca ayaṃ gatigatināma. “Imesaṃ kho ahaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ neva jānāmi gatiṃvā🔽agatiṃvā”ti ayaṃ nibbattigati nāma. “Evaṃ kho te ahaṃ brahme gatiñca jānāmi jutiñca🔽jānāmī”ti ayaṃ ajjhāsayagati nāma. “Vibhavo gati dhammānaṃ, nibbānaṃ arahato gatī”ti
analyzed: tattha tam gatim pecca gacchāmi iti ca yassa gatim na jānanti devāḥ gandhabba mānusāḥ ti  ca ayam gati gati nāma imesam kho aham bhikkhūnam sīlavantānam na iva jānāmi gatim vā  agatim vā ati ayam nibbatti gati nāma evam kho te aham brahme gatiñca jānāmi jutiñca  jānāmi iti ayam ajjhāsaya gati nāma vibhavaḥ gati dhammānam nibbānam arahataḥ gati iti
translated: Herein, “I shall go to that destination in the life to come” and “Whose destination neither gods nor gandhabbas nor men know” are the destination called “destination.”🔽“I do not know the destination or non-destination of these bhikkhus who are virtuous” is the destination called “rebirth.”🔽“Thus, O Brahmā, I know your destination and your radiance” is the destination called “intention.”🔽“The end of destinations is the ending of determinations; Nibbāna is the destination of the Worthy One” is the destination called “the ultimate.”🔽

original: ayaṃ vibhavagati nāma. “Dve gatiyo bhavanti anaññā”ti ayaṃ nipphattigati nāma. “Taṃ🔽tattha gatimā dhibhimā”ti ca “sundaraṃ nibbānaṃ gato”ti ca ayaṃ ñāṇagati nāma. Etthetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: ayam vibhavagati nāma dve gatiyaḥ bhavanti anaññā ati ayam nipphattigati nāma taṃ  tattha gatimā ca sundaram nibbānam gataḥ ti ca ayam ñāṇagatī nāma ettha etam vuccati
translated: Herein, “I shall go to that destination after death” and “Whose destination neither gods nor gandhabbas nor men know” are destination-as-destination. “I do not know the destination or non-destination of these bhikkhus who are virtuous” is destination-as-rebirth. “Thus, O Brahmā, I know your destination and your radiance” is destination-as-intention. “The ending of perception and feeling is the destination of ideas, and the arahat’s death is his destination” is destination-as-ending. “There are two destinations, no other” is destination-as-issue. “He is gone to that destination, he is gone to the conceit ‘I am’” and “He has gone to the fair destination of extinction” are destination-as-knowledge. This is how the word “destination” should be understood in each instance.🔽As destination, as rebirth,

original: Gatigatyañca nibbatyaṃ, vibhavajjhāsayesu ca;

translated: As ending, as intention,🔽As issue, and as knowledge,

original: Nipphattiyañca ñāṇe ca, gatisaddo pavattati.

original: Hiṅgujātīti kathitā, vinayaṭṭhakathāya hi.🔽Jagūti cutito jātiṃ gacchatīti jagu. Indriyena gacchatīti indagū. Atha vā indabhūtena🔽kammunā gacchatīti indagu. “Hindagū”tipi pāḷi. Tattha hindanti maraṇaṃ. Taṃ gacchatīti🔽hindagū. Sabbametaṃ sattādhivacanaṃ, liṅgato pulliṅgaṃ. Medhagoti attano nissayañca🔽parañca medhamāno hiṃsamāno gacchati pavattatīti medhago, kalaho. “Tato sammanti
analyzed: hiṅgu jātī iti kathitā vinaya ṭṭha kathāya hi  jagu iti cutitaḥ jātim gacchati iti jagu indriyena gacchati iti indagū atha vā inda bhūtena  kammunā gacchati iti tattha hindanti maraṇam tam gacchati iti  sabbam etam satta adhivacanam liṅgataḥ put liṅgam medhago ti attanaḥ nissayam ca  param ca medhamānaḥ hiṃsamānaḥ gacchati pavattati iti medha gaḥ kalahaḥ tatas
translated: Are said to be hiṅgujā, in the commentary on the Vinaya.

original: medhagā”ti ettha hi kalaho medhagasaddena bhagavatā vutto. Gamitvāti ettha –
analyzed: medhagā ti ettha hi kalahaḥ medhaga saddena bhagavatā vuttaḥ gamitvā ati ettha
translated: “It goes to birth from death” is jagu. “It goes with a faculty” is indagū. Or alternatively, “it goes with a kamma that is a state of abundance” is indagu. The reading is also hindagū. Herein, it goes to death, thus it is hindagū. All this is a designation for a being. The masculine gender is because of the word’s origin. “It goes, it harms, its support and another, it is envious, it is quarrelsome” is medhago. “They are quarrelsome, they go to envy” is said here. Having gone is gamitvā. Herein,

original: “Isivhayaṃ gamitvāna, vinitvā pañcavaggiye;
analyzed: isivhayam gamitvāna vinitvā pañcavaggiye
translated: having gone to Isipatana, having trained the group-of-five,

original: Tato vinesi bhagavā, gantvā gantvā tahiṃ tahi”nti
analyzed: tatas vinesi bhagavā gantvā gantvā tahim tahinti
translated: Expelled them all, and so the danger was removed.

original: Ayaṃ pāḷi nidassanaṃ. Sappoti sappatīti sappo, saṃsappanto gacchatīti attho. Tenāha
analyzed: ayam nidassanam sappo ti sappati iti sappo saṃsappantaḥ gacchati iti attho tena āha
translated: This is the text. A snake is a sappo because it creeps along, saṃsappanto gacchati. Hence it is said with reference to this text:

original: āyasmā sāriputto “yo kāme parivajjeti, sappasseva padāsiro”ti imissā pāḷiyā niddese🔽“sappo vuccati ahi. Kenaṭṭhena sappo? Saṃsappanto gacchatīti sappo. Bhujanto gacchatīti🔽bhujago. Urena gacchatīti urago. Pannasiro gacchatīti pannago. Sarīrena sappatīti🔽sarīsapo. Bile sayatīti bilāsayo. Dāṭhā tassa āvudhoti dāṭhāvudho. Visaṃ tassaghoranti
analyzed: āyasmā sāriputto yaḥ kāme parivajjeti sappassa iva imissā pāḷiyā niddese  sappaḥ vuccati ahi kenaṭṭhena sappaḥ saṃsappantaḥ gacchati iti sappaḥ bhujantaḥ gacchati iti  bhujagaḥ urena gacchati iti uragaḥ panna siraḥ gacchati iti pannagaḥ sarīrena sappati iti  sarīsapaḥ bile sayati iti bilāsayaḥ dāṭhā tassa āvudhā uti dāṭhāvudhaḥ visam
translated: “The venerable Sāriputta said: ‘He who avoids sense desires, like a snake a pair of shoes’ ” .

original: ghoraviso. Jivhā tassa duvidhāti dujivho. Dvīhi jivhāhi rasaṃ sāyatīti dvirasaññū”ti.
analyzed: jivhā tassa duvidhā ati du jivhaḥ dvīhi jivhāhi rasam sāyati iti
translated: A snake is called a sappo in the sense of creeping along, saṃsappanto gacchati. It creeps along, bhujanto gacchati, thus it is a bhujanga . It creeps along with its chest, urena gacchati, thus it is an uraga . It creeps along with its belly, pannena gacchati, thus it is a pannaga . It creeps along with its body, sarīrena sappati, thus it is a sarīsapa . It lies in a hole, sayati bile, thus it is a bilāsaya . Its weapon is a fang, dāṭhā tassa āvudho, thus it is a dāṭhāvudha . Its poison is terrible, visaṃ tassa ghoraṃ, thus it is a ghoravisa . It has a double tongue, jivhā tassa duvidhā, thus it is a dujivha . It creeps with two tongues, dvihi jivhāhi rasaṃ sayati, thus it is a dvirasaññū .

original: Sappinīti uragī. Pīṭhasappīti pīṭhena sappati gacchatīti pīṭhasappī, paṅguḷo. Sappīti
analyzed: sappinī iti uragī pīṭhasappī iti pīṭhena sappati gacchati iti pīṭhasappī paṅguḷaḥ sappī iti
translated: A snake’s wife is a sappini . A snake’s cripple is a pīṭhasappi . It creeps with a stump, pīṭhena sappati gacchati, thus it is a pīṭhasappi , a cripple. A snake is a sappī .

original: yo na paribhuñjati, tassa balāyuvaḍḍhanatthaṃ sappati gacchati pavattatīti sappi, ghataṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ na paribhuñjati tassa balāyu vaḍḍhana attham sappati gacchati pavattati iti sappi ghatam
translated: It goes to him who does not use it, and it goes on increasing his strength and life-span, thus it is ghee, a pot.

original: Sakka ṭeka laṅgha gatyattā. Sakkati, nisakkati, parisakkati. Nisakko, parisakkanaṃ. Ṭekati. Ṭīkā. Laṅghati, ullaṅghati, olaṅghati, laṅghako, ullaṅghikā pīti.
analyzed: sakka ṭeka laṅgha gati attā sakkati nisakkati parisakkati nisakkaḥ parisakkanam ṭekati ṭīkā laṅghati ullaṅghati olaṅghati laṅghakaḥ ullaṅghikā pi iti
translated: It is sakka because of the meaning of “it is able” . One is able, one is eager, one is ready. Eagerness, readiness. It is ṭeka because of the meaning of “it is climbed” . One climbs, one climbs up, one climbs over, a climber, a climber up, a climber over.

original: Ke re ge sadde. Kāyati. Rāyati. Gāyati. Jātakaṃ. Rā. Gītaṃ. Kāyituṃ. Rāyituṃ, gāyituṃ. Kāyitvā. Rāyitvā. Gāyitvā.
analyzed: ke re ge sadde kāyati rāyati gāyati jātakam rā gītam kāyitum rāyitum gāyitum kāyitvā rāyitvā gāyitvā
translated: Ke re ge sadde. One is able, one is eager, one sings, a birth story, a song, to be able to, to be eager, to sing, having been able, having been eager, having sung.

original: Tattha jātakanti jātaṃ bhūtaṃ atītaṃ attano caritaṃ kāyati katheti bhagavā etenāti🔽jātakaṃ. Jātakapāḷi hi idha jātakanti vuttaṃ. Aññatra pana jātaṃ evaṃ jātakanti gahetabbā.
analyzed: tattha jātakanti jātam bhūtam atītam caritam kāyati kathā iti bhagavā etena ati  jātakam jātaka pāḷi hi idha jātakanti vuttam aññatra pana jātam evam jātakanti gahetabbā
translated: Herein, birth story is what the Blessed One says thus “I was able, I was eager, I sang” .🔽For it is the text of the Jataka that is called “birth story” here. But elsewhere it should be taken as “what is born” .

original: Tathā hi jātakasaddo pariyattiyampi vattati “itivuttakaṃ jātakaṃ abbhutadhamma”ntiādīsu,
analyzed: tathā hi jātaka saddaḥ pariyattiyam pi vattati itivuttakam jātakam abbhuta dhamman ti ādīsu
translated: For the word “birth story” is used in the sense of “what is learnt” in such passages as “The birth stories, the marvels” .

original: jātiyampi vattati “jātakaṃ samodhānesī”tiādīsu. Rā vuccati saddo. Gītanti gāyanaṃ.
analyzed: jātiyam pi vattati jātakam samodhānesi iti ādīsu rā vuccati saddaḥ gītam ti gāyanam
translated: Rā is said to be a sound. Gītanti gāyanaṃ = singing.

original: Khe je se khaye. Khāyati. Jāyati. Sāyati. Khayaṃ gacchatīti attho.
analyzed: khe je se khaye khāyati jāyati sāyati khayam gacchati iti attho
translated: Khe je se khaye. Khāyati. Jāyati. Sāyati. Khayaṃ gacchatīti attho = it is used in the sense of perishing.

original: Ettha pana siyā “nanu ca bho khāyatīti padassa khādatīti vā paññāyatīti vā attho
analyzed: ettha pana siyā nanu ca bho khāyati iti padassa khādati iti vā paññāyati iti vā attho
translated: Here it may be asked: “But is not the meaning of the word khāyati to be known as ‘it is being eaten’ or ‘it is being known,’

original: bhavati, tathā jāyatīti padassa nibbattatīti attho, sāyatīti padassa rasaṃ assādetīti
analyzed: bhavati tathā jāyati iti padassa nibbattati iti atthaḥ sāyati iti padassa rasam assādeti iti
translated: and is not the meaning of the word jāyati ‘it is being produced,’ and is not the meaning of the word sāyati ‘it is being tasted,’

original: attho, evaṃ sante bho kasmā idha evaṃ attho tumhehi kathiyatī”ti? Saccaṃ, dhātūnantu
analyzed: evam sante bho kasmai idha evam tumhehi kathiyati iti saccam
translated: so why do you give it this meaning here?”—It is true, but it is possible to give the meaning in this way because of the many meanings of the

analyzed: anekattha ttā evam atthaḥ kathetum labbhati tathā hi appassutā ayam purisaḥ balibaddo va
translated: roots. For just as in the passage, “This man, though he has little learning,

analyzed: vadati evam sampadam idam daṭṭhabbam

analyzed: gu ghu ku u sadde gavati ghavati kavati avati
translated: Gu ghu ku u sadde = gu, ghu, ku, u are used in the sense of sound. Gavati. Ghavati. Kavati. Avati.

original: Khu ru ku sadde. Khoti. Roti. Koti.
analyzed: khu ru ku sadde khoti roti koti
translated: Khu ru ku sadde. Khoti, roti, koti.

original: Cu ju pu plu gā se gatiyaṃ. Cavati. Javati. Pavati. Plavati. Gāti. Seti. Cavanaṃ, cuti. Javanaṃ, javo. Pavanaṃ, plavanaṃ. Gānaṃ. Setu. Poto. Plavo.
analyzed: cu ju pu plu gā se gatiyam cavati javati pavati plavati gāti sa iti cavanam cuti javanam javo pavanam plavanam gānam setu poto plavo
translated: Cu ju pu plu gā se gatiyaṃ. Cavati, javati, pavati, plavati, gāti, seti. Cavanaṃ, cuti. Javanaṃ, javo. Pavanaṃ, plavanaṃ. Gānaṃ. Setu. Poto. Plavo.

original: Ettha gānanti gamanaṃ. Pototi pavati gacchati udake etenāti poto, nāvā. Tathā plavati
analyzed: ettha gānanti gamanam poto iti pavati gacchati udake etena ati poto nāvā tathā plavati
translated: Herein, gānaṃ is going. Poto is that by which one goes, floats, in water; it is a boat. So too, plavaṃ.

analyzed: na sīdati iti plavaḥ nāvā eva bhinna plavaḥ sāgarassa iva majjhe iti hi jātaka pāḷi dissati

original: “Nāvā, poto, plavo, jalayānaṃ, taraṇa”nti nāvābhidhānāni.
analyzed: nāvā poto plavaḥ jalayānam nāvā abhidhānāni
translated: “Boat, raft, float, watercraft, ferry” are synonyms for boat.

original: Dhe the saddasaṅghātesu. Dhāyati. Thāyati. Bhāve – dhiyati, thiyati. Itthī. Thī.
analyzed: dhe the sadda saṅghātesu dhāyati thāyati bhāve dhiyati thiyati itthī thī
translated: Dhe the saddasaṅghātesu. Dhāyati, thāyati. Bhāve—dhiyati, thiyati. Itthī. Thī.

translated: De te pālane. Dāyati, dayā. Tāṇaṃ.

translated: Rā lā ādāne. Rāti, lāti.

analyzed: ati adi bandhane andati antam
translated: Ati adi bandhane. Antati, andati. Antaṃ, andu.

analyzed: ruca dittiyam jotati sobhati rocati virocati
translated: Jutasubha ruca dittiyaṃ. Jotati, sobhati, rocati, virocati.

analyzed: kuṭilāyam gatiyam akati
translated: In the sense of a crooked course: he goes crookedly, he goes crookedly.
