analyzed: sā sunidhā atime saddā pumānesu pavattare
translated: For males, and for females too.

original: Sunakhī kukkurī sī’ti, ime itthīsu vattare.
analyzed: sunakhī kukkurī sīti ime itthīsu vattare
translated: “Hound,” “mongrel,” and so on,

original: Sunakhā sārameyyāti, ādi bahuvaco pana;🔽Pavattati pumitthīsu, aññatrāpi ayaṃ nayo;
analyzed: sunakhā sārameyyā iti ādi bahuvacaḥ pana  pavattati pum itthīsu aññatra api ayam nayo
translated: Are used for both male and female.

original: Kukkuroti ayaṃ tattha, bālakāle ravena ve;🔽Mahallakepi sunakhe, rūḷhiyā sampavattati.🔽Tathā hi aṭṭhakathācariyā kukkurajātake “ye kukkurā rājakulamhi vaḍḍhā, koleyyakā
analyzed: ayam tattha bāla kāle ravena 🔽mahallake api su nakhe rūḍhiyā sampavattati 🔽tathā hi aṭṭhakathā cariyā kukkura jātake ye kukkurāḥ rājakulamhi vaḍḍhā koleyyakā
translated: “Dog” is used for a young one,🔽And for a big bitch too.

original: vaṇṇabalūpapannā”tiimasmiṃpadese evamatthaṃ vaṇṇayiṃsu “ye kukkurāti ye sunakhā.
analyzed: evam attham vaṇṇayiṃsu ye kukkurā ati ye su nakhā
translated: In this place they have explained the meaning thus: “Dogs” means dogs.

original: Yathā hi taruṇopi passāvo pūtimuttanti tadahujātopi siṅgālo “jarasiṅgālo’ti, komalāpi
analyzed: yathā hi taruṇaḥ api passāvaḥ tad ahu jātaḥ api siṅgālaḥ komalā api
translated: For just as a young mango is called “rotten mango,” and a jackal born that very day is called “an old jackal,” and a tender creeper

original: gaḷācīlatā ‘pūtilatā’ti, suvaṇṇavaṇṇopi kāyo ‘pūtikāyo’ti vuccati, evameva vassasatikopi
analyzed: gaḷācī latā pūtilatā ati suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ api kāyo pūti kāyo ti vuccati evam eva vassa satikaḥ api
translated: of the vine is called “a rotten creeper,” and a body beautiful with a golden complexion is called “a rotten body,” so too, a dog a hundred years old is called “a dog.”

original: sunakho ‘kukkuro’ti vuccati, tasmā mahallakā kāyūpapannāpi te ‘kukkurā’tveva vuttā”ti.🔽Ki hiṃsāyaṃ. Kiṇoti, kiṇāti, kiṇanti.
analyzed: sunakho kukkurā iti vuccati tasmā mahallakā kāyūpapannā api te kukkurā tu eva vuttā ati  ki hiṃsā ayam kiṇoti kiṇāti kiṇanti
translated: That is why, although they have attained to a big body, they are called “dogs.”🔽What is the meaning of the word “kiṇ”? It means “to cut,” “to cut up,” “to cut off,” “to cut away,” “to cut out,” “to cut across,” “to cut through,” “to cut short,” “to cut off the life,” “to kill.”

original: Saka sāmatthiye. Samatthabhāvo sāmatthiyaṃ, yathā dakkhiyaṃ. Sakkuṇāti, sakkuṇanti. Asakkhi. Sakkhissati. Sakko. Sakkī.
analyzed: saka sāmatthiye samattha bhāvaḥ sāmatthiyam yathā dakkhiyam sakkuṇāti sakkuṇanti asakkhi sakkhissati sakkaḥ sakkī
translated: The meaning of the word “sak” is “ability.” The state of being able is ability, as in “the visible.” He is able, they are able. He was able. He will be able. He is able. He is able.

original: Ettha sakkoti devarājā. So hi parahitaṃ sakahitañca kātuṃ sakkuṇātīti sakko. Apica
analyzed: ettha sakkoti devarājā saḥ hi para hitam saka hitam ca kātum sakkuṇāti iti sakkaḥ apica
translated: Herein, Sakka is the king of the gods. He is called Sakka because he is able to do what is beneficial to others and to himself. Moreover,

original: sakyakulajāto yo kocipi. Tathā hi “atha kho mahānāmo sakko”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Bhagavantañca
analyzed: sakya kula jātaḥ yaḥ koci pi tathā hi atha kho mahānāmaḥ sakko ti ādi vuttam bhagavantam ca
translated: anyone born in the Sakyan clan is also a Sakka. For this is said: “Then the Sakyan Mahānāma … ” and so on. “The Blessed One is a Sakka, Mahānāma, and I am a Sakka too. Let us go and see the Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened.”

original: piṅgiyo maṃ sakka samuddharāhīti ālapi. Sakyā vata bho kumārā paramasakyā vata bho🔽kumārā”ti vacanamupādāya sabbepi sakyakule jātā “sakyā”ti ca “sākiyā”ti ca “sakkā”ti
analyzed: piṅgiyaḥ mama sakka samuddharāhi iti ālapi sakyāḥ vata bho kumārā parama sakyāḥ vata bho  kumārā ati vacanam upādāya sabbe pi sakya kule jātā ca sākiyāti ca sakkāti
translated: “Piṅgiya, you are my deliverer,” he said. “The young men of the Sakyans are indeed Sakyans,🔽the young men of the Sakyans are indeed Sakyans.” And because of this statement, all those born in the Sakyan clan are called “Sakyans,” “Sākiyans,” and “Sakkas.”🔽

original: ca vuccanti. Ettha svādittepi anekassaradhātuto ekova uṇāpaccayo hoti, na ṇu ṇāpaccayāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca vuccanti ettha an eka ssara dhātutaḥ ekaḥ u va u ṇā paccayaḥ hoti na ṇu ṇā paccayā ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: He addressed me as ‘Sakka, the one who rescues me from the ocean.’ Because of the words ‘The young men are Sakyans, the young men are the supreme Sakyans,’ all those born in the Sakyan clan are called ‘Sakyans,’ ‘Sākiyans,’ and ‘Sakkas.’ Here, even though many roots are melted down, only one suffix is formed, namely, the uṇ-suffix, not the ṇ-suffix.

original: Khī khaye. Khīṇoti. Khīṇāti. Khīṇā jāti. Khīṇo. Ayogā bhūrisaṅkhayo.
analyzed: khī khaye khīṇāti khīṇā jāti khīṇaḥ ayogāḥ bhūri saṅkhayaḥ
translated: Khī means ‘exhaustion.’ Khīṇā means ‘exhausted.’ Khīṇāti means ‘one should exhaust.’ Khīṇā jāti means ‘birth is exhausted.’ Khīṇo means ‘exhausted.’ Ayogā bhūrisaṅkhayo means ‘the great destruction of the yoke.’

original: Ge sadde. Giṇoti, giṇāti.
analyzed: ge sadde giṇoti giṇāti
translated: Ge means ‘sound.’ Giṇoti means ‘he hears.’ Giṇāti means ‘he hears.’

original: Ci caye. Ṇakārassa nakārattaṃ. Pākāraṃ cinoti. Citaṃ kusalaṃ. Ceto puggalo.
analyzed: ci caye ṇakārassa nakāra ttam pākāram cinoti citam kusalam puggalo
translated: Ci means ‘accumulation.’ The ṇ becomes a ṅ. Pākāraṃ cinoti means ‘he builds a wall.’ Citaṃ kusalaṃ means ‘skill is accumulated.’ Ceto puggalo means ‘the person is accumulated.’

original: Ru upatāpe. Ruṇoti, ruṇāti.
analyzed: ru upatāpe ruṇoti ruṇāti
translated: Ru means ‘to burn.’ Ruṇoti means ‘he burns.’ Ruṇāti means ‘he burns.’

original: Rādha sādha saṃsiddhiyaṃ. Rādhuṇāti. Sādhuṇāti. Rādhanaṃ. Ārādhanaṃ. Sādhanaṃ.
analyzed: rādha sādha saṃsiddhiyam rādhuṇā ati sādhuṇā ati rādhanam ārādhanam sādhanam
translated: Rādha means ‘to succeed.’ Rādhuṇāti means ‘he succeeds.’ Sādhuṇāti means ‘he succeeds.’ Rādhanaṃ means ‘success.’ Ārādhanaṃ means ‘success.’ Sādhanaṃ means ‘success.’

original: Pī pītiyaṃ. Pīṇoti, pīṇāti. Pīti, piyo.
analyzed: pīṇoti pīṇāti pīti
translated: Pī means ‘joy.’ Pīṇoti means ‘he delights.’ Pīṇāti means ‘he delights.’ Pīti means ‘joy.’ Piyo means ‘dear.’

original: Apa pāpuṇe sambhu ca. Pāpuṇoti, pāpuṇāti. Patto. Sabbaññutaṃ satthā patto. Sampatto yamasādhanaṃ. Sambhuṇāti, na kiñci atthaṃ abhisambhuṇāti. Sambhuṇanto, abhisambhuṇamāno.
analyzed: apa pāpuṇe sambhu ca pāpuṇoti pāpuṇāti pattaḥ sabbaññu tam satthā pattaḥ sampattaḥ yama sādhanam sambhuṇāti na kiñci attham abhisambhuṇāti sambhuṇantaḥ abhisambhuṇamāno
translated: He reaches, he reaches out; the attained; the Teacher attained omniscience; he attained the state of being a Master; he is not able to reach any meaning; he is reaching, he is reaching out.🔽Herein, the attained: the prefix pa- is like the prefix upa- in the word upappotī .

original: Tattha pattoti pasaddo upasaggo “pappotī”ti ettha pasaddo viya. Tathā hi “patto”ti
analyzed: tattha patto ti pasaddo upasaggo pappoti iti ettha pasaddaḥ viya tathā hi patto ti
translated: For thus: the attained.

original: ettha pāpuṇīti atthe papubbassa apadhātussa pakāre lutte tapaccayassa dvibhāvo bhavati.
analyzed: ettha pāpuṇi iti atthe pa pubbassa apadhātussa pakāre lutte ta paccayassa dvi bhāvaḥ bhavati
translated: Herein, in the sense of ‘he reaches’, the prefix pa- of the prefix pa- has the function of the reduplication and the function of the dual.

original: Tattha na abhisambhuṇātīti na sampāpuṇāti, na sādhetīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tattha na abhisambhuṇāti iti na sampāpuṇāti na sādheti iti vuttam hoti
translated: Herein, he is not able to reach is he is not able to attain, he is not able to accomplish, is what is said.

original: Khipa khepe. Khipuṇāti. Khippaṃ. Khippanti macchapañjaro.
analyzed: khipa khepe khipuṇāti khippam khippanti macchapañjaraḥ
translated: Khip- : to throw away. He throws away; quickly. Quickly is a fish trap.

original: Āpa byāpane. Āpuṇāti. Āpo.
analyzed: āpa byāpane āpuṇāti āpaḥ
translated: Āpa- : to spread. He spreads; water.

original: Mi pakkhepane. Minoti. Mitto.
analyzed: mi pakkhepane minoti mittaḥ
translated: Mi- : to throw away. He throws away; a friend.🔽And here a friend is so called because he is thrown in , thrown together , with all secrets.

analyzed: ettha ca sabbaguyhesu mittaḥ mittaḥ have satta padena hoti iti
translated: But the statement ‘A friend is one who walks seven steps with him’

translated: is made according to usage, not according to the meaning. If it were, then anyone who is not trustworthy

analyzed: satta padavī tihāra mattena api saha gacchantaḥ saha gacchantassa
translated: “One is called a friend because of speaking pleasing words to one who goes along with him even for the distance of seven footsteps,

analyzed: aññamaññam ālāpa sallāpa karaṇa mattena mittaḥ nāma hoti iti vattabbam kiṃkāraṇā daḷha vissāso
translated: and because of exchanging greetings and conversation with him. Why?

original: mitto nāma na bhaveyyāti mittassa guṇapasaṃsāvasena evaṃ vutta”nti.
analyzed: mittaḥ nāma na bhaveyya ati mittassa guṇa pasaṃsā vasena evam vuttan ti
translated: Because one who is not a friend would not be so. This is said in terms of the praise of a friend’s qualities.”

original: Vu saṃvaraṇe. Vuṇoti, vuṇāti, saṃvuṇoti, saṃvuṇāti. Paṇḍito sīlasaṃvuto.
analyzed: saṃvaraṇe vuṇoti vuṇāti saṃvuṇoti saṃvuṇāti paṇḍitaḥ sīla saṃvutaḥ
translated: Vu: in restraint. He restrains, they restrain, he restrains, they restrain. The wise one is restrained by virtue.

analyzed: su abhisave abhisavaḥ nāma pīḷanam manthanam sandhānam sinhānam vā suṇoti suṇāti
translated: Su: in piercing. Piercing is the piercing, the churning, the mixing, the stirring. He hears, they hear.

translated: Here, however, even though there is no samānānattā, samānānattā is said to be samodhāna.

translated: Dikkhuṇāti. Kivuṇāti. Ciruṇāti. Jiruṇāti. Dāsuṇāti. Duṇoti, duṇātīti rūpāni hiṃsāvācakāni bhavanti.🔽So many forms have been seen as good

original: Kītaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ. Kayo, vikkayo. Vikkiṇeyya haneyya vā.🔽Khi gatiyaṃ. Khiṇāti. Atikhiṇo saro. Khaṃ, khāni. Nakārassa ṇakārattaṃ.
analyzed: kītam bhaṇḍam kayaḥ vikkayaḥ haneyya vā  khi gatiyam khiṇāti ati khiṇaḥ saraḥ kham khāni nakārassa ṇakāra ttam
translated: “Kītaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ” means “goods to be sold.” “Kayo, vikkayo” means “selling, bartering.” “Vikkiṇeyya haneyya vā” means “he may sell or kill.”🔽“Khi gatiyaṃ” means “going.” “Khiṇāti” means “he goes.” “Atikhiṇo saro” means “the arrow has gone too far.” “Khaṃ, khāni” means “space, spaces.” The “n” of the “na” is changed to “ṇ.”

analyzed: tattha khiṇāti iti gacchati atikhinoti atigataḥ atra ayam senti ca apa atikhiṇāva
translated: “Khiṇāti” means “he goes.” “Atikhiṇo” means “gone too far.” The following passage occurs in the texts: “They lie down like arrows shot from a bow,

analyzed: purāṇāni anutthunanti tattha cāpa atikhiṇā ati cāpataḥ atikhiṇā atigatā
translated: old age following upon youth.” Here “atikhiṇā” means “gone too far.” In the commentary

original: pana “cāpātikhiṇāti cāpato atikhiṇā cāpā vinimuttāti attho”ti padatthavivaraṇaṃ kataṃ,
analyzed: pana cāpa atikhiṇā ati cāpataḥ atikhiṇā cāpā vinimuttā ati attho ti padattha vivaraṇam katam
translated: the meaning is explained as follows: “Atikhiṇā means gone too far; the meaning is: released from the bow.”

original: tampi gatatthaññeva sandhāya adhippāyatthavasena katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tatra khanti
analyzed: tam pi gata tthaññeva sandhāya adhippāya ttha vasena kata nti daṭṭhabbam tatra khanti
translated: This explanation should be regarded as given with reference to the meaning of the word “gone too far.” “Tatra khanti” means “there, in heaven.”

original: saggo. So hi katapuññehi gantabbattā “kha”nti vuccati. Khānīti saggā.
analyzed: saggaḥ saḥ hi kata puññehi gantabbattā khanti vuccati khāni iti saggā
translated: “Kha” is used because heaven is to be gone to by those who have performed meritorious deeds. “Khānī” means “heavens.”

original: Ci caye. Puññaṃ cināti. Pākāraṃ cināti. Pāramiyo vicināti, vicinati ca. Pupphaṃ ocināti,
analyzed: ci caye puññam cināti pākāram cināti pāramiyaḥ vicināti vicinati ca puppham ocināti
translated: “Ci caye” means “to accumulate.” “Puññaṃ cināti” means “he accumulates merit.” “Pākaraṃ cināti” means “he builds a rampart.” “Pāramiyo vicināti, vicinati ca” means “he examines, investigates the pāramīs.” “Pupphaṃ ocināti” means “he plucks a flower.”

original: ocinati vā. Pacināti. Pacinitvā. Citaṃ kusalaṃ. Cayo sañcayo. Cito pākāro. Cinātīti
analyzed: ocinati vā pacināti pacinitvā citam kusalam cayo sañcayo citaḥ u pākāraḥ cināti iti
translated: He cooks. He has cooked. Cooked is wholesome. A heap is a collection. A heap is a rampart. He piles up.

analyzed: cetaḥ iṭṭhaka vaḍḍhakī yo satto puñña sañcayo sañcayaḥ rāsi samūhaḥ piṇḍaḥ gaṇaḥ saṅghaḥ  kadambaḥ vaggaḥ karaḥ pariyāyā  ji jaye jināti vijināti jiniyati jetā jinaḥ jitaḥ māraḥ māram jitaḥ jitavā jitāvī
translated: The mind is a builder of bricks. Any being is a heap of merit. “A heap, a collection, a multitude, a mass, a group, a gathering,

The sage of sages is a Supreme Buddha.

original: sekkhā. Asekkhamunīti khīṇāsavo. Paccekamunīti paccekabuddho. Munimunīti sammāsambuddho.
analyzed: sekkhā asekkha muni iti khīṇāsavaḥ pacceka muni iti paccekabuddhaḥ muni muni iti sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: He is of many kinds as the house- holder sage, the house- less sage, the trainee sage, the adept sage, the individual-liberated sage, and the supreme sage. Herein, the householder sage is a house- holder who has reached the fruit and come to know the Master’s True Idea. The houseless sage is one of that sort gone forth into homelessness. The trainee sage is the seven kinds of trainers. The adept sage is one whose cankers are destroyed. The individual-liberated sage is a Paccekabuddha. The supreme sage is a Supreme Buddha.

original: Tathā hi āyasmāpi sāriputto āha “munīti vuccati tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti.
analyzed: tathā hi āyasmā api sāriputtaḥ āha muni iti vuccati tathāgataḥ araham sammāsambuddhaḥ ti
translated: For the venerable Sariputta said: “‘Sage’ is said of the Tathāgata, accomplished and fully enlightened” .🔽Pū: in the sense of “purify.”

original: Pū pavane. Pavanaṃ sodhanaṃ. Punāti. Puññaṃ, putto, dantapoṇaṃ.🔽Ettha ca puññanti attano kārakaṃ punāti sodhetīti puññaṃ. Atha vā yattha sayaṃ uppannaṃ
analyzed: pur pavane pavanam sodhanam punāti puññam puttaḥ danta poṇam  ettha ca attanaḥ kārakam punāti sodheti iti puññam atha vā yattha sayam uppannam
translated: Punāti = puññaṃ , putto , dantapoṇaṃ .

original: taṃsantānaṃ punāti visodhetīti puññaṃ. Kintaṃ? Sucaritaṃ kusalakammaṃ. Sakammikattā
analyzed: tad santānam punāti visodheti iti puññam kintam su caritam kusala kammam sa kammikattā
translated: Herein, puññaṃ is that which purifies itself, it purifies, it cleanses, thus it is puññaṃ . Or alternatively, that in which what has arisen purifies, it cleanses, thus it is puññaṃ . What? Good conduct, profitable action.🔽The explanation of the meaning is allowable in terms of the function of the element of one’s own action.

original: dhātussa kāritavasena atthavivaraṇaṃ labbhati. Puttoti attano kulaṃ punāti sodhetīti
analyzed: dhātussa kārita vasena attha vivaraṇam labbhati putto ti attanaḥ kulam punāti sodheti iti
translated: Putto is that which purifies, it cleanses, its own family, thus it is putto .

original: putto. Evañca sati hīnajaccānaṃ caṇḍālādīnaṃ putto nāma na bhaveyyāti na vattabbaṃ
analyzed: puttaḥ evam ca sati caṇḍāla ādīnam puttaḥ nāma na bhaveyya iti na vattabbam
translated: And if that were so, then the son of a low-born person such as a caṇḍāla, etc., would not be a son.

original: saddānamatthakathanassa nānappakārena pavattito, tasmā attano pitu hadayaṃ pūretīti
analyzed: saddānam attha kathanassa nānappakārena pavattitaḥ tasmai attanaḥ pitu hadayam pūreti iti
translated: It is the occurrence in various ways of the meaning of the word “son.” Therefore it “fills its father’s heart” .

original: puttoti evamādināpi nibbacanaṃ gahetabbameva. Nānādhātuvasenapi hi padāni siddhiṃ samupagacchanti.
analyzed: putto ti evamādinā api nibbacanam gahetabbam eva nānā dhātu vasena api hi padāni siddhim samupagacchanti
translated: So the derivation may be taken in this way too. For words are established by various etymologies.

original: Putto ca nāma atrajo khetrajo antevāsiko dinnakoti catubbidho. Tattha attānaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: putto ca nāma atra jaḥ khetra jaḥ antevāsikaḥ dinnakaḥ iti catubbidhaḥ tattha attānam paṭicca
translated: And a son is of four kinds: one born of oneself, one bought, one adopted, and one given. Herein, one born of oneself is called “born.”

original: jāto atrajo nāma. Sayanapīṭhe pallaṅke ureti evamādīsu nibbatto khetrajo nāma. Santike🔽sippuggaṇhanako antevāsiko nāma. Posāpanatthāya dinno dinnako nāma dantapoṇanti dante
analyzed: jātaḥ atrajaḥ nāma sayana pīṭhe pallaṅke ure ti evamādīsu nibbatto khetrajaḥ nāma santike  sippuggaṇhanakaḥ antevāsikaḥ nāma posāpana tthāya dinnaḥ dinnakaḥ nāma danta poṇanti dante
translated: One born on a bed, on a seat, on a lap, and so on, is called “born of a womb.”🔽One who learns a craft in one’s presence is called “adopted.”

original: punanti visodhenti etenāti dantapoṇaṃ, dantakaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: punanti visodhenti etena ati danta poṇam danta kaṭṭham
translated: One given for the sake of support is called “given.” Dantapoṇaṃ = dantapoṇam .

original: Pī tappanakantīsu. Piṇātīti pīti. Ettha ca pītīti pīṇanaṃ pīti, tappanaṃ kantīti
analyzed: tappana kantīsu piṇāti iti pīti ettha ca pīti iti pīṇanam pīti tappanam kanti iti
translated: Pīti = pīti . Herein, pīti is the act of swelling up , and pīti is the act of heating and shining .

original: ca vuttaṃ hoti. Idaṃ bhāvavasena nibbacanaṃ. Idaṃ pana hetukattuvasena piṇayatīti
analyzed: ca vuttam hoti idam bhāva vasena nibbacanam idam pana hetu kattu vasena piṇayati iti
translated: But it is also described as “arisen by being caused to occur” .

original: pīti, tappetīti attho.
analyzed: pi tappeti iti attho
translated: It “causes to occur” , thus it is happiness .

original: Sā panesā khuddakāpīti khaṇikāpīti okkantikāpīti ubbegāpīti pharaṇāpītīti pañcavidhā
analyzed: sā pana esā khuddakā api iti khaṇikā api iti okkantikā api iti ubbegā api iti pharaṇā api iti iti pañcavidhā
translated: This happiness is of five kinds as “minor happiness,” “fleeting happiness,” “transporting happiness,” “uplifting happiness,” and “all-pervading happiness.”

original: hoti. Tattha khuddakāpīti sarīre lomahaṃsanamattameva kātuṃ sakkoti. Khaṇikāpīti🔽khaṇe khaṇe vijjuppādasadisā hoti. Okkantikāpīti samuddatīraṃ vīci viya kāyaṃ okkamitvā
analyzed: hoti tattha khuddakā api iti sarīre loma haṃsana mattam eva kātum sakkoti khaṇikā api iti  khaṇe khaṇe vijjuppāda sadisā hoti okkantikā api iti samudda tīram kāyam okkamitvā
translated: Herein, the minor kind of happiness is only able to make the hairs of the body bristle.🔽The fleeting kind of happiness is like the flash of lightning.🔽The transporting kind of happiness invades the body and breaks out again and again like the waves on the sea shore.

original: okkamitvā bhijjati. Ubbegāpīti balavatī hoti kāyaṃ uddhaggaṃ katvā ākāse laṅghāpanappamāṇā
analyzed: okkamitvā bhijjati ubbegā apīti balavatī hoti kāyam uddhaggam katvā ākāse laṅghāpana ppamāṇā
translated: The uplifting kind of happiness is strong. It is capable of lifting up the body and is like the measure for leaping into the air.

original: hoti. Pharaṇāpītiyā pana uppannāya sakalasarīraṃ dhamitvā pūritavatthi viya mahatā
analyzed: hoti pharaṇa apītiyā pana uppannāya sakala sarīram dhamitvā pūrita vatthi viya mahatā
translated: But when the all-pervading kind of happiness arises, the whole body is as if smeared inside with oil or as if filled with the light of the sun.🔽And it is like the interior of a rock cleft that opens up with the impact of a thunderbolt.

original: udakoghena pakkhandapabbatakucchi viya ca anupariphuṭaṃ hoti, evaṃ pañcavidhā pīti,
analyzed: udaka oghena pakkhanda pabbata kucchi viya ca anupariphuṭam hoti evam pañcavidhā pi iti
translated: This is the fivefold happiness.

original: sā sampiyāyanalakkhaṇattā “piṇātī”ti pītīti suddhakattuvasenapi vattuṃ yujjati. Ettha🔽“piyāyati, pitā, piyo, pemo”tiādīni pīdhātuyā eva rūpāni. Tattha “puttaṃ piyāyatīti
analyzed: sā sampiyāyana lakkhaṇa ttā piṇāti iti pīti iti suddha kattu vasena api vattum yujjati ettha  piyāyati pitā piyaḥ pemā iti ādīni pī dhātuyāḥ eva rūpāni tattha puttam piyāyati iti
translated: It is also proper to call it “pīti” in the sense of the pure verb “to expand” because it has the characteristic of causing one to expand.🔽Herein, “to expand” (piyāyati), “father” (pitā), “dear” (piyo), “love” (pemo) are all forms of the root “to expand” (pī). Herein, they say, “He expands (piyāyati) his son, therefore he is a father (pitā).”

original: pitā”ti vadanti. Piyāyitabboti piyo. Pemanaṃ pemo.
analyzed: pitā ati vadanti piyāyitabbaḥ ti piyaḥ pemanam pemaḥ
translated: That which should be expanded (piyāyitabba) is dear (piyo). Love (pemo) is the state of loving.

original: Mā parimāṇe. Mināti. Mānaṃ, parimāṇaṃ, mattaṃ, mattā, mano, vimānaṃ, minitabbaṃ, metabbaṃ, chāyā metabbā. Īdisesu ṭhānesu anīyapaccayo na labbhati.
analyzed: mā parimāṇe mināti mānam parimāṇam mattam mattā manaḥ vimānam minitabbam metabbam chāyā metabbā īdisesu ṭhānesu anīya paccayaḥ na labbhati
translated: “Mā” is a measure. “Min” is a measure. “Māna” is a measure. “Parimaṇa” is a measure. “Matta” is a measure. “Mattā” is a measure. “Mano” is a measure. “Vimāna” is a measure. “Minitabba” is a measure. “Metabba” is a measure. “Chāyā metabbā” is a measure. In such places as these, the instrumental case is not found.

original: Ettha manoti ekāya nāḷiyā ekāya ca tulāya minamāno viya ārammaṇaṃ mināti paricchindatīti
analyzed: ettha ekāya nāḷiyā ekāya ca tulāya minamānaḥ viyaḥ ārammaṇam mināti paricchindati iti
translated: Herein, “mano” is so called because it measures (mināti) an object by defining it, as if by a single reed and a single scale.

original: mano. Visesato miniyate paricchindiyateti vimānaṃ, devānaṃ puññabalena nibbattabyamhaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ visesataḥ vimānam devānam puñña balena
translated: “Vimāna” is so called because it is measured (miniyate) and defined (paricchindiyate) in a special way, and it is a mansion (vimāna) of the gods produced by the power of their merit.

original: devaniketaṃ. Yaṃ vimānaṃ upasobhitaṃ, pabhāsatimidaṃ byamhanti ca ādinā thomiyati.
analyzed: deva niketam yam vimānam upasobhitam pabhāsatim idam ca ādinā thomiyati
translated: “Vimāna” is a mansion (vimāna) that shines (upasobhita) and glows (pabhāsatī) with light, as in the passage beginning, “This mansion (vimāna) of the gods is resplendent (sobhita) with light (pabhā).”

original: Mī hiṃsāyaṃ. Mināti. Mīno, kumīnaṃ.
analyzed: mī hiṃsa ayam mināti mīnaḥ kumīnam
translated: “Mī” is a root meaning “to kill” (hiṃsā). “Min” is a root meaning “to measure” (min). “Mīna” is a fish. “Kumīnaṃ” is a fish-trap.

original: Ettha mīnoti maccho. Macchassa hi “mīno maccho ambujo vārijo vāricaro”ti anekāni🔽nāmāni. Visesanāmāni pana “amaro khaliso candakulo kandaphali indaphali indavalo
analyzed: ettha mīnoti macchaḥ macchassa hi mīnaḥ macchaḥ ambu jaḥ vāri jaḥ vāri caroti anekāni  nāmāni visesa nāmāni pana amaraḥ khalisaḥ candakulo kandaphali indaphali indavalo
translated: Herein, it is a fish that “min”s, for a fish has many names such as “min” , “macch” , “ambuja” , “vārija” , “vārijo” , “vāricara” ,

original: kuliso vāmi kuṅkutalo kaṇḍiko sakulo maṅguro siṅgī satavaṅko rohito pāṭhīno kāṇo
analyzed: kulisaḥ vāmi kuṅkutalaḥ kaṇḍikaḥ sakulaḥ maṅguraḥ siṅgī satavaṅkaḥ rohitaḥ pāṭhīnaḥ kāṇaḥ
translated: and also such special names as “amaro” , “khaliso” , “candakula” , “kandaphalī” , “indaphalī” , “indavala” , “kulisā” , “vāmi” , “kuṅkutalā” , “kaṇḍikā” , “sakulā” , “maṅgurā” , “siṅgī” , “satavaṅkā” , “rohita” , “pāṭhīna” , “kāṇo” ,

original: savaṅko pāvuso” iccevamādīni, “timi timiṅgalo” iccevamādīni ca bhavanti. Kumīnanti
analyzed: pāvuso iti evamādīni timi timiṅgalaḥ iti evamādīni ca bhavanti
translated: “savaṅkā” , “pāvusā” , and also such as “timī” , “timīṅgalā” .

original: kucchitenākārena macche minanti hiṃsanti etenāti kumīnaṃ, macchabandhanapañjaro.
analyzed: kucchitena ākārena macche minanti hiṃsanti etena ati kumīnam
translated: “Kumīna” is a net for catching fish, for they “min” , i.e. they harm, with that because of its shape like a belly.

original: So pana pāḷiyaṃ kumīnasaddena vuccati. Tathā hi –
analyzed: saḥ pana pāḷiyam kumīna saddena vuccati tathā hi
translated: But in the texts it is called a “kumīna” by the word “kumīna” , for this stanza is found:🔽“Though I am like a water-lily,

original: “Vārijasseva me sato, bandhassa kumināmukhe;
analyzed: vāri jassa iva me sataḥ bandhassa kuminā mukhe
translated: I am caught in a kumīna’s mouth;🔽I am reviled and struck,

original: Akkosati paharati, piye putte apassato”ti🔽Pāḷi dissati.
analyzed: akkosati paharati piye putte a passatoti  pāḷi dissati
translated: Not seeing my dear children.”

original: Mū bandhane. Munāti. Muni.
analyzed: bandhane munāti muni
translated: “Mun” is a root meaning “to bind” . “Muni” is a recluse.

original: Ettha munīti attano cittaṃ munāti mavati bandhati rāgadosādivasaṃ gantuṃ na detīti muni.
analyzed: ettha muni iti cittam munāti mavati bandhati rāga dosāḥ divasam gantum na deti iti muni
translated: Herein, a recluse is one who “mun”s, i.e. who “munā” , keeps, binds, his own mind, who does not let it go as it wishes to lust, hate, and so on.

original: Ri gatidesanesu. Rikāti. Reṇu. Nakārassa ṇattaṃ.
analyzed: ri gati desanesu reṇu nakārassa ṇattam
translated: Rik means Reṇu. The n is changed to ṇ.

original: Lī silese. Lināti, nilināti. Līnaṃ, sallīnaṃ, paṭisallānaṃ.🔽Vī tantasantāne. Vatthaṃ vināti. Iminā suttena cīvaraṃ vināhi. Kamme – idaṃ kho āvuso
analyzed: silese lināti nilināti līnam sat līnam paṭisallānam  tanta santāne vattham vinā ati iminā suttena cīvaram idam kho āvuso
translated: Lī means to stick. It sticks, it sticks fast. Stuck, stuck fast, sticking fast.

original: cīvaraṃ maṃ uddissa viyyati. Vītaṃ. Suvītaṃ. Appakaṃ hoti vetabbaṃ. Kārite “vāyāpeti,
analyzed: cīvaram mam uddissa viyyati vītam su vītam appakam hoti vetabbam kārite
translated: Vī means a series of threads. It weaves cloth. “Weave this robe with this thread” is said. In making: “This robe, friends, is being woven for me. Woven, well woven. There is little to be woven. Having had it made, he causes it to be woven

original: tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpessāmā’ti cīvaraṃ vāyāpesuṃ” iccevamādīni bhavanti.
analyzed: tantavāyehi cīvaram vāyāpessāma ati cīvaram icca evamādīni bhavanti
translated: by weavers, ‘We will weave a robe’” and so on.

original: Vī hiṃsāyaṃ. Vināti. Veṇu. Veṇūti vaṃso.
analyzed: vī hiṃsa ayam vināti veṇu veṇūti vaṃso
translated: Vī means to destroy. It destroys. Reed. Reed means bamboo.

original: Lū chedane. Lunāti. Loṇaṃ, kusalaṃ, bālo, lūto.
analyzed: chedane lunāti loṇam kusalam bālaḥ
translated: Lū means to cut. It cuts. Salt, good, fool, thief.

original: Ettha ca loṇanti lunāti vītarasabhāvaṃ vināseti sarasabhāvaṃ karotīti loṇaṃ, lavaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca lunāti vīta rasa bhāvam sa rasa bhāvam karoti iti loṇam lavaṇam
translated: And here salt is so called because it cuts out, destroys, the waterless state and brings about the watery state.

original: Kuso viya hatthappadesaṃ akusaladhamme lunātīti kusalaṃ, anavajjaiṭṭhavipākalakkhaṇo
analyzed: kusaḥ viya hattha ppadesam akusala dhamme lunāti iti kusalam anavajja eṭṭha vipāka lakkhaṇo
translated: Good is so called because it cuts off, removes, the state of being unskilled from the part of the body as if it were a limb.

original: dhammo. Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyike dve atthe lunātīti bālo, avidvā. Lūtoti makkaṭako🔽vuccati. Tassa hi suttaṃ “lūtasutta”nti vadanti. Yūsaṃ pātuṃ paṭaṅgamakkhikādīnaṃ
analyzed: dhammaḥ diṭṭhadhammika samparāyike dve atthe lunāti iti bālaḥ a vidvā lūto ti makkaṭakaḥ  vuccati tassa hi suttam lūtasuttam ti vadanti yūsam pātum paṭaṅga makkhikā ādīnam
translated: the Dhamma. The fool, the undiscerning one, destroys two benefits that are visible in this very life and in the life to come. The word “destroyer” is a term for a monkey.🔽For they say that the Thread is called “The Thread of the Destroyer” . The juice for drinking of flies and bees, etc.,🔽

original: jīvitaṃ lunātīti lūto.
analyzed: jīvitam lunāti iti
translated: and the Dhamma. The fool, the unwise, cuts off the two benefits that are in the here-and-now and in the life to come. He cuts off: a monkey is what is called a “cutter-off” . For his Thread is called the “Cutter-off’s Thread” . He cuts off the life of flies and bluebottles, etc., that come to drink the juice. He cuts off: a “cutter-off” .

original: Si bandhane. Sināti. Sīmā, sīsaṃ.
analyzed: si bandhane sināti sīmā sīsam
translated: Si is for “binding” . He binds: a boundary, a head.

original: Ettha sīmāti sinīyate samaggena saṅghena kammavācāya bandhiyateti sīmā. Sā duvidhā
analyzed: ettha sīmā ati sinīyate samaggena saṅghena kamma vācāya bandhiyate iti sīmā sā duvidhā
translated: Herein, a boundary is what is bound by a legal procedure of the Community acting together. It is bound: a boundary . It is twofold:

original: baddhasīmā abaddhasīmāti. Tāsu abaddhasīmā mariyādakaraṇavasena “sīmā”ti veditabbā.
analyzed: baddha sīmā abaddha sīmā ati tāsu abaddha sīmā mariyāda karaṇa vasena sīmā ati veditabbā
translated: a bound- ary and an unbound boundary. Herein, an unbound boundary should be understood as a boundary in the sense of a limit.

original: Sināti bandhati kese moḷikaraṇavasena etthāti sīsaṃ. Aññānipi yojetabbāni.
analyzed: sināti bandhati kese moḷikaraṇa vasena ettha ati sīsam aññāni pi yojetabbāni
translated: He binds: it is bound in this way by the binding of the hair in a topknot. A head: it is bound in this way by the binding of the hair in a topknot. Other instances can be found.

original: Sā pāke. Sināti.
analyzed: sā pāke sināti
translated: Sa is for “cooking” . He cooks:

original: Su hiṃsāyaṃ. Suṇāti. Parasu. Paraṃ suṇanti hiṃsanti etenāti parasu.
analyzed: su hiṃsā ayam suṇāti parasu param suṇanti hiṃsanti etena ati parasu
translated: Su is for “cutting” . He cuts: an axe. It cuts: an axe .

original: Asa bhojane. Vuttānaṃ phalamasnāti. Asanaṃ.
analyzed: bhojane phalam asnāti
translated: Asa is for “eating” . He eats: food. He eats: food.

original: Ettha asananti āhāro. So hi asiyati bhuñjiyatīti “asana”nti vuccati. “Asnātha khādatha pivathā”ti idamettha nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: ettha asananti āhāro so hi bhuñjiyati iti asananti vuccati asnātha khādatha pivatha ati idam ettha nidassanam
translated: Herein, asan means nutriment. For that is said to be “nutriment” since it is what is eaten , is chewed , is sucked , is drunk . “Eat, chew, suck, drink” is the illustration here.

original: Kilisa vibādhane. Kilisnāti. Kileso.
analyzed: kilisa vibādhane kilisnāti kileso
translated: Kilisa is in the sense of affliction. It defiles , thus it is defilement .

original: Ettha ca kilesoti rāgādayopi dukkhampi vuccati.🔽Uddhasa uñche. Uñcho pariyesanaṃ. Uddhasnāti.
analyzed: ettha ca kilesaḥ ti rāga ādayaḥ api dukkham pi vuccati  uddhasaḥ uñche uñchaḥ pariyesanam
translated: And here “defilement” is said to be both the lust, etc., and also suffering.🔽Uddhasa is in the sense of seeking. It seeks , thus it is seeking .

original: Isa abhikkhaṇe. Isnāti.
analyzed: isa abhikkhaṇe isnāti
translated: Isa is in the sense of piercing. It pierces , thus it is piercing .

original: Visa vippayoge. Visnāti. Visaṃ.🔽Pusa sinehasavanapūraṇesu. Pusnāti.
analyzed: visa vippayoge visam  sineha savana pūraṇesu
translated: Visa is in the sense of separation. It separates , thus it is separation . It is a poison .🔽Pusa is in the sense of moistening, of pouring in, of filling. It moistens , thus it is moistening .

original: Pusa posane. Pusnāti.
analyzed: pusa posane
translated: Pusa is in the sense of nourishing. It nourishes , thus it is nourishing .

original: Musa theyye. Musnāti. Musalo.
analyzed: musa theyye
translated: Musa is in the sense of deceiving. It deceives , thus it is a club .

original: Kiyādī ettakā diṭṭhā, dhātavo me yathābalaṃ;
analyzed: ettakāḥ diṭṭhāḥ dhātavaḥ me yathābalam
translated: So many roots have been seen By me as far as my ability extends;

original: Suttesvaññepi pekkhitvā, gaṇhavho atthayuttito.
analyzed: pekkhitvā gaṇhavhaḥ attha yuttitaḥ
translated: Having looked at them in the texts, You should grasp them by their meaning.

original: Sāsanā lokato cete,

original: tasadhātuto nipphannataṇhāsaddasmā parassa āyapaccayassa vasena nipphannaṃ. Tathā🔽kiñcāpi rūpiyasaṃvohārasikkhāpadavaṇṇanāyaṃ “vāsiphalaṃ tāpetvā udakaṃ vā khīraṃ
analyzed: tasa dhātutaḥ parassa āya paccayassa vasena nipphannam tathā  kiñca api rūpiya saṃvohāra sikkhāpada vaṇṇanāyam vāsi phalam tāpetvā udakam vā khīram
translated: and the word “he heats” is formed by the prefix ā- and the verbal noun paccaya, which is formed by the prefix ni- and the verbal noun tanhā, which is formed by the prefix ta- and the verbal noun dhātu.

original: vā uṇhāpetī”ti imasmiṃ padese “uṇhāpetī”ti hetukattuvācakaṃ kriyāpadaṃ dissati, tathāpi
analyzed: vā uṇhā apeti iti imasmin padese uṇhā apeti iti hetu kattu vācakam kriyā padam dissati tathā api

analyzed: uṇhāpayati iti diṭṭham eva hoti

analyzed: kiñca bhiyyas vinaya ṭṭhakathā ayam uṇhāpeti iti kārita padassa diṭṭha ttāya iva uṇhati iti

analyzed: kattu padam pi nayataḥ diṭṭham eva hoti kattu kārita padānam eka dhātumhi  yathā gaṇhati gaṇhāpeti gacchati gacchāpeti iti tasmai dāheti uṇhati iti
translated: The form of the verb is seen to be the same in the case of the causative as in the case of the non-causative, since the verb and the verbal noun are found in the same element,🔽as in the case of “He seizes, he causes to seize; he goes, he causes to go.” Therefore, having understood that the element of “he heats” is the same as that of “he burns,”

original: rūpaṃ upalabbhatīti mantvā “uṇhatīti uṇha”nti nibbacanaṃ kātabbaṃ. Iti ppapaccayo
analyzed: rūpam upalabbhati iti mantvā uṇhati iti uṇhanti nibbacanam kātabbam iti
translated: the derivation should be given as “He heats, therefore heat.” So the -ppaccaya

original: ekadhā labbhatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kiñcāpettha evaṃ niyamo vutto, tathāpi sāṭṭhakathe
analyzed: ekadhā labbhati iti daṭṭhabbam kiñcā api ittha evam niyamaḥ vuttaḥ tathā api sa aṭṭhakathe
translated: And why is this rule stated thus? Although in the nine-factored sutta

translated: other nominal and verbal bases should be sought. But since the groups of verbs beginning with “to seize” have been taken by us in this way in accordance with the Buddha Word,

analyzed: amhehi gahitāḥ imasmai nayāḥ aññaḥ nayo pasatthataraḥ natthi ayam eva pasatthataraḥ tasmā
translated: there is no other method more approved than this one; this one alone is more approved.

analyzed: ayam nīti sāsana ṭṭhitiyā āyasmantehi sādhukam dhāretabbā vācetabbā ca

original: Tanādigaṇika

translated: The group of words beginning with ‘tanu’

original: Tanu vitthāre. Tanoti. Āyatanaṃ, tanu. Kammani “taniyyati, taniyyanti. Vitaniyyatī”ti🔽rūpāni. Atrāyaṃ pāḷi “yathā hi āsabhaṃ cammaṃ, pathabyā vitaniyyatī”ti. Garū pana

original: “patāyate, pataññatī”ti rūpāni vadanti. Tanituṃ, tanitvāna. Tumantādirūpāni.🔽Tattha āyatananti āyabhūte dhamme tanoti vitthāretīti āyatanaṃ. Tanūti sarīraṃ. Tañhi
analyzed: patāyate pataññati iti rūpāni vadanti tanitum tanitvāna tumanta ādi rūpāni  tattha āyatanam ti āya bhūte dhamme tanoti vitthāreti iti āyatanam tanūti sarīram tat hi
translated: But the grammarians say that ‘rūpa’ is so called because it is spread out on the ground, like a hide, and because it is spread out, extended, in the sky. ‘Tanoti’ is to extend, and ‘tanitvāna’ is having extended. ‘Tum’ is a nominal affix. ‘Rūpa’ are the material dhammas.

original: kalalato paṭṭhāya kammādīhi yathāsambhavaṃ taniyyati vitthāriyati mahattaṃ pāpiyatīti

translated: But in such passages as “The heart-deliverance due to fading of lust, the heart- deliverance due to fading of hatred, the heart-deliverance due to fading of delusion” ,🔽the word “fading” is a synonym for “little,” and we do not find a verbal form corresponding to it.

original: tasmā nipātapadena tena bhavitabbaṃ. Tanusaddo nipātapadanti vuttaṭṭhānampi na passāma,

analyzed: taniyyanti taniyyasi itiādinā vitthāretabbam

original: Tattha sakkoti devarājā. So hi atthānaṃ sahassampi muhuttena cintanasamatthatāya🔽saparahitaṃ kātuṃ sakkotīti “sakko”ti vuccati. Aññatra pana dhātūnaṃ avisaye taddhitavasena

translated: Herein, Sakka is the king of the gods. He is called “Sakka” because he is able to do what is to be done without help,🔽since he is able to consider a thousand matters in a moment. But in other instances, in the absence of a verbal root,

analyzed: vuttaṃ hi bhagavatā sakkaḥ mahāli devānamindo pubbe manussa bhūtaḥ samāno sakkaccam

analyzed: dānam adāsi tasmā sakko ti vuccati iti sakkontaḥ sakkontī sakkontam kulam

analyzed: khuṇu khiṇu hiṃsa ayam khuṇoti khiṇoti

analyzed: iṇu gatiyam iṇoti iṇam  adane tiṇoti tiṇam ettha tiṇanti yavasam tat hi tiṇiyate tiṇa bhakkhehi goṇa ādīhi adiyate khādiyate iti tiṇam  ghiṇu dittiyam ghiṇoti
translated: Iṇu is a verb of going.🔽Tiṇu is a verb of eating.🔽Ghiṇu is a verb of seeing.

analyzed: hanu apanayane apanayanam an ālāpa karaṇam nibbacana tā karaṇam hanoti hanute
translated: Hanu is a verb of sending away.

original: Panu dāne panoti. Panute.
analyzed: panu dāne panoti panute
translated: Panu is a verb of giving.🔽Manu is a verb of waking up.

original: Manu bodhane. Manoti. Manute. Mano. Manaṃ. Mānasaṃ. Manusso. Mānavo. Māṇavo.
analyzed: manu bodhane manoti manute manaḥ manam mānasam manussaḥ mānavaḥ māṇavaḥ
translated: Mano is a noun derived from the verb manoti.

analyzed: ettha manoti manute bujjhati iti mano evam manam imesam pana dvinnam mana saddānam
translated: The two words mano and manaṃ are derived from the verb manoti.

original: “yasmiṃ mano nivisati. Santaṃ tassa manaṃ hotī”tiādīsu punnapuṃsakaliṅgatā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: yasmin manaḥ nivisati santam tassa manam hoti itiādīsu punnapuṃsaka liṅga tā daṭṭhabbā
translated: In such passages as “Yasmiṃ mano nivisati, santaṃ tassa manaṃ hotī” , the words mano and manaṃ should be regarded as having the neuter and masculine genders respectively.

original: Mānasanti rāgopi cittampi arahattampi. “Antalikkhacaro pāso, yvāyaṃ carati mānaso”ti
analyzed: mānasanti rāgaḥ api cittam api arahattam api antalikkha caraḥ pāsaḥ yvā ayam carati mānasa uti
translated: “Mind” here stands for lust, for the mind, and for arahatship. “The snare that lies concealed, that goes by mind” .🔽

original: ettha hi rāgo mānasaṃ. “Cittaṃ mano mānasa”nti ettha cittaṃ. “Appattamānaso sekkho,🔽kālaṃ kayirā jane suto”ti ettha arahattaṃ. Etthetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: ettha hi rāgaḥ mānasam cittam manaḥ mānasanti ettha cittam appatta mānasaḥ sekkho  kālam ettha arahattam ettha itam vuccati
translated: “Mind” is lust, cognizance, and Arahantship. In the passage “The snare that wanders in the mind “ , lust is the mind. In the passage “Mind, cognizance, and the mind” , it is cognizance. In the passage “The disciple in training, not yet reached His mind’s desire, may die” , it is Arahantship. This is how it is said:

original: Rāgo cittaṃ arahattañca, “mānasa”nti samīritaṃ;
analyzed: rāgaḥ cittam samīritam
translated: Lust, cognizance, and Arahantship Are called “mind” in the Dispensation,

original: Satthuno sāsane pāpa-sāsane’khilasāsane.
analyzed: satthuno sāsane pāpa sāsana akhila sāsane
translated: In the Dispensation of the Blessed One, the Dispensation of the Good, the Dispensation of the Whole.

original: Tattha sampayuttamanasi bhavoti rāgo mānaso. Mano eva mānasanti katvā cittaṃ mānasaṃ.
analyzed: tattha sampayutta manasi bhavaḥ ti rāgaḥ mānasaḥ manaḥ eva mānasanti katvā cittam mānasam
translated: Herein, lust is the mind in the sense of “what is associated with the mind” . Cognizance is the mind in the sense of “mind itself is the mind” .

original: Anavasesato mānaṃ siyati samucchindatīti aggamaggo mānasaṃ. Tannibbattattā pana arahattassa🔽mānasatā daṭṭhabbā. Manūti satto. “Yena cakkhupasādena, rūpāni manu passatī”ti ettha
analyzed: anavasesataḥ mānam siyati samucchindati iti aggamaggaḥ mānasam tad nibbatta ttā pana arahattassa  mānasa tā daṭṭhabbā manu iti sattaḥ yena cakkhu pasādena rūpāni manu passati iti ettha
translated: The Noble Eightfold Path is the mind in the sense of “it causes the cutting off of all the kinds of conceit” . But Arahantship’s mindness should be regarded as due to its being produced by that .🔽“Man” is a being. In the passage “By means of the eye-sensitivity a man sees visible shapes” ,

original: hi “manū”ti satto vutto. Atha vā manūti paṭhamakappikakāle manussānaṃ mātāpibhuṭṭhāne
analyzed: hi manu iti sattaḥ vuttaḥ atha vā manu iti paṭhama kappika kāle manussānam mātā pibhu ṭṭhāne
translated: “man” is a being. Or alternatively, “man” is the place where the mothers and fathers of men in the first period of mankind’s life ate.

original: ṭhito manunāmako puriso, yo sāsane “mahāsammatarājā”ti vutto. So hi sakalalokassa
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ manu nāmakaḥ puriso yaḥ sāsane mahā sammata rājā ati vutto so hi sakala lokassa
translated: The man who stood there was called Manu, who is called in the Dispensation the “Great Elect.” For he is called “Manu” because he “measures” what is good for the world,

original: hitaṃ kātuṃ manute jānātīti “manū”ti vuccati. Yathābalaṃ attano hitaṃ manute jānātīti🔽manusso, manassa vā ussannattā manusso. Atha vā vuttappakārassa manuno apaccaṃ manusso.
analyzed: hitam kātum manute jānāti iti vuccati yathābalam attanaḥ hitam manute jānāti iti  manussaḥ manassa vā ussannattā manussaḥ atha vā vutta ppakārassa manunaḥ apaccam manussaḥ
translated: or because he “measures” what is good for himself according to his ability,🔽or because he is “man” because of the abundance of “mind” ,

original: Evaṃ mānavo māṇavo ca, nakārassa hi ṇakāre kate “māṇavo”ti rūpaṃ sijjhati. Keci panāhu
analyzed: evam mānavaḥ māṇavaḥ ca nakārassa hi ṇakāre kate māṇavaḥ iti rūpam sijjhati keci pana āhu
translated: or because he is the “offspring” of Manu. So too with “manava” and “māṇava.” For the form “māṇava” is derived by adding the suffix “-ava” to the word “māṇa” .

original: “dantajanakārasahito mānavasaddo sabbasattasādhāraṇavacano, muddhajaṇakārasahito
analyzed: danta jana kāra sahitaḥ mānava saddaḥ sabba satta sādhāraṇa vacanaḥ muddha jaṇa kāra sahitaḥ
translated: But some say that the word “manava” with the prefix “danta” is a term common to all beings,

original: pana māṇavasaddo kucchitamūḷhāpaccavacano”ti, taṃ vīmaṃsitvā yuttañce, gahetabbaṃ,
analyzed: pana māṇava saddo kucchita mūḍhā paccavacanaḥ ti tam vīmaṃsitvā yuttam ce gahetabbam
translated: but that the word “māṇava” with the prefix “muddha” is a term for the foolish and ignorant. That can be accepted if it is examined and found correct.

original: na panettha vattabbaṃ “māṇavasaddassa atthuddhāravacane idaṃ vacanaṃ virujjhatī”ti
analyzed: na pana ittha vattabbam māṇava saddassa attha uddhāra vacane idam vacanam virujjhati iti
translated: But here it should not be said that this statement contradicts the derivation of the meaning of the word “māṇava”

original: antarasaddassa atthuddhāre antaraantarikāsaddānampi āharaṇassa dassanato.
analyzed: antara saddassa attha uddhāre antara antarikā saddānam pi āharaṇassa dassanato
translated: because the word “antara” is included in the derivation of the meaning of the word “manava” since the words “antara” and “antarikā” are mentioned.

original: Tatra panāyaṃ vīmaṃsanā – cūḷakammavibhaṅgasuttasmiñhi “subho māṇavotodeyyaputto”ti
analyzed: tatra pana ayam vīmaṃsanā cūḷa kamma vibhaṅga suttasmin hi subhaḥ māṇavotodeyya putto ti
translated: Here is the investigation: In the Cūḷakammavibhaṅgasutta, in the passage beginning “The brahmin student Subha, the son of Todeyya,”

original: imasmiṃ padese aṭṭhakathācariyehi “subhoti so kira dassanīyo ahosi pāsādiko, tenassa
analyzed: imasmin padese aṭṭhakathā cariyehi subho ti so kira dassanīyaḥ ahosi pāsādiko tena assa
translated: the teachers of the commentaries have explained the word māṇava as follows: “Subha was handsome and pleasing, and because of his physical beauty

original: aṅgasubhatāya ‘subho’tveva nāmaṃ akaṃsu. ‘Māṇavo’ti pana taṃ taruṇakāle vohariṃsu,🔽so mahallakakālepi teneva vohārena vohariyatī”ti evaṃ muddhajaṇakārassa māṇavasaddassa🔽attho pakāsito, taṭṭīkāyampi garūhi “yaṃ apaccaṃ kucchitaṃ muddhaṃ vā, tattha loke
analyzed: aṅga subha tāya nāmam pana tam taruṇa kāle  saḥ mahallaka kāle pi tena iva vohārena vohariyati iti evam muddha jaṇakārassa māṇava saddassa  atthaḥ pakāsitaḥ tad ṭīkāyam pi garūhi yam apaccam kucchitam muddham vā tattha loke
translated: they gave him the name ‘Subha.’ But they called him a māṇava when he was young,🔽and even when he was old they still called him by that term.”🔽Thus they have explained the meaning of the word māṇava, which is derived from the word muddha. In the subcommentary, the teachers have said:

original: māṇavavohāro, yebhuyyena ca sattā daharakāle muddhadhātukā hontīti vuttaṃ ‘taruṇakāle
analyzed: māṇava vohāraḥ yebhuyyena ca sattāḥ dahara kāle muddha dhātukāḥ honti iti vuttam taruṇa kāle
translated: “The word māṇava is used in the world to refer to a young person whose head has not yet been shaved. And since most beings are of a foolish disposition when young,🔽it is said that he was called a māṇava when he was young.”

original: vohariṃsū”ti, evaṃ muddhajaṇakārassa māṇavasaddassa attho pakāsito. Idāni māṇavasaddassa
analyzed: vohariṃsu iti evam muddha jaṇa kārassa māṇava saddassa attho pakāsito idāni māṇava saddassa
translated: Thus they have explained the meaning of the word māṇava, which is derived from the word muddha. Now the derivation of the word māṇava is as follows:

original: atthuddhāro bhavati, māṇavoti sattopi coropi taruṇopi vuccati. “Coditā devadūtehi,
analyzed: atthuddhāraḥ bhavati māṇavaḥ ti sattaḥ api coraḥ api taruṇaḥ api vuccati coditā deva dūtehi
translated: A māṇava is either a thief, a young person, or a brahmin.

original: ye pamajjanti māṇavā”tiādīsu hi satto “māṇavo”ti vutto. “Māṇavehi saha gacchanti
analyzed: ye pamajjanti māṇava ati ādīsu hi sattaḥ māṇavaḥ iti vuttaḥ māṇavehi saha gacchanti
translated: In such passages as “They go with young men🔽who have done and who have not done their duties” the thief is called “young man.”

original: katakammehipi akatakammehipī”tiādīsu coro. “Ambaṭṭho māṇavo”tiādīsu taruṇo “māṇavo”ti vutto.
analyzed: kata kammehi pi a kata kammehi pi itiādīsu coraḥ ambaṭṭhaḥ māṇavo tiādīsu taruṇaḥ māṇavo ti vutto
translated: In such passages as “The young man Ambattha” the tender one is called “young man.”🔽Appa is a measure.

original: Appa pāpuṇe. Appoti. Āpo.
analyzed: appa pāpuṇe āpaḥ
translated: Appa is āpo.

original: Ettha āpoti appoti taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ vissaratīti āpo.
analyzed: ettha āpo iti tam tam ṭhānam vissarati iti āpo
translated: Herein, āpo is that which spreads to this and that place.🔽Mā is a measure.

original: Mā parimāṇe. Minoti. Upamā, upamānaṃ, vimānaṃ. Aññānipi yojetabbāni.
analyzed: mā parimāṇe minoti upamā upamānam vimānam aññāni pi yojetabbāni
translated: Mino is a simile, a comparison, a disparagement. Others should be construed too.

original: Ettha ca yā accantaṃ na minoti na vicchindati, sā mānassa samīpe vattatīti upamā
analyzed: ettha ca yā accantam na minoti na vicchindati sā mānassa samīpe vattati iti upamā
translated: And here that which does not at all mino, does not break up, is near to a measure, is a simile,🔽like “a bull like an ox.”🔽Upamānanti is a simile itself,

original: yathā “goṇo viya gavajo”ti. Upamānanti upamā eva. Tathā hi “vītopamānamappamāṇamanāthanātha”nti.
analyzed: yathā goṇaḥ upamānanti upamāḥ eva tathā hi vīta upamānam appamāṇam anātha nātham ti
translated: for it is said, “Vītopamānamappamāṇamanāthanātha” .

original: Ettha vītopamānanti imassa vītopamaṃ, nirupamanti attho. Atha vā upamānanti upametabbākāro
analyzed: ettha vīta upamānam ti imassa vīta upamam nirupamam ti atthaḥ atha vā upamānam ti upametabba ākāraḥ
translated: Herein, vītopamānam means “having a simile left out,” the meaning is “without a simile.” Or alternatively, upamānanti is the mode of comparison,

original: “sīho viya bhagavā”ti. Ettha hi sīho upamā, bhagavā upameyyo tejoparakkamādīhi upametabbattā,
analyzed: sīhaḥ viya bhagavā ti ettha hi sīhaḥ upamā bhagavā upameyyaḥ teja uparakkama ādīhi upametabba ttā
translated: like “The Blessed One is like a lion,” for here the lion is the simile, the Blessed One is the object of comparison, because he is to be compared by means of his fiery energy, etc.,

original: tejoparakkamādayo upametabbākāro. Ettha pana sātisayattā kiñcāpi sīhassa tejādīhi
analyzed: teja upara kkama ādayaḥ upametabba ākāraḥ ettha pana sa atisaya ttā kiñcā api sīhassa teja ādīhi
translated: The lion’s courage, etc., are the modes of resemblance. But although the Blessed One’s courage, etc., are not actually similar to the lion’s, etc., in the sense of being the same, still they are similar in being non-deficient in courage, etc.,

original: bhagavato tejādiupametabbākāro natthi, tathāpi hīnūpamāvasena “sīho viya bhagavā”ti🔽vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vimānanti utusamuṭṭhānattepi kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhānattā kammena
analyzed: bhagavato teja ādi upametabba ākāraḥ na atthi tathā api hi inūpamā vasena sīhaḥ viya bhagavā ti  vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam vimānan ti utu samuṭṭhāna tte pi kamma paccaya otu samuṭṭhāna ttā kammena
translated: and so they can be called “courage, etc.,” and so they are called “courage, etc.,” which are modes of resemblance, by the method of the inferior example.

original: visesato miniyati paricchindiyatīti vimānaṃ.🔽Kara karaṇe. “Karoti, kayirati, kubbati, krubbati, pakaroti, upakaroti, apakaroti,🔽paṭikaroti, nirākaroti, paṭisaṅkharoti, abhisaṅkharoti” iccevamādīni kattari bhavanti.🔽Kamme pāḷinayavasena ikārāgamaṭṭhāne yakārassa dvebhāvo. Tasmiṃyevaṭhāne rayakārānaṃ
analyzed: visesataḥ vimānam  kara karaṇe karoti kayirati kubbati krubbati pakaroti upakaroti apakaroti  paṭikaroti nirākaroti paṭisaṅkharoti abhisaṅkharoti icca evamādīni kattari bhavanti  kamme ikāra āgama ṭṭhāne yakārassa dvebhāvaḥ
translated: Vimāna : it is measured out by kamma, thus it is a vimana .

original: vipariyāye sati na dvebhāvo. Tathā īkārāgamaṭṭhāne “kariyyati, kayirati, karīyati,

original: kayyati, pakarīyati, pakariyyati, paṭisaṅkhariyyati, abhisaṅkhariyyati” iccevamādīni kammani bhavanti.
analyzed: pakarīyati pakariyyati paṭisaṅkhariyyati abhisaṅkhariyyati icca evamādīni kammani bhavanti
translated: It is built, it is being built, it will be built, it is being considered, it is being planned.

original: Ettha ca kayiratīti padaṃ dvīsu ṭhānesu dissati kattari kamme ca. Tesa kattuvasena🔽“puriso kammaṃ kayiratī”ti yojetabbaṃ, kammavasena pana ayaṃ pāḷi “kuṭi me kayirati
analyzed: ettha ca padam dvīsu ṭhānesu dissati kattari kamme ca kattu vasena  puriso kammam kayirati iti yojetabbam kamma vasena pana ayam me
translated: And the word kayirati is found in two places, in the nominative case as the subject of a verb and in the accusative case as the object of a verb.🔽In the first place, it is to be construed as follows: “A man builds a hut.”

original: adesitavatthukā”ti. Tattha ca kattuvasena vuttaṃ kattupadaṃ yirapaccayena siddhaṃ.
analyzed: a desita vatthukā ti tattha ca kattu vasena vuttam kattu padam yira paccayena siddham
translated: In the second place, the passage “A hut is being built for me” is to be construed as follows: “A hut is being built for me by another, not by myself.”

original: Kammavasena pana vuttaṃ kammapadaṃ ikārāgamassa ādiantabhūtānaṃ rayakārānaṃ vipariyāyenāti
analyzed: kamma vasena pana vuttam kamma padam ikāra āgamassa ādi anta bhūtānam raya kārānam vipariyāyena ati
translated: And here the word kayirati in the accusative case is formed by the addition of the suffix yira to the verb form kayi in the nominative case.🔽But the word kayirati in the nominative case is formed by the addition of the suffix ray to the verb form kā in the third person singular, and then the vowel a is changed to i, and the suffix yati is added.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Kāreti, kārayati, kārāpeti, kārāpayatī”ti cattāri kāritarūpāni, yāni🔽“hetukatturūpānī”ti vuccanti taddīpakattā.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam kāreti kārayati kārāpeti kārāpayati iti cattāri kārita rūpāni yāni  hetu kattu rūpāni iti vuccanti tad dīpa kattā
translated: The four forms kāreti, kārayati, kārāpeti, kārāpayati are called “causative forms” because they illustrate the causative process.

original: Idāni pana padamālā vattabbā, tatra paṭhamaṃ “kubbatī”ti padasseva padamālaṃ yojessāma
analyzed: idāni pana pada mālā vattabbā tatra paṭhamam kubbati iti padassa iva pada mālam yojessāma
translated: Now the series of words should be stated. First we shall state the series of words for the word kubbatī.

original: sabbāsu vibhattīsu ekākārena yojetabbattā. “Karotī”ti okārānantaratyantapadassa pana🔽“kāretī”ti ekārānantaratyantapadassa ca padamālaṃ yathāsambhavaṃ pacchā yojessāma
analyzed: sabbāsu vibhattīsu eka ākārena yojetabba ttā karoti iti okāra anantara ti anta padassa pana  kāra iti iti ca pada mālam yathāsambhavam pacchā yojessāma
translated: The series of words beginning with “karoti” and ending with “okāra”🔽and the series of words beginning with “kāreti” and ending with “ekāra” we shall construe later on as occasion arises.

original: ekākārena ayojetabbattā.
analyzed: eka ākārena a yojetabba ttā
translated: because it has to be construed in different ways in the different tenses.

original: Tatra kubbati, kubbanti. Kubbasi, kubbatha. Kubbāmi, kubbāma. Kubbate, kubbante. Kubbase, kubbavhe. Kubbe, kubbamhe. Vattamānāvasena vuttarūpāni.
analyzed: tatra kubbati kubbanti kubbasi kubbatha kubbāmi kubbāma kubbate kubbante kubbase kubbavhe kubbe kubbamhe vattamāna avasena vutta rūpāni
translated: Therein, kubbati, kubbanti, kubbasi, kubbatha, kubbāmi, kubbāma, kubbate, kubbante, kubbase, kubbavhe, kubbe, kubbamhe are the forms in the present tense.

original: Pañcamiyādīnaṃ vasena pana kubbatu, kubbantu. Kubbeyya, kubbeyyuṃ. Sesaṃ “bhavati, bhavantī”ti vuttanayānusārena sabbattha vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: vasena pana kubbatu kubbantu kubbeyya kubbeyyum sesam bhavati bhavanti iti vutta naya anusārena sabbattha vitthāretabbam
translated: Kubbatu, kubbantu, kubbeyya, kubbeyyun are the forms in the fifth case, etc. The rest should be expanded in all cases in the same way as “bhavati, bhavantī” is given above.

original: “Kariyatī”tiādīnipi a kārānantaratyantapadāni evameva yojetabbāni. Ettha ca “kubbati,
analyzed: kariyati iti ādīni pi a kāra anantara ti anta padāni evam eva yojetabbāni ettha ca kubbati
translated: The words beginning with “kariyatī” and ending with “akāra” should be construed in the same way. And here this series of words beginning with “kubbati,

original: kubbanti. Kubbasī”tiādinā vuttā ayaṃ padamālā pāḷinayadassanato edisī vuttā. Saddasatthavidū
analyzed: kubbanti kubbasi iti ādinā vuttā ayam pada mālā pāḷi naya dassanato edisī vuttā sadda sattha vidū
translated: kubbanti, kubbasī” is given in this way because it is shown in the texts. Those who know the science of grammar

original: pana sāsanikā saddasattheyeva ādaraṃ katvā “kubbati, kubbasī”ti evaṃpakārāni rūpāni🔽pāḷiyaṃ natthīti maññantā na icchanti. Tehi saddasatthe viya pāḷiyampi “asanto nānukubbantī”tiādīsu
analyzed: pana sāsanikā ādaram katvā kubbati kubbasi iti evaṃpakārāni rūpāni  pāḷiyam natthi iti maññantā na icchanti tehi sadda satthe viya pāḷiyam pi asantaḥ na anukubbanti itiādīsu
translated: But the followers of the scriptures, who have paid attention only to the language of the scriptures, think that the forms “kubbati, kubbasī” are not in the texts because they are not in the texts in the way they have been taught.

original: okārapaccayassādesabhūto ukāro sareyeva pare vakāraṃ pappotīti maññamānā “kubbanti,🔽kubbante”tiādīniyeva rūpāni icchanti, parasarassābhāvato “kubbati, kubbasī”tiādīni
analyzed: okāra paccayassa ādesa bhūtaḥ ukāraḥ sareya iva pare vakāram pappoti iti maññamānā kubbanti  rūpāni icchanti para sarassa abhāvataḥ kubbati kubbasi itiādīni
translated: They do not want them. They think that in the language of the scriptures, as in the language of the world, the vowel a in the word “asanto” is elided before the vowel a in the word “nānu” in the phrase “asanto nānu-kubbanti” ,🔽and that the vowel a in the word “kubbanti” is elided before the vowel a in the word “kubbasī” in the phrase “kubbanti kubbasī” .

original: pāḷiyaṃ natthīti na icchanti. Mayaṃ pana pāḷinayadassanato tāni rūpāni icchāma. Atra
analyzed: pāḷiyam natthi iti na icchanti mayam pana pāḷi naya dassanato tāni rūpāni icchāma atra
translated: They want only the forms “kubbanti, kubbasī” . They do not want the forms “kubbati, kubbasī” because they are not in the texts in the way they have been taught. But we want those forms because we see them in the texts.

original: sotārānaṃ kaṅkhāvinodanatthaṃ kiñci pāḷinayaṃ vadāma – “sīlavanto na kubbanti, bālo
analyzed: sotārānam kaṅkhā vinodana attham kiñci pāḷinayam vadāma sīlavantaḥ na kubbanti
translated: In order to remove the doubts of those who listen to us, we shall give some examples of the texts. “Sīlavanto na kubbanti, bālo sīlāni kubbatī” ,

original: sīlāni kubbatī”ti ca, “kasmā bhavaṃ vijanamaraññanissito, tapo idha krubbatī”ti ca,
analyzed: sīlāni kubbati iti ca kasmai bhavam vijana marañña nissitaḥ tapaḥ idha krubbati iti ca
translated: “Kasmā bhavaṃ vijanamaraññanissito, tapo idha krubbatī” ,

original: “pharusāhi vācāhi pakrubbamāno”ti ca. Īdisesu pana ṭhānesu akārāgamo kātabbo. Acinteyyo
analyzed: pharusāhi vācāhi pakrubbamānaḥ iti ca īdisesu pana ṭhānesu akāra āgamaḥ kātabbaḥ a cinteyyaḥ
translated: “Pharusāhi vācāhi pakrubbamāno” . But in such passages as these the vowel a must be added: “Acinteyyaṃ buddhānaṃ, sāsanam-anuttaraṃ” ,

original: hi pāḷinayo, yebhuyyena saddasatthanayavidūro ca. Tathā hi yathā “agginiṃ sampajjalitaṃ
analyzed: hi ca tathā hi yathā sampajjalitam
translated: for it is the method of the texts, and it is far removed from those who are skilled in the method of the language. For just as a fire that has been lit🔽

original: pavisantī”ti pāḷigatidassanato “aggini, agginī, agginayo. Agginiṃ, agginī, agginayo.🔽Aggininā”ti padamālā kātabbā hoti, evameva “bālo sīlāni kubbatī”ti pāḷigatidassanato
analyzed: pavisanti iti pāḷigati dassanataḥ aggini agginī agginayaḥ agginim agginī agginayaḥ  aggininā ati pada mālā kātabbā hoti evam eva bālaḥ sīlāni kubbati iti pāḷigati dassanato
translated: for the method of the text is far removed from the method of the grammar. For just as the series “aggini, aggini, agginī, agginī, agginayo, agginī, agginayo, aggininā” should be made by seeing the text “agginiṃ sampajjalitaṃ pavisantī” ,

original: “kubbati, kubbanti. Kubbasī”ti padamālāpi yojetabbāva.🔽Yathā ca “bahumpetaṃ asabbhi jātavedā”ti pāḷigatidassanato “santo sabbhīhi saddhiṃ🔽sataṃ dhammo na jaraṃ upetīti pavedayantī”ti aṭṭhakathāgatidassanato ca “sabbhi,
analyzed: kubbati kubbanti kubbasi iti pada mālā api yojetabbā ava  yathā ca bahumpetam jātavedā ati pāḷigati dassanato santaḥ sabbhīhi saddhim  satam dhammaḥ na jaram upeti iti pavedayanti iti aṭṭhakathā gati dassanato ca sabbhi

original: sabbhī, sabbhayo. Sabbhiṃ, sabbhī, sabbhayo. Sabbhinā”ti padamālā yojetabbā hoti,
analyzed: sabbhī sabbhayo sabbhim sabbhī sabbhayo sabbhinā ati pada mālā yojetabbā hoti

original: Tatra taṇhaṅkaroti veneyyānaṃ taṇhaṃ lobhaṃ karoti hiṃsatīti taṇhaṅkaro. Atha vā
analyzed: tatra taṇhaṅkaroti veneyyānam taṇham lobham karoti hiṃsati iti taṇhaṅkaraḥ atha vā

original: taṇhaṅkaro. Kāraṇāti hiṃsanā. Pakrubbamānoti hiṃsamāno. Sante na kurute piyanti sappurise🔽attano piye iṭṭhe kante manāpe na karotīti attho. Atha vā piyaṃ piyāyamāno tussamāno

original: modamāno sante na kurute na sevatīti attho. Yathā “rājānaṃ sevatī”ti etasmiṃ atthe🔽rājānaṃ piyaṃ kuruteti saddasatthavidū mantenti, dullabhāyaṃ nīti sādhukaṃ manasi kātabbā.

translated: Or just as in the case of the expression “he attends on the king” the meaning is that he does what is dear to the king,🔽so too here the meaning is that he does what is dear to the good. This is how the little profit is in the element of hate.

original: kāmāvacarasattā kilesaloko. Jhānābhiññāparibuddhiyā rūpāvacarasattā bhavaloko. Āneñjasamādhibahulatāya
analyzed: kāmāvacara sattā kilesa lokaḥ jhāna abhiññā paribuddhiyā rūpāvacara sattā bhava lokaḥ āneñja samādhi bahula tāya

original: visadindriyattā arūpāvacarasattā indriyaloko. Atha vā kilissanaṃ kileso, vipākadukkhanti
analyzed: visad indriya ttā arūpāvacara sattā indriya lokaḥ atha vā kilissanam kilesaḥ vipāka dukkhanti

Or alternatively, the world is defilement because of the meaning of ‘that which is soiled’ .🔽Therefore beings in the unhappy destinies are the world of defilement because of the abundance of suffering.

original: attho. Tasmā dukkhabahulatāya apāyesu sattā kilesaloko. Tadaññe sattā sampattibhavabhāvato
analyzed: atthaḥ tasmā dukkha bahula tāya apāyesu sattā kilesa lokaḥ tad aññe sattā sampatti bhava bhāvato
translated: Other beings are the world of existence because of the existence of the happy destinies.

original: bhavaloko. Tattha ye vimuttiparipācakehi indriyehi samannāgatā sattā, so indriyalokoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhava loko tattha ye vimutti paripācakehi indriyehi samannāgatā sattā saḥ indriya loko ti veditabbaṃ
translated: And herein, beings who possess the sense faculties that are the conditions for deliverance should be understood as the world of the sense faculties.

analyzed: lokaḥ ettha ekaḥ loko sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā pe aṭṭhārasa lokāḥ aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo ti

translated: therein is mastery gained by one of mind-made body” , the world of location is stated.🔽But in the sense of the collection and continuity of aggregates bound up with faculties, the world of beings is stated;

original: Atthato pana indriyabaddhānaṃ khandhānaṃ samūho santāno ca sattaloko, rūpādīsu sattavisattatāya
analyzed: atthataḥ pana indriya baddhānam khandhānam samūhaḥ santāno ca satta lokaḥ rūpa ādīsu satta visatta tāya

original: satto, lokiyati ettha kusalākusalaṃ tabbipāko cāti. Anindriyabaddhānaṃ rūpānaṃ samūho🔽santāno ca okāsaloko, lokiyanti ettha tasā thāvarā ca, tesañca okāsabhūtoti, tadādhāraṇatāya
analyzed: sattaḥ ettha kusala akusalam tad vipāko ca ati an indriya baddhānam rūpānam samūho  ca okāsa lokaḥ ettha tasā thāvarā ca tesam ca okāsa bhūtā iti tad ādhāraṇa tāya
translated: The world of beings is so called because it is the world of the seven or twenty-two kinds of beings,🔽and because it is the world of what is mundane in the sense of being subject to destruction . The world of location is so called because it is the world of what is mundane in the sense of being the location of the beings, and because it is the world of what is mundane in the sense of being the support of the beings.🔽And it is called the “receptacle world” because it is the support for that .

original: hesa “bhājanaloko”tipi vuccati. Duvidhopi cesa rūpādidhamme upādāya paññattattā upādāpaññattibhūto
analyzed: ha isa bhājana lokaḥ ti pi vuccati duvidhaḥ api ca isa rūpa ādi dhamme upādāya paññatta ttā upādā paññatti bhūto
translated: And since it is the world of beings and the world of location that is referred to by the word “world” in the passage, “The world is a jungle, a tangled mass” , it is the world of beings and the world of location that are called “the world.”

original: aparamatthasabhāvo sappaccaye pana rūpārūpadhamme upādāya paññattattā tadubhayassāpi
analyzed: aparam attha sabhāvaḥ sappaccaye pana rūpa arūpa dhamme upādāya paññatta ttā tad ubhayassa api
translated: But the other-meaning-nature of the states of material form and immateriality together with their conditions is to be understood figuratively as “existence dependent on conditions” by way of the two kinds of assuming,

original: upādānānaṃ vasena pariyāyato paccayāyattavuttitā upacaritabbā, tadubhaye khandhā
analyzed: upādānānam vasena pariyāyataḥ paccaya āyatta vutti tā upacaritabbā tad ubhaye khandhāḥ
translated: because it is manifested by assuming the two kinds of khandhas,

original: saṅkhāraloko, paccayehi saṅkhariyanti, lujjanti palujjanti cāti ettha paccayāyattavuttitāya🔽maggaphaladhammānampi satipi lujjanapalujjanatte tebhūmikadhammānaṃyeva “loko”ti
analyzed: saṅkhāra lokaḥ paccayehi saṅkhariyanti lujjanti palujjanti ca ati ettha paccaya āyatta vutti tāya  magga phala dhammānam pi tebhūmika dhammānam yā iva
translated: which are called the world of formations because they are formed and broken up and destroyed by conditions.🔽And although the states of the path and fruition have breaking up and destruction, they are not called “the world” because only states of the three planes are intended here.

original: adhippetattā natthi lokatāpajjanaṃ. Tathā hi te “lokuttarā”ti vuttā.🔽Ālokoti rasmi, ālokenti etena bhuso passanti janā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ vāti āloko. Olokananti🔽heṭṭhā pekkhanaṃ. Vilokananti uddhaṃ pekkhanaṃ. Ālokananti purato pekkhanaṃ. Vilokananti
analyzed: adhippeta ttā natthi lokatā āpajjanam tathā hi te lokuttarā ti vuttā  āloko ti rasmi ālokenti etena bhuso passanti janā cakkhu viññāṇam vāti ālokaḥ olokananti  heṭṭhā pekkhanam vilokananti uddham pekkhanam ālokananti puratas pekkhanam vilokananti
translated: That is why they are called “supramundane.”

original: dvīsu passesu pekkhanaṃ, vividhā vā pekkhanaṃ. Apalokananti “saṅghaṃ apaloketvā”tiādīsu
analyzed: dvīsu passesu pekkhanam vividhā vā pekkhanam apalokanan ti saṅgham apaloketvā ātiādīsu
translated: “Light” is a ray; people see with it well, thus it is light . “Looking down” is looking down below. “Looking up” is looking up above. “Looking around” is looking in front. “Looking all around” is looking in the two directions, or looking in various ways. “Looking away” is in such passages as “Having looked away at the Saṅgha” .

original: viya jānāpanaṃ. Avalokananti “nāgāvalokitaṃ avaloketvā”tiādīsu viya purimakāyaṃ parivattetvā🔽pekkhanaṃ. “Ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hotī”ti etthāpi bhāvavasena ālokanaṃ ālokitaṃ
analyzed: viya jānāpanam avalokanam ti nāgāvalokitam avaloketvā ati ādīsu viya purima kāyam  pekkhanam ālokite vilokite sampajāna kārī hoti iti ettha api bhāva vasena ālokanam ālokitam
translated: “Looking” is looking back over the former body, as in such passages as “having looked back with the look of a Nāga” .

original: vilokanaṃ vilokitanti attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: vilokanam vilokitanti atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: “Looking down” is looking down, as in such passages as “he is one who, when looking down, looks down with full awareness” . Here too the meaning should be understood as looking down in the sense of the state of looking down.

original: Thaka paṭighāte. Thaketi, thakayati dvāraṃ puriso.
analyzed: paṭighāte dvāram purisaḥ
translated: Thaka is in the sense of a door being closed. A man thas or thasati a door.

original: Takka vitakke. Takketi, vitakketi, vitakkayati. Takko, vitakko, vitakkitā.🔽Tattha takkanaṃ takko, ūhananti vuttaṃ hoti, evaṃ vitakko. Atha vā vitakkenti etena,🔽sayaṃ vā vitakketi, vitakkanamattameva vā etanti vitakko. “Takko, vitakko, appanā,
analyzed: takka vitakke takka iti vitakka iti vitakkayati takkaḥ vitakkaḥ vitakkitā  tattha takkanam takkaḥ ūhananti vuttam hoti evam vitakkaḥ atha vā vitakkenti etena  sayam vā vitakketi vitakkana mattam eva vā etat ti vitakkaḥ takkaḥ vitakkaḥ appanā
translated: Takka is in the sense of thinking. One takkas or vitakkas or vitakkayas. Takka, vitakka, vitakkitā are derived in the same way.

original: byappanā, cetaso abhiniropanā”ti abhidhamme pariyāyasaddā vuttā. Vitakketīti vitakkitā,
analyzed: byappanā cetasaḥ abhiniropanā ti abhidhamme pariyāya saddāḥ vuttā vitakketi iti vitakkitā
translated: Herein, takkanaṃ takko is thinking, pondering, is what is meant, so too vitakko. Or alternatively, vitakkenti etena is vitakka, or it is vitakketi itself, or it is merely the state of thinking, thus it is vitakka. In the Abhidhamma the terms are used as synonyms thus: “Takko, vitakko, appanā, byappanā, cetaso abhiniropanā” . One who vitakkas is vitakkitā.

original: puggalo. “Avitakkitā maccumupabbajantī”ti pāḷi.
analyzed: puggalaḥ a vitakkitā maccum upabbajanti iti
translated: The text has “avitakkitā maccumupabbajanti” .

original: Aki lakkhaṇe. Lakkhaṇaṃ saññāṇaṃ, sañjānanakāraṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. Atridaṃ sallakkhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: lakkhaṇe lakkhaṇam saññāṇam sañjānana kāraṇam ti vuttam hoti atra idam sat lakkhitabbam
translated: In the characteristic of the letter a. The characteristic is the act of discerning, the cause of discerning is what is meant. This should be considered here.

original: Ye imasmiṃ curādigaṇe anekassarā asaṃyogantā ikārānubandhavasena niddiṭṭhā dhātavo,
analyzed: ye imasmin curādi gaṇe anekassarāḥ asaṃyoga antāḥ ikāra anubandha vasena niddiṭṭhāḥ dhātavaḥ
translated: The elements that are shown in this group beginning with cu, etc., as consisting of many syllables without conjunction and ending with the letter i,

original: te evaṃvuttehi imehi tīhi lakkhaṇehi samannāgatā ākhyātattaṃ nāmikattañca pāpuṇantā
analyzed: te evaṃvuttehi imehi tīhi lakkhaṇehi samannāgatāḥ ākhyāta ttam nāmika ttam ca pāpuṇantā
translated: when they have the three characteristics stated thus, and they attain the state of being a name-base and the state of being a letter-base,

original: ekantato niggahītāgamena nipphannarūpāyeva bhavanti, na katthacipi vigataniggahītāgamarūpāni
analyzed: ekantataḥ niggahīta āgamena nipphanna rūpāya iva bhavanti na katthacipi vigata niggahīta āgama rūpāni
translated: they are only the form produced by the complete method of pronunciation, not the form produced by the incomplete method of pronunciation in any way.

original: bhavanti. Aṅketi, aṅkayati. Aṅkanaṃ, aṅko. Samāse pana “sasaṅko, cakkaṅkitacaraṇo”tiādīni rūpāni bhavanti.
analyzed: bhavanti aṅketi aṅkayati aṅkanam samāse pana cakkaṅkita caraṇa uti ādīni rūpāni bhavanti
translated: Aṅka is a mark. Aṅkanaṃ, aṅka, are the forms in a compound, as in “sasaṅka, cakkaṅkitacaraṇa.”

original: Sakka vakka bhāsane. Sakketi, sakkayati. Vakketi, vakkayati.
analyzed: sakka vakka bhāsane sakka iti sakkayati vakka iti vakkayati
translated: Sakka is a cry. Sakketi, sakkayati. Vakketi, vakkayati.

original: Nakka vakka nāsane. Nakketi, nakkayati. Vakketi, vakkayati.
analyzed: nakka vakka nāsane nakka iti nakkayati vakka iti vakkayati
translated: Nakka is a cry. Nakketi, nakkayati. Vakketi, vakkayati.

original: Cakka cukka byathane. Cakketi, cakkayati. Cukketi, cukkayati. Cakkaṃ. Cakkanti kenaṭṭhena cakkaṃ? Cakketi byathati hiṃsatīti atthena cakkaṃ. Cakkasaddo –
analyzed: cakka cukka byathane cakketi cakkayati cukkā iti cukkayati cakkam cakkanti kenaṭṭhena cakkam cakketi byathati hiṃsati iti atthena cakkam cakka saddaḥ
translated: The wheel, the saw, the plough, the pestle. One wheels, one saws, one ploughs, one pounds. Wheel, saw, plough, pestle. Why is it called a wheel? It is called a wheel because it wheels, i.e. it moves round. The word cakka occurs in the following senses:

original: Sampattiyaṃ lakkhaṇe ca, rathaṅge iriyāpathe;
analyzed: sampattiyam lakkhaṇe ca rathaṅge iriyāpathe
translated: In excellence, in a mark, in a chariot part, in a posture,

original: Dāne ratnadhammakhura-cakkādīsu padissati;
analyzed: dāne ratna dhamma khura cakka ādīsu padissati
translated: In giving, in a jewel, in the Dhamma, in a saw, in an eye, and so on.

original: “Cattārimāni bhikkhave cakkāni yehi samannāgatānaṃ devamanussāna”ntiādīsu hi ayaṃ🔽sampattiyaṃ dissati. “Pādatalesu cakkāni jātānī”ti ettha lakkhaṇe. “Cakkaṃva vahato🔽pada”nti ettha rathaṅge. “Catucakkaṃ navadvāra”nti ettha iriyāpathe. “Dada bhuñja
analyzed: cattāri imāni bhikkhave cakkāni yehi samannāgatānam deva manussānam ti ādīsu hi ayam  sampattiyam dissati pāda talesu cakkāni jātāni iti ettha lakkhaṇe cakkam va vahato  ettha rathaṅge catu cakkam nava dvāranti ettha iriyāpathe dada bhuñja
translated: For example: “Bhikkhus, there are these four wheels. Possessed of these four wheels, the devas and humans revolve, as it were, on a wheel, revolving in the round of births, in the round of old age and death” .

original: ca mā cappamādo, cakkaṃ vattassu pāṇina”nti ettha dāne. “Dibbaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pāturahosī”ti
analyzed: ca mā cappamādo cakkam ettha dāne dibbam cakka ratanam pāturahosi iti
translated: Here it occurs in the sense of excellence. “The wheels appeared on the soles of his feet” . Here it occurs in the sense of a mark. “The wheel that rolls on” . Here it occurs in the sense of a chariot part. “The four-wheeled, nine-doored” . Here it occurs in the sense of a posture. “Give, enjoy, and do not be negligent, Wheel-turner, over the people” .🔽Here it occurs in the sense of giving. “The divine wheel-gem appeared” .

original: ettha ratanacakke. “Mayā pavattitaṃ cakka”nti ettha dhammacakke. “Icchāhatassa posassa,
analyzed: ettha ratana cakke mayā pavattitam cakkan ti ettha dhamma cakke icchā hatassa posassa
translated: Here it occurs in the sense of the wheel-gem. “The wheel has been set rolling” . Here it occurs in the sense of the Dhamma-wheel. “For one who is struck down by desire,

original: cakkaṃ bhamati matthake”ti ettha khuracakke. “Khurapariyantena cepi cakkenā”ti ettha
analyzed: cakkam bhamati matthaka iti ettha khura cakke khura pariyantena cepi cakkena ati ettha
translated: in the case of the wheel on the head. In the case of “If he were to go with a wheel with a thousand spokes” ,🔽

original: paharaṇacakke. “Asanivicakka”nti ettha asanimaṇḍaleti.
analyzed: paharaṇa cakke ettha asani maṇḍalā iti
translated: ‘The wheel revolves on his head’ , it is a razor wheel. ‘Even if he were to be cut up with a wheel of razors’ , it is a weapon wheel. ‘The wheel of swords’ , it is a sword circle.

original: Taki bandhane. Taṅketi, taṅkayati.
analyzed: taki bandhane taṅketi taṅkayati
translated: Taki is a binding. Taṅka is a kind of binding.

original: Akka thavane. Thavanaṃ thuti. Akketi, akkayati. Akko. Akkoti sūriyo. So hi mahājutitāya🔽akkiyati abhitthaviyati tappasannehi janehīti akko. Tathā hi tassa “natthi sūriyasamā
analyzed: thavane thavanam thuti akka iti akkayati akkaḥ sūriyaḥ saḥ hi mahā jutitāya  akkiyati tad pasannehi janehi iti akko tathā hi tassa na atthi sūriya samā
translated: Akka is a kind of standing. Standing is a kind of standing. Akka is a kind of standing. Akka is the sun. He is called akka because he is heated by people who are hot with the heat of the sun.

original: ābhā. Udetayaṃ cakkhumā ekarājā”tiādinā abhikkhuti dissati.
analyzed: ābhā dissati
translated: For this is seen to be praised thus: ‘There is no radiance equal to the sun. The one-king with eyes rises’ , and so on.

original: Hikka hiṃsāyaṃ. Hikketi, hikkayati.
analyzed: hikka hiṃsā ayam hikkā iti hikkayati
translated: Hikka is a kind of hurting. Hikka is a kind of hurting.

original: Nikka parimāṇe. Nikketi, nikkayati.
analyzed: nikka parimāṇe nikketi nikkayati
translated: Nikka is a kind of measuring. Nikka is a kind of measuring.

original: Bukka bhassane. Ettha sunakhabhassanaṃ bhassananti gahetabbaṃ, na vācāsaṅkhātaṃ bhassanaṃ.
analyzed: bukka bhassane ettha su nakha bhassanam bhassananti gahetabbam na vācā saṅkhātam bhassanam
translated: Bukka is a kind of barking. Here it should be taken as the barking of a dog, not as the barking called speech.

original: Bukketi, bukkayati. Ettha ca “bukkayati sā core” iti lokiyappayogo veditabbo. Bhūvādigaṇe
analyzed: bukkā iti bukkayati ettha ca bukkayati sā core iti lokiya ppayogaḥ veditabbaḥ bhūva ādi gaṇe
translated: Bukka is a kind of barking. And here the mundane usage ‘He barks at the thief’ should be understood. In the group with bhū as the first member,

original: pana “bukkati sā”ti rūpaṃ bhavati. Añño tu “bukka paribhāsane” iti paṭhati, evaṃ🔽paṭhantepi sunakhabhassanamevādhippetaṃ.
analyzed: pana rūpam bhavati tu iti paṭhati evam  paṭhante pi su nakha bhassanam eva adhippetam
translated: and even if he reads thus, the meaning intended is “the barking of a dog.”

original: Daka laka assādane. Daketi, dakayati. Laketi, lakayati.
analyzed: daka laka assādane daka iti dakayati laka iti lakayati
translated: Daka laka in the sense of “to eat”: dakati, dakayati; laketi, lakayati.

original: Takka loka bhāsāyaṃ. Takketi, takkayati. Loketi, lokayati.
analyzed: takka loka bhāsā ayam takka iti takkayati loka iti lokayati
translated: Takka loka in the sense of “to speak”: takketi, takkayati; loketi, lokayati.

original: Cika sika āmasane. Ciketi, cikayati. Siketi, sikayati.
analyzed: cika sika āmasane cika iti cikayati sika iti sikayati
translated: Cika sika in the sense of “to touch”: ciketi, cikayati; siketi, sikayati.

original: Kakārantadhāturūpāni.
analyzed: kakāra anta dhātu rūpāni
translated: Kakārantadhāturūpāni.

original: Khakārantadhātu
analyzed: khakāra anta dhātu
translated: Khakārantadhātu

original: Lakkha dassanaṅkesu. Dassanaṃ passanaṃ. Aṅko lañjanaṃ. Lakkheti, lakkhayati. Sallakkheti, sallakkhayati. Lakkhaṃ vijjhati usunā, lakkhaṃ karoti.
analyzed: lakkha dassana aṅkesu dassanam passanam aṅkaḥ lañjanam lakkheti lakkhayati sallakkheti sallakkhayati lakkham vijjhati usunā lakkham karoti
translated: Lakkha in the sense of “to see” and “to mark”: dassanaṃ passanaṃ; aṅko lañjanaṃ. Lakkheti, lakkhayati; sallakkheti, sallakkhayati. Lakkhaṃ vijjhati usunā, lakkhaṃ karoti.🔽The sand of the Ganges may be exhausted,

original: Gaṅgāya vālukā khīye, udakaṃ khīye mahaṇṇave;
analyzed: gaṅgāya vālukā khīye udakam khīye mahaṇṇave
translated: The water of the ocean may be exhausted,🔽The earth of the great earth may be exhausted,

original: Mahiyā mattikā khīye, lakkhe na mama buddhiyā.
analyzed: mahiyā mattikā khīye lakkhe na mama buddhiyā
translated: But my intelligence is not exhausted in marking.

analyzed: pucchāmi tam mahā yakkha ettha sakkaḥ devarājā yakkho ti
translated: “I ask you, Great Yakkha, Lord of all beings,” here Sakka, King of the Gods, is called “Yakkha.”
